Authors with affiliations: Yakimets, I.V., G. M. Krzhizhanovskii Power Engineering Institute, Russian Federation; Narovlyanskii, V.G., G. M. Krzhizhanovskii Power Engineering Institute, Russian Federation; Matveikin, V.M., G. M. Krzhizhanovskii Power Engineering Institute, Russian Federation
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Authors: Dolbnya I.P., Kurylo S.G.
Title: Absolute spectral sensitivity of linear-photodiode arrays in 7-20 keV energy x-ray range
Affiliations: Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Dolbnya, I.P., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Kurylo, S.G., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation
Abstract: This paper deals with the study of the absolute spectral sensitivity of linear photodiode arrays (of LF1024-25/2 type) as x-ray one-coordinate detectors within the 7-20 keV energy range. The threshold sensitivity of such detectors was estimated in the indicated range. The measurements were made using synchrotron radiation from the VEPP-3 storage ring.

Authors: Perera R.C.C., Melczer M.E., Warwick A., Jackson A., Kincaid B.M.
Title: Diagnostic beamline for a third generation storage ring
Affiliations: Advanced Light Source, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States
Authors with affiliations: Perera, R.C.C., Advanced Light Source, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States; Melczer, M.E., Advanced Light Source, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States; Warwick, A., Advanced Light Source, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States; Jackson, A., Advanced Light Source, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States; Kincaid, B.M., Advanced Light Source, Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, Berkeley, CA 94720, United States
Abstract: A knowledge of the position, size, and stability of the source and the angle of emission of synchrotron radiation (SR) from the storage ring are essential for optimizing the operation of storage ring, insertion devices and monochromators. Berkeley's Advanced Light Source (ALS) has a natural emittance of 3.4×10-9 mrad, and has beam sizes σh and σv (assuming a 10% emittance ratio into the vertical direction) in bending magnet 1 (BM1) of 44 and 83 μm, respectively. Simple diffractive optical calculations show that imaging this beam using visible light optics is not feasible and imaging must be performed using photon energies greater than 50 eV. This will be the same for all third generation low emittance storage rings. The synchrotron radiation diagnostics at ALS will consist of an imaging system for 200 eV photons and a "white beam" port with a streak camera to obtain the timing information. The imaging system will employ two crossed spherical mirrors in a Kirkpatrick-Baez configuration, to eliminate astigmatism. Use of 1:1 imaging will eliminate coma, resulting in an image of the source which is only limited by the residual aberrations of the optics. Real time imaging of the beam is deemed feasible by the use of a high resolution charged coupled device (CCD), and the associated electronics necessary to read the CCD. The design of the imaging system of the diagnostic beamline for ALS and the detection system will be discussed with a view toward applications in other third generation SR sources.

Authors: Sinyukov M.P., Makarov O.A.
Title: The project of using a compact SR source at the Siberian microelectronic center
Affiliations: Institute of Semiconductor Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Sinyukov, M.P., Institute of Semiconductor Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Makarov, O.A., Institute of Semiconductor Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation
Abstract: The project for the x-ray lithography facility using a compact storage ring SIBERIA-AS is considered. The SR source with 600-MeV electron energy and an orbit circumference of about 3 m has an ironless superconducting azimuthally symmetrical magnet. It allows us to install up to 15 SR beam lines. The scope of the project is further development of x-ray lithography, and new technologies in this area for development of scientific research: vacuum ultraviolet spectroscopy, photoinduced etching, photoelectron spectroscopy, and radiometry.

Authors: Kusev S.V., Raiko V.I., Skuratovskii I.Ya.
Title: The status of beam lines for macromolecular crystallography at the Siberia-2 storage ring
Affiliations: Institute of Molecular Genetics, USSR Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Kusev, S.V., Institute of Molecular Genetics, USSR Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russian Federation; Raiko, V.I., Institute of Molecular Genetics, USSR Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russian Federation; Skuratovskii, I.Ya., Institute of Molecular Genetics, USSR Academy of Sciences, Moscow, Russian Federation
Abstract: An overview is presented of the x-ray optics of the four macromolecular crystallography beam lines under construction at the storage ring SIBERIA-2, Moscow. The four workstations are to utilize isomorphous replacement, anomalous dispersion, reflections energy profile, and the Laue technique. The instrumentation details, the results of ray-tracing analysis, and the use of an area detector are discussed.

Authors: Yen E.
Title: Synchrotron radiation research center (SRRC) in Taiwan
Affiliations: Hsinchu Science-Based Industrial Park, 1 R and D Road VI, Hsinchu 30077, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Yen, E., Hsinchu Science-Based Industrial Park, 1 R and D Road VI, Hsinchu 30077, Taiwan
Abstract: Aiming to upgrade the local research environment and to promote local technology, the government of the Republic of China on Taiwan endeavors to construct and establish the first synchrotron radiation facility in Taiwan. The main facility is a 1.3-GeV storage ring with full energy injection from a booster synchrotron. Design and procurement of accelerator components are progressing well. The start of installation is scheduled for February 1992. Commissioning with beam is projected toward the end of 1992.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: The Hamburg Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory (HASYLAB)
Abstract: HASYLAB is situated at the storage ring DORIS. Existng experimental stations at HASYLAB are summerized. Brief information concerning the source and optical, system, energy range and other operating parameters is given. (AIP).

Authors: Tomimasu T.
Title: Compact sources in Japan and their intended applications
Affiliations: Electrotechnical Laboratory, Umezono, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Tomimasu, T., Electrotechnical Laboratory, Umezono, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan
Abstract: In these ten years, thirteen compact sources whose electron energy is not higher than 1 GeV have been constructed in Japan. Five sources have been developed by Electrotechnical Laboratory jointly with Sumitomo Electric Industries, Ltd. and Kawasaki Heavy Industries, Ltd. It is worth mentioning that the operations of ten rings (NIJI-II, III, IV, NAR, SuperALIS, SORTEC, AURORA, LUNA, JSR, HITACHI) have started since 1988. Recent status of these sources and their intended applications including visible and ultraviolet free electron laser projects using insertion devices installed in TERAS and NIJI-IV are briefly reported and key technologies needed to realize compact sources for ultralarge scale integration lithography and angiography, such as the electron undulating method and long lived, high-current beam storage at the early stage of commissioning, are discussed.

Authors: Liou J.J.
Title: Charge storage in the quasineutral regions of Si homojunction, AlGaAs/GaAs heterojunction, and Si/SiGe heterojunction bipolar transistors
Affiliations: Electrical Engineering Department, University of Central Florida, Orlando, FL 32816, United States
Authors with affiliations: Liou, J.J., Electrical Engineering Department, University of Central Florida, Orlando, FL 32816, United States
Abstract: Charge storage in the quasineutral regions of a bipolar transistor often limits the switching speed of the device, particularly when the transistor is operated in saturation mode (both emitter-base and base-collector junctions are forward biased), a bias condition which occurs frequently in logic circuits. This paper studies and compares the free-carrier charges stored in the quasineutral regions of the conventional Si homojunction bipolar transistor (Si BJT) and the increasingly important AlGaAs/GaAs and Si/SiGe heterojunction bipolar transistors (HBTs). The diffusion capacitances associated with this stored charge, which are used in the Gummel-Poon bipolar transistor model, are also calculated and discussed. It is shown that the AlGaAs/GaAs HBT has the least carrier accumulation in the quasineutral regions among the three devices due primarily to the relatively large energy band gap of GaAs-related materials. Also, the Si/SiGe HBT is expected to operate at a higher switching speed compared to the Si BJT, because the valence band discontinuity at the Si/SiGe base-collector heteroface impedes the minority-carrier injection from the base into the collector.

Authors: Arnaut L.G., Caldwell R.A., Elbert J.E., Melton L.A.
Title: Recent advances in photoacoustic calorimetry: Theoretical basis and improvements in experimental design
Affiliations: Departamento de Química, Universidade de Coimbra, 3000 Coimbra, Portugal; University of Texas at Dallas, Richardson, TX 75080
Authors with affiliations: Arnaut, L.G., Departamento de Química, Universidade de Coimbra, 3000 Coimbra, Portugal; Caldwell, R.A., University of Texas at Dallas, Richardson, TX 75080; Elbert, J.E., University of Texas at Dallas, Richardson, TX 75080; Melton, L.A., University of Texas at Dallas, Richardson, TX 75080
Abstract: Recent developments in time-resolved photoacoustic calorimetry (PAC) are discussed. An equation is derived relating the amplitude of the maximum photoacoustic signal to parameters of a photoacoustic cell, to physical properties of the solvents, and to the energy deposited as heat. The equation is validated by a series of scaling experiments: it correctly correlates the dependence of the PAC signal on cell thickness, on energy deposition, and on solvent properties. The dominant sources of background signal have been determined and the background signal reduced substantially relative to previous work. It is now possible to measure energies and lifetimes of transients in solutions with optical densities as low as ∼5×10-4. Data are presented for the energy of 2-cyclopentenone triplet, a transient for which interpretable PAC measurements were previously not possible. Its triplet energy is 73.1±1.1 kcal/mole. With reduced background and a faster digital storage oscilloscope, a quite short transient lifetime, 7.53±0.2 ns, and a triplet energy of 51.0±2.1 kcal/mol have been measured for 1,1-bis-(p-bromophenyl)ethene. The lifetime agrees very well with that determined by kinetic absorption spectroscopy and the triplet energy agrees with expectation based on the unsubstituted 1,1-diphenylethene.

Authors: Kitriotis D., Ozasa K., Meguro T., Shimoda S., Nishi K., Aoyagi Y.
Title: Nanosecond laser-driven reflection high energy electron diffraction system providing digital imaging in real time
Affiliations: RIKEN, Institute of Physical and Chemical Research, Wako-shi, Saitama 351-01, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kitriotis, D., RIKEN, Institute of Physical and Chemical Research, Wako-shi, Saitama 351-01, Japan; Ozasa, K., RIKEN, Institute of Physical and Chemical Research, Wako-shi, Saitama 351-01, Japan; Meguro, T., RIKEN, Institute of Physical and Chemical Research, Wako-shi, Saitama 351-01, Japan; Shimoda, S., RIKEN, Institute of Physical and Chemical Research, Wako-shi, Saitama 351-01, Japan; Nishi, K., RIKEN, Institute of Physical and Chemical Research, Wako-shi, Saitama 351-01, Japan; Aoyagi, Y., RIKEN, Institute of Physical and Chemical Research, Wako-shi, Saitama 351-01, Japan
Abstract: High current densities of 1940 A/cm2 have been produced by a Cu/Be alloy photocathode, activated by 355 nm Q-switched laser pulses. The transient photocurrent, 7 ns full width, is utilized for the development of a pulsed reflection high energy electron diffraction (RHEED) system. Digital imaging and storage of single shot, two-dimensional diffraction patterns are achieved in real time with good spatial and intensity resolution.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Performance and upgrades of the NSLS storage rings and photon sources
Abstract: The usefulness of synchrotron radiation sources is not only determined by current, energy, and magnetic field but also orbit stability and lifetime. The status and developments at NSLS in storage ring performance are discussed. Efforts at NSLS to look toward the future in source development are presented. In particular, small gap undulator development and studies toward development of an ultraviolet free-electron laser at the Accelerator Test Facility are described.

Authors: Kamitsubo H.
Title: The JAERI-RIKEN SPring-8 Project
Affiliations: JAERI-RIKEN SPring-8 Project Team, Honkomagome 2-28-8, Bunkyoku, Tokyo 113, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kamitsubo, H., JAERI-RIKEN SPring-8 Project Team, Honkomagome 2-28-8, Bunkyoku, Tokyo 113, Japan
Abstract: The Japan Atomic Energy Research Institute (JAERI) and the Institute of Physical and Chemical Research (RIKEN) are building an 8-GeV synchrotron radiation source in Harima Science Garden City, 100 km west of Osaka. The facility consists of an 8-GeV storage ring of 1436-m circumference with a natural emittance of 6.9 nm rad, an injector linac of 1 GeV, and an 8-GeV synchrotron. Sixty-one beam lines will be installed: 38 on insertion devices and 23 on bending magnets. Construction started in 1991 and the first beam is foreseen in 1997.

Authors: Rix W., Miller A.R., Thompson J., Waisman E., Wilkinson M., Wilson A.
Title: Pulsed power inductive energy storage in the microsecond range
Source title: Beams 92 - Proceedings of the 9th International Conference on High-Power Particle Beams
Authors with affiliations: Rix, W.; Miller, A.R.; Thompson, J.; Waisman, E.; Wilkinson, M.; Wilson, A.
Abstract: During the past five years Maxwell has developed a series of inductive energy storage (IES) pulsed power generators; ACE 1, ACE 2, ACE 3, and ACE 4, to drive electron-beam loads. They are all based on a plasma opening switch (POS) contained in a single vacuum envelope operating at conduction times of around one microsecond. They all employ fast capacitor bank technology to match this conduction time without intermediate power conditioning. Oil or air filled transmission lines transfer capacitor bank energy to a vacuum section where the final pulse compression is accomplished. Development of the ACE series is described, emphasizing capacitor bank and the opening switch technology for delivering high voltage, multimegampere pulses to electron beam loads. © 1992 National Technical Information Service.
Index Keywords: Capacitor bank; High voltage; Inductive energy storage; Opening switch; Plasma opening switch; Power conditioning; Pulsed-power; Pulsed-power generators; Transfer capacitor; Electron beams; Energy storage; Pulse generators; Vacuum; Capacitors

Authors: Coyne R.A., Hulen H., Watson R.
Title: Storage systems for national information assets
Source title: Proceedings of the International Conference on Supercomputing
Affiliations: IBM Federal Systems Company, 3700 Bay Area Blvd., Houston, TX  77058, United States; Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, P.O. Box 808, Livermore, CA  94550, United States
Authors with affiliations: Coyne, R.A., IBM Federal Systems Company, 3700 Bay Area Blvd., Houston, TX  77058, United States; Hulen, H., IBM Federal Systems Company, 3700 Bay Area Blvd., Houston, TX  77058, United States; Watson, R., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, P.O. Box 808, Livermore, CA  94550, United States
Abstract: An industry-led collaborative project, called the National Storage Laboratory, has been organized to investigate technology for storage systems that will be the future repositories for our national information assets. Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory through its National Energy Research Supercomputer Center (NERSC) is the operational site and the provider of applications. It is anticipated that the integrated testbed system will represent a significant advance in the technology for distributed storage systems capable of handling gigabyte class files at gigabit-per-second data rates. © 1992 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Multiprocessing systems; Supercomputers; Collaborative projects; Data rates; Distributed storage system; Energy research; Information assets; Lawrence livermore national laboratories; Storage systems; Test bed systems; Digital storage

Authors: Menthel U., Peatman W.B., Senf F.
Title: Conservation of brightness in undulator beamlines: Tangent errors and their reduction
Affiliations: Berliner Elektronenspeicherring-Gesellschaft für Synchrotronstrahlung m.b.H. (BESSY), Berlin 33, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Menthel, U., Berliner Elektronenspeicherring-Gesellschaft für Synchrotronstrahlung m.b.H. (BESSY), Berlin 33, Germany; Peatman, W.B., Berliner Elektronenspeicherring-Gesellschaft für Synchrotronstrahlung m.b.H. (BESSY), Berlin 33, Germany; Senf, F., Berliner Elektronenspeicherring-Gesellschaft für Synchrotronstrahlung m.b.H. (BESSY), Berlin 33, Germany
Abstract: Creating and conserving the high brightness of undulator light sources on storage rings of the third generation requires an optimization of (a) undulator design and operation, (b) beamline design, and (c) cooling schemes to minimize the effect of the photons absorbed in the optical components on the performance of those components. For storage rings with electron energies of 1.5-2 GeV, the problems associated with conservation of brightness through the entire system to and including the experiment are surmountable. In the present work the optimization details to points (a) and (b) above as presented in a previous work are summarized, and point (c) is developed in some detail. With the help of the finite element method (FEM) cooling schemes were investigated that minimize the loss of brightness resulting from the heat loading of the optical components. A new concept for external cooling that fulfills the requirements and that appears feasible to build is presented.

Authors: Véron L., Boivinet R., Rouillé C., Etlicher B., Peugnet C., Dufour B.
Title: Plasma opening switch characterization and optimization for inductive energy storage
Affiliations: Laboratoire de Physique des Milieux Ionisés, Laboratoire du CNRS, Ecole Polytechnique, 91128 Palaiseau, France
Authors with affiliations: Véron, L., Laboratoire de Physique des Milieux Ionisés, Laboratoire du CNRS, Ecole Polytechnique, 91128 Palaiseau, France; Boivinet, R., Laboratoire de Physique des Milieux Ionisés, Laboratoire du CNRS, Ecole Polytechnique, 91128 Palaiseau, France; Rouillé, C., Laboratoire de Physique des Milieux Ionisés, Laboratoire du CNRS, Ecole Polytechnique, 91128 Palaiseau, France; Etlicher, B., Laboratoire de Physique des Milieux Ionisés, Laboratoire du CNRS, Ecole Polytechnique, 91128 Palaiseau, France; Peugnet, C., Laboratoire de Physique des Milieux Ionisés, Laboratoire du CNRS, Ecole Polytechnique, 91128 Palaiseau, France; Dufour, B., Laboratoire de Physique des Milieux Ionisés, Laboratoire du CNRS, Ecole Polytechnique, 91128 Palaiseau, France
Abstract: Some experimental results on carbon plasma guns are reported. Plasma density, as a function of time, is measured both by microwave interferometry (37.5 GHz) and Faraday cups. Plasma velocity is measured by a time-of-flight technique with the Faraday cups and is, also, deduced from the axial resolution of the density measurement. The plasma composition is determined by time-integrated spectroscopy. The time evolution of line radiation has been correlated with both interferometry and charge collectors. Three different ion species have been observed and studied in time: H+, with velocity VH=7 cm/μs, and C+ and C2+, both with velocity VC=2 cm/μs. Both plasma expansion in space and electrode effects are studied by time-integrated photography.

Authors: Pacios L., Guasp J., Vega J.
Title: A fully programmable data acquisition system for the TJ-I and TJ-IU devices
Affiliations: Asociación EURATOM/CIEMAT para Fusión, Avda. Complutense, 22, 28040 Madrid, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Pacios, L., Asociación EURATOM/CIEMAT para Fusión, Avda. Complutense, 22, 28040 Madrid, Spain; Guasp, J., Asociación EURATOM/CIEMAT para Fusión, Avda. Complutense, 22, 28040 Madrid, Spain; Vega, J., Asociación EURATOM/CIEMAT para Fusión, Avda. Complutense, 22, 28040 Madrid, Spain
Abstract: A new data acquisition system has been developed for the TJ-I tokamak and the TJ-IU torsatron. This system is based on the VME standard and it is controlled by an MC68020 microprocessor. This scheme is similar to the ones existing at CERN and used in high-energy physics experiments. [On-line Computing Group, Valet-Plus Operation Guide, Data handling, CERN DD Division OC Group]. The data acquisition system consists of 60 independent, fully programmable channels. Each channel has its own analog-to-digital converter (ADC) with a resolution of ten bits and a RAM memory of 128 kbytes (kB). A digital-to-analog converter is also included for providing an analog output in order to display the stored signal on oscilloscopes. The maximum sampling rate achievable with the ADC used is 500 Ksamples/s, which is equivalent to a sampling period of 2 μs. Each channel is programmed to have its own sampling period (in 400-ns steps), and to use the amount of storage required according to the sampling period and the pulse length, up to a maximum of 128 kB. The system controls not only the 7680 kB corresponding to the memory of the 60 channels, but a RAM buffer of 4 MB as well. The system is linked to a local ETHERNET network in order to send the recorded data to the disks of a VAX/VMS computer, where the data are available for analysis.

Authors: Botman J.I.M., Xi B., Timmermans C.J., Hagedoorn H.L.
Title: The EUTERPE facility
Affiliations: Eindhoven University of Technology, Cyclotron Laboratory, P.O. Box 513, 5600 MB Eindhoven, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Botman, J.I.M., Eindhoven University of Technology, Cyclotron Laboratory, P.O. Box 513, 5600 MB Eindhoven, Netherlands; Xi, B., Eindhoven University of Technology, Cyclotron Laboratory, P.O. Box 513, 5600 MB Eindhoven, Netherlands; Timmermans, C.J., Eindhoven University of Technology, Cyclotron Laboratory, P.O. Box 513, 5600 MB Eindhoven, Netherlands; Hagedoorn, H.L., Eindhoven University of Technology, Cyclotron Laboratory, P.O. Box 513, 5600 MB Eindhoven, Netherlands
Abstract: The 400-MeV electron storage ring EUTERPE is a University project set up for studies of charged particle beam dynamics and applications of synchrotron radiation, and for the education of students in these fields. The ring has a relatively large circumference for the maximum beam energy contained, which is useful for accommodating insertion devices and diagnostic tools. The critical wavelength of the emitted photon spectrum is 8.3 nm for the regular dipole magnets and 1.2 nm corresponding to 1.03 keV for a 10-T wiggler. This provides useful radiation, e.g., for x-ray fluorescence up to 3.2 keV. An undulator with a periodicity distance of 2.5 cm is planned, to generate radiation of 40 nm. The major ring components are being constructed in the University workshop, including a 70-MeV injector microtron. The main characteristics of the machine and the present status are reported. Future options include a bypass system for microdevices.

Authors: Artamonova L.D., Gentselev A.N., Deis G.A., Krasnoperova A.A., Mikhalyov E.V., Prokopenko V.S., Kulipanov G.N., Mezentseva L.A., Pindyurin V.F.
Title: X-ray lithography at the VEPP-3 storage ring
Affiliations: VOSTOK Company, 630075 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Artamonova, L.D., VOSTOK Company, 630075 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Gentselev, A.N., VOSTOK Company, 630075 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Deis, G.A., VOSTOK Company, 630075 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Krasnoperova, A.A., VOSTOK Company, 630075 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Mikhalyov, E.V., VOSTOK Company, 630075 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Prokopenko, V.S., VOSTOK Company, 630075 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Kulipanov, G.N., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Mezentseva, L.A., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Pindyurin, V.F., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation
Abstract: The paper deals with an x-ray lithography station at the VEPP-3 storage ring of the Institute of Nuclear Physics (Novosibirsk) and some recent results are reported. The utilization of rather high quantum energies is shown not to deteriorate the quality of x-ray replication. The presented work is an extension of the studies that were performed at VEPP-2M [E. S. Gluskin, A. A. Krasnopyorova, G. N. Kulipanov, V. P. Naz'mov, V. F. Pindyurin, A. N. Skrinsky, and V. V. Chesnokov, Nucl. Instrum. Methods 208, 393 (1983)].

Authors: Dolbnya I.P., Gavrilov N.G., Mezentsev N.A., Pindyurin V.F.
Title: Development of an x-ray microscopy and microtomography station at the VEPP-3 storage ring
Affiliations: Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Dolbnya, I.P., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Gavrilov, N.G., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Mezentsev, N.A., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Pindyurin, V.F., Institute of Nuclear Physics, 630090 Novosibirsk, Russian Federation
Abstract: The current status of the experimental station for x-ray scanning transmission subtraction microscopy and microtomography using synchrotron radiation produced by a wiggler-magnet installed at the storage ring VEPP-3 (2 GeV, 100-200 mA, 2 T) is described. The working x-radiation energies range from 5 to 35 keV. The results are presented concerning the achievement of 1-μm spatial resolution in this spectral range.

Authors: Andersson M.O., Farmer K.R., Engström O.
Title: Negative charging in ultrathin metal-oxide-silicon tunnel diodes
Affiliations: Department of Solid State Electronics, Chalmers University of Technology, S-412 96 Göteborg, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Andersson, M.O., Department of Solid State Electronics, Chalmers University of Technology, S-412 96 Göteborg, Sweden; Farmer, K.R., Department of Solid State Electronics, Chalmers University of Technology, S-412 96 Göteborg, Sweden; Engström, O., Department of Solid State Electronics, Chalmers University of Technology, S-412 96 Göteborg, Sweden
Abstract: A negative charging effect is studied in small, ultrathin metal-oxide-silicon diodes biased at constant voltage. The charging is seen as a gradual decrease in the magnitude of the tunnel current over time. Along with the charging, the current noise power decreases. Results are described from measurements of the temperature and voltage dependence of the current transients. A physical model is presented in which filling and emptying of electron traps in the as-grown oxide cause the noise, and the conductance decrease is caused by the transformation of these traps into fixed negative charge storage centers. From fits of the model to measured data, we obtain a thermal activation energy of 0.3 eV for the charging process. A low-temperature annealing treatment at 200°C restores the conductance of a previously charged device to its initial value. On the other hand, the charging effect can be eliminated by a 350°C anneal in nitrogen. Together, these experiments suggest that the traps are water- or hydrogen-related defects.

Authors: Schneider J.R., Bell F., Tschentscher Th., Rollason A.J.
Title: (γ,eγ) spectroscopy: A new technique to determine electron momentum densities of solids
Affiliations: Hamburger Synchrotronsstrahlungslabor HASYLAB, Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron DESY, Notkestrasse 85, D-2000 Hamburg 52, Germany; Sektion Physik, Ludwig Maximilians Universität München, Am Coulombwall 1, D-8046 Garching, Germany; Department of Physics, University of Keele, Staffordshire, ST5 5BG, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Schneider, J.R., Hamburger Synchrotronsstrahlungslabor HASYLAB, Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron DESY, Notkestrasse 85, D-2000 Hamburg 52, Germany; Bell, F., Sektion Physik, Ludwig Maximilians Universität München, Am Coulombwall 1, D-8046 Garching, Germany; Tschentscher, Th., Hamburger Synchrotronsstrahlungslabor HASYLAB, Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron DESY, Notkestrasse 85, D-2000 Hamburg 52, Germany; Rollason, A.J., Department of Physics, University of Keele, Staffordshire, ST5 5BG, United Kingdom
Abstract: In the past γ-ray Compton scattering experiments proved their value for the investigation of many-body effects in the electronic structure of solids by measuring the projection of the electron momentum density onto the scattering vector, the so-called Compton profile. Due to the availability of modern synchrotron radiation facilities the momentum resolution of the technique was improved substantially and, by using circular polarized photons, "magnetic" Compton profiles could be determined in ferromagnetic materials. A new approach, where the Compton scattered photon is measured in coincidence with the recoiling electron, allows for a direct determination of electron momentum densities in solids. This (γ,eγ) scattering technique will reach its full potential once synchrotron radiation from undulators in electron storage rings operating at energies above 10 GeV will be available.

Authors: Bennett M.A., Smith P.A., Waterhouse D.K., Ford M.J., Flexman J., Williams J.F.
Title: Histogramming data acquisition system for an (e,2e) coincidence experiment
Affiliations: Center for Atomic, Molecular and Surface Physics, Physics Department, University of Western Australia, Nedlands, Perth, WA 6009, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Bennett, M.A., Center for Atomic, Molecular and Surface Physics, Physics Department, University of Western Australia, Nedlands, Perth, WA 6009, Australia; Smith, P.A., Center for Atomic, Molecular and Surface Physics, Physics Department, University of Western Australia, Nedlands, Perth, WA 6009, Australia; Waterhouse, D.K., Center for Atomic, Molecular and Surface Physics, Physics Department, University of Western Australia, Nedlands, Perth, WA 6009, Australia; Ford, M.J., Center for Atomic, Molecular and Surface Physics, Physics Department, University of Western Australia, Nedlands, Perth, WA 6009, Australia; Flexman, J., Center for Atomic, Molecular and Surface Physics, Physics Department, University of Western Australia, Nedlands, Perth, WA 6009, Australia; Williams, J.F., Center for Atomic, Molecular and Surface Physics, Physics Department, University of Western Australia, Nedlands, Perth, WA 6009, Australia
Abstract: A four-dimensional histogramming data acquisition system has been developed for use on an 80386 IBM-compatible computer. The method has a large data storage capacity providing good experimental resolution and system flexibility. A custom-built analog-to-digital board generates a memory address in hardware from the incoming data which permit the use of a simple and elegant histogramming algorithm. The system is used to collect and analyze data from (e,2e) experiments. Results from coplanar symmetric (e,2e) experiments on argon, at an incident energy of 3 keV, are presented to demonstrate the performance of the instrument. The method is applicable to experiments where data from several sources have to be combined and then histogrammed in real time.

Authors: Sugiyama S., Ohgaki H., Mikado M., Noguchi T., Yamada K., Chiwaki M., Suzuki R., Koike M., Yamazaki T., Tomimasu T., Keishi T., Usami H., Hosoda Y.
Title: Design of 10-T superconducting wiggler for angiography
Affiliations: Electrotechnical Laboratory, 1-1-4 Umezono, Tsukuba City, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Sumitomo Electric Industries, Ltd., 1-1-3, Shimaya, Konohana-ku, Osaka 554, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Sugiyama, S., Electrotechnical Laboratory, 1-1-4 Umezono, Tsukuba City, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Ohgaki, H., Electrotechnical Laboratory, 1-1-4 Umezono, Tsukuba City, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Mikado, M., Electrotechnical Laboratory, 1-1-4 Umezono, Tsukuba City, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Noguchi, T., Electrotechnical Laboratory, 1-1-4 Umezono, Tsukuba City, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Yamada, K., Electrotechnical Laboratory, 1-1-4 Umezono, Tsukuba City, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Chiwaki, M., Electrotechnical Laboratory, 1-1-4 Umezono, Tsukuba City, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Suzuki, R., Electrotechnical Laboratory, 1-1-4 Umezono, Tsukuba City, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Koike, M., Electrotechnical Laboratory, 1-1-4 Umezono, Tsukuba City, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Yamazaki, T., Electrotechnical Laboratory, 1-1-4 Umezono, Tsukuba City, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Tomimasu, T., Electrotechnical Laboratory, 1-1-4 Umezono, Tsukuba City, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Keishi, T., Sumitomo Electric Industries, Ltd., 1-1-3, Shimaya, Konohana-ku, Osaka 554, Japan; Usami, H., Sumitomo Electric Industries, Ltd., 1-1-3, Shimaya, Konohana-ku, Osaka 554, Japan; Hosoda, Y., Sumitomo Electric Industries, Ltd., 1-1-3, Shimaya, Konohana-ku, Osaka 554, Japan
Abstract: The design of a 10-T superconducting wiggler as a synchrotron radiation source for angiography has been carried out to be installed in an 800-MeV electron storage ring, TERAS, at Electrotechnical Laboratory (ETL). Synchrotron radiation generated by the wiggler has a critical photon energy of 4.47 keV and the radiation spectrum identical to that from a 2.5-GeV storage ring with a bending radius of 8.3 m. The magnet of the wiggler consists of three pairs of iron-cored superconducting coils designed to provide a peak field of 10.5 T on the beam trajectory. The effect of the wiggler on the storage ring has been investigated and a pair of quadrupole doublets on both sides of the wiggler can compensate a large deviation of the betatron tune.

Authors: Emery John J., MacKay Michael H., Umar Pervez A., Vanderveer Doug G., Pichette Ray J.
Title: Use of wastes and byproducts as pavement construction materials
Affiliations: John Emery Geotechnical Engineering, Ltd
Authors with affiliations: Emery, John J., John Emery Geotechnical Engineering, Ltd; MacKay, Michael H., John Emery Geotechnical Engineering, Ltd; Umar, Pervez A., John Emery Geotechnical Engineering, Ltd; Vanderveer, Doug G., John Emery Geotechnical Engineering, Ltd; Pichette, Ray J., John Emery Geotechnical Engineering, Ltd
Abstract: The current and potential reuse and recycling of top-ranking wastes and byproducts (old asphalt, old concrete, blast furnace slag, fly ash, steel slag, silica fume, nickel and copper slags, bottom ash, mine waste rock, waste tires, kiln dusts, waste foundry, sand, waste glass and waste shingles) as bulk and cementitious materials in transportation construction is summarized. Factors limiting the use of wastes as pavement construction materials such as inherent variability, collection, storage and processing costs, lack of technical guidance and specifications. environmental constraints and agency conservatism are addressed from a materials engineering technical perspective. While the transportation construction industry reuse and recycling of wastes and byproducts makes an important contribution to reduced landfill disposal, the overall impact on aggregates and energy conservation will continue to be modest. It is important for sustainable development to nurture and expand the use of wastes to avoid the landfilling of potential construction materials.
Index Keywords: Aggregates; Byproducts; Energy conservation; Environmental impact; Industrial wastes; Land fill; Pavements; Recycling; Refuse disposal; Roadbuilding materials; Wood wastes; Cementitious materials; Landfill disposal; Materials engineering technical perspective; Pavement construction materials; Transportation construction industry; Waste utilization

Authors: McCreath Dougal R., Diederichs Mark S.
Title: Canadian concept for a nuclear fuel waste disposal facility: Assessing the potential for near-field fracturing of the rock mass
Affiliations: Laurentian Univ, Sudbury, Canada
Authors with affiliations: McCreath, Dougal R., Laurentian Univ, Sudbury, Canada; Diederichs, Mark S., Laurentian Univ, Sudbury, Canada
Abstract: A concept for the permanent storage of Canada's nuclear fuel waste which is based on in-floor burial of waste cannisters within an engineered repository constructed in plutonic rocks of the Canadian shield has been developed by the Atomic Energy of Canada Limited (AECL). Environment Canada has undertaken scoping calculations to assess the potential for fracturing of the rock mass around the repository rooms and cannister emplacement holes. The goal of the work was to undertake simple modelling, based on the boundary element program EXAMINE2D, consistent with the current stage of concept review. Finding suggests that in-floor storage of the waste cannisters should be critically reviewed before being accepted as part of the AECL disposal concept.
Index Keywords: Boundary element method; Computer simulation; Crack propagation; Mathematical models; Nuclear fuels; Radioactive waste disposal; Research laboratories; Rocks; Stress analysis; Thermal stress; Atomic Energy of Canada Limited (AECL); Underground research laboratory (URL); Waste cannisters; Geological repositories

Authors: Israel Peggy, Croom David
Title: Optimal distribution of N points on a sphere with a Coulomb energy network
Source title: Intelligent Engineering Systems Through Artificial Neural Networks
Affiliations: Univ of Alabama in Huntsville, Huntsville, United States
Authors with affiliations: Israel, Peggy, Univ of Alabama in Huntsville, Huntsville, United States; Croom, David, Univ of Alabama in Huntsville, Huntsville, United States
Abstract: We present here a new application of the Coulomb energy network. In the past this neural network has been used as a relaxation model for associative memory. We show here how the network can be used to solve a completely different problem: that of finding the optimal distribution of n points on a sphere. The goal in this problem is to distribute n points over a sphere in such a way that the minimum distance between them is maximized. This problem is related to the sphere packing problem, which has application in mathematics, the design of codes for data transmission and storage, and other engineering applications. We show here how the Coulomb energy network provides a very natural and elegant solution to this problem. In this novel application, each of the n points on the sphere is modeled as a negatively charged particle in the electrostatic field. The model utilizes an energy function which expresses the potential energy associated with each charged point at its location in space. This function is minimized when points of like charge are as far away from each other as possible. At each time step, a point is moved in a direction proportional to the negative gradient of the energy function, but is confined to remain on the sphere's surface. At equilibrium the n points are as far apart as possible. The algorithm converges rapidly and lends itself well to the inherent parallel processing potential of the Coulomb energy network.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Electric charge; Electrostatics; Functions; Mathematical models; Optimization; Parallel processing systems; Potential energy; Problem solving; Coulomb energy networks; Sphere packing problem; Neural networks

Authors: Chao Daniel Y., Wang David T., Hung Douglas D.
Title: On threshold functions and multi-valued networks
Source title: Intelligent Engineering Systems Through Artificial Neural Networks
Affiliations: New Jersey Inst of Technology, Newark, United States
Authors with affiliations: Chao, Daniel Y., New Jersey Inst of Technology, Newark, United States; Wang, David T., New Jersey Inst of Technology, Newark, United States; Hung, Douglas D., New Jersey Inst of Technology, Newark, United States
Abstract: The binary order Hopfield neural network of multi-valued neurons is proposed. An energy function is proposed for synchronous and asynchronous operations. The convergence of this type of network is verified and the upper bounds of convergence time are studied. The number of threshold functions for multi-valued neurons is investigated. The enhancement of memory capacity is also discussed.
Index Keywords: Data storage equipment; Functions; Multi-valued Hopfield networks; Threshold functions; Neural networks

Authors: Young Karl S.
Title: Design of a 3,000 mile range transit bus powered by hydrogen fuel cells
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Yung Technologies Intl Inc
Authors with affiliations: Young, Karl S., Yung Technologies Intl Inc
Abstract: Using only 650 lbs of liquid hydrogen, a full size transit bus driven by electric motors can travel non-stop for 3,000 miles. The energy conversion comes from a 150 kW fuel cell at 55-65% efficiency. The two types of fuel cells that will be practical for rubber-wheeled transportation at this time are the proton exchange membrane (PEM) and the alkaline type. Advanced batteries will be incorporated in the design to assist with acceleration and for regenerative braking. The low temperature hydrogen will help to cool the fuel cell, increase power output of the electric motors, and cool the passenger space. The bus will have four independent wheel drives, with 4-wheel steering to reduce turn-radius. The purpose for this demonstration bus is to lay the design foundation for zero-emission urban buses.
Index Keywords: Buses; Computers; Control systems; Energy storage; Internal combustion engines; Energy storage basics; Hydrogen fuel cells; Hydrogen safety; Proton exchange membrane (PEM); Rubber-wheeled transportation; Zero-emission urban buses; Fuel cells

Authors: Hoyer Marcus C., Sterling Raymond L.
Title: Results of the third long-term cycle at the university of Minnesota aquifer thermal energy storage (ATES) field test facility
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Minnesota, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hoyer, Marcus C., Univ of Minnesota, United States; Sterling, Raymond L., Univ of Minnesota, United States
Abstract: The third long-term ATES cycle (LT3) was conducted between October 1989 and March 1990. Objectives of LT3 were to demonstrate that high-temperature ATES could supply a real heating load and to simplify the water chemistry modeling. For LT3 the Field Test Facility (FTF) was connected to a nearby campus building to demonstrate the FTF's ability to meet a real heating load. For LT3 the wells were modified so that only the most permeable portions of the Ironton-Galesville aquifer were used to simplify water chemistry comparisons and modelling. The campus steam plant was the source for heat stored during LT3. A total volume of 63.2 × 103 m3 of water was injected at a rate of 54.95 m3/hr into the storage well at a mean temperature of 104.7°C from October through December 1989. Tie-in to the Animal Sciences Veterinary Medicine (ASVM) building was not completed until late December. A total volume of 66.0 × 103 m3 of water was recovered at a rate of 44.83 m3/hr from the storage well at a mean temperature of 76.5°C from January through March 1990. Highest and lowest temperatures of recovered water were 100.0 and 47.8°C, respectively. Approximately 66% of the energy added to the aquifer was recovered. The useful minimum temperature for recovered water was 49°C; approximately 50% of the energy added to the aquifer above 49°C (33% of the total energy stored) was delivered to the ASVM building. Approximately 15% of the usable (10% of the total) energy stored was actually used in the ASVM building. Operations during heat recovery with the ASVM building's reheat system were troublefree. Integration into more of the ASVM (or other) building's mechanical system would have resulted in significantly increasing the proportion of energy used during heat recovery. The cost to connect to other ASVM building systems for this experimental cycle was the main reason for not incorporating other building systems into the FTF. The FTF ion-exchange water softener reduced hardness of the source water to <5 mg/L as CaCO3 prior to heating, allowing successful operation. Water chemistry is critical to the operation of the University of Minnesota FTF, or any ATES facility. This work was conducted for the U.S. Department of Energy through its Pacific Northwest Laboratory.
Index Keywords: Aquifers; Energy storage; Ion exchange; Aquifers thermal Energy storage; Field tests; Heat storage

Authors: Sorensen Stig Niem, Reffstrup Jan
Title: Prediction of long-term operational conditions for single-well groundwater heat pump plants
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Technical Univ of Denmark, Denmark
Authors with affiliations: Sorensen, Stig Niem, Technical Univ of Denmark, Denmark; Reffstrup, Jan, Technical Univ of Denmark, Denmark
Abstract: When using groundwater as a primary energy source in combination with heat pumps, the groundwater is pumped from the groundwater zone, cooled in the heat exchanger of the heat pump, and then reinjected into the groundwater zone. The design of traditional groundwater heat pump plants is based on the use of a separate pumping and reinjection well. An alternative design is to use a single-well for both pumping and reinjection. However a minimum distance between well screens is required in order to prevent break-through, caused by short-circuiting of the cooled groundwater. The present paper describes a simplified mathematical model to be used to analyze steady-state operational temperature conditions for a single-well groundwater heat pump plant. The model is based on a finite element solution of the temperature distribution in the pumping and reinjection zones of a groundwater reservoir. Furthermore, a model for the calculation of the ratio of the vertical to the horizontal permeability is presented in the paper. This ratio is one of the important parameters in the design of a single-well groundwater heat pump plant. Both models have been tested against data from a full-scale experimental plant on the campus of the Technical University, where the hydrogeological conditions are familiar. The results of a comparison between model predictions and experimental field data are included in the paper.
Index Keywords: Aquifers; Energy storage; Groundwater; Heat exchangers; Heat storage; Hydrogeology; Heat pump systems

Authors: Hull John R., Uherka Kenneth L.
Title: Recent advances in high-temperature superconductor wire fabrication and applications development
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Argonne Natl Lab
Authors with affiliations: Hull, John R., Argonne Natl Lab; Uherka, Kenneth L., Argonne Natl Lab
Abstract: In this paper, recent advances in fabrication of high-temperature superconductor wires are summarized and detailed discussion is provided on developments in near- and intermediate-term applications. Near-term applications, using presently obtainable current densities, include liquid-nitrogen depth sensors, cryostat current leads, and magnetic bearings. Intermediate-term applications, using current densities expected to be available in the near future, include fault-current limiters and short transmission lines.
Index Keywords: Electric wire; Energy storage; Magnetic bearings; Sensors; Current densities; Superconducting wires; High temperature superconductors

Authors: Guven Hal, Flynn Jack
Title: TES commissioning issues
Source title: Energy Engineering: Journal of the Association of Energy Engineering
Affiliations: San Diego State Univ, United States
Authors with affiliations: Guven, Hal, San Diego State Univ, United States; Flynn, Jack, San Diego State Univ, United States
Abstract: If properly designed, installed, operated, and maintained, a thermal energy storage (TES) system can significantly reduce cooling costs in buildings with heavy peak-period cooling loads. This economic savings is achieved by using less expensive off-peak power to cool a storage medium such as water,ice or eutectic salts and then storing the cooling energy for use during on-peak periods when electric rates are much higher. This losdshift is useful to electric utilities in that it helps defer the need to build costly new power plants to help meet increasing peal loads.
Index Keywords: Buildings; Cooling systems; Costs; Energy management; Heat storage; Laws and legislation; British commissioning systems; Commissioning project; Commissioning workshop; Conventional chillers; HVAC systems; Energy storage

Authors: Minck R.W., Chang R.R., Halbach C.R., Divsalar F., Kuo Ying-Yan
Title: Space flight demonstration of the sodium-sulfur cell
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Loral Aeronutronic, United States
Authors with affiliations: Minck, R.W., Loral Aeronutronic, United States; Chang, R.R., Loral Aeronutronic, United States; Halbach, C.R., Loral Aeronutronic, United States; Divsalar, F., Loral Aeronutronic, United States; Kuo, Ying-Yan, Loral Aeronutronic, United States
Abstract: The sodium-sulfur battery is emerging as a prime high-temperature energy storage technology for space flight applications. Useable specific energy of two to three times that of Ni-H2 batteries is the key advantage of Na-S. This represents a significant launch cost savings, and increased payload mass capability. A Na-S cell temonstration is planned for a 1995 NASA Space Shuttle flight which focuses on the micro-gravity effects on individual cells. This paper will describe the experiment plan in detail.
Index Keywords: Electric batteries; Energy storage; Hydrides; Sodium; Space shuttles; Sulfur; Sodium hydride batteries; Sodium sulfur cells; Space flight

Authors: Brown Curt, Miller Lee
Title: Battery support for solar vehicle development
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Eagle-Picher Industry Inc, United States
Authors with affiliations: Brown, Curt, Eagle-Picher Industry Inc, United States; Miller, Lee, Eagle-Picher Industry Inc, United States
Abstract: Since 1984 Eagle-Picher Ind., Inc. has provided hardware and technical support to the budding solar vehicle industry. The batteries are used in the solar vehicles to provide storage of the electrical energy from the solar cells for use during brief periods when the power requirements exceed the capability of the solar cells, such as hill climbing, passing, or low sun conditions. Though the early development of these vehicles has focused on races which place emphasis on both speed and endurance, the ultimate goal is a commercial vehicle which will reduce the consumption of fossil fuels for transportation. Eagle-Picher Industries silver-oxide zinc system has proven ideal for use in this development phase because of their high energy density and reliability. Eagle-Picher Industries developed their secondary silver-oxide zinc systems over the past four decades to provide power for America's growing Aerospace industry where a high priority has always been placed on light weight and reliable performance. The batteries have helped the solar vehicle development progress from speeds of 10 mph and a few miles between failures to speeds in excess of 60 mph and distances of over 2,000 miles over public highways in harsh desert environments. Batteries supplied by Eagle-Picher Industries have powered the winning entries in all of the major races and a majority of all batteries used for all races.
Index Keywords: Electric vehicles; Solar energy; Solar power generation; Space applications; Vehicles; Silver oxide zinc batteries; Solar vehicles; Electric batteries

Authors: Rockenfeller Uwe, Sarkisian Paul, Kirol Lance D.
Title: Coordinative complex compounds for efficient storage of polar refrigerants and gases
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Rocky Research
Authors with affiliations: Rockenfeller, Uwe, Rocky Research; Sarkisian, Paul, Rocky Research; Kirol, Lance D., Rocky Research
Abstract: The coordinative bond that is established between metal inorganic salt based adsorbents and polar refrigerants and gases, such as ammonia, sulfur dioxide and water, bears significant thermodynamic advantages over commonly used zeolite or activated carbon inclusion compound sorption media. Complex compounds utilize this unique bond to hold large amounts of refrigerant in a process that is reversible, allowing for their application to storage processes. This paper describes the physical and thermodynamic properties of monovariant complex compounds and compares resulting equipment specifications of mass and energy storage products with competing technologies. An evaluation of the thermodynamic process and the operation of these systems for refrigerant storage/recycling and low temperature thermal storage is also described for specific applications.
Index Keywords: Ammonia; Carbon; Energy storage; Heat storage; Thermodynamic properties; Complex compounds; Polar refrigerants; Refrigerants

Authors: Widrig Richard D.
Title: Renewable energy technologies for space at DOE
Affiliations: Pacific Northwest Lab
Authors with affiliations: Widrig, Richard D., Pacific Northwest Lab
Abstract: The involvement of the Department of Energy (DOE) in renewable energy technologies is discussed focused on terrestrial applications for NASA and DoD. Various energy sources such as solar energy, and excited space fuels are mentioned. Also discussed are energy transmission and distribution, energy storage, and energy management.
Index Keywords: Solar energy; Space flight; Space research; Excited space fuels; Renewable energy technologies; Renewable energy resources

Authors: Anon
Title: Natural gas era has begun
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: When Colonel Drake bored into a petroleum well in Titusville, Pennsylvania, on 28th August 1859, he was not able to make much use of the gas flowing out of the borehole together with the petroleum. He could not have imagined what a development in the application of this resource would occur later. The production (Fig. 1), purification, transport, storage and distribution as well as the further processing of this natural product, for example in the petrochemical sector, have justified huge investment. Changes are taking place in this sector now which can be compared with the changeover from coal to petrochemicals which took place some 40 years ago. The Sulzer Corporation is participating in the extension of natural gas processing by supplying a multiplicity of products and services. The following examples are selected for further comment in this issue: compressors for natural gas storage natural gas storage and transport structured packings in the drying of natural gas natural gas as motorcar fuel.
Index Keywords: Combustion; Fossil fuels; Fuel cells; Liquefied natural gas; Liquid methane; Natural gas; Natural gas conditioning; Environmental compatibility; Gas exploitation; Gas processing; Energy resources

Title: Aerospace Power

Abstract: Volume 2 of the Proceedings of the Conference is devoted to aerospace power and contains 75 papers. The following subjects are considered: space nuclear power - thermionic systems and technology; reactor thermoelectric technology; computer simulation of spacecraft power systems; electric batteries for space applications, including nickel hydrogen, nickel cadmium, nickel-metal hydride and silver-metal hydride batteries; space power management and distribution; space static/dynamic conversion and component technology; thermionics systems; wireless power transmission, power beaming, including laser power beaming; aerospace power thermal management; isotopic fueled power systems and technology; aircraft electric power.

Authors: Meckler Milton
Title: Integrating thermal energy storage systems with automatic fire sprinkler
Source title: Energy Engineering: Journal of the Association of Energy Engineering
Affiliations: Meckler Group, Encino, United States
Authors with affiliations: Meckler, Milton, Meckler Group, Encino, United States
Abstract: Section 5-6 of the National Fire Protection Association Standard NFPA-13 describes approved methods whereby non-fire protection circulating-closed loops can be interconnected with conventionally designed building automatic fire sprinkle (AFS) systems by means of NNFPA-permitted closed-loop piping arrangements. This paper discusses the NFPA-13 requirements, HVAC industry practices, utilization of available time-of-day utility rate structures, and the understandable concerns of safety officials for potential misuse and/or misapplication of such non-fire protection interconnections.
Index Keywords: Building codes; Heat storage; Laws and legislation; Office buildings; Sprinkler systems (fire fighting); Automatic fire sprinklers; Circulating closed loop systems; Thermal energy storage; Energy storage

Authors: Calogeras James E., Dustin Miles O.
Title: Ground testing of a 2kWe solar dynamic space power system
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: NASA Lewis Research Cent, United States
Authors with affiliations: Calogeras, James E., NASA Lewis Research Cent, United States; Dustin, Miles O., NASA Lewis Research Cent, United States
Abstract: Over the past 25 years Space Solar Dynamic component development has advanced to the point where it is considered a leading candidate power source technology for the evolutionary phases of the Space Station Freedom (SSF) program. Selection of SD power was based on studies and analyses which indicated significant savings in life cycle costs, launch mass and EVA requirements were possible when the system is compared to more conventional photovoltaic/battery power systems. However, line any new or untested system proposed for space applications a number of issues have been raised concerning performance of the components when integrated into a system in a vacuum environment. Issues associated with micro-gravity operation such as the behavior of the thermal energy storage materials are being addressed in other programs. A ground test of a 2kWe solar dynamic system is being planned by the NASA Office of Aeronautics and Space Technology to address the integration issues. The test will be scalable to 25 kWe, we will be flight configured and will incorporate relevant features of the SSF Solar Dynamic Power Module design.
Index Keywords: Electric batteries; Electric power systems; Photovoltaic cells; Solar energy; Space flight; Space stations; Spacecraft power supplies; NASA; Photovoltaic/battery power systems; Space power; Space Station Freedom; Solar power generation

Authors: Yimer B.
Title: Thermal radiation effects in phase change energy storage systems
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Heat Transfer Division, (Publication) HTD
Affiliations: Univ of Kansas, Lawrence, United States
Authors with affiliations: Yimer, B., Univ of Kansas, Lawrence, United States
Abstract: In this study a numerical model was developed to determine the transient temperature distribution, solid/liquid interface location, and energy storage capacity of a semi-transparent phase change medium. The medium is bounded between two concentric cylinders and internal energy transfer occurs simultaneously by conduction and thermal radiation. In the analysis, the radiation transport equation was coupled with the energy equation. In the describing energy equation, both enthalpy and temperature were employed as the dependent variables. The spherical harmonic approximation (P-N approximation) was used to obtain solutions for the radiative heat flux. The coupled law of conservation of energy and moment differential equations were solved by iterative numerical finite difference schemes using the appropriate thermal and radiant boundary/interface conditions. The numerical model was used to study the effects of radiation on the solidification (melting) transient temperature distribution, and energy storage capacity of an absorbing, emitting and isotropically scattering semi-transparent gray medium contained in a cylinderical annulus. Results that increase an understanding of internal energy transfer and show the effects of optical properties, conduction/radiation parameter, and geometric dimensions are presented. The results of this study will lead to a better design and optimization of phase change energy storage systems.
Index Keywords: Liquids; Solids; Temperature distribution; Thermal effects; Energy equation; Phase change energy storage systems; Solid/liquid interface location; Thermal radiation effects; Energy storage

Authors: Fittro Roger L., Anand Davinder K.
Title: Neural network controller design for a magnetic bearing flywheel energy storage system
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Maryland, United States
Authors with affiliations: Fittro, Roger L., Univ of Maryland, United States; Anand, Davinder K., Univ of Maryland, United States
Abstract: The control and analysis of magnetic bearings has been primarily based upon classical linear control theory. This approach does not allow for some important system complexities and nonlinearities to be taken into account. The resulting simplifications degrade the overall system performance. This paper investigates the use of a neural network to control a magnetic bearing flywheel energy storage system. A plant simulation is developed as well as a neural network emulator and controller.
Index Keywords: Control systems; Energy storage; Flywheels; Neural networks; Flywheel energy storage; Magnetic bearings

Authors: Datta Partha, Sengupta Subrata, Roy Sanjay Kumar
Title: Natural convection heat transfer in an enclosure with suspensions of microencapsulated phase change materials
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Heat Transfer Division, (Publication) HTD
Affiliations: Univ of Michigan, Dearborn, United States
Authors with affiliations: Datta, Partha, Univ of Michigan, Dearborn, United States; Sengupta, Subrata, Univ of Michigan, Dearborn, United States; Roy, Sanjay Kumar, Univ of Michigan, Dearborn, United States
Abstract: Preliminary investigations on heat transfer enhancement in natural convection flows, using suspensions of microencapsulated phase change materials have been conducted in a cubical enclosure heated from below. The side walls of the enclosure are insulated, the lower wall is a constant heat flux surface and the upper wall is isothermal. The parameters studied were the Rayleigh number, the volumetric particle concentration, the Stefan number and the particle size. The data indicates that it is possible to obtain enhancements of upto 80% with concentrations as low as 1%. The Rayleigh number and the Stefan number were the other dominating parameters.
Index Keywords: Channel flow; Confined flow; Heat convection; Heat storage; Solar energy; Heat flux; Heat transfer enhancement; Phase change materials; Thermal energy storage; Heat transfer

Authors: Rosenberg Sanders D.
Title: Weight and power requirements for a lunar oxygen plant
Affiliations: Aerojet Propulsion Div, Sacramento, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rosenberg, Sanders D., Aerojet Propulsion Div, Sacramento, United States
Abstract: The utilization of extraterrestrial resources will become a key element of the Space Exploration Initiation and the exploration and colonization of the Moon and Mars in the 21st century. Indeed, the development and operation of in-situ manufacturing plants are required to enable the establishment of permanent lunar and Martian bases. Oxygen manufacture for propulsion and life support will be the central process for the first of these plants. The Aerojet Carbothermal Process for the manufacture of lunar oxygen is based on a three-step cyclic process, that is (1) reduction of in-situ minerals with methane, (2) reduction of carbon monoxide with hydrogen, and (3) electrolysis of water. Estimates of the weight and power requirements for such an oxygen plant have been made. The assumption was made that no water is present in, or obtainable from, the in-situ minerals. Two different methods of heat rejection were studied, that is (1) a dual-cycle refrigeration system to pump the heat up to a high heat rejection temperature, and (2) direct heat rejection to space by radiation. Large differences in weights results when these different cooling methods were used due to the large amounts of waste heat produced. The complete process is described and the results studied are present. Each step is reviewed as are ancillary steps, such as oxygen liquefaction and storage. Finally, a summary of lunar oxygen plant weight and power requirements is provided.
Index Keywords: Energy utilization; Power generation; Extraterrestrial resource utilization; Lunar oxygen plant power requirements; Lunar oxygen plant weight; Permanent lunar base; Permanent Martian base; Water electrolysis section; Moon bases

Authors: Andersson Olo, Sellberg Bjorn
Title: Swedish ATES applications: experiences after ten years of development
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: VBB VIAK AB
Authors with affiliations: Andersson, Olo, VBB VIAK AB; Sellberg, Bjorn, VBB VIAK AB
Abstract: During the last 10 years, the general concept of using the subsurface for the storage of energy has been increasingly developed in Sweden. Among the many alternatives, aquifers are one of the most promising options. Potentially they can be used both for seasonal and short-term energy storage at temperatures ranging from 2°C to more than 100°C. So far, Sweden has had only experimental experience with storage of high-temperatures (>50°C). However, there are several low temperature systems (<25°C) that have been operated for more than two years. In this paper, these ATES plants are overviewed and some general technical problems are identified, as well as measures that have been taken to solve these problems. The range of problems includes the aquifer system itself, but also problems related to the total system and how it is operated. Further, the economics are briefly described, as well as environmental aspects. The ATES concept still has some weaknesses that need improvement, but commercialization of the technology should be quite close.
Index Keywords: Aquifers; Economics; Energy storage; Environmental impact; Sweden; Heat storage

Authors: Vail L.W., Jenne E.A., Eary L.E.
Title: H2OTREAT: an aid for evaluating water treatment requirements for aquifer thermal energy storage
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Pacific Northwest Lab
Authors with affiliations: Vail, L.W., Pacific Northwest Lab; Jenne, E.A., Pacific Northwest Lab; Eary, L.E., Pacific Northwest Lab
Abstract: A public-domain software package is available to aid engineers in the design of water treatment systems for Aquifer Thermal Energy Storage (ATES). Geochemical phenomena that cause problems in ATES systems include formation of scale in heat exchangers, clogging of wells, corrosion in piping and heat exchangers, and degradation of aquifer materials. Preventing such problems frequently requires employing water treatment systems. Individual water treatment methods vary in cost, effectiveness, environmental impact, corrosion potential, and acceptability to regulatory bodies. Evaluating these water treatment options is generally required to determine the feasibility of ATES systems. The H20TREAT software was developed by Pacific Northwest Laboratory for use by engineers with limited or no experience in geochemistry. At the feasibility analysis and design stages, the software utilizes a recently revised geochemical model, MINTEQ, to calculate the saturation indices of selected carbonate, oxide, and hydroxide minerals based on water chemistry and temperature data provided by the user. The saturation index of a specific mineral defines whether that mineral is oversaturated, hence may precipitate at the specified temperature. The saturation indices of key calcium, iron, silica, and manganese carbonates, oxides, and hydroxides (calcite, rhodochrosite, siderite, Fe(OH)3[a], birnessite, chalcedony, and SiO2) are calculated. User input is separated into 'required' and 'optional' data (Table 1). Currently, H2OTREAT does not perform cost calculations; however, treatment capacity requirements are provided. Treatments considered include 1) Na and H ion exchangers and pellet reactors to avoid calcite precipitation, and 2) in situ nitrate addition and cascade precipitators to prevent Fe and Mn oxide precipitation. The H2OTREAT software also provides the user with guidance on other geochemical problems that must be considered, such as SiO2 precipitation, corrosion, and environmental considerations. The sodium adsorption ratio and sodium hazard are calculated to evaluate the likelihood of clay swelling and dispersion caused by high Na concentrations (e.g., as a result of Na ion exchange water treatment used to prevent calcite precipitation). H2OTREAT is available for DOS and UNIX computers.
Index Keywords: Aquifers; Computer software; Energy storage; Water treatment; Aquifers thermal Energy storage; Software package H2OTREAT; Heat storage

Authors: Willemsen A.
Title: PHREEQM-2D: a computer model to calculate geochemical reactions during transport of groundwater; model description and application to the Utrecht University ATES
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: IF Technology
Authors with affiliations: Willemsen, A., IF Technology
Abstract: When hot water is injected into an aquifer, the water will react with the mineral present in the aquifer. The most important processes are cation exchange, precipitation/dissolution of carbonates, and dissolution/precipitation of silicates. If the redox condition of the water is changed during the process (e.g., because of contact with oxygen in the air or because of mixing of water with a different redox status) redox reactions will be important as well. In many cases, the water will have to be treated to prevent carbonate scaling during heating. This treatment will influence the reactions in the aquifer. Because the water is (at least partly) reused each cycle, the reactions in the aquifer may cause an increase or a decrease in necessary treatment in subsequent cycles. Also, the treatment and the reactions in the aquifer may have an influence on the environmental impact of the store because the quality of the water lost from the store is changed. To be able to assess the relevance of these processes, a model has been developed that calculates the chemical reactions during transport of groundwater. An example of use of the model is given for the Utrecht University ATES system. At this site, a split treatment of Ca-Na softening is used to prevent carbonate sealing. The calculations have helped to make decisions on how to proceed with water treatment.
Index Keywords: Aquifers; Energy storage; Groundwater geochemistry; Heat exchangers; Aquifers thermal Energy storage; Utrecht University; Heat storage

Authors: Seiffert Ulrich
Title: The need for innovations in automobile technology (Plenary address)
Affiliations: Volkswagen AG, Wolfsburg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Seiffert, Ulrich, Volkswagen AG, Wolfsburg, Germany
Abstract: The need for research and development in the automobile industry is discussed, with particular reference to the experience at Volkswagen. Particular attention is given to the technical progress of VW/Audi automobiles, the drag coefficient of VW and Audi cars, the development of European emission laws, measures for fuel economy, the VW multifuel concept for methanol-gasoline operation, the storage characteristics of transportation energy, the electronic differential lock system, the Audi procon-ten system, and the VW Futura.

Authors: Bartholomeusz Brian, Kopalidis Peter
Title: Thermal stability of amorphous rare earth-transition metal optical data storage media
Affiliations: Eastman Kodak Co, Rochester, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bartholomeusz, Brian, Eastman Kodak Co, Rochester, United States; Kopalidis, Peter, Eastman Kodak Co, Rochester, United States
Abstract: Amorphous rare earth-transition metal thin films can undergo appreciable localized temperature excursions during optical data storage applications. With time this can lead to thermally-induced change in material properties. In extreme situations crystallization can occur. We have undertaken experimental and theoretical studies of these materials and evolved fresh insights into their thermal stability including the existence of an activation energy spectrum for the thermal relaxation process itself. We have also examined the impact of thermally induced material changes in optical recording scenarios.
Index Keywords: Optical Materials - Thermal Properties; Rare Earth Elements; Relaxation Processes - Thermal Effects; Transition Metals; Amorphous Rare Earth Transition Metal Thin Films; Thermal Stability; Data Storage, Optical

Authors: Sterrett Richard H.
Title: Operator influence on the performance of chillers and thermal energy storage systems
Source title: Energy Engineering: Journal of the Association of Energy Engineering
Affiliations: Science Applications Int Corp, San Diego, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sterrett, Richard H., Science Applications Int Corp, San Diego, United States
Abstract: Science applications International Corp. (SAIC) installed instrumentation on the cooling systems of nine commercial facilities and monitored their performance. This paper briefly summarizes the operator influence on the results. The systems, which were efficiently operated, had a high degree of commitment from both the operator and the facilities' management. This commitment was demonstrated in the level of training, maintenance procedures and support for the building engineer.
