Authors: Nomura Eiichi, Matsui Kazumasa, Kunimoto Asao, Takashima Koichiro, Matsumaru Yuji, Iijima Shigeru, Matsuo Yasushi, Hirabayashi Toshihiko, Furuta Shigenobu
Title: Final report on the development and operation of a 1MW/8MWh Na/S battery energy storage plant
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Yuasa Batter Co Ltd, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nomura, Eiichi, Yuasa Batter Co Ltd, Japan; Matsui, Kazumasa, Yuasa Batter Co Ltd, Japan; Kunimoto, Asao, Yuasa Batter Co Ltd, Japan; Takashima, Koichiro, Yuasa Batter Co Ltd, Japan; Matsumaru, Yuji, Yuasa Batter Co Ltd, Japan; Iijima, Shigeru, Yuasa Batter Co Ltd, Japan; Matsuo, Yasushi, Yuasa Batter Co Ltd, Japan; Hirabayashi, Toshihiko, Yuasa Batter Co Ltd, Japan; Furuta, Shigenobu, Yuasa Batter Co Ltd, Japan
Abstract: The Yuasa Battery Company and NGK Spark Plug Company have successfully completed installation, and started operation of a 1MW/MWh Na/S battery energy storage plant in the Tatsumi energy storage facility of The Kansai Electric Power Company, under the sponsorship and direction of the New Energy and Industrial Technology Development Organization. The 1MW/8MWh Na/S battery plant has been constructed in two steps. The first half of the plant, corresponding to 0.5MW/4MWh, was constructed in September, 1990, and tested until May, 1991, when 85 charge/discharge cycles were counted. The second half plant corresponding to 0.5MW/4MWh was assembled in May, 1991, heated up to the operating temperature, and combined with the first half plant to complete a full 1MW/8MWh Na/S battery energy storage plant. After passing the official test, the operation of the full 1MW/8MWh battery plant officially started. The full size 1MW/8MWh Na/S battery plant functioned satisfactorily with charge/discharge efficiencies of about 86.3% on the DC/DC basis excluding auxiliary power consumption, and 126 charge/discharge cycles were completed by March 31, 1992. During this period, the first half 0.5MW/4MWh plant achieved of 211 cycles. The operation of the 1MW/8MWh full plant was officially continued till the end of March, 1992, followed by independent research by Yuasa Battery Company and The Kansai Electric Power Company.
Index Keywords: Energy storage; Battery energy storage plant; Beta-alumina tubes; Discharge/charge energy efficiency; Energy efficiency calculation; Sodium/Sulfur battery pilot plant; Electric batteries

Authors: Humphris Robert R.
Title: Versatile diagnostic device for use with magnetic bearings
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Virginia, United States
Authors with affiliations: Humphris, Robert R., Univ of Virginia, United States
Abstract: A compact portable device, which permits the measurement and determination of various properties of machinery using magnetic bearings, has been constructed. This mostly analog device has a white noise generator, a variable frequency, variable amplitude sine wave and square wave output and can generate a ramped frequency 'rotating' electronic signal to simulate rotor speed run-up. It may be utilized during normal operation or when the rotor is in support, but not rotating. Probably it would be most helpful during initial test-stand testing. System dynamic properties, such as critical speeds, stiffness, damping, maximum and optimum clearances, rub angle locations, amplification factors, log decrements, structure resonances, cross coupling, etc., can be determined. A dynamic balancing feature using open-loop control, with the 'rotating' electronic signal synchronized via a key-phasor, may be manually set at a given speed. This balancing feature may be automatically activated and then turned off at previously determined speeds. The open-loop control features also may be used as a run-out compensator and for foundation vibration reduction. A block diagram description of the operational functions of this diagnostic device is presented, along with experimental results and dynamic properties gathered from its use on several magnetic bearing rigs.
Index Keywords: Energy storage; Rotors; Vibration control; White noise; Diagnostic devices; Dynamic balancing; Magnetic bearings

Authors: Jenne E.A., Andersson O., Willemsen A.
Title: Well, hydrology, and geochemistry problems encountered in ATES systems and their solutions
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Pacific Northwest Lab
Authors with affiliations: Jenne, E.A., Pacific Northwest Lab; Andersson, O., Pacific Northwest Lab; Willemsen, A., Pacific Northwest Lab
Abstract: In aquifer thermal energy storage (ATES) systems, wells provide the interface between the energy storage and use. Efficient operational wells are, therefore, essential for the system to run at maximum (design) efficiency. Adequate test drilling to accurately predict aquifer properties is essential in the design phase; proper construction and development are crucial; and proper monitoring of performance is necessary to identify the early stages of clogging and to evaluate the adequacy of well rehabilitation. Problems related to hydrology, well, and aquifer properties include 1) loss of permeability resulting from gas exsolution, chemical precipitation, and dispersion and movement of fine-grained particles; 2) loss of recoverable heat caused by excessive regional ground-water gradient, hydrodynamic mixing of injected and native ground water, buoyancy flow (because of temperature-induced differences in water density); 3) leakage up along the well casing; and 4) 'fracturing' of a shallow upper aquiclude as a result of an injection pressure greater than the hydro-static pressure on the aquiclude. The predominant geochemical problems encountered are precipitation of carbonates in some areas and iron plus manganese oxides in others. These precipitation problems can be anticipated, and thus avoided, via geochemical calculations. The likelihood of iron carbonate (FeCO3) precipitation is less certain because of the lack of adequate research. Corrosion is a frequent problem. Most of the hydrochemically related clogging and corrosion problems that have been encountered in ATES systems can be predicted and avoided by appropriate design, construction, and operation of new ATES systems, assuming that a comprehensive and careful site investigation that includes appropriate hydrologic and geochemical modeling is carried out in advance. Because of local variations in hydrology and water chemistry, each project must be carefully examined and the installation planned based on a knowledge of the kind of problems that could be encountered and site conditions. It is prudent to carefully consider the need for water treatment and to anticipate that there will be some increase in injection pressure and decrease of specific capacity over time. Therefore, the design should include 1) the capability to monitor the specific capacity, 2) an injection pressure control, 3) a permanent backflush system, and 4) a safety valve.
Index Keywords: Aquifers; Energy storage; Geochemistry; Hydrology; Aquifers thermal Energy storage; Heat storage

Authors: Morofsky Edward L., Cataford Robert, Mirza Cameran
Title: Monitoring energy consumption at the Canada centre ATES site
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Public Works Canada, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Morofsky, Edward L., Public Works Canada, Canada; Cataford, Robert, Public Works Canada, Canada; Mirza, Cameran, Public Works Canada, Canada
Abstract: The Canada Centre Building was designed to accommodate 1,900 workers on 12 floors in a 30,000 m2 office structure in Scarborough, Canada. Its unique energy conserving features include 700 m2 of roof mounted solar energy collectors, chillers modified to operate as heat pumps, and an aquifer thermal energy storage (ATES) system operating on four 60 m deep wells producing flows of 10 to 30 L/s from a 10 m thick fine to medium sand aquifer. The ATES and solar domestic hot water heating systems have been used since 1985. Instrumentation for ATES performance monitoring was installed during construction of the building, for research and verification of geothermal models. Energy monitoring, however, was implemented in 1991, to evaluate the energy consumed in operating various energy conserving systems. Initial data show coefficients of performance (COP) of about 4 to 5 for the ATES and heat pump systems respectively.
Index Keywords: Aquifers; Energy storage; Energy utilization; Monitoring; Aquifers thermal Energy storage; Canada; Heat storage

Authors: Dabadghav Ram
Title: Estimating planning level costs of pumped storage projects
Source title: Transactions of the American Association of Cost Engineers
Affiliations: Harza Engineering Co, Chicago, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dabadghav, Ram, Harza Engineering Co, Chicago, United States
Abstract: Pumped storage projects can serve a very useful purpose for utility companies. A pumped storage is a hydroelectric project and should be of interest to those who do not have enough information on their applicability. The discussions establish the basic principles of a pumped storage project and its main components, and suggest suitable methods of developing costs of major items at the conceptual and planning level by using cost curves. All cost curves are not presented (for lack of space), but they can be prepared on similar principles. A pumped storage project pumps water from a reservoir at a lower elevation to a reservoir at a higher elevation during off-peak hours when there is unused capacity from base-load generating units in the system. During on-peak hours, water passes from the upper reservoir to the lower reservoir to generate electricity and meet the system peaking demand. This operation improves overall system efficiency and reduces the cost of power production. Pumped storage provides dependable capacity, peaking, and shoulder energy production and dynamic benefits to electric utility system. Technology advances have improved the cycle efficiency, turn-around, and regulation capability. The water resource for a pumped storage project can be either natural or artificially stored. A daily to weekly cycle of pumping and generating referred to as pure pumped storage projects is discussed.
Index Keywords: Economics; Electric Utilities; Estimation; Hydroelectric Power; Project Management; Pumped Storage Power Plants; Reservoirs (water); Scheduling; Cost Curves; Estimating Planning Level Costs; Power Production Costs; Pumped Storage Projects; Costs

Authors: Marinov Philip, Pavlov Stefan
Title: Multiple flywheel recuperation system
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Design Engineering Division (Publication) DE
Affiliations: Technical Univ, Sofia, Bulgaria
Authors with affiliations: Marinov, Philip, Technical Univ, Sofia, Bulgaria; Pavlov, Stefan, Technical Univ, Sofia, Bulgaria
Abstract: A multiple flywheel is studied for the purpose of storing and recuperating kinetic energy. The objective of the design of such systems is a maximum storage and recuperation of the stored energy. The dynamical models of the proposed and the conventional system are compared. Coefficients of storing and recuperating efficiency are introduced for demonstrating the advantages of the multiple flywheel system. An optimization is made regarding to maximum recuperating efficiency.
Index Keywords: Energy storage; Mathematical models; Mechanisms; Numerical methods; Optimization; Conventional systemCoefficients of storing; Dynamical models; Flywheel recuperation system; Kinetic energy; Multiple flywheel; Recuperating efficiency; Flywheels

Authors: Claesson Johan, Hellstrom Goran
Title: Conformal flow models for warm and cold storage in aquifers
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Lund, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Claesson, Johan, Univ of Lund, Sweden; Hellstrom, Goran, Univ of Lund, Sweden
Abstract: The paper presents the thermohydraulic models for aquifer thermal energy storage developed by the Lund Group for Ground Heat. The basic assumption is that the aquifer is horizontally homogeneous and that the groundwater flow is two-dimensional without a vertical component. The groundwater flow field is then given by an analytical function, or conformal transformation, which is obtained from the positions of the well, the pumping rates, and the regional flow. The first set of PC models concerns the groundwater flow and the motion of thermal fronts for any set of wells and a regional flow. The flow field, with streamlines and stagnation points, is presented graphically on the screen. The motion of the thermal fronts is determined by particle tracking. These interactive models have proven to be very convenient and useful design tools. The complete three-dimensional thermal process is solved in the second set of PC models. The groundwater flow is again given by the explicit analytical formulas, while the thermal process is solved numerically. The coupled groundwater and the heat flow process in the aquifer is dealt with using a new entropy-conservation technique. The models are carefully documented and available on PC. They have been validated against a few field experiments and they are used extensively for design studies.
Index Keywords: Aquifers; Energy storage; Flow of water; Groundwater; Heat exchangers; Thermodynamic properties; Aquifers thermal Energy storage; Heat storage

Authors: Stewart Jr. W.E., Becker B.R., Cai L., Sohn C.W.
Title: Downward impinging flows for stratified chilled water storage
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Heat Transfer Division, (Publication) HTD
Affiliations: Univ of Missouri Kansas City, Independence, United States
Authors with affiliations: Stewart Jr., W.E., Univ of Missouri Kansas City, Independence, United States; Becker, B.R., Univ of Missouri Kansas City, Independence, United States; Cai, L., Univ of Missouri Kansas City, Independence, United States; Sohn, C.W., Univ of Missouri Kansas City, Independence, United States
Abstract: Downward impinging flows were investigated to determine whether non-isothermal, turbulent jet flows will stratify for chilled water thermal energy storage systems. The impinging jet flows were modeled using a turbulence kinetic energy and turbulence length scale in a stream function and vorticity formulation. Numerical results show that non-isothermal, downwardly impinging flows are primarily forced flow dominated rather than buoyancy dominated. The product of jet Reynolds number and jet width and the ratio of jet height above the wall to jet width determine the range of flows which remain stratified in the non-isothermal flow field.
Index Keywords: Jets; Turbulent flow; Downward impinging flows; Nonisothermal flowfields; Stratified chilled water storage; Flow of water

Authors: Zagrodnik Jeffrey P., Jones Kenneth R.
Title: Nickel hydrogen batteries for terrestrial applications
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Johnson Controls Battery Group Inc, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zagrodnik, Jeffrey P., Johnson Controls Battery Group Inc, United States; Jones, Kenneth R., Johnson Controls Battery Group Inc, United States
Abstract: Nickel-Hydrogen (Ni-H2) batteries have an extensive database of successful operation in aerospace applications requiring long life, no maintenance, and extremely high reliability. In the common pressure vessel (CPV) design configuration, the life cycle cost of the system is actually lower than that of lead acid and other competing battery technologies. This cost advantage can be directly attributed to the long life, exceeding 10,000 deep discharge cycles, and no maintenance capabilities of the CPV Nickel-Hydrogen battery. As a result the CPV has significant market potential in terrestrial applications such as load leveling, remote energy storage, and aircraft starting. A nominal 7 kilowatt-hour photovoltaic energy storage battery continues on test at Johnson Controls following a 2-year demonstration at Sandia National Laboratories (SNL). This battery has completed over 800 cycles to date. It is now delivering almost 10-kWh with no signs of performance degradation. The battery has shown steady performance over a wide range of charge and discharge rates (C/3 to C/20). A pair of 2-kilowatt-hour photovoltaic batteries continues on test at the Florida Solar Energy Center (FSEC). FSEC completed a series of application profile cycles including lighting, vaccine refrigeration and repeater station over the past year with a pair of batteries in a parallel configuration. The tests are now being repeated with the batteries in series. A 20-volt, 55 amp-hour CPV aircraft starting battery is being tested at Wright Patterson Air Force Base (WPAFB). The CPV attributes of high reliability, no maintenance, and direct state-of-charge monitoring from battery pressure make it an excellent candidate for this application.
Index Keywords: Aircraft; Battery performance degradation; Common pressure vessel (CPV) design; CPV aircraft starting battery; CPV-nickel-hydrogen battery; Nickel hydrogen batteries; Electric batteries

Authors: Lund Kurt O.
Title: FFT analysis of sensible-heat solar-dynamic receivers
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Univ of California at San Diego, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lund, Kurt O., Univ of California at San Diego, United States
Abstract: Solar Dynamic receiver designs are investigated and evaluated for possible use with sensible energy storage in single-phase materials. The designs are similar to previous receivers having an axial distribution of concentrated solar input flux, and an axial flow of the working fluid. The objective is to study the feasibility of single-phase designs which have comparable weight and thermal performance to existing two-phase designs. Linearized heat transfer equations are formulated for the storage of sensible heat in the receivers. The periodic input solar flux is represented as the sum of steady and oscillating distributions, which results in steady and oscillating components in the one-dimensional, time-dependent thermal model. The steady component is solved analytically to produce the desired receiver steady outlet gas temperature. For the oscillating components the Fast Fourier Transform algorithm (FFT) is applied, and the resulting one-dimensional equations solved analytically in the transform space. The complex transfer function of the receiver is obtained and evaluated as a filter for the input spectrum. Convolution of the source and the transfer function, and inverse transformation, results in the amplitudes and mode shapes of the oscillating solid and gas temperatures. By adjustment of design parameters, the amplitude of the oscillating component of the outlet gas temperature is limited to an acceptable magnitude. The overall result of the investigation is that sensible-heat receiver designs exist with comparable performance to present state-of-the-art two-phase receivers. As these designs also offer improvements in cost reduction and reliability they warrant further detailed investigation.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Energy conversion; Fast Fourier transforms; Receivers (containers); Solar energy; Space applications; FFT analysis; Sensible energy storage; Sensible heat solar dynamic receivers; Single phase materials; Energy storage

Authors: Schneider Michael G., Brege Mark H., Greenlee William J.
Title: Design of a cavity heat pipe receiver experiment
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Sundstrand Aerospace, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schneider, Michael G., Sundstrand Aerospace, United States; Brege, Mark H., Sundstrand Aerospace, United States; Greenlee, William J., Sundstrand Aerospace, United States
Abstract: A cavity heat pipe experiment has been designed to test the critical issues involved with incorporating thermal energy storage canisters into a heat pipe. The experiment is a replication of the operation of a heat receiver for a Brayton solar dynamic power cycle. The heat receiver is composed of a cylindrical receptor surface and an annular heat pipe with thermal energy storage canisters and gaseous working fluid heat exchanger tubes surrounding it. Hardware for the cavity heat pipe experiment will consist of a sector of the heat pipe, complete with gas tube and thermal energy storage canisters. Thermal cycling tests will be performed on the heat pipe sector to simulate the normal energy charge/discharge cycle of the receiver in a spacecraft application.
Index Keywords: Energy storage; Fluids; Heat exchangers; Heat storage; Receivers (containers); Solar energy; Spacecraft; Tubes (components); Cavity heat pipe receivers; Gaseous working fluids; Heat exchanger tubes; Thermal energy storage canisters; Heat pipes

Authors: Verrier D.C., Donley S.W.
Title: Post storage conditioning of nickel-hydrogen battery cells
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: TRW Space and Technology Group
Authors with affiliations: Verrier, D.C., TRW Space and Technology Group; Donley, S.W., TRW Space and Technology Group
Abstract: Extended room temperature storage of nickel -hydrogen battery cells has resulted in a capacity loss when the cells are initially cycled following the storage period. Because it may be necessary to 'store' nickel -hydrogen batteries for long periods at room temperature (i.e., shipment, installation, etc.), tests were performed to establish the effects on capacity recovery of several post-storage conditioning methods. The tests included two groups of cells; a 60-day storage group and 120-days storage group. Each group comprised three 2-cell packs. The capacity of each cell was measured under the same controlled conditions both prior to storage and after post-storage conditioning. Each 2-cell pack in a group was conditioned differently over a 13-day period following storage. The results attained with the 60-day storage group were essentially confirmed with the 120-day storage group. In addition, Group 1 was subjected to a second 60-day storage period after which the effects of variations of the conditioning methods were evaluated. The paper describes in detail the cell design, the test procedures, and the test results.
Index Keywords: Energy storage; Spacecraft power supplies; Battery testing; Nickel-hydrogen batteries; Secondary batteries

Authors: Ries Douglas M., Kirk James A.
Title: Design and manufacturing for a composite multi-ring flywheel
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: FARE, Inc.
Authors with affiliations: Ries, Douglas M., FARE, Inc.; Kirk, James A., FARE, Inc.
Abstract: This paper outlines a manufacturing analysis of a composite flywheel that can then be manufactured, assembled, balanced, and integrated with a magnetically suspended system test apparatus, for use in an inertial energy storage system. The preferred flywheel geometry was found to be a constant thickness disk with a hole in the center, having an inside to outside diameter ratio of 0.45. On the basis of the detailed stress analysis performed, the usable stored energy density of the interference assembled flywheel is 65 Watt - hour/kg, when operating over a speed range of 37.5% to 75% of maximum speed. The preferred flywheel fabrication method is wet filament winding, with high strength carbon fibers, in an epoxy matrix. These fibers are arranged in the hoop direction. A composite material test program was designed to validate the required performance of the composite material. The methodology used to assemble the flywheel was developed to insure that the proper amounts of interference are achieved. Composite machining methods were defined which will insure that the dimensional accuracy required by the interference assembly method are achieved.
Index Keywords: Carbon fibers; Composite materials; Energy storage; Multiring flywheels; Flywheels

Authors: Adinolfi Maurizio, Ruck Wolfgang
Title: Microbiological and environmental effects of aquifer thermal energy storage
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Universitat of Stuttgart, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Adinolfi, Maurizio, Universitat of Stuttgart, Germany; Ruck, Wolfgang, Universitat of Stuttgart, Germany
Abstract: The storage of thermal energy, either heat or chill, in aquifers or impoundments creates local perturbations of the indigenous microflora and the environmental properties. Within an international working group of the International Energy Agency (IEA Annex Vl) possible environmental impacts of ATES-systems were recognized and investigated. Investigations of storage systems on natural sites, man-made aquifers and large-scale models of impounded aquifers showed changes in microbial populations, but until now no adverse microbiological processes associated with ATES-systems could be documented (Winters, 1992). However, examinations with a model system indicate an increased risk of environmental impact. Therefore, the operation of ATES-systems should be accompanied by chemical and biological investigations.
Index Keywords: Aquifers; Energy storage; Environmental impact; Microbiology; Aquifers thermal Energy storage; Heat storage

Authors: Satyanarayana P., Suresh M.S., Subrahmanyam A., Agrawal B.L.
Title: On orbit performance of IRS1A 40 Ah nickel cadmium batteries
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference

Authors with affiliations: Satyanarayana, P., ISRO, India; Suresh, M.S., ISRO, India; Subrahmanyam, A., ISRO, India; Agrawal, B.L., ISRO, India
Abstract: The first Indian Remote Sensing Satellite IRS 1A was launched on March 17, 1988. The energy storage for this spacecraft was by two 40Ah nickel-cadmium batteries operating between 7% to 8% DOD. The performance of these batteries show marginal degradation over the 3 year mission life.
Index Keywords: Cadmium; Degradation; Nickel; Remote sensing; Satellites; Space applications; Spacecraft; India; On orbit performance; Remote sensing satellites; Electric batteries

Authors: Krause Siegfried
Title: Investigation of a new heat-pipe/latent-heat-storage receiver element for solar dynamic space power systems
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Inst fuer Technische Thermodynamik, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Krause, Siegfried, Inst fuer Technische Thermodynamik, Germany
Abstract: A new latent heat storage technique for space applications developed by the DLR-ITT uses LiF as the storage medium in graphite capsules with internal capillary notches to accomodate the volume change upon melting. The receivers of solar dynamic power systems (SDPS) may contain a large number of heat pipes carrying annular such storage capsules for very effective heat transfer and thermal storage. The thermal behavior of one of these heat-pipe/latent-heat-storage elements was investigated theoretically and shall be verified experimentally, both in a geometrically and energetically 1:1 scale with respect to a 25 kWe SDPS. This paper summarizes the most important theoretical predictions and describes the planned experiment. The theoretical results show that the required heat flows are essentially achievable but subject to variation with the state of charge of the heat storage units. The relevant temperatures vary in a similar manner.
Index Keywords: Energy storage; Heat pipes; Heat storage; Receivers (containers); Space applications; Capillary notches; Graphite capsules; Latent heat storage receivers; Lithium fluoride; Solar dynamic space power systems; Solar power plants

Authors: Gallagher Daniel T., Billerbeck W.J.
Title: System level analysis of spacecraft power systems with PSpice
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: MRJ, Inc, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gallagher, Daniel T., MRJ, Inc, United States; Billerbeck, W.J., MRJ, Inc, United States
Abstract: Computer analyses of satellite power systems have generally been divided into two categories. The first may be referred to as System Level Studies, which generally develop mathematical relationships for the power system components, and which are used for 'high level' examinations such as energy balance analysis and simplified dynamics studies. The second category of analyses is Circuit Level Studies, which develop circuit level models of the power system electronics, and are typically used for studies such as stability analysis, load transient studies and bus impedance characterizations. Unfortunately, the two categories of analyses are generally not integrated. That is, it is not usually possible to begin with a system level model, and develop it into a detailed circuit model for further studies. In the past, software tools that were suitable for system level studies were not convenient or practical for circuit analysis. Conversely, the electronics circuit analysis programs did not have the capabilities needed to characterize the major power generation, energy storage, and regulation blocks of the power system. However, using the MicroSim PSpice circuit simulator, MRJ personnel have successfully integrated these two approaches to power systems analysis. Several examples of its usefulness in modelling power system components will be provided, followed by an illustration of system level dynamics analysis.
Index Keywords: Satellites; Space applications; Spacecraft; Circuit level studies; Computer analysis; Satellite power systems; System level studies; Power plants

Authors: Kane Dan
Title: Federal waste management system. An overview
Affiliations: US Dep of Energy, Washington, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kane, Dan, US Dep of Energy, Washington, United States
Abstract: The Nuclear Waste Policy Act of 1982 (NWPA) recognized the Federal Government's responsibility to provide for the permanent disposal of spent nuclear fuel and high-level radioactive waste in order to protect the public health and safety and the environment. The NWPA charged the Department of Energy (DOE) with responsibility for carrying out the Federal waste policy and created within the DOE the Office of Civilian Radioactive Waste Management (OCRWM). OCRWM's mission is to provide permanent disposal of spent nuclear fuel and high-level radioactive wastes in a manner that protects the health and safety of the public and the workers, and the quality of the environment. In order to carry out its mission, OCRWM is developing a comprehensive waste-management system that includes three major subsystems: a transportation system to safely move the wastes among waste generators and waste subsystems, a Monitored Retrievable Storage (MRS) facility for the temporary storage of a limited quantity of commercial spent nuclear fuel, and a geologic repository for the permanent disposal of spent nuclear fuel and high-level radioactive waste. The target date for spent fuel acceptance at the MRS is January 1998. If the Yucca Mountain is found suitable for development as a repository, the current schedule calls for waste emplacement operations to begin in 2010. The three major subsystems are discussed.
Index Keywords: Nuclear fuel reprocessing; Radioactive waste disposal; Spent fuels; Storage (materials); Federal waste management system; Monitored retrievable storage facilities; Spent nuclear fuel; Waste disposal

Authors: Ashley Christopher R., Hayden Joseph H., Ibrahim Timour H.
Title: Electrical power system for a mobile communications spacecraft
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Hughes Aircraft Co, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ashley, Christopher R., Hughes Aircraft Co, United States; Hayden, Joseph H., Hughes Aircraft Co, United States; Ibrahim, Timour H., Hughes Aircraft Co, United States
Abstract: A regulated high voltage solar array/battery system using large area silicon solar cells and a group of Ni-H energy storage cells meets the requirements of a multikilowatt geosynchronous orbit application. The electrical power bus operates at approximately 50 Vdc, minimizing unbalanced magnetic torques and distribution harness weight. The program design goal of 12 years of operation on station, including up to 2 years of orbital storage, represents a significant extension of total mission life.
Index Keywords: Communication satellites; Electric power systems; Secondary batteries; Silicon solar cells; Solar cell arrays; Geosynchronous orbits; Mobile communication spacecraft; Nickel-hydrogen cells; Solar array/battery systems; Spacecraft power supplies

Authors: Krodkiewski J., Kirk J.A., Zmood R.B., Lashley C.M.
Title: Influence of magnetic bearing operating constraints on rotor-bearing system performance
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Melbourne
Authors with affiliations: Krodkiewski, J., Univ of Melbourne; Kirk, J.A., Univ of Melbourne; Zmood, R.B., Univ of Melbourne; Lashley, C.M., Univ of Melbourne
Abstract: Because of their many advantages non-contact magnetic bearings have been developed over the last 20 years for space-borne applications. In spite of these advantages these bearings have often proved difficult to design when installed in compliant structures due to the complex interaction of the structural resonances on the one hand and the static and dynamic constraints of the bearings actuators and their power amplifiers on the other. In this paper a mathematical model of the magnetic bearing rotor system for a flywheel energy storage system is developed, which takes these factors into account. Using this model it is shown by formulating an optimization problem that the vibrations due to rotor imbalance can be minimized by appropriate choices of the magnetic bearing stiffness and damping coefficients within the range allowed by the system constraints. It is shown that marked performance improvement over the case where the damping and stiffness are held fixed can be obtained by programming these coefficients as a function of speed. A brief discussion of a method of implementing this vibration control scheme is also presented.
Index Keywords: Energy storage; Flywheels; Mathematical models; Matrix algebra; Rotors; Space applications; Vibration control; Flywheel energy storage; Magnetic bearings

Authors: Jollien L., Remonnay S., Miserez F.
Title: Heat storage at SPEOS (swiss ATES pilot plant): chemical and microbiological aspects and problems
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: ICC, South Africa
Authors with affiliations: Jollien, L., ICC, South Africa; Remonnay, S., ICC, South Africa; Miserez, F., ICC, South Africa
Abstract: The Swiss ATES pilot plant, SPEOS, is located in Lausanne near Lake Geneva. The installation consists of a large central well with a network of horizontal drains in each of two successive sandy aquifers. Water goes from one level to the other during the injection and production cycles. Slight changes in the chemistry of the aquifer have been observed, generally with a low impact. Scaling and clogging by calcium carbonate precipitation are the biggest problem. Many experiments have been performed to find a good solution. Different types of heat exchangers have been tested: tubular, plate, and fluidized bed. Several water treatment methods were also investigated: mechanical, electromagnetic conditioning and injection of chemicals. The fluidized bed heat exchanger is currently running in SPEOS. Continuous injection of HCl (hydrochloric acid) was an effective solution for scaling prevention but it resulted in an increase in chloride concentration and in corrosion of the equipment (including stainless steel). Therefore, a better solution must be chosen, possibly without the use of chemicals, which may lead to environmental impacts. Microbiological studies were performed to help understand the behaviour of the aquifer microflora to an increase in temperature and possible other changes provoked by the aquifer's exploitation as a thermal storage. Up to now, the hygienic quality of the water has not been altered. But some potentially pathogen microorganisms like Legionella may represent a biological hazard. Therefore, it is necessary to evaluate disinfection methods.
Index Keywords: Aquifers; Energy storage; Environmental impact; Microbiology; Aquifers thermal Energy storage; Heat storage

Authors: Bisio G.
Title: Energy and exergy analysis of systems for electrical energy production and heating purposes at various temperatures
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Genoa, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Bisio, G., Univ of Genoa, Italy
Abstract: Cogeneration, i.e. the combined production of electrical and thermal power at an energy conversion plant, has received significant attention particularly since the oil crises of the 70s. The idea of cogeneration is attractive due to the very low exergy efficiency of traditional separate heating plants, using every kind of fuel. The aim of this paper is to compare the usual energy analysis with a meaningful exergy analysis of a combined thermal and electrical power plant. The above exergy analysis is also the basis for a proper allotment of costs between electrical and thermal energy at various temperatures. Authors: Chant Verne G., Morofsky Edward
Title: Overview of projects with seasonal storage for cooling from four countries
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Hickling Corp
Authors with affiliations: Chant, Verne G., Hickling Corp; Morofsky, Edward, Hickling Corp
Abstract: This paper presents the results from a review of projects, technologies and applications utilizing seasonal thermal energy storage (STES) primarily for cooling loads. The review covers four countries (Canada, Germany, The Netherlands, Sweden) participating in an IEA R&D collaborative work program. The characteristics of 55 projects are summarized. Projects included in the review include projects with feasibility study only, projects under preparation and completed projects (approximately equal in number in each category). Project load type, system configuration, storage type, size and cost are included. Experience and lessons learned are also summarized. Assessments of the infrastructure in each country to design and implement such projects are given. Market development characteristics are reviewed in terms of legislation and regulations, and other barriers and drivers.
Index Keywords: Aquifers; Energy conversion; Energy storage; Canada; Germany; Netherlands; Seasonal thermal energy storage; Sweden; Heat storage

Authors: Rosen M.A., Hooper F.C.
Title: Exergy analysis of aquifer thermal energy storages
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Ryerson Polytechnical Inst
Authors with affiliations: Rosen, M.A., Ryerson Polytechnical Inst; Hooper, F.C., Ryerson Polytechnical Inst
Abstract: The application of exergy analysis (Second-Law analysis) to aquifer thermal energy storage (ATES) systems is investigated in order to facilitate proper assessments of overall system performances. The investigation involves the creation of an elementary ATES model, and the development of the corresponding expressions for efficiencies and for the quantities of energy and exergy that are injected and recovered. It is demonstrated that ATES performance measures based on exergy often are more useful and meaningful than those based on energy. Exergy efficiencies account for the temperatures associated with energy transfers to and from an ATES, as well as the quantities of energy transferred, and consequently provide a measure of how nearly ATES systems approach ideal thermodynamic performance. Energy efficiencies only account for energy transfer quantities, and thus do not provide a measure of approach to ideal performance. In fact, energy efficiencies are often misleadingly high because some of the energy recovered can be at too low a temperature to be available for a useful purpose. However, it is shown that the use of an appropriate threshold recovery temperature can partially eliminate the inherent misleadingness in ATES energy efficiencies.
Index Keywords: Aquifers; Energy storage; Integral equations; Thermodynamics; Aquifers thermal Energy storage; Heat storage

Authors: Schreiber Jeffrey G., Shaltens Richard K., Beremand Donald G.
Title: Electric and hybrid electric vehicle study utilizing a time-stepping simulation
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: NASA Lewis Research Cent, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schreiber, Jeffrey G., NASA Lewis Research Cent, United States; Shaltens, Richard K., NASA Lewis Research Cent, United States; Beremand, Donald G., NASA Lewis Research Cent, United States
Abstract: Advanced power technologies are being investigated by the Power Technology Division (PTD) of the NASA Lewis Research Center (LeRC). These technologies are varied and the applications are diverse. Among these technologies are batteries, high efficiency induction motors, high frequency electric power distribution, dynamic energy storage, and Stirling cycle machines. While the emphasis of the PTD research is the application of these technologies to fulfill space power requirements, terrestrial applications may also exist. Future regulation of vehicular emission levels has prompted a recent increase in interest in electric and hybrid vehicles. Electric vehicles have been limited in range and performance by the storage capability of currently available batteries. As an alternative, the hybrid vehicle may render a more near term solution to provide an environmentally safe, full performance vehicle. With proper optimization and integration of the subsystems, a hybrid vehicle has the potential for reduced emissions and increased fuel economy, with comparable range and performance relative to the present day automobile. This paper describes a study performed to assess the applicability of NASA's advanced power technologies to electric and hybrid vehicles. In support of this study, a time-stepping computer simulation was developed to model electric and hybrid vehicles operating over the Federal Urban Driving Schedule (FUDS). Variations in vehicle configuration and subsystem specifications are possible. By the nature of a time-stepping simulation, both the energy and power demands of the FUDS are taken into consideration, consequently vehicle economy, range and performance are addressed simultaneously. Features of the LeRC simulation include options to evaluate abrupt power requirements such as 0-30 mph and 0-60 mph acceleration times, and for the user to create, store and edit alternate driving cycles. A description of simulation is presented along with initial results of the study.
Index Keywords: Electric drives; Flywheels; Mathematical models; Drive motor model; Electric link model; Federal urban driving schedule (FUDS); Flywheel unit model; High frequency electric power distribution; Hybrid electric vehicle study; Time-stepping simulation; Vehicles

Authors: Oester Ueli
Title: Refueling right at home
Affiliations: Sulthane Compression Systems
Authors with affiliations: Oester, Ueli, Sulthane Compression Systems
Abstract: The word 'cocooning' originates from the name of the self-protective structure made by the silkworm. It means retreat into safe surroundings, such as one's own home. This word, now popular with Americans, expresses a trend which is recognized in many industrialized countries. The presence of a cocoon signifies peace and protection, comfort and order. Electronics forwards this trend to a great extent; e.g. teleshopping, tele-banking or video (as replacement for visiting the cinema). Fueling stations (Fig. 1), by means of which refueling can take place at home, are completely in line with the idea. The sales figures for a new generation of small fueling stations confirm this.
Index Keywords: Automobile engines; Compressors; Gas fuel storage; Natural gas conditioning; Densified energy; Gas-powered automobiles; Power consumption; Refueling appliances; Energy resources

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Natural Convection in Enclosures - 1992
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Heat Transfer Division, (Publication) HTD
Abstract: This conference proceedings contains 15 papers discussing natural convection within confined spaces. The papers provide a good representation of natural convection topics. Applications considered within these papers include convection and rollover in storage tanks, energy transport between rooms in buildings, kitchen-stove energy diffusion, fire driven flows, and solar systems. Cavity flows remain a benchmark in this field and are represented by four papers in this conference. One of these includes thermocapillary forces. Extensions to the classic Benard problem are studied in two papers. The diffusion and dissipation of a plume perpetrating a stratified, stable is given a new look. Partitioned or multizone enclosures are studied in several papers. Time-dependent and moving boundary conditions are also represented.

Authors: Williams Verle A.
Title: Case study: successful thermal energy storage applications
Source title: Energy Engineering: Journal of the Association of Energy Engineering
Affiliations: Verle A. Williams & Associates, Inc, San Diego, United States
Authors with affiliations: Williams, Verle A., Verle A. Williams & Associates, Inc, San Diego, United States
Abstract: Pomerado Hospital, Poway, CA, was being expanded 42 percent to include a skilled nursing facility (SNF). The original central plant had been designed to accommodate a third 320-ton chiller, associated pumps, a third cooling tower, and a third 65-psig steam boiler. However, the owners asked if it were possible to construct this addition without adding the third set of equipment. That was a possibility because the facilities department had implemented some very effective energy conservation projects. Those in the department were also considering the possible benefits of a Thermal Energy Storage (TES) system. If it proved to be cost-effective for them to install such a system, they believed the time to do it was before or during the construction of the new SNF.
Index Keywords: Cooling systems; Energy conservation; Heat storage; Case study; Chilled water systems; Cooling load; Electric Chillers; Pomerado hospital; Thermal energy storage; Energy storage

Authors: Kimnach Greg L., Baez Anastacio N.
Title: Power system monitoring and source control of the Space Station Freedom DC-power system testbed
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: NASA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kimnach, Greg L., NASA, United States; Baez, Anastacio N., NASA, United States
Abstract: Unlike a terrestrial electric utility which can purchase power from a neighboring utility, the Space Station Freedom (SSF) has strictly limited energy resources; as a result, source control, system monitoring, system protection and load management are essential to the safe and efficient operation of the SSF Electric Power System (EPS). These functions are being evaluated in the DC Power Management and Distribution (PMAD) Testbed which NASA LeRC has developed at the Power System Facility (PSF) located in Cleveland, Ohio. The testbed is an ideal platform to develop, integrate, and verify power system monitoring and control algorithms. State Estimation (SE) is a monitoring tool used extensively in terrestrial electric utilities to ensure safe power system operation. It uses redundant system information to calculate the actual state of the EPS, to isolate faulty sensors, to determine source operating points, to verify faults detected by subsidiary controllers, and to identify high impedance faults. Source control and monitoring safeguard the power generation and storage subsystems and ensure that the power system operates within safe limits while satisfying user demands with minimal interruptions. System monitoring functions, in coordination with hardware implemented schemes, provide for a complete fault protection system. The objective of this paper is to overview the development and integration of the state estimator and the source control algorithms.
Index Keywords: Electric power distribution; Electric power systems; Electric utilities; Test facilities; Testing; DC power systems; Space Station Freedom; Testbeds; Space stations

Authors: Bennett Gary L., Pilcher Carl B., Smith William L.
Title: Projected NASA power requirements for space science and exploration missions
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: NASA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bennett, Gary L., NASA, United States; Pilcher, Carl B., NASA, United States; Smith, William L., NASA, United States
Abstract: NASA's Office of Space Science and Applications has recently completed its long-range strategic plan which describes a number of exciting space science missions into the early 21st century. In parallel, NASA's new Office of Exploration has begun defining in more detail the architectures of the Space Exploration Initiative (SEI) for returning to the Moon and going to Mars. Both the space science missions and the SEI missions are dependent upon power sources and energy storage with strong requirements for reliability, long life, ease of assembly, autonomy, and light weight. This paper reviews the currently planned space science and SEI missions and focuses upon the power requirements with a view toward guiding technology developers and power designers.
Index Keywords: Natural resources exploration; Technological forecasting; Exploration missions; NASA; Space exploration initiative; Space science; Space research

Authors: Somasundaram S., Brown Daryl R., Drost M.Kevin
Title: Cost evaluation of diurnal thermal energy storage for cogeneration applications
Source title: Energy Engineering: Journal of the Association of Energy Engineering
Affiliations: Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, United States
Authors with affiliations: Somasundaram, S., Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, United States; Brown, Daryl R., Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, United States; Drost, M.Kevin, Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, United States
Abstract: Cogeneration is playing an increasing important role in providing energy efficient power generation and thermal energy for space heating and cooling, as well as in industrial process heat applications. The range of applications for cogeneration could be further increased if the generation of electricity could be decoupled from the generation of process heat. Thermal energy storage can decouple power generation from the production of process heat, allowing the production of dispatchable power while fully utilizing the thermal energy available from the prime mover.This paper discusses the relative performance and economic benefits ofincorporating a diurnal thermal energy storage system with a simple gas turbine cogeneration system.

Authors: Murry Robert J., Mitchell Bill F.
Title: Transitioning from mainframe to personal computer based models doesn't have to be painful
Source title: Proceedings, Annual Technical Meeting - Institute of Environmental Sciences
Affiliations: Boeing Petroleum Services
Authors with affiliations: Murry, Robert J., Boeing Petroleum Services; Mitchell, Bill F., Boeing Petroleum Services
Abstract: This paper documents the transition from a mainframe computer based availability model to a Personal Computer based model. Computer models of the Strategic Petroleum Reserve (SPR) sites have been developed and used to predict site availability. These models describe the connectivity of systems that comprise an oil storage site and are used as a tool for predicting mission success. Prior to implementation of the PC based model, all availability calculations were done on the Department of Energy mainframe computer. The cost of evaluating the models was high. Typical problems included difficulty with access time on the mainframe, a difficult programming language, expensive computer time and an inability to reproduce the results consistently. The mainframe model was very rigorous and thorough, but very difficult to use. A move away from mainframe computers to personal computers began on the SPR project in 1986 with the evaluation of several competing software packages designed to compute availability. After a long evaluation process, the program decided upon was the Reliability Block Diagram Analysis (RBDA) program from Science Applications International Corporation, Inc. (SAIC). The advantages of this product over the mainframe were numerous and included lower costs of operation, ease of use and better support. The software was developed for the PC user and included a more friendly user interface that allowed for easier interaction with the integrated software package. Before any applied modeling could be done with the package, it was necessary to verify and validate the evaluation results produced with the software. A simple sample model was created and evaluated using the three methods of analysis available; hand calculations, personal computer and mainframe computer calculation.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Fuel storage; Mathematical models; Personal computers; Reliability; Mainframe computers; Strategic petroleum reserve; Crude petroleum

Authors: Gill S.P., Frye P., Rosemary J.
Title: Laser power beaming systems for lunar surface applications
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Rockwell Int, United States
Authors with affiliations: Gill, S.P., Rockwell Int, United States; Frye, P., Rockwell Int, United States; Rosemary, J., Rockwell Int, United States
Abstract: Future space exploration missions will require new and innovative approaches to supplying electric power. Due to the very high transportation cost associated with the lunar and Mars missions, the mass of these power systems will be a critical factor. Power systems currently being considered for these applications include both nonnuclear and nuclear systems. For lunar applications, the 354-hour-long nighttime presents a formidable challenge to energy storage technology for nonnuclear power systems. Because of their low energy densities, energy storage systems can be prohibitively massive at higher power levels. Consequently, the nonnuclear power systems may be limited to low-power mission applications on the surface of the Moon. Eliminating or greatly reducing the need for energy storage makes these systems competitive with nuclear power systems. A Free Electron Laser (FEL) power system based in lunar orbit was examined for providing power by beaming energy to the lunar surface. The FEL power system was compared with surface-based nuclear and nonnuclear power systems over a range of user power requirements. Preliminary results show the laser power beaming system to be increasingly competitive on a mass basis with the nonnuclear power at power levels above 50 kWe. However, compared with a surface-based nuclear power plant, the laser beaming power system is an unattractive option unless, for some reason, a nuclear plant cannot be situated on the lunar surface.
Index Keywords: Aerospace engineering; Energy storage; Laser beams; Lunar missions; Moon; Planets; Space applications; Free electron laser power systems; Laser power beaming systems; Lunar surface applications; Mars missions; Space exploration missions; Electric power transmission

Authors: Fiorino Donald P.
Title: Thermal energy storage program for the 1990s
Source title: Energy Engineering: Journal of the Association of Energy Engineering
Affiliations: Texas Instruments, Inc, Dallas, United States
Authors with affiliations: Fiorino, Donald P., Texas Instruments, Inc, Dallas, United States
Abstract: Texas Instruments has chilled water thermal energy storage systems in operation at two of its major defence electronics manufacturing facilities in North Texas. This paper covers the objectives, strategy, method, design, operation, schedule, cost, return, and performance of the first system within the context of the energy cost outlook in North Texas as well as existing conditions at the retrofitted facility. The improvements in the operation of the first system as well as the advancements in design of the second system are also covered.
Index Keywords: Cooling systems; Costs; Economics; Heat storage; Performance; Chilled water storage system; Energy costs; Texas Instruments; Thermal energy storage; Energy storage

Abstract: The proceedings contains 56 papers. The topics discussed are: aquifer thermal storage; energy storage technology and magnetic bearing applications; new technologies for energy utilization; superconductivity; thermal storage; nuclear fission and fusion power; thermal management of energy systems; marine energy; new technologies for energy utilization; advanced and innovative concepts; and alternative fuels.
