Authors: Recupero V., Alderucci V., Di Leonardo R., Lagana M., Maggio G., Giordano N.
Title: Performance evaluation of 1kW phosphoric fuel cell
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Natl Council of Research Inst
Authors with affiliations: Recupero, V., Natl Council of Research Inst; Alderucci, V., Natl Council of Research Inst; Di Leonardo, R., Natl Council of Research Inst; Lagana, M., Natl Council of Research Inst; Maggio, G., Natl Council of Research Inst; Giordano, N., Natl Council of Research Inst
Abstract: Phosphoric acid fuel cell PAFC prototype of 1 kW, integrated by a methanol reforming unit, has been designed and developed at CNR (National Research Council) Institute for Transformation and Storage of Energy, Messina, Italy, ('Progetto Volta', Enea contract) on the basis of the development of proprietary component materials (catalyst, electrodes and matrix). The 1 kW stack is provided with process and cooling plates of proprietary design and construction; internal gas collectors for the working gases in order to have a more compact system and to simplify the gas sealing; an original electrolyte replenishment system. With regard to the projected goals (to determine the optimal working conditions of the system: temperature, pressure, utilization of the alimentation gas, start-up and shut- down procedure, etc.), this paper describes the technical features regarding the engineering design and, particularly, the results of our investigations on the stack performance, the air cooling and the acid replenishment systems efficiencies. The results provided useful information in relation with material and stack design improvements.
Index Keywords: Methanol; Phosphoric acid; Acid replenishment system efficiencies; Methanol reforming unit; Phosphoric acid fuel cell (PAFC); Stack design improvements; Fuel cells

Authors: Kmita J.
Title: Measurement of dynamic pressures in silos during emptying
Source title: National Conference Publication - Institution of Engineers, Australia
Affiliations: Swinburne Inst of Technology
Authors with affiliations: Kmita, J., Swinburne Inst of Technology
Abstract: This paper presents a method for examining dynamic pressures in silos during emptying. The method is based on the examination of the energy balance of self-induced vibration in a silo and takes into account the interaction between the granular material and the silo structure. The method requires the simultaneous measurement of both normal pressure and shear stress on the silo wall as well as normal and tangential vibrations at the point of pressure measurement. The criteria for selection of recorded data are given, together with their analyses and interpretation.
Index Keywords: Data reduction; Dynamic response; Granular materials; Materials handling equipment; Shear stress; Silos (agricultural); Storage (materials); Structural analysis; Unloading; Vibrations (mechanical); Dynamic pressures; Normal vibrations; Self induced vibration; Tangential vibrations; Pressure measurement

Authors: Miaoulis Ioannis N., Thompson Christopher S., Kwak Sehoon
Title: Thermal energy storage with reversible hydration of lithium bromide
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Heat Transfer Division, (Publication) HTD
Affiliations: Tufts Univ, Medford, United States
Authors with affiliations: Miaoulis, Ioannis N., Tufts Univ, Medford, United States; Thompson, Christopher S., Tufts Univ, Medford, United States; Kwak, Sehoon, Tufts Univ, Medford, United States
Abstract: The feasibility of storing thermal energy in Lithium Bromide (LiBr) and recovering it by direct hydration of the material was examined experimentally. The energy storage density for LiBr in various ethyl alcohol solutions was determined for a range of heat storage and recovery conditions. The solubility of LiBr was identified for a variety of ethyl alcohol/water solutions in order to determine the optimum ratio of solvent to solute and maximize the heat output during hydration in a thermal storage system. Breakdown temperature conditions for the LiBr, and compatible materials for heat exchanger design, were determined. Results presented can be used for development of thermal energy storage and recovery systems that require no insulation.
Index Keywords: Design; Heat exchangers; Lithium compounds; Catalytic converter preheater; Heat exchanger design; Lithium bromide reversible hydration; Thermal energy storage; Energy storage

Authors: Stovall T.K., Tomlinson J.J.
Title: What are the potential benefits of including latent storage in common wallboard?
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Oak Ridge Natl Lab
Authors with affiliations: Stovall, T.K., Oak Ridge Natl Lab; Tomlinson, J.J., Oak Ridge Natl Lab
Abstract: Previous work has shown that wallboard can be successfully manufactured to contain up to 30% phase change material (PCM), or wax, thus enabling this common building material to serve as a thermal energy storage device. This material was analyzed for passive solar applications and found to save energy with a reasonable pay-back time period. Further evaluations of the wallboard are reported in this paper. This analysis looks at potential applications of PCM wallboard as a load management device and as a comfort enhancer. Results show that the wallboard is ineffective in modifying the comfort level but can provide significant load management relief with no energy penalty. Modifications to typical heating and air-conditioner control strategies were necessary for successful load management.
Index Keywords: Buildings; Integral equations; Paraffin waxes; Phase transitions; Phase change materials; Wall boards; Heat storage

Authors: Tanaka T., Miyoshi A., Tada T., Yano Y., Iguchi Y., Furuta S., Hirabayashi T.
Title: 1000 kW sodium-sulfur battery pilot plant: its operation experience at tatsumi test facility
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Kansai Electric Power Co Inc, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Tanaka, T., Kansai Electric Power Co Inc, Japan; Miyoshi, A., Kansai Electric Power Co Inc, Japan; Tada, T., Kansai Electric Power Co Inc, Japan; Yano, Y., Kansai Electric Power Co Inc, Japan; Iguchi, Y., Kansai Electric Power Co Inc, Japan; Furuta, S., Kansai Electric Power Co Inc, Japan; Hirabayashi, T., Kansai Electric Power Co Inc, Japan
Abstract: Since 1978, the Agency of Industrial Science and Technology (AIST) of MITI has promoted research and development of 'Large-Scale Energy Conservation Technology' popularly known as the 'Moonlight Project'. As the first step, 'system technology tests' using improved lead acid batteries started at Kansai Electric's Tatsumi Electric Energy Storage System Test Plant on October 1, 1986. The results showed that this system can work not only as a load-leveling apparatus but also as a high-quality power source which can support the utility power system with its load frequency control and voltage regulation capabilities. As the second step of these R&D activities, a 1MW/8MWh sodium-sulfur battery pilot plant was constructed at the same Tatsumi site. On July 11, 1991, 1000 kW× 8H facility, the largest of its type in the world, was completed and started operation. This paper describes the construction experience and operation results of the pilot plant.
Index Keywords: Technology; Energy efficiency tests; Large scale energy conservation technology; Moonlight project; One thousand kilowatt power plant; Sodium sulfur battery pilot plant; System technology tests; Electric batteries

Authors: Koch Michael, Ruck Wolfgang
Title: Injection of CO2 for the inhibition of scaling in ATES systems
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Universitat of Stuttgart, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Koch, Michael, Universitat of Stuttgart, Germany; Ruck, Wolfgang, Universitat of Stuttgart, Germany
Abstract: A new water treatment method for the prevention of carbonate scaling is described. This method uses carbon dioxide for adjusting the water to fulfill Tillmans Equilibrium. The pH is lowered and therefore no scaling occurs. The experimental plant used in the experiments is sketched and results of a field test in a Swiss ATES system are presented. This water treatment method proved to be economical, effective and environmentally beneficial.
Index Keywords: Aquifers; Carbon dioxide; Energy storage; Environmental impact; Water treatment; Aquifers thermal Energy storage; Carbonate scaling; Heat storage

Authors: Marseille Thomas J., Wilke Douglas A.
Title: Review of the aquifer seasonal thermal energy storage building HVAC system at the Melville, New York, Mid-Island mail facility
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Pacific Northwest Lab
Authors with affiliations: Marseille, Thomas J., Pacific Northwest Lab; Wilke, Douglas A., Pacific Northwest Lab
Abstract: The successful widespread commercialization of aquifer thermal energy storage (ATES) in the United States will depend on the effectiveness with which the experiences gained from early full-scale systems are used as guides in the design, installation and operation of future projects. One such early system from which both anecdotal and quantitative information is available is the Mid-Island Postal Facility in Melville, New York. At this facility, built in the mid-1980's, and ATES system has been integrated with the building's central heating and cooling plant. 'Cold' wells are charged with water that is cooled during the winter by heat pump and closed circuit cooler operation. Water from these cold wells is then used to meet the facility's cooling load during the summer, before being pumped back into the ground at 'Warm' wells. Dehumidification during summer operation is accomplished by a liquid desiccant system that uses propane boilers to provide a heat source for desiccant regeneration. This system will also add water to the air during periods of low humidity. This paper provides an overview of the project, and describes the analysis being performed to assess energy and economic merits of this innovative system.
Index Keywords: Aquifers; Energy storage; Heat pump systems; Aquifers thermal Energy storage; HVAC systems; Heat storage

Authors: Locker James R., Geers Stephens
Title: High temperature superconducting impulse generator
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: IAP Research, Inc
Authors with affiliations: Locker, James R., IAP Research, Inc; Geers, Stephens, IAP Research, Inc
Abstract: A mechanism based upon the Superconducting Vector Switch (SVS) effect displays the property of impulse generation. The principle of operation of this impulse generator is discussed. Experimental results and analytical predictions are presented.
Index Keywords: Electric switches; Energy storage; thin films; Impulse generators; Superconducting vector switches; High temperature superconductors

Authors: Johnson Ryan G., Pang Da-Chen, Kirk James A., Anand Davinder K.
Title: Computer-aided modelling and analysis of a magnetic bearing system
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: U.S. Navy
Authors with affiliations: Johnson, Ryan G., U.S. Navy; Pang, Da-Chen, U.S. Navy; Kirk, James A., U.S. Navy; Anand, Davinder K., U.S. Navy
Abstract: AMBER (Active Magnetic Bearing Evaluation Routine) is a computer algorithm developed for the University of Maryland pancake magnetic bearing, which supports and controls a flywheel in a kinetic energy storage system. Because of the gap growth due to centrifugal forces at high speed, the bearing axial load capability degrades and the axial characteristics become critical in the bearing design. AMBER applies magnetic circuit theory, magnetic material saturation curves, coenergy theory, and finite permeance-based elements to solve the air gap flux density and coenergy over a series of incremental axial displacements. Differentiation of the coenergy of the magnetic field yields axial force and stiffness characteristics. An axial test machine is constructed to conduct experiments to verify the flux distribution and axial forces predicted by the model. User interaction with AMBER allows modification of the bearing geometry and composition to optimize future prototypes. NOMENCLATURE B: Flux Density Kz: Axial Stiffness R: Reluctance of Flux Paths vol: Volume of Air Gap W'fld: Coenergy of Magnetic Field φ: Magnetic Flux μ: Permeability
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Computer aided analysis; Computer simulation; Energy storage; Flywheels; Software package AMBER; Magnetic bearings

Authors: Kumar B.
Title: Magnetic energy storage devices for small scale applications
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Dayton, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kumar, B., Univ of Dayton, United States
Abstract: Power sources based on magnetic energy derived from superconductivity have been considered for commercial utility power, air and ground mobile power uses, and spacecraft applications. The advent of high temperature superconductors has reduced one of the penalties of superconducting magnetic energy storage in that the refrigeration and cryocontainers become greatly simplified. Still, structural and current density issues that limit the energy density and size of the superconducting inductors do not change. This paper covers basic principles of magnetic energy storage, structure requirements and limitations, configurations of inductors, attributes of high-Tc superconducting materials including thermal instabilities, a relative comparison with the state-of-the-art high energy density power sources, and refrigeration requirements. Based on these fundamental considerations, the design parameters of a micro superconducting magnetic energy unit for Air Force applications is presented and discussed.
Index Keywords: Energy storage; Magnetic fields; Military engineering; Refrigeration; Air force; Magnetic energy storage; High temperature superconductors

Authors: Lin Cheng-Hsiung, Cheng Ya-Tang, Liu Jih-Phong, Tseng Ming-Tzong
Title: 25 kJ superconducting magnetic energy storage system
Source title: Proceedings, Annual Technical Meeting - Institute of Environmental Sciences
Affiliations: Natl Tsing Hua Univ, Hsinchu, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Lin, Cheng-Hsiung, Natl Tsing Hua Univ, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Cheng, Ya-Tang, Natl Tsing Hua Univ, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Liu, Jih-Phong, Natl Tsing Hua Univ, Hsinchu, Taiwan; Tseng, Ming-Tzong, Natl Tsing Hua Univ, Hsinchu, Taiwan
Abstract: A 25 kJ superconducting magnetic energy storage system(SMES) was designed, constructed, and tested. The SMES system contains a solenoid, thermal switch, thermal insulation containers, and charge/discharge devices. The solenoid where the current flows permanently was wound with 1 mm Nb-Ti superconducting wire for 1600 turns in 8 layers and operated 400 A. The height and diameter of the solenoid are 200 mm. The calculation results of the magnetic fields and mechanical stress show that the maximum field is 2.97 T and the maximum stresses is 6.25×107 N/m2. The solenoid was at a stable superconducting state and within safe mechanical stress range because its operating current 400 A was only 37% of its critical current at 3 T and its maximum mechanical stress was only 41.7% of yield strength.
Index Keywords: Electric energy storage; Magnetic fields; Mathematical models; Solenoids; Magnetic stress; Superconducting magnetic energy storage; Superconducting solenoids; Superconducting devices

Authors: Midkiff K.C., Brett C.E., Balaji K., Song Y.K.
Title: Long-term performance of an air-conditioning system based on seasonal aquifer chill energy storage
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Alabama, United States
Authors with affiliations: Midkiff, K.C., Univ of Alabama, United States; Brett, C.E., Univ of Alabama, United States; Balaji, K., Univ of Alabama, United States; Song, Y.K., Univ of Alabama, United States
Abstract: A nominal 520 kW (thermal) air-conditioning system based on the seasonal storage of cold water in an aquifer has cooled a University of Alabama building since 1983. During cold weather, ambient, 18° C water is pumped from warm supply wells, chilled to about 6° C in a cooling tower, and reinjected into separate cold storage wells. In warm weather, water is withdrawn from the cold wells and pumped through building heat exchangers for air conditioning. Presented here are results of 6 years of study [sponsored by the U.S. Department of Energy through Pacific Northwest Laboratory] of the first successful U.S. application of this technology. This system yields high energy efficiency, with measured annual average COP of about 5 (SEER = Btu/Wh), and energy recovery efficiency ranging from 40 to 85%, shifts utility loads from summer to winter, and no chlorofluorocarbon (CFC) release.
Index Keywords: Aquifers; Climatology; Energy storage; Chlorofluorocarbon; Seasonal aquifer chill; Air conditioning

Authors: Vetsch Rolf
Title: Gas supply continuity guaranteed
Affiliations: Sulzer-Escher
Authors with affiliations: Vetsch, Rolf, Sulzer-Escher
Abstract: The supply of natural gas has to be available to the consumer at all times without interruption. Widely varying consumption, dependent on the time of day, day of the week and season has to be reconciled with the uniform quantity flowing from the sources. The balance has to be created by buffer stocks. One possibility is the leaching of caverns in large salt deposits. The natural gas can be stored in such caverns at a pressure of up to 220 bar. At Etzel, between Emden (Fig. 1) and Wilhelmshafen in north-east Friesland (Germany), Statoil, the Norwegian state oil company, as operator, has set up such an underground gas storage facility with a capacity of 500 million cubic metres. Sulzer-Escher Wyss, Zurich, received the contract to supply an injection compressor station equipped with two gas turbine driven radial compressors for this storage facility.
Index Keywords: Gas fuel storage; Natural gas deposits; Natural gas pipelines; Natural gas transportation; Norvegian gas fields; Steady supply; Storage caverns; Underground storage; Energy resources

Authors: Burrows Linda M., Hansen Irving G.
Title: Electromechanical systems with transient high power response operating from a resonant AC link
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: NASA Lewis Research Cent
Authors with affiliations: Burrows, Linda M., NASA Lewis Research Cent; Hansen, Irving G., NASA Lewis Research Cent
Abstract: The combination of an inherently robust asynchronous (induction) electrical machine with the rapid control of energy provided by a high frequency resonant ac link enables the efficient management of higher power levels with greater versatility. This could have a variety of applications from launch vehicles to all-electric automobiles. These types of systems utilize a machine which is operated by independent control of both the voltage and frequency. This is made possible by using an indirect field-oriented control method which allows instantaneous torque control in all four operating quadrants. Incorporating the ac link allows the converter in these systems to switch at the zero crossing of every half cycle of the ac waveform. This 'zero loss' switching of the link allows rapid energy variations to be achieved without the usual frequency proportional switching loss. Several field-oriented control systems have been developed by NASA Lewis and General Dynamics Space Systems Division under contract to NASA. This paper will begin with a description of a single motor, electromechanical actuation system and then focus on a conceptual design for an AC electric vehicle. This design will incorporate an induction motor/generator together with a flywheel for peak energy storage. System operation and implications along with the associated circuitry will be addressed. Such a system would greatly improve all-electric vehicle ranges over the Federal Urban Driving Cycle (FUD).
Index Keywords: Control systems; Electric generators; Electric vehicles; Induction motors; AC links; All-electric vehicles; Resonant AC links; Electromechanical devices

Authors: Young Karl S.
Title: Fast uninterruptable power supplies using hydrogen fuel cells
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Yung Technologies Intl Inc
Authors with affiliations: Young, Karl S., Yung Technologies Intl Inc
Abstract: Laboratory tests show that the proton exchange membrane (PEM) fuel cell can be a fast-response power source able to produce full power in less than 200 μs. For every standard cubic foot (28.3 liter) of hydrogen, approximately 45 Whrs of electrical energy can be produced from a PEM fuel cell. A 100 kW PEM fuel cell would weigh approximately 300 lbs (136 kg) at the current level of material technology. Since the fuel cell can operate for many years continuously, the duration of power sustainment depends upon the quantity of stored reactants. Using hydrogen and oxygen, a PEM fuel cell results in one of the highest energy density power devices for the UPS application. Hydrogen storage methods discussed include gas, liquid, metal hydride, and carbon adsorption.
Index Keywords: Fast uniterruptable power supplies; Fuel cell pulse; Hydrogen fuel cells; Hydrogen storage methods; Proton exchange membrane (PEM) fuel cells; Fuel cells

Authors: Hahne E., Hornberger M.
Title: Experience with a solar heating ATES system for a university building
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Universitat of Stuttgart, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Hahne, E., Universitat of Stuttgart, Germany; Hornberger, M., Universitat of Stuttgart, Germany
Abstract: At Stuttgart University, a solar heating system for an office building with laboratories and lecture rooms was installed in 1985. The heating system consists of 211 m2 of unglazed solar collectors, a 1050 m3 water-flooded pebble bed heat store, and a heat pump. This installation is a pilot facility and is included in the activities of the International Energy Agency (IEA). The experimental heat storage contains all heat exchanger systems that are used for ground stores: direct water exchange and a 4853 m long tube for heat exchange. Heat can be supplied to the store from the solar collectors or from a power station (as waste heat). The store and its behaviour are described. The whole system has worked successfully for 5 years under varied strategies. In the first two heating periods, the heating strategy was aimed to collect as much solar energy as possible. Thus, about 60% of the heat demand could be covered by solar energy; but the yearly heat pump coefficient-of-performance (C.O.P.) was only around 2.76. With an improved heat pump, which was installed during the last 2 months of the second heating cycle, a monthly C.O.P. of 3.6 was obtained. Heat losses from the storage amounted to about 20%.
Index Keywords: Aquifers; Energy storage; Solar ponds; Aquifers thermal Energy storage; Solar heating

Authors: van der Heide K., van Loon L.J.M.
Title: High-temperature ATES at the university of Utrecht, the Netherlands
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Heidemij Consultants
Authors with affiliations: van der Heide, K., Heidemij Consultants; van Loon, L.J.M., Heidemij Consultants
Abstract: A long-term thermal energy storage system has been implemented at the University of Utrecht campus in the Netherlands. The project will extend co-generation operation into the summer beyond heat demand periods, resulting in increased electricity generation. The stored heat (90 °C ) is used in winter for space heating of several university buildings. In this demonstration project experience is being gained, among others, with groundwater treatment and flow-rate control in an aquifer thermal energy plant. The storage system has been in full operation since May 13, 1991. In this paper a short review is presented of the technical problems that were met during the design stage and one year of operation. The general conclusion is that during the first operational period too much water had been treated so that there was a risk of clay-swelling. This problem was caused by a technical failure of the spit-control for water treatment. Since the control system has been altered the high temperature ATES has been functioning perfectly.
Index Keywords: Aquifers; Energy storage; Groundwater; Aquifers thermal Energy storage; Netherlands; Heat storage

Authors: Hall Stephen H., Raymond John R.
Title: Geohydrologic characterization for aquifer thermal energy storage
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Pacific Northwest Lab
Authors with affiliations: Hall, Stephen H., Pacific Northwest Lab; Raymond, John R., Pacific Northwest Lab
Abstract: Successful operation of an aquifer thermal energy storage system depends on three elements: 1) the presence of a suitable aquifer for ground-water supply and energy storage; 2) the availability of a source of free or low-cost thermal energy, such as industrial waste heat or environmental chill; and 3) a temporal mismatch between thermal energy availability and thermal energy use. Using conventional hydrogeologic methods for aquifer characterization, the presence of a suitable aquifer is the most difficult of these three elements to assess quantitatively. By combining conventional methods with drift-and-pumpback and point-dilution single-well tracer tests, however, the rate of ground-water flow, the effective porosity, and the vertical distribution of hydraulic conductivity of the aquifer can be estimated quickly and economically.
Index Keywords: Aquifers; Energy storage; Geology; Groundwater; Hydrology; Aquifers thermal Energy storage; Geohydrology; Heat storage

Authors: Sibbald C.L., Stuchly S.S.
Title: A new aperture admittance model for open-ended waveguides
Source title: IEEE MTT-S International Microwave Symposium Digest
Affiliations: Dept of Electr Eng, Univ of Ottawa,, Ont, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Sibbald, C.L., Dept of Electr Eng, Univ of Ottawa,, Ont, Canada; Stuchly, S.S., Dept of Electr Eng, Univ of Ottawa,, Ont, Canada
Abstract: A novel model for the aperture admittance of open-ended waveguide structures radiating into a homogeneous, lossy dielectric is presented. The model is based on the physical and mathematical properties of the driving point admittance of passive, stable one-port networks. The model parameters, which depend on the geometry of the waveguide and aperture, are determined from a relatively small number of computed admittances. These computed data are obtained by a full-wave moment method solution and, hence, include the effects of radiation and energy storage in the near-field and the evanescent waveguide modes. The accuracy of the model, for both the direct and the inverse problem, is verified. The proposed model has important applications in the field of dielectric spectroscopy.
Index Keywords: Dielectric properties of solids; Electric impedance; Guided electromagnetic wave propagation; Waveguides; Aperture admittance model; Lossy dielectrics; Open ended waveguides; Microwave measurement

Authors: Kramer William E., Winn C.Byron
Title: Optimized control of a solar powered vehicle with control constraints
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Colorado State Univ, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kramer, William E., Colorado State Univ, United States; Winn, C.Byron, Colorado State Univ, United States
Abstract: An optimal control strategy is determined for a solar powered vehicle which requires that the time to reach its final destination be minimized while maximizing the energy remaining in the batteries. A vehicle which travels a straight line path from point A to point B where there are no hills, and the incident solar radiation is constant is considered.
Index Keywords: Optimal control systems; Solar radiation; Storage battery vehicles; Control constraints; Incident solar radiation; Solar powered vehicles; Solar energy

Authors: Richter Scott W.
Title: Experimental determination of in situ utilization of lunar regolith for thermal energy storage
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Sverdrup Technology
Authors with affiliations: Richter, Scott W., Sverdrup Technology
Abstract: A Lunar Thermal Energy from Regolith (LUTHER) experimental has been designed and fabricated at the NASA Lewis Research Center to determine the feasibility of using lunar soil as thermal energy storage media. The experimental apparatus includes an alumina ceramic canister (10 in. diameter by 18 in. length) which contains simulated lunar regolith, a heater (either radiative or conductive), 9 heat shields, a heat transfer cold jacket, and 19 type B platinum rhodium thermocouples. The simulated lunar regolith is a basalt, mined and processed by the University of Minnesota, that closely resembles the lunar basalt returned to earth by the Apollo missions. The experiment will test the effects of vacuum, particle size, and density on the thermophysical properties of the regolith. The properties include melt temperature (range), specific heat, thermal conductivity, and latent heat of storage. Two separates tests, using two different heaters, will be performed to study the effect of heating the system using radiative, and conductive heat transfer. The physical characteristics of the melt pattern, material compatibility of the molten regolith, and the volatile gas emission will be investigated by heating a portion of the lunar regolith to its melting temperature (1162 °C) in a 10-6 torr vacuum chamber, equipped with a gas spectrum analyzer. A finite differencing SINDA model was developed at NASA Lewis to predict the performance of the LUTHER experiment. The analytical results of the code will be compared with the experimental data generated by the LUTHER experiment. The code will predict the effects vacuum, particle size, and density has on the heat transfer of the simulated regolith.
Index Keywords: Energy storage; Heat storage; Heat transfer; Space research; Thermocouples; Lunar Regolith; LUTHER experiment; Lunar surface analysis

Authors: Thakar Girish S.
Title: HVAC retrofit opportunities with thermal storage and cold air distribution system
Source title: Energy Engineering: Journal of the Association of Energy Engineering
Affiliations: H.F. Lenz Co, United States
Authors with affiliations: Thakar, Girish S., H.F. Lenz Co, United States
Abstract: In recent years thermal storage systems have gained wide popularity because of their ability to shift significant amounts of electrical demand from peak to off-peak periods, thereby reducing the energy costs associated with operating chilled water systems. This article addresses issues with thermal storage and cold air distribution systems as compared to conventional HVAC systems on retrofit projects.
Index Keywords: Air conditioning; Cooling systems; Costs; Economics; Heat storage; Maintenance; Advantages; Cold air distribution; Disadvantages; HVAC systems; Thermal energy storage; Energy storage

Authors: Bents D.J., Knight D.A.
Title: Optimization of armored spherical tanks for storage on the lunar surface
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: NASA Lewis Research Cent, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bents, D.J., NASA Lewis Research Cent, United States; Knight, D.A., NASA Lewis Research Cent, United States
Abstract: A redundancy strategy for reducing micrometeroid armoring mass is investigated, with application to cryogenic reactant storage for a regenerative fuel cell (RFC) on the lunar surface. In that micrometeoroid environment, the cryogenic fuel must be protected from loss due to tank puncture. The tankage must have a sufficiently high probability of survival over the length of the mission that the probability of system failure due to tank puncture is low compared to the other mission risk factors. Assuming that a single meteoroid penetration can cause a storage tank to lose its contents, two means are available to raise the probability of surviving micrometeoroid attack to the desired level. One can armor the tanks to a thickness sufficient to reduce probability of penetration of any tank to the desired level; or add extra capacity, in the form of spare tanks, that results in survival of a given number out of the ensemble at the desired level. In this paper a combination of these strategies (armoring and redundancy) is investigated. The objective is to find the optimum combination which yields the lowest shielding mass per cubic meter of surviving fuel out of the original ensemble. The investigation found that, for the volumes of fuel associated with multikilowatt class cryo storage RFC's and the armoring methodology and meteoroid models used, storage should be fragmented into small individual tanks. Larger installations (more fuel) pay less of a shielding penalty than small installations. For the same survival probability over the same time period, larger volumes will require less armoring mass per unit volume protected.
Index Keywords: Cryogenics; Energy storage; Fuel cells; Meteor impacts; Tanks (containers); Armored spherical tanks; Micrometeroid armoring mass; Lunar surface analysis

Authors: Makita Toshiaki, Aoshima Teruo
Title: Construction of underground rock cavern for Kuji oil storage base
Affiliations: Japan Underground Oil Storage Co Ltd, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Makita, Toshiaki, Japan Underground Oil Storage Co Ltd, Japan; Aoshima, Teruo, Japan Underground Oil Storage Co Ltd, Japan
Abstract: To cope with instability of the oil market in the outside world, Japan has been working to reduce the ratio shared by oil in total energy usage through diversification of energy resources, while at the same time developing and introducing energy-saving technology. The government, meanwhile in amending the `Japan National Oil Corporation Law' in June 1978, decided to construct national storage bases for crude oil, totaling 30 million KL, by the end of fiscal 1988. These facilities were to be built by the Japan National Oil Corporation. To date, 10 sites for this National Storage Base have been selected throughout Japan, and three of the bases have already been completed. The remains are now under construction. The aim of 30 million KL of storage was achieved by the end of fiscal 1988. As to the future of oil storage, expansion of storage is still in progress with a target of 50 million KL (approximately 90 days' supply) by the middle of the 1990s. The following storage systems have been adopted in Japan: (1) Above ground steel tanks, (2) reinforced concrete in-ground tanks, (3) Steel floating storage barges, and (4) Underground storage in unlined rock caverns (this is called `water seal type rock tank' in Japanese).In this paper, the construction of Kuji Underground Oil Storage Base has been described.
Index Keywords: Construction; Storage (materials); Oil storage; Rock tank; Underground rock cavern; Geological repositories

Authors: Hamilton Kenneth
Title: Process design of water for injection systems: a hydrodynamic analysis
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Bioengineering Division (Publication) BED
Affiliations: Molecular Biosystems, Inc, San Diego, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hamilton, Kenneth, Molecular Biosystems, Inc, San Diego, United States
Abstract: a computer-based model has been developed to optimize the design of WFI systems. It determines the optimum recirculation rate, pump and heat exchanger size, capacity of the WFI storage tank and loop hydrodynamics; pressure losses due to valves, fittings and instruments are determined for any number of users and length of WFI pipework. This approach has been used for the design of WFI systems. It is a systematic approach, leading to improved designs. The model combines a steady-state analysis of the hydrodynamics of the recirculation loop, setting up a momentum balance and determining the wall shear rate, with an energy balance between heat generated by pumping and convective and radiant losses. The series of implicit equations are solved in a stepwise fashion each using the Newton-Raphson method. The algorithm iterates until an acceptable velocity and pipe diameter are obtained. The Graetz number is determined to select the suitable expression for convective heat transfer. The process design is completed by calculations to size the recirculation pump, heat exchanger and pressure losses through the system. Simulations are given for a variety of designs.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Computer simulation; Heat exchangers; Hydrodynamics; Pipe; Pumps; Abstract only; Graetz number; Newton-Raphson method; Water for injection systems; Biotechnology

Authors: Meier Christian, Steinbach Johane
Title: Optimal use of renewable energy
Affiliations: Sulzer Esellen Wyss, Winterthur, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Meier, Christian, Sulzer Esellen Wyss, Winterthur, Switzerland; Steinbach, Johane, Sulzer Esellen Wyss, Winterthur, Switzerland
Abstract: Integral water husbandry is a concept for managing several storage spaces in a region. The object is to maximize the overall yieldby optimizing the energy production within the ecological and hydrological constraints. Today, most operators of the hydroelectric power schemes employ microprocessor-assisted control, yet very few of the computers used for this purpose pass their calculation results straight on to the machines. New concepts and technologies are opening up new possibilities.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Hydroelectric power plants; Monitoring; Pumped storage power plants; River basin projects; Water power; Headwater; Hydraulic systems; Optimal exploitation; Renewable energy resources

Authors: Hussain M.A., Peters D.C.J.
Title: Retrofit integration of fire protection storage as chilled-water storage - a case study
Affiliations: Southland Industries, Long Beach, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hussain, M.A., Southland Industries, Long Beach, United States; Peters, D.C.J., Southland Industries, Long Beach, United States
Abstract: An existing fire protection water storage pond was successfully retrofitted as a chilled-water thermal energy storage tank. The pond now serves the dual function of fire protection and chilled-water storage, without adversely impacting either function. As a chilled-water storage tank, the pond is of unusual geometry and was perceived as a major challenge. This paper explains how an experimental model was used to assist the design and compares modeled and field results.
Index Keywords: Fire protection; Heat storage; Chilled water storage; Fire protection water storage; Thermal energy storage tank; Energy storage

Authors: Rosen M.A., Hooper F.C.
Title: Modelling the temperature distribution in vertically stratified thermal energy storages to facilitate energy and exergy evaluation
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Advanced Energy Systems Division (Publication) AES
Affiliations: Ryerson Polytechnical Inst, Toronto, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Rosen, M.A., Ryerson Polytechnical Inst, Toronto, Canada; Hooper, F.C., Ryerson Polytechnical Inst, Toronto, Canada
Abstract: The superiority of exergy methods in evaluating the thermodynamic advantages of thermal storages is in many cases not being utilized because some engineers see the procedures as too complex. This paper is one of a series by the authors directed toward presenting approximations which will reduce the complexity of the analysis while retaining adequate accuracy for most engineering purposes, and hence encourage broader use of these methods. Four models are proposed for the temperature distribution in vertically stratified thermal storages, which facilitate the evaluation of energy and exergy contents of a storage. For each model, expressions for temperature as a function of height are given, and expressions for storage energy and exergy contents are derived. An illustrative example is presented. The reductions in computational effort and of the corresponding losses in precision are discussed.
Index Keywords: Approximation theory; Energy storage; Mathematical models; Temperature distribution; Temperature measurement; Thermal stratification; Thermodynamics; Energy and exergy evaluations; Vertically stratified thermal energy storages; Heat storage

Authors: Adebiyi G.A., Hodge B.K., Steele W.G., Jalalzadeh A., Nsofor E.C.
Title: Computer simulation of a high temperature thermal energy storage system employing multiple families of phase-change storage materials
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Advanced Energy Systems Division (Publication) AES
Affiliations: Mississippi State Univ, United States
Authors with affiliations: Adebiyi, G.A., Mississippi State Univ, United States; Hodge, B.K., Mississippi State Univ, United States; Steele, W.G., Mississippi State Univ, United States; Jalalzadeh, A., Mississippi State Univ, United States; Nsofor, E.C., Mississippi State Univ, United States
Abstract: Previous work by one of the authors entailed modeling of a packed bed thermal energy storage system utilizing phase-change materials (PCM). A principal conclusion reached is that the use of a single family of phase-change storage material may not in fact produce a thermodynamically superior system relative to one utilizing sensible heat storage material. This paper describes the model constructed for the high temperature thermal energy storage system utilizing multiple families of phase-change materials and presents results obtained in the exercise of the model. Other factors investigated include the effect on system performance due to the thermal mass of the containment vessel wall and variable temperature of the flue gas entering the packed bed during the storage process. The preliminary results obtained indicate efficiencies for the system utilizing the five PCM families exceeding those for the single PCM family by as much as 13% to 26%. It was also established that the heat transfer to the containment vessel wall could have a significant detrimental effect on system performance.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Energy storage; Flue gases; Heat storage; Heat transfer; High temperature applications; Mass transfer; Mathematical models; Phase transitions; Thermodynamics; Walls (structural partitions); High temperature thermal energy storage system; Phase change storage materials; Packed beds

Authors: Stevens J.L., Garg S.K., Luu L., Barker T.G., Pritchett J.W., Truesdell A.H., Quijano Luis
Title: GEOSYS: an X/motif-based system for analysis and management of geothermal data
Affiliations: S-Cubed, La Jolla, United States
Authors with affiliations: Stevens, J.L., S-Cubed, La Jolla, United States; Garg, S.K., S-Cubed, La Jolla, United States; Luu, L., S-Cubed, La Jolla, United States; Barker, T.G., S-Cubed, La Jolla, United States; Pritchett, J.W., S-Cubed, La Jolla, United States; Truesdell, A.H., S-Cubed, La Jolla, United States; Quijano, Luis, S-Cubed, La Jolla, United States
Abstract: The Geothermal Data Management System (GEOSYS) has been developed to allow storage, retrieval, and analysis of the large volume of data associated with a geothermal reservoir, including well drilling data, well log data, production (chemical and flow) data, and geographical data. The system allows the user to display overlays of well locations, faults, and surface features on maps or topographic images. Subsurface cross-sections can be displayed by selecting any two points on the map. Cross sections show subsurface topography together with the projections of wells along the cross section. The structure of each individual well can also be displayed in detail. Downhole well logs can be selected, displayed, and expanded to arbitrary scale. Time histories of production data can be displayed for the field and for each well. Data from the Cerro Prieto geothermal field has been used for development and testing of the system. This type of system has been made possible by recent advances in hardware and software technology, and the dramatic reduction in cost of high speed workstations and disk storage. GEOSYS was developed using the X Window System and the OSF/Motif widget set. The X Window System was designed specifically to provide hardware independence for interactive systems based on bitmapped graphics with a Graphical User Interface (GUI). Systems developed using X run on most modern workstations, and can run across a network with the application being resident on only one computer, but accessible to all others.
Index Keywords: Management; Reservoirs (water); Geothermal data management system; Graphical user interface; Geothermal energy

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Ocean Energy Recovery - The State of the Art
Source title: Ocean Energy Recovery - The State of the Art
Abstract: This volume consists of 12 chapters which establish the state of the art in the full range of renewable ocean energy technologies. The topics discussed range from mature technologies such as tidal energy extraction, ocean thermal energy conversion and wave power recovery to conjectural technologies such as salinity gradients. In addition, the economics of the major systems are compared in a uniform manner, making it possible to realistically assess their economic potential. This publication provides a single source of balanced technical and economic assessments of competing technologies and should be of interest to all who are involved in the search for alternative sources of energy. All papers are indexed and abstracted separately.
Index Keywords: Direct energy conversion; Electric power generation; Energy storage; Ocean engineering; Ocean thermal energy conversion; Renewable energy resources; Seawater effects; Tidal power; Wave power; Alternative energy sources; Ocean energy based electric power generation; Ocean energy recovery; Ocean salinity gradients; Tidal energy extraction; Wave power recovery; Water waves

Authors: Zeler Rudolf
Title: Turbine control systems increase efficiency and lower personnel costs
Affiliations: Sulzer Electronics, Winterthur, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Zeler, Rudolf, Sulzer Electronics, Winterthur, Switzerland
Abstract: In spite of changes in the quantity of water available and widely varying consumption of electrical energy, hydro power stations have to operate at high efficiency as well as at constant turbine speed. The control and regulation operations required to achieve these conditions are particularly exacting when power plants work in an interlinked configuration. Modern Sulzer - Escher Wyss digital control systems achieve these conditions reliably and inexpensively. The basis of these control systems is the SICOS 1500 automation system, developed by Sulzer Electronics for Sulzer Corporation internal applications.
Index Keywords: Control systems; Controllability; Efficiency; Hydroelectric power plants; Kaplan turbines; Optimization; Outages; Pumped storage power plants; Reliability; River basin projects; Inlet flow control; Outage location; Potential energy; Runner vanes; Hydraulic turbines

Authors: Dini Said, Saniei Nader
Title: Refrigerant hydrate as a cool storage medium
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Heat Transfer Division, (Publication) HTD
Affiliations: Western New England Coll, Springfield, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dini, Said, Western New England Coll, Springfield, United States; Saniei, Nader, Western New England Coll, Springfield, United States
Abstract: In this study a gas hydrate was formed and was used as a cool storage medium using Freon 11 in water. This gas hydrate phase change material has a freezing temperature of about 47.6°F as compared to 32°F for water. The thermal storage capacity is 120.04 Btu/lb., about 24 Btu/lb. less than that of water-ice (144 Btu/lb.). The experimental system for this investigation consisted of a vertical cylindrical plexiglass vessel with direct contact heat exchanger for both the charge (freeze) and discharge (melt) of the storage media. The charge cycle of the clathrate system reduced the temperature of the clathrate, forcing it to change phase, thus creating the latent storage of the system. Since the clathrate was slightly heavier than water, solid or frozen material was built up from the bottom toward the top of the tank during the charge cycle. Based on the experimental results obtained in this investigation clathrate may be produced on a reliable basis at 47.6°F. This represents significant improvement over lower temperature storage systems such as ice-water with a freezing temperature of 32°F.
Index Keywords: Energy storage; Heat storage; Phase transitions; Refrigerants; Cool storage medium; Gas hydrate phase change material; Gas hydrates

Authors: Dreute J., Heinrich W., Rocher H., Harboe Sorensen R., Adams L., Schardt D., Vetter J.
Title: Investigation of single event effects of high energetic heavy ions
Source title: First European Conference on Radiation and Its Effects on Devices and Systems - RADECS 91
Affiliations: Univ of Siegen, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Dreute, J., Univ of Siegen, Germany; Heinrich, W., Univ of Siegen, Germany; Rocher, H., Univ of Siegen, Germany; Harboe Sorensen, R., Univ of Siegen, Germany; Adams, L., Univ of Siegen, Germany; Schardt, D., Univ of Siegen, Germany; Vetter, J., Univ of Siegen, Germany
Abstract: We started a research program using heavy ion beams at the GSI Darmstadt to investigate radiation effects on microelectronic devices. In order to expose static random access memory (SRAM) devices to heavy ions a test system was installed. This setup was first operated using different ions at the GSI UNILAC with energies below 20 MeV/nucleon. After these first tests further measurements were performed with ions of different charge and energy up to 1 GeV/nucleon at the GSI-SIS. As ions with energies of some hundred MeV/nucleon are a good representation of space conditions such beams are interesting for reliability tests of microelectronic space equipment. The experimental setup and the exposure conditions at GSI are described in this paper and first results are presented.
Index Keywords: Ion beams; Microelectronics; Random access storage; Heavy ions; Single event effects; Radiation effects

Authors: Takahashi Patrick K., McKinley K.R., Rocheleau R.E., Jensen C.M., Bylina E.J.
Title: Hawaii solar hydrogen program
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Solar Energy Division (Publication) SED
Affiliations: Univ of Hawaii at Manoa, Honolulu, United States
Authors with affiliations: Takahashi, Patrick K., Univ of Hawaii at Manoa, Honolulu, United States; McKinley, K.R., Univ of Hawaii at Manoa, Honolulu, United States; Rocheleau, R.E., Univ of Hawaii at Manoa, Honolulu, United States; Jensen, C.M., Univ of Hawaii at Manoa, Honolulu, United States; Bylina, E.J., Univ of Hawaii at Manoa, Honolulu, United States
Abstract: Hawaii possesses no indigenous, conventional energy resources. It is because of this vulnerability that Hawaii has undertaken a serious effort to develop the State's renewable energy resources. Hydrogen, representing the most environmentally acceptable energy carrier and the most sensible replacement for fossil fuels, has played an important role in state planning. A leader in this effort is the Hawaii Natural Energy Institute of the University of Hawaii at Manoa. This paper will detail the recent achievements of the Institute's Hydrogen from Renewable Resources Research Program. We detail our efforts in hydrogen production and storage and indicate how our program complements the other renewable resources research programs within the Institute and the State. We also discuss how our efforts complement a national hydrogen research and development initiative now underway in the United States.
Index Keywords: Hydrogen fuels; Production; Solar energy; Hawaii Natural Energy Institute; Hydrogen from Renewable Resources Research Program; University of Hawaii at Manoa; Renewable energy resources

Authors: von Spakovsky Michael R., Curti Vinicio, Batato Magdi
Title: Performance optimization of a cogeneration/heat pump facility
Affiliations: Ecole Polytechnique Federale de, Lausanne, Lausanne, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: von Spakovsky, Michael R., Ecole Polytechnique Federale de, Lausanne, Lausanne, Switzerland; Curti, Vinicio, Ecole Polytechnique Federale de, Lausanne, Lausanne, Switzerland; Batato, Magdi, Ecole Polytechnique Federale de, Lausanne, Lausanne, Switzerland
Abstract: With the push for greater energy conservation, the need for heating and/or power production is being filled by cogeneration facilities. Thus, the search for the best performance at the least cost for such multi-purpose plants is made much more difficult by the fact that such facilities must meet differing goals or demands. Such a facility exists at the Ecole Polytechnique Federale de Lausanne (EPFL) and has been studied in order to find the optimum modes of operation as a function of time for variations in both the heating and electrical demands which this facility must meet. The results of this study are presented below. The plant itself provides heat and electricity for both the EPFL and the University of Lausanne and is projected to supply electricity to the exterior utility grid provided it can be shown to be economically viable. The plant's primary components include two gas turbines, a heat recovery system, two heat pumps, a set of heat storage tanks and both medium and low temperature district heating networks. In order to find the optimum mode of operation, a mixed-integer programming approach was used which balances the competing costs of operation and minimizes these costs subject to the operational constraints placed on the system. The effects of both the cost of the fuel and the costs of electricity sold and bought on the best performance of the system are evaluated. In addition, the important features of the modeling process are discussed, in particular the heat storage tanks which, though operated as steady state as opposed to nonsteady state devices, complicate the optimization of the series of steady state models used to model the overall transient behavior of the system.
Index Keywords: Electric power generation; Energy conservation; Fuel consumption; Gas turbines; Heat pump systems; Heat storage; Industrial economics; Linear programming; Optimization; Thermodynamics; Heat storage tanks; Mixed integer programming; Cogeneration plants

Authors: Pfotenhauer J.M.
Title: Design issues for a superfluid helium subcooler
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Heat Transfer Division, (Publication) HTD
Affiliations: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, United States
Authors with affiliations: Pfotenhauer, J.M., Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, United States
Abstract: Proposed operating conditions for Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage (SMES) coils will be a temperature of 1.8 K and a pressure of 0.1 MPa. The subcooled superfluid helium environment is created by a combination of a low heat leak path to communicate 0.1 MPa pressure to the liquid helium bath and a subcooler heat exchanger to lower the temperature. This report addresses the design issues critical to the components of the subcooler system including those related to the issue of operating the heat exchanger in superfluid helium, and identifies the factors which can limit the overall performance. Specifically, it discusses the details of the Joule-Thomson (JT) valve, including flow characteristics, the precooler, the Kapitza resistance across the liquid-liquid heat exchanger, and the generation of helium mass flow. Taking all the factors into account, a methodology is presented for designing to a desired capacity. The impact of the various parameters on the design of the He II system for the proposed 20 MWh Engineering Test Model (ETM) SMES coil will be studied to determine their relation to refrigerator efficiency. When constructed, the ETM will include the largest He II cooled magnet system in the world.
Index Keywords: Cryogenic liquids; Flow of fluids; Heat exchangers; Heat transfer; Helium; Liquefied gases; Mathematical models; Superconducting magnets; Engineering test model (ETM); Joule Thomson valves; Kapitza resistance; Superconducting magnetic energy storage; Superfluid helium subcooler system; Cooling systems

Authors: Hopkinson G.R.
Title: Radiation effects on CCDS for spaceborne acquisition and tracking applications
Source title: First European Conference on Radiation and Its Effects on Devices and Systems - RADECS 91
Affiliations: Sira Ltd, Kent, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Hopkinson, G.R., Sira Ltd, Kent, United Kingdom
Abstract: This paper reviews the results of recent Co60 and proton testing of TH7863 and THX31160-1 CCDs. The Co60 gamma ray tests were performed on devices both biased and unbiased during irradiation and at two dose rates (1 krad/hr and 50 rad/hr). In all cases the biased devices showed a threshold voltage shift of approx.0.09V/krad and significant increases in surface dark current (approx.10nA/cm2/krad at 22°C) which continued after irradiation had ceased. Both threshold voltage and dark current damage were reduced for unbiased devices. Power consumption, charge transfer efficiency (CTE), full well capacity and charge to voltage conversion factor were also measured but did not show large changes. Proton testing was carried out at 1.5 and 10 MeV again for biased and unbiased devices and dark current changes due to bulk damage were observed. These were bias independent. There was significant annealing of bulk damage after 3 months storage (this time the dark current reduced). After annealing a damage constant of roughly 2.4nA/cm2 per MeV of damage energy at 22°C was found. Changes in CTE were too small to be measured, probably because the time constants of the radiation induced traps were long compared with the clock overlap times (approx.50ns) used in this application. Some large dark current spikes (amplitude up to approx.3nA/cm2 at 22°C) were observed and these had somewhat erratic temperature behaviour. These are probably due to field-enhanced emission.
Index Keywords: Charge coupled devices; Gamma rays; Protons; Space applications; Charge transfer; Dark currents; Treshold voltages; Radiation effects

Authors: Attas Michael, Chen J.D., Young Gary J.
Title: Ultraviolet imager for nuclear safeguards inspectors
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Atomic Energy of Canada Ltd.,, Pinawa, Manitoba, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Attas, Michael, Atomic Energy of Canada Ltd.,, Pinawa, Manitoba, Canada; Chen, J.D., Atomic Energy of Canada Ltd.,, Pinawa, Manitoba, Canada; Young, Gary J., Atomic Energy of Canada Ltd.,, Pinawa, Manitoba, Canada
Abstract: An ultraviolet imaging device has been developed for use in nuclear safeguards. The handheld device detects and amplifies a restricted portion (250 - 350 nm) of the faint Cerenkov glow produced in water around irradiated nuclear fuel stored in used-fuel pools. A 105 mm quartz objective lens, a UV-pass filter and a microchannel-plate image intensifier tube form the real- time visible-light image, which can be photographed or viewed directly through an eyepiece. Normal artificial lighting of the fuel storage bay does not interfere with the Cerenkov-light image. Anomalous fuel assemblies can be detected in the presence of normal assemblies by differences in the Cerenkov-light image. The latest version of this Cerenkov Viewing Device, the Mark IV CVD, is being used routinely by inspectors from the International Atomic Energy Agency to verify declared inventories of irradiated light-water power-reactor fuel. Its design and operation are illustrated and described in this paper, together with plans for further enhancements of the instrumentation.
Index Keywords: Cerenkov counters; Image intensifiers (solid state); Inspection; Optical filters; Photography; Quartz; Radiation counters; Radioactivity; Ultraviolet radiation; Water; Cerenkov light devices; Cerenkov viewing devices; Radioactive detection; UV-pass filters; Nuclear materials safeguards

Title: Fundamentals of Phase Change: Freezing, Melting, and Sublimation - 1992
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Heat Transfer Division, (Publication) HTD
Abstract: This volume contains 11 papers from the conference proceedings. The topics discussed are the following: ice crystal growth in turbulent falling films; experiments on natural convection in aqueous solutions: influence of the density maximum on phase change; stability of clathrate-hydrate of carbon dioxide in highly pressurized water; steady state liquid solidification in a tube with viscous dissipation and axial conduction; definition of prominent thermal mechanisms associated with the buoyancy-induced transport of hafnium-carbide within a solidifying uranium-hafnium alloy; an enthalpy scheme for solving the hyperbolic Stefan problem; the boundary element method applied to freezing and melting problems; an analytical solution and sensitivity study of sublimation-dehydration within a porous medium with volumetric heating; refrigerant hydrate as a cool storage medium; latent heat thermal energy storage for lunar oxygen production; and the minimization of the solidification time of a thin cylindrical shell.

Authors: Ismail K.A.R., Mello C.A.
Title: Fusion of PCM around vertical cylinder in the presence of natural convection
Affiliations: UNICAMP-FEM-DETF, Sao Paolo, Brazil
Authors with affiliations: Ismail, K.A.R., UNICAMP-FEM-DETF, Sao Paolo, Brazil; Mello, C.A., UNICAMP-FEM-DETF, Sao Paolo, Brazil
Abstract: In this paper the Boussinesq model is used to formulate the fluctuation term while the equations of conservation of mass, momentum and energy are formulated in terms of the vorticity and the stream functions. The dimensionless variables used lead to continuous fusion in the discretized control volumes while the boundary conditions at the moving liquid-solid interface are determined iteratively in terms of the enthalpy and the stream functions. In this study are presented the interface boundaries, heat flow through the walls of the inner cylinder and the heat stored. The results agree well with available theoretical and experimental results. Additionally the transient profiles of the stream function are presented to indicate the convective currents in the pcm.

Authors: Baker G.C.
Title: New technology applicable to tidal power
Source title: Ocean Energy Recovery - The State of the Art
Authors with affiliations: Baker, G.C.
Abstract: The main thrust of technical development has been toward optimum design of single or double effect, single basin tidal plants and for this purpose present technology is relatively mature. Further improvements will no doubt be achieved in the design of both overall systems and individual components. However, the gains in cost-effectiveness are likely to be modest. There is considerable scope for a better understanding of how energy storage may be integrated with tidal power to provide a high quality source of generation for electrical systems. Neither experience nor optimization methods are available to chart an efficient course through the maze of systemic options. This is an area which will probably attract more attention in the future than in the past, particulatrly if utility capacity costs increase to regain their pre-OPEC relationship to energy costs.
Index Keywords: Economic and social effects; Engineering research; Technology; Tidal power plants; La Rance project; Technical improvement; Tidal power

Authors: Romero Alejandro F., Ullman Terry L.
Title: Experiments in trap regeneration using storage of energy as heat
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Internal Combustion Engine Division (Publication) ICE
Affiliations: Ciudad Univ, Mexico
Authors with affiliations: Romero, Alejandro F., Ciudad Univ, Mexico; Ullman, Terry L., Ciudad Univ, Mexico
Abstract: Engine exhaust particulate matter collection using ceramic or fiber filters as inline particulate traps has been successful, as reported in the technical literature. Periodic cleaning or thermal regeneration of these filters by oxidizing the accumulated soot particles using a high temperature flow of air or exhaust gases with sufficient oxygen concentration, however, remains a major problem. This paper presents experimental efforts in obtaining thermal regeneration with a process requiring greatly reduced rates of energy input. The concept of storing energy as heat was used to accumulate energy for delivery at high temperature levels required for regeneration. A large mass of metal, mainly stainless steel, was used as a thermal energy reservoir (TER). Heat stored in the metal mass was then transferred to the particulate trap to obtain controlled thermal regeneration of the trap allowing the trap to continue accumulation of additional exhaust particulate. Experiments with the TER were somewhat successful, but much more work is necessary to produce a viable system for regeneration of particulate traps on buses.
Index Keywords: Buses; Energy storage; Exhaust gases; Heat transfer; Particulate emissions; Buses particulate traps; Engine exhaust particulate matter collection; Heat energy storage; Inline particulate traps; Thermal energy reservoir (TER); Trap regeneration experiments; Internal combustion engines

Authors: Blanar George J., Sumner Richard
Title: New time digitizer applications in particle physics experiments
Affiliations: LeCroy Corp, Chestnut Ridge, United States
Authors with affiliations: Blanar, George J., LeCroy Corp, Chestnut Ridge, United States; Sumner, Richard, LeCroy Corp, Chestnut Ridge, United States
Abstract: Charged particle tracking detectors for elementary particle and heavy ion physics experiments require high density, fast readout time digitizers with nanosecond resolution and multi-hit capability. To satisfy these requirements, a new Time-to-Digital Converter (TDC), Application Specific Integrated Circuit, the LeCroy Model MTD132 monolithic Time Digitizer, has been developed. This revolutionary all digital TDC was designed for high multiplicity forward spectrometer drift chamber readout as well as 4π geometries for collider drift and time projection chambers. The MTD132 monolithic integrated circuit has been implemented in low power CMOS technology and exceeds all required specifications. In addition to being used as a time measuring device, the MTD132 can also be used for analog signal measurement. This high resolution multi-hit TDC can digitize both leading and trailing edges of pulses. It can be used as a timer for a Wilkinson type ADC. The MTD132 can also be directly applied in the time-over-threshold technique, where the pulse is shaped so that the width is related to the quantity of interest. Both techniques can result in a true pipelined ADC with no analog storage requirement for the trigger delay. Monte Carlo studies of the measurement and readout of several types of detectors with an MTD132-like device will be presented. The availability of pipelined TDC and ADC instruments makes new data acquisition architectures possible. The use of this type of instrument in both standard and novel data acquisition architectures for future high intensity fixed target and collider experiments will be discussed.
Index Keywords: Codes (symbols); Computer architecture; Data acquisition; High energy physics; Monolithic integrated circuits; Particle detectors; Pipeline processing systems; Fast readout time digitizers; Time to digital converter (TDC); Microprocessor chips

Authors: Pope Ian
Title: Facilitating technology for electric power generation
Source title: Ocean Energy Recovery - The State of the Art
Affiliations: LE Energy Ltd, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Pope, Ian, LE Energy Ltd, United Kingdom
Abstract: This chapter is concerned with existing electric power systems, and suggests new features that would enable ocean energy sources to be incorporated into them on a significant scale. The perspective is primarily of the operation of power systems, both large and small, and how present practice, proven new technology and anticipated developments might be adopted in a satisfactory manner. Energy storage plus demand side management are envisaged as furthering the introduction of ocean energy.
Index Keywords: Electric power generation; Electric power systems; Energy storage; Ocean currents; Renewable energy resources; Technology; Demand side management; Ocean energy sources; Tidal power

Authors: Aceves-Saborio Salvador, Nakamura Hajime, Reistad Gordon M.
Title: Optimum efficiencies and phase change temperatures in latent heat storage systems
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Advanced Energy Systems Division (Publication) AES
Affiliations: Daido Inst of Technology, Nagoya, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Aceves-Saborio, Salvador, Daido Inst of Technology, Nagoya, Japan; Nakamura, Hajime, Daido Inst of Technology, Nagoya, Japan; Reistad, Gordon M., Daido Inst of Technology, Nagoya, Japan
Abstract: This paper presents an analysis of a class of latent heat storage systems (LHSS). The analysis is based on a lumped model (the basic model) that allows a broad class of LHSSs to be completely specified, with only two parameters and a set of operating temperatures, while still retaining the main thermodynamic aspects associated with its operation. Characterization of the performance in this manner permits the broad base application potential of such systems to be viewed. This modelling is in contrast to most studies to date, which employ many parameters to include details of specific systems and therefore obscure, to a great extent, this broad based application potential. The basic model is later modified in three ways to analyze operating conditions that either occur in practical units or are desirable for an improved operation of the units. The modifications include, first, the consideration of the LHSS as being formed by many independent phase-change material (PCM) capsules. Second, the possibility of having PCMs with different phase change temperatures filling the capsules. Third, the case when the PCM melts over a temperature range. The results indicate that the efficiency of the basic model represents an upper bound for the efficient operation of LHSSs. The only possibility of obtaining efficiencies higher than those obtained with the basic model is by using PCMs with different phase change temperatures in the heat storage unit. Using PCMs with different phase change temperatures represents also the only possibility for reversible operation of LHSSs.
Index Keywords: Efficiency; Energy storage; Heat transfer; Mass transfer; Mathematical models; Optimization; Performance; Specific heat; Thermal effects; Thermodynamics; Latent heat storage systems (LHSS); Optimum efficiency; Phase change material (PCM); Phase change temperature; Heat storage

Authors: Dumas J.P., Strub F., Bedecarrats J.P., Zeraouli Y., Broto F., Lenotre Ch.
Title: Influence of undercooling on cold storage systems
Affiliations: Universite de Pau et des Pays de, l'Adour, Pau, France
Authors with affiliations: Dumas, J.P., Universite de Pau et des Pays de, l'Adour, Pau, France; Strub, F., Universite de Pau et des Pays de, l'Adour, Pau, France; Bedecarrats, J.P., Universite de Pau et des Pays de, l'Adour, Pau, France; Zeraouli, Y., Universite de Pau et des Pays de, l'Adour, Pau, France; Broto, F., Universite de Pau et des Pays de, l'Adour, Pau, France; Lenotre, Ch., Universite de Pau et des Pays de, l'Adour, Pau, France
Abstract: Air conditioning and refrigeration have an increasing technologic importance and the use of a storage process is economically a good solution. The presented cold storage process consists in the use of the solid-liquid transformation of Phase Change Materials (P.C.M.) encapsulated in spherical nodules. These nodules fill a tank placed in the refrigeration loop. The advantages of the latent heat storage are described. Laboratory experiments allow to specify the nature and the importance of the non symmetry between the crystallization (energy storage) and the melting (energy release) due to the undercooling. Using special catalysts, the delay is reduced to a few degrees but never cancelled. The erratic character of the crystallizations is particularly evidenced. Statistical results are given by the simultaneous study of 32 nodules. We conclude that it is the erratic undercooling phenomenon which imposes the kinetics of energy storage and not the power of the refrigerating machines.
Index Keywords: Air conditioning; Crystallization; Heat storage; Kinetic theory; Materials; Mathematical models; Melting; Phase transitions; Refrigeration; Latent heat storage; Phase change materials; Solid liquid transformation; Spherical nodules; Undercooling phenomenon; Cold storage

Authors: Merkel Martin
Title: Crystal barrel data acquisition system
Affiliations: Inst fuer Physik der Johannes, Gutenberg Universitaet, Mainz, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Merkel, Martin, Inst fuer Physik der Johannes, Gutenberg Universitaet, Mainz, Germany
Abstract: The main detector components of the Crystal Barrel (CBAR) experiment at the LEAR facility at CERN are two proportional wire chambers, a jet drift chamber and an electromagnetic calorimeter composed of 1380 CsI(Tl) crystals, with in total 4380 analog channels. This paper describes the use of distributed VME-based microcomputers to collect data from the various subdetectors and to merge the full event information in a global event builder. At this level the data are transferred to a μVAX for tape storage and monitoring.
