Authors: Cleary Michael P., Barr David T.
Title: Global vs. local diffusion phenomena in underground heat and mass transfer
Affiliations: Massachusetts Inst of Technology, Cambridge, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cleary, Michael P., Massachusetts Inst of Technology, Cambridge, United States; Barr, David T., Massachusetts Inst of Technology, Cambridge, United States
Abstract: Classical descriptions of fluid flow in porous media have always assumed that the storage and fluid flux are dependent only on the local pressure and its gradient, and thus that local mass conservation involves only the pressure at nearest nodal points. This leads to conveniently banded matrices for resulting simulators employed by groundwater hydrologists and petroleum engineers alike. Some non-local dependency has been recognized, with the advent of the Biot consolidation theory, in which pore-pressures are induced by stresses which are governed by elliptic rather than parabolic equations. However, an even more dramatic non-local effect involves the presence of fractures: although these are often lumped into dual-porosity and other such simple models, they do in fact change the nature of both the flow and the stress transmission problem. While some basic diffusive features can still be derived, the detailed simulation problem is considerably harder and introduces many new complexities to the numerical modelling process. Sample problems and their solutions give particular application to the important process of underground fracturing, on which the authors have conducted extensive theoretical and laboratory studies, with a broad range of applications to practical field problems. One conclusion is that the currently popular use of large-scale complex flow simulators often serves more to mislead than enlighten the scientific/engineering community, when these simulators do not incorporate the primary global mechanisms of heat and mass transfer.
Index Keywords: Diffusion; Flow of fluids; Heat transfer; Mass transfer; Geothermal energy

Authors: Hagerman George
Title: Economics of wave power
Source title: Ocean Energy Recovery - The State of the Art
Affiliations: SEASUN Power Systems, Alexandria, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hagerman, George, SEASUN Power Systems, Alexandria, United States
Abstract: Although wave power has not yet moved into the commercial marketplace, it is much closer now than it was ten years ago. Within the last decade, several full-scale prototypes and demonstration plants have been built, ranging in size from 20 kWe to 500 kWe, and most of these are still operating. In the economic evaluation presented herein, levelized energy costs are computed for land-based, caisson-based, and offshore wave power plant designs derived from this recent experience. Land-based Tapered Channel technology, developed in Norway, is on the verge of commercialization, with orders placed for two small plants in Australia and Indonesia. Japanese caisson-based systems are expected to enter the Pacific island market during the next five years. The development of offshore wave power is less advanced. Without long-term demonstration, private financing of an offshore project is unlikely, due to large uncertainties in absorber fabrication cost, plant maintenance requirements, component durability, and wave energy absorption efficiency. For plant sizes of 30 MWe or less, the projected cost of wave-generated electricity is lower than that for other ocean energy technologies. At this scale, wave power is also less expensive than small hydropower or diesel generation. Where demand growth is sufficiently high to warrant construction of a coal-fired plant, however, wave power loses its competitiveness with fossil fuels, although it remains the least costly ocean energy option for all but the largest tidal power plants. Several co-products enhance wave power's economic appeal, including seawater pumping for aquaculture, fresh water production by direct reverse osmosis, and breakwater protection. The case is made that for island applications, fresh water may be more valuable than electricity, in terms of both market size and energy impact. Given a scenario of commercial success in island markets, long-term demonstration of offshore components and systems, and the development of an onshore infrastructure for the storage and distribution of hydrogen, wave power can ultimately supply a large fraction of global demand for electricity, heating, and transportation fuel.
Index Keywords: Caissons; Costs; Design; Economics; Electric power plants; Offshore power plants; Underwater power plants; Land base Tapered Channel technology; Wave generated electricity costs; Wave power

Authors: Simpson Jr. William A., McClung Robert W.
Title: Ultrasonic detection of fatigue damage in glass-epoxy composite flywheels
Affiliations: Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, United States
Authors with affiliations: Simpson Jr., William A., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, United States; McClung, Robert W., Oak Ridge Natl Lab, Oak Ridge, United States
Abstract: Energy storage flywheels fabricated of S2 glass-epoxy composite were studied to determine the behavior of the ultrasonic properties as a function of strain history and to identify possible predictors of incipient failure. Tension specimens of the flywheel material were loaded uniaxially, and the ultrasonic properties (that is, the shear and longitudinal wave velocities and the attenuation) were measured as a function of strain. Finished flywheels were similarly tested at various stages during cyclic spin testing, in addition, the polar backscattering intensity as a function of fatigue cycle was recorded. The velocities are excellent indicators of the maximum strain incurred at each point of the flywheel, and the attenuation delineates the region in which the stress is high enough to initiate microcracking in the matrix.
Index Keywords: Composite materials; Energy storage; Fatigue of materials; Nondestructive examination; Strain; Stresses; Ultrasonics; Energy storage flywheels; Fatigue cycle function; Fatigue damage ultrasonic detection; Glass-epoxy composite flywheels; Flywheels

Authors: Ramohalli Kumar, Ousterhout K., Sridhar K.R., DiFrancesco J.M.
Title: Robotic common lunar lander concept in support of the space exploration initiative
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Aerospace Division (Publication) AD
Affiliations: Univ of Arizona, Tucson, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ramohalli, Kumar, Univ of Arizona, Tucson, United States; Ousterhout, K., Univ of Arizona, Tucson, United States; Sridhar, K.R., Univ of Arizona, Tucson, United States; DiFrancesco, J.M., Univ of Arizona, Tucson, United States
Abstract: This paper develops the concept of an intelligent lunar lander that can demonstrate robotic processing of local soil to produce useful substances. The main aim is to evolve an economical design that is not demanding in terms of (overall life-cycle) mission cost, mass, volume, power, or communication/monitoring. This work is motivated by the Space Exploration Initiative, which intends to send Common Lunar Landers as precursors to more extensive missions to the Moon. The fundamental concept revolves around a compact, deployable robot that weighs less than 65 kg and is completely self-contained. The aim is to demonstrate that full-system engineering can be accomplished in small packages. The initial experiment consists of producing oxygen from the lunar soil using solar thermal energy. The 1 kw of thermal energy needed for chemical processing is derived through a low-mass composite reflector that was pioneered at The University of Arizona. The electrical energy needed is minimal (< 0.5 kw) and is generated through an array of photovoltaic cells in conjunction with a small bank of rechargeable batteries. The robot consists of a 6-degrees-of-freedom unit that scoops up the soil, sieves it into ceramic crucibles, mixes the soil with a small mass of imported carbon, positions it at the focal point, monitors and identifies the liberated gases before storing them, and replaces the spent material after converting it into a small briquette. The process is carried out during a lunar day and data storage is through a computer. During the lunar night, the stored data will be extensively processed before the results are communicated to a mother craft, or directly to Earth.
Index Keywords: Intelligent robots; Lunar landing; Moon bases; Planetary landers; Robot applications; Robotic arms; Space research; Life cycle; Mother craft; Space exploration; Lunar missions

Authors: Harboe-Sorensen R., Muller R., Daly E., Nickson B., Schmitt J., Rombeck F.J.
Title: Radiation pre-screening of 4 Mbit dynamic random access memories for space application
Source title: First European Conference on Radiation and Its Effects on Devices and Systems - RADECS 91
Affiliations: European Space Agency/ESTEC, Noordwijk, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Harboe-Sorensen, R., European Space Agency/ESTEC, Noordwijk, Netherlands; Muller, R., European Space Agency/ESTEC, Noordwijk, Netherlands; Daly, E., European Space Agency/ESTEC, Noordwijk, Netherlands; Nickson, B., European Space Agency/ESTEC, Noordwijk, Netherlands; Schmitt, J., European Space Agency/ESTEC, Noordwijk, Netherlands; Rombeck, F.J., European Space Agency/ESTEC, Noordwijk, Netherlands
Abstract: Many space projects today require large capacity on-board data storage which can be achieved with the use of 1 Mbit static Random Access Memory (sRAM) or 4 Mbit dynamic Random Access Memory (dRAM). However, of todays large number or commercially available RAMs, very little is known about their radiation sensitivity, which is one of the first parameters to consider when selecting devices for a space project. We present the results of a radiation pre-screening program carried out on eleven types of commercially available 4 Mbit dRAMs. This evaluation program covered total ionising dose and Single Event Upset/Latch-up (SEU/SEL) testing. The Cobalt-60 irradiation facility at ESTEC was used for the creation of the total ionising dose data and SEU/SEL data are presented using Californium-252, accelerator heavy ion and proton irradiation. The ESTEC 'CASE' facility was used for the verification of test hardware/software and to produce initial SEU/SEL cross section data. Further heavy ion testing was carried out at the Institut de Physique Nucleaire (IPN), Orsay, using the Tandem van de Graaff covering a Linear Energy Transfer (LET) range of 0.6 to 54.0 MeV/(mg/cm2). Proton testing was carried out at the SATURNE synchrotron at the Commissariat a l'Energie Atomique (CEA) facility, Saclay, using energies of 30, 50, 100, 200 and 500 MeV. Details of these tests including test strategy, the memory tester used, test facilities and memory details are provided, and preliminary calculations of the expected in-orbit upset rate, using the ground test SEU data and the CREME suite of programs, are also presented.
Index Keywords: Digital storage; Ion beams; Particle accelerators; Random access storage; Space applications; Single event latchup; Single event upsets; Radiation effects

Authors: Shute R.W.
Title: Integrated access floor HVAC
Affiliations: Mitchell Partnership Ltd, Toronto, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Shute, R.W., Mitchell Partnership Ltd, Toronto, Canada
Abstract: For more than a decade, HVAC systems have been designed with distribution in access floor plenums, using floor-level air supply. Systems were generally ducted similarly to ceiling distribution equivalents. This paper discussed the significant breakthrough whereby the distribution is no longer fully ducted and the access floor plenum is used as a cooling reservoir. This provides unique flexibility complemented with the control stability and energy economy of building mass thermal storage. The experience shared here was gained over six years of system development in a four-phase office project located in TOronto, Ontario, Canada. During this developmental period, inquiries have come from throughout North America, Europe, and Australia. The author believes the system concept has matured sufficiently to look to the industry to participate in its further development.
Index Keywords: Ducts; Floors; Heat pump systems; Heating; Ventilation; Access floor plenums; Building mass thermal storage; HVAC systems; Underfloor supply methods; Air conditioning

Authors: Dewinkel Carel C., Koeppe Paul F.
Title: Superconductor technology offers ``ride-through'' capability for large industrial critical process loads
Source title: Proceedings of the American Power Conference
Affiliations: Superconductivity Inc, Middleton, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dewinkel, Carel C., Superconductivity Inc, Middleton, United States; Koeppe, Paul F., Superconductivity Inc, Middleton, United States
Abstract: The new Superconducting Storage Device (SSD) from Superconductivity, Inc. (SI) stores enough electrical energy to provide megawatts of 'ride-through' power during voltage sags and momentary power losses lasting several seconds. The SSD's features and capabilities make it the first attractive means of successfully combating the costly problem of voltage sags and momentary outages for large industrial loads. This paper is written to acquaint the reader with the SSD, describe how it works and review its performance.
Index Keywords: Electric load distribution; Electric load management; Energy storage; Industrial applications; Superconducting magnets; Superconducting storage device; Superconducting materials

Authors: Potter I.J., Reader G.T., Walker G.
Title: Energy source selection for Stirling engine driven AUV's
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Calgary, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Potter, I.J., Univ of Calgary, Canada; Reader, G.T., Univ of Calgary, Canada; Walker, G., Univ of Calgary, Canada
Abstract: Many non-renewable land-based resources are becoming depleted and the search for alternative sources of raw materials is intensifying. This situation has lead to the involvement of a number of countries, especially those of the European Community, in heavily funded 'Wealth from the Oceans' projects. A significant element of the research being conducted under the auspices of these projects is concerned with the development of small unmanned and untethered autonomous underwater vehicles (AUVs). To carry out their intended autonomous missions these vehicles will need reliable power systems which have high energy densities. However, although research into navigation, control and command systems has progressed considerably under this development effort, only limited headway has been made in the development of power systems which could be readily integrated into these vessels. Electrochemical power systems have been used in underwater applications for a number of years but those presently available cannot meet the rigorous specifications demanded by AUV missions. Consequently high performance fuel cells and advanced battery systems are being developed which should be generally available within the next ten years. Until then, power systems based on the utilisation of the more mature heat engine technologies appear to offer the possibility of a quicker solution to the energy density problem. Of the heat engine types available the Stirling Engine, already proven in larger submarines, shows considerable promise. One of the main reasons for the selection of the Stirling engine is it's ability to utilise any heat source, such as radioisotopes, thermal energy storage and metallic fuels. In this paper a project is described in which the design requirements for a Stirling engine driven AUV have been examined together with the identification of the most suitable primary energy source for a specific mission. As part of this project a user-friendly PC-based computer program has been developed which allows rapid assessments of the use of different energy sources with a double-acting Stirling for user defined missions. The structure and use of this code is discussed.
Index Keywords: Computer software; Energy resources; Stirling cycle; Submersibles; Autonomous underwater vehicles; Computer code; Double acting Stirling engines; Energy source selection; Stirling engines; Heat engines

Authors: Andresen I., Brandemuehl M.J.
Title: Heat storage in building thermal mass: a parametric study
Affiliations: Norwegian Inst of Technology, Norway
Authors with affiliations: Andresen, I., Norwegian Inst of Technology, Norway; Brandemuehl, M.J., Norwegian Inst of Technology, Norway
Abstract: This paper describes the results of a series fo computer simulations that characterize the dynamic thermal performance of a typical office space. The effects of different night setback schedules are investigated in conjunction with a sensitivity analysis that involves changing system parameters such as lighting distribution, structural mass, heat transfer coefficients, carpet, and furniture. The effect of including a return air plenum in the zone model is also discussed. The results show that building thermal mass can be used to reduce peak cooling loads and electrical demand by controlling the variables that influence the interaction between the conditioned air and the structural mass. The results also indicate that mechanical precooling of building mass during off-peak hours can reduce peak cooling loads by as much as 50 % compared to a strategy of turning off HVAC equipment at night.
Index Keywords: Air conditioning; Buildings; Cooling; Heating; Ventilation; Building thermal mass; Dynamic thermal performance; Electrical demand; Peak cooling loads; Energy utilization

Authors: Holness G.V.R.
Title: Case study of combined chilled-water thermal energy storage and fire protection storage
Affiliations: Albert Kahn Assoc, Detroit, United States
Authors with affiliations: Holness, G.V.R., Albert Kahn Assoc, Detroit, United States
Abstract: This paper addresses as example of integrated design technologies that permit the joint use of fire protection ground suction tanks for chilled-water thermal storage. The issued of life safety and integrity of the fire protection services are addressed along with a review of the overall application. the fire protection requirements at the 770,000-square-foot truck plant for assembly and painting operations dictated the provision of sully automatic sprinkler protection with two independent water supply sources. Two 400, 000-gallon fire protection ground suction tanks and associated diesel pumps were provided to meet that need. Evaluation of alternative air-conditioning methods for the plant led to selection of a chilled-water system utilizing the available capacity of the fire protection tanks as a thermal storage source. This enabled a reduction in the chiller plant capacity from 2,550 tons to 1,650 tons and stabilized operating loads on the chiller. Meetings with the insurance underwriter resolved the requirements necessary to safeguard the integrity of the fire protection source, fully meeting the requirements of NFPA 22, when used for alternative service.
Index Keywords: Air conditioning; Sprinkler systems (fire fighting); Storage (materials); Water supply; Chilled water thermal energy storage; Fire protection Storage; Ground suction tank; Integrated design technology; Fire protection

Authors: Asahina Tadashi, Tajiri, Kosaka Mineo
Title: Thermal properties of organic and inorganic thermal storage materials in direct contact with heat carriers
Affiliations: Government Industrial Research Inst, Nagoya, Nagoya, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Asahina, Tadashi, Government Industrial Research Inst, Nagoya, Nagoya, Japan; Tajiri, Government Industrial Research Inst, Nagoya, Nagoya, Japan; Kosaka, Mineo, Government Industrial Research Inst, Nagoya, Nagoya, Japan
Abstract: Direct-contact heat transfer is an attractive method for latent-heat thermal energy storage systems. However, in direct contact heat transfer system where oil bubbles rise up through the fused inorganic hydrate a rather long distance is necessary for the droplets to gain adequate heat along a path from the bottom to the surface of the storage medium. Some methods for increasing the dwelling time of the droplets were studied to make the direct-contact system small.
Index Keywords: Thermodynamic properties; Direct contact heat transfer; Inorganic thermal storage materials; Latent-heat thermal storage systems; Heat transfer

Authors: Froehlich Donald R., Feild Charles T., Tancock John R.
Title: Stanley Canyon hydroelectric project
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Fluids Engineering Division (Publication) FED
Affiliations: Black & Veatch, Kansas City, United States
Authors with affiliations: Froehlich, Donald R., Black & Veatch, Kansas City, United States; Feild, Charles T., Black & Veatch, Kansas City, United States; Tancock, John R., Black & Veatch, Kansas City, United States
Abstract: The City of Colorado Springs, Colorado, is expanding its water supply system by constructing a tunnel from the existing Rampart Reservoir to the new J. A. McCullough Water Treatment Center. The water system expansion project offers an excellent opportunity to jointly use many of the project civil facilities, available head, and water for a hydroelectric project. This paper describes two hydroelectric project alternatives being considered by the City. A 20.7 MW conventional hydroelectric plant could recover the energy currently being dissipated in the water prior to treatment and distribution. The conventional project would include a powerhouse with three pelton turbine generator units and a transmission line as the only facilities added to the water project. Alternatively, the project could be developed as a 90 MW pumped storage project to meet the future system peaking needs. The pumped storage project would require a new Rampart Dam outlet, powerhouse, and lower reservoir. Shared use of the water supply system facilities significantly reduced the hydro project capital costs, but also required close coordination of the design parameters of both projects. In particular, the hydro project conceptual designs ensured that the hydraulic transients, under normal and emergency conditions, did not exceed the design limits of the water facilities. The hydro project must also include provisions to isolate it from the water project to ensure that water supplies are not interrupted. The conceptual designs for both the Conventional and Pumped Storage project alternatives demonstrate that combining water and hydro projects can achieve substantial benefits which outweigh any limitations imposed by the combined operations.
Index Keywords: Cost accounting; Energy utilization; Hydroelectric power; Project management; Pumped storage power plants; Regional planning; Turbogenerators; Water distribution systems; Water supply systems; Water treatment; J.A. McCullough Water Treatment Center; Rampart Reservoir; Stanley Canyon hydroelectric project; Hydroelectric power plants

Authors: Messenger George C.
Title: Summary review of displacement damage from high energy radiation in semiconductors and semiconductor devices
Source title: First European Conference on Radiation and Its Effects on Devices and Systems - RADECS 91
Authors with affiliations: Messenger, George C.
Abstract: High energy radiation produces defect complexes in semiconductor materials which reduce minority carrier lifetime, change majority carrier density, and reduce mobility. Most of the experimental data on semiconductors and semiconductor devices has been taken using high energy neutrons. Recent research has shown that this data can be extrapolated to other high energy radiation such as protons, electrons, alpha particles and gamma rays by normalizing to the energy going to atomic processes. Minority carrier lifetime is the most sensitive electronic property of silicon in the neutron environment. The degredation of minority carrier lifetime results in changes in semiconductor device properties such as current gain, storage time, saturation voltage and sink current. Carrier removal is the next most important characteristic of displacement damage and it causes a decrease in carrier mobility and an increase in resistivity. The dependence of these basic semiconductor properties on neutron flunce is introduced into device models such as SPICE and the resulting radiation inclusive model permits quantitative determination of device parameters as a function of neutron fluence.
Index Keywords: Charge carriers; Computer simulation; Neutrons; Semiconducting silicon; Semiconductor device testing; Minority carriers; Software package SPICE; Radiation damage

Authors: Cesaroni F., Gentile S., Pascale G., Gao Z.
Title: A fast ECL bus memory: dual input memory
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare, Sezione di Roma, Roma, Italy; Dipartimento di Fisica, Università La Sapienza, Roma, Italy; Dipartimento di Fisica, Università della Calabria, Cosenza, Italy; CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; ITCP, Trieste, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Cesaroni, F., Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare, Sezione di Roma, Roma, Italy, Dipartimento di Fisica, Università La Sapienza, Roma, Italy; Gentile, S., Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare, Sezione di Roma, Roma, Italy, Dipartimento di Fisica, Università della Calabria, Cosenza, Italy, CERN, Geneva, Switzerland; Pascale, G., Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare, Sezione di Roma, Roma, Italy, Dipartimento di Fisica, Università La Sapienza, Roma, Italy; Gao, Z., Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare, Sezione di Roma, Roma, Italy, ITCP, Trieste, Italy
Abstract: A fast and flexible dual input memory (DIM) has been constructed as single CAMAC unit. The device has been designed to receive via front panel two 16-bit data words, which can be stored in sequential mode into a memory and, at the same time, presented on the output. The design implemented also the possibility to connect 16-bit differential ECL outputs of many DIMs modules on the same bus. Its timing characteristics for writing and reading into and from memory is only 20 ns. This makes the module a useful element for all kinds of fast acquisition systems, as temporary storage of data, or data source or spy module. It will be, for example, used in the new energy trigger of the L3 experiment, designed for the 8 × 8 bunch mode operation of LEP in 1992. © 1992.
Index Keywords: Computer hardware; Data acquisition; Data processing; Response time (computer systems); Trigger circuits; Dual input memory; Fast acquisition systems; First level energy trigger; Hadron calorimeter; Data storage equipment

Authors: Lu Chris X., Bell Rodney D., Rees Neville W.
Title: Deaerator modelling and control
Source title: National Conference Publication - Institution of Engineers, Australia
Affiliations: Univ of NSW, Kensington
Authors with affiliations: Lu, Chris X., Univ of NSW, Kensington; Bell, Rodney D., Univ of NSW, Kensington; Rees, Neville W., Univ of NSW, Kensington
Abstract: A mathematical model suitable for predicting the transient behaviour of deaerator plant is presented. The model is based on energy and mass balance equations applied to the deaerator, storage tank and feedpump suction pipe. The model's parameters are based entirely on the physical characteristics of the plant and hence the model can be easily adapted to plants of different size. A study of various control strategies on deaerator water level control to prevent cavitation has been carried out by simulation based on the presented model and the results are very promising.
Index Keywords: Cavitation corrosion; Control system synthesis; Corrosion prevention; Mathematical models; Parameter estimation; Process control; Water levels; Deaerators; Feedpump suction pipes; Storage tanks; Transient behavior; Water level control; Water treatment plants

Authors: Barclay J.A., Corless A.J.
Title: Cost analysis of a magnetic liquefier in a fleet-size cryofuel refuelling system
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Solar Energy Division (Publication) SED
Affiliations: Univ of Victoria, Victoria, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Barclay, J.A., Univ of Victoria, Victoria, Canada; Corless, A.J., Univ of Victoria, Victoria, Canada
Abstract: Concern over global environmental disruption is causing a growing motivation for adoption of fuels alternate to gasoline, diesel and jet-A. Barriers to the transition to alternate fuels include cost of vehicle conversion, cost of production, distribution, and on-board storage of the fuels, and lack of economic refuelling stations. For example, even though natural gas feedstock is relatively inexpensive compared to gasoline, the combined costs of vehicle conversion, conventional liquefaction/compression, distribution, and dispensing result in natural gas fuel prices on an energy equivalent basis only slightly less than the present prices of gasoline or diesel fuel. Similarly, the cost of gaseous hydrogen feedstock is approximately one third the cost of gasoline, but after costs of conventional liquefaction/compression, distribution, and storage are added to hydrogen feedstock costs, the economics for conversion to hydrogen fuel are unattractive in most situations. A major reduction in the liquefaction/compression costs for fleet-size refuelling stations would reduce the price of the fuel to the consumer, increase motivation to install refuelling stations, and therefore provide increased incentive for conversion to natural gas and hydrogen. One technology which offers a potential reduction in life-cycle costs of liquefying equipment for natural gas and hydrogen is magnetic refrigeration. Numerous studies have shown the promise for higher thermodynamic efficiency and lower associated operating costs, but few studies of capital costs of magnetic liquefiers have been done. The objective of this paper is to report an analysis of capital costs for a 1000 gal/day, fleet-size magnetic liquefier for LNG to determine the potential for capital cost reduction using this technology instead of conventional gas-cycle liquefaction technology.
Index Keywords: Costs; Efficiency; Liquefied natural gas; Refrigeration; Synthetic fuels; Thermodynamics; Fleet size cryofuel refuelling system; Magnetic liquefier; Thermodynamic efficiency; Condensers (liquefiers)

Authors: Cleveland Theodore G., Chuang Lu-Chia
Title: Optimal aquifer management for controlling land subsidence
Source title: Water Resources Planning and Management: Saving a Threatened Resource - In Search of Solutions, Proceedings of the Water Resources Sessions at Water Forum
Affiliations: Univ of Houston, Houston, United States
Authors with affiliations: Cleveland, Theodore G., Univ of Houston, Houston, United States; Chuang, Lu-Chia, Univ of Houston, Houston, United States
Abstract: This paper discusses on-going research in optimal regional aquifer management that has a multiplicity of goals: water supply, subsidence control, and energy management. Current research is directed at simulation and optimization of the aquifer system using a variety of methods. The goal of the research is to identify pumping policies that control subsidence, yet meet current and projected groundwater demands and require minimal lift (a surrogate for energy). Two fundamentally different operational strategies are studied: (1) pumping (extraction) only; and (2) pumping combined with injection where net extraction meets demand. The simulation model uses the USGS modular three-dimensional finite difference groundwater flow code with the interbed storage package for modeling flow and subsidence. The current model is a four-layer model with spatial resolution of 2.5 miles in the horizontal dimensions and 0.1 miles in the vertical dimension.
Index Keywords: Codes (symbols); Finite difference method; Flow of water; Groundwater; Management; Mathematical models; Optimization; Regional planning; Subsidence; Surface waters; Three dimensional; Groundwater models; Groundwater withdrawals; Houston Galveston area; Aquifers

Authors: Stassinopoulos E.G., Borowick Jim
Title: Correlation of proton and heavy-ion test results on CMOS bulk memories used for space applications
Source title: First European Conference on Radiation and Its Effects on Devices and Systems - RADECS 91
Affiliations: NASA/Goddard Space Flight Cent, Greenbelt, United States
Authors with affiliations: Stassinopoulos, E.G., NASA/Goddard Space Flight Cent, Greenbelt, United States; Borowick, Jim, NASA/Goddard Space Flight Cent, Greenbelt, United States
Abstract: Experiments were performed to determine the heavy-ion and proton sensitivity of CMOS Bulk 2K×8 RH Space-Qualified SRAMs. The tests were conducted at room temperature and worst-case supply voltage on devices with several different cross-coupled memory cell resistor values. The results indicated correlation between heavy-ion LET threshold versus proton apparent threshold. The heavy-ion data indicate a correlation between the upset cross-sections and resistor values as well. Several proton energies were used to determine energy dependence of proton sensitivity. A special assessment/evaluation of the measured, calculated, and inferred parameter values was performed. The results were used to predict upset rates for a mission-specific space environment.
Index Keywords: CMOS integrated circuits; Ion beams; Protons; Random access storage; Space applications; Heavy ions; SRAM; Radiation effects

Authors: Farison James B., Shin Youngin, Shields Mark
Title: Compression and reconstruction of medical image sequences
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Univ. of Toledo, Toledo, OH, USA
Authors with affiliations: Farison, James B., Univ. of Toledo, Toledo, OH, USA; Shin, Youngin, Univ. of Toledo, Toledo, OH, USA; Shields, Mark, Univ. of Toledo, Toledo, OH, USA
Abstract: Many important imaging applications generate a sequence of images that are (or can be made to be) a spatially invariant image sequence with linearly additive contributions from the components that form the images. They include functional images in nuclear medicine, multiparameter MR imaging, multi-energy x-ray imaging for DR and CT, and multispectral satellite images. Recent results in the modelling and analysis of linearly additive spatially invariant image sequences are based on the inherent structure of such images, and can be used to achieve significant data compression for image storage and still provide good reconstruction. The technique is applied here to a human renogram, with compression of a very noisy 180-image sequence to a 4-image set. The resulting reconstruction illustrates the potential of the method.
Index Keywords: Computerized tomography; Image reconstruction; Magnetic resonance imaging; Nuclear medicine; Medical image sequences; Multi-energy x-ray imaging; Renogram; Spatially invariant image sequence; Medical imaging

Authors: Rogdakis E.D., Antonopoulos K.A.
Title: Performance of a solar driven H2O/LiBr absorption panel cooling system
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Advanced Energy Systems Division (Publication) AES
Affiliations: Natl Technical Univ of Athens, Athens, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Rogdakis, E.D., Natl Technical Univ of Athens, Athens, Greece; Antonopoulos, K.A., Natl Technical Univ of Athens, Athens, Greece
Abstract: In panel cooling of buildings, the heat produced within or inserted into a room is received by a cold fluid flowing through pipes fitted in the ceiling of the room. With such systems, considerable energy savings may be obtained because higher cooling temperatures are adequate owing to the available large cooling surfaces and the radiative heat exchange between people's heads and ceiling. Moreover cool storage within structural elements may decrease peak loads. The panel cooling system examined here uses a solar driven H2O/LiBr absorption refrigeration unit. A thermodynamic and thermal analysis of the whole system is carried out and the expected performance is predicted for operation during the typical summer in Athens using local climatological data. Because of the very high evaporation temperatures (up to 18°C), the theoretical coefficient of performance of the H2O/LiBr unit is much higher than that obtained in usual refrigeration applications, i.e. it reaches 94% with specific cooling capacity 2410-2450 kJ/kg H2O. For ratio of the panel to the solar collector areas equal to 2, the panel cooling power reaches at noon a value of 200 W/m2 and therefore the proposed system seems to be sufficient for the usual building-cooling needs in Greece. Diagrams are also provided for the selection of the panel pipe spacing which ensures best thermal matching between the refrigeration unit and the panel.
Index Keywords: Buildings; Heat radiation; Lithium compounds; Mathematical models; Performance; Solar collectors; Solar refrigeration; Structural panels; Thermoanalysis; Thermodynamics; Water; Solar driven water/lithium bromide absorption panel cooling system; Cooling systems

Authors: Niemi A., Kling T., Ettala M.
Title: Simulation of a field experiment for storage of heat in porous unsaturated soil, Vierumaki, southern Finland
Affiliations: Technical Research Cent of Finland, Espoo, Finland
Authors with affiliations: Niemi, A., Technical Research Cent of Finland, Espoo, Finland; Kling, T., Technical Research Cent of Finland, Espoo, Finland; Ettala, M., Technical Research Cent of Finland, Espoo, Finland
Abstract: In this study a field experiment testing a new method for storage of thermal energy in porous soil is modelled. In the method thermal energy is stored in the unsaturated zone of soil by injecting ambient air into the soil during summer and discharging the storage during winter. Heat is transported both by conduction and with the air by convection. A two year field experiment where the method was tested in the unsaturated zone of an esker formation in Vierumaki, southern Finland, is modelled. For the numerical simulation we use the multiphase - multicomponent model TOUGH that simulates the coupled transport of air, water and heat in gas and liquid phases. First, a one-dimensional model is used for studying the effect of seasonal variations on soil temperature and water content. The results are used as initial conditions for modelling the field experiment. Next, the air injection-production experiment from summer 1990 till spring 1991 is modelled and the model parameters calibrated based on the experimental results from this period. With the parameter values yielding the best results the experiment from summer 1991 is simulated. Finally, the model is used for making simple preliminary predictions of system performance under different conditions. Variations studied include the effect of increasing the injection temperature and injection flow rate as well as comparing the results to situation with production without injection and to situation under natural conditions.
Index Keywords: Climatology; Computer simulation; Flow of water; Heat conduction; Heat convection; Mathematical models; Multiphase flow; Porous materials; Soils; Temperature; Air injection production experiment; Multiphase multicomponent model TOUGH; Porous unsaturated soil; Seasonal variation effects; Vierumaki, Finland; Water content; Heat storage

Source title: Proceedings of the American Power Conference

Abstract: This paper defines the considerations for specifying capacitor banks to minimize cost, improve reliability and help standardize design. The components making up the bank will be individually discussed with special emphasis on the protection and control.

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: DOE Facilities Programs, Systems Interaction, and Active/Inactive Damping
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Pressure Vessels and Piping Division (Publication) PVP
Abstract: The 24 papers presented in this conference proceedings discuss Department of Energy (DOE) facilities programs. Seismic analysis and qualification constitutes an important part of the structural upgrade program in DOE facilities. Most of the aged structures and components in these facilities are upgraded and analyzed in order to meet the latest seismic design requirements. Seismic upgrade includes the addition of seismic restraints and supports while at the same time meeting the requirements of thermal constraints. Constitutive models are giving validating the seismic isolation elastomer through mechanical tests. A nonlinear finite element analysis of the concrete fuel storage facility under thermal loading in the Fast Flux Test Facility (FFTF) is given. Different innovative methods of analysis and seismic qualifications for engineering components, equipments and structures in different nuclear facilities are presented.
Index Keywords: Accident prevention; Concrete construction; Damping; Earthquake resistance; Finite element method; Fracture mechanics; Nuclear fuels; Nuclear power plants; Nuclear reactors; Piping systems; Structural analysis; Viscoelasticity; Active-inactive damping; Adjustable hydraulic dampers; Building roof structure seismic qualification; Department of energy facilities programs; EiREV; Fast Flux Test facility (FFTF); High Flux Beam Reactor (HFBR) facility; Piping system structural dynamics; Seismic design requirements; Seismic fragility analysis; Structural design

Authors: Lehman Peter A., Chamberlin Charles E.
Title: Operating experience with a photovoltaic-hydrogen-fuel cell energy system
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Solar Energy Division (Publication) SED
Affiliations: Humboldt State Univ, Arcata, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lehman, Peter A., Humboldt State Univ, Arcata, United States; Chamberlin, Charles E., Humboldt State Univ, Arcata, United States
Abstract: We report development and operational results of a stand-alone renewable energy system using hydrogen as the energy storage medium and a fuel cell as the regeneration technology. The system installed at the Humboldt State University Marine Laboratory consists of a 9.2 KW photovoltaic (PV) array coupled to a high pressure, bipolar alkaline electrolyzer. The array powers the Laboratory's air compressor system whenever possible; excess power is shunted to the electrolyzer for hydrogen and oxygen production. When the array cannot provide sufficient power, stored hydrogen and oxygen are furnished to a proton exchange membrane fuel cell which, smoothly and without interruption, supplies the load. The control and monitoring subsystems are complete. We describe the rationale and hardware of each and the results of day-long, automatic operation. We also report on electrolyzer operation and on particular problems which have been solved in adapting a production line unit for PV use.
Index Keywords: Control systems; Energy storage; Fuel cells; Hydrogen fuels; Monitoring; Regenerators; Renewable energy resources; Solar cell arrays; High pressure bipolar alkaline electrolyzer; Humboldt State University Marine Laboratory; Photovoltaic hydrogen fuel cell energy system; Solar cells

Authors: Wu K.C.
Title: Operating experience using venturi flow meters at liquid helium temperature
Affiliations: Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wu, K.C., Brookhaven Natl Lab, Upton, United States
Abstract: Experiences using a commercial venturi to measure single phase helium flow near 4 K (degree Kelvin) for cooling superconducting magnets have been presented. The mass flow rate was calculated from the differential pressure and the helium density evaluated from measured pressure and temperature. The venturi flow meter, with a full range of 290 g/s (0.29 Kg/s) at design conditions, has been found to be reliable and accurate. The flow measurements have been used, with great success, for evaluating the performance of a cold centrifugal compressor, the thermal acoustic heat load of a cryogenic system and the cooling of a superconducting magnet after quench.
Index Keywords: Calorimeters; Compressors; Cryogenic liquids; Energy storage; Flow measurement; Flowmeters; Helium; Superconducting magnets; Thermal load; Cold compressor; Liquid helium temperature; Venturi flowmeter; Cryogenics

Authors: Daryanian B., Norford L.K., Tabors R.D.
Title: RTP-Based energy management systems: monitoring, communication, and control requirements for buildings under real-time pricing
Affiliations: Tabors Caramanis & Assoc, Cambridge, United States
Authors with affiliations: Daryanian, B., Tabors Caramanis & Assoc, Cambridge, United States; Norford, L.K., Tabors Caramanis & Assoc, Cambridge, United States; Tabors, R.D., Tabors Caramanis & Assoc, Cambridge, United States
Abstract: Optimal and automatic scheduling of electricity use in buildings under real-time pricing (RTP) requires integrated monitoring, computing, and communications capabilities beyond the conventional present-day practice. This paper describes the general requirements of the RTP-based energy management system based on the authors' experience with the development and implementation of an RTP-based control system for storage heating and cooling in a number of commercial buildings. It describes the overall structure of the data logging/control system; data types; on-line interaction of data collection, storage, and data processing; and the way data are utilized in load prediction and the optimization of building response to RTP rates.
Index Keywords: Buildings; Control systems; Cooling; Heating; Storage (materials); Commercial buildings; Data logging; Load prediction; Real time pricing; Energy management

Authors: Blackham David
Title: Measurements of complex permittivity and permeability using vector network analyzers
Source title: Polymeric Materials Science and Engineering, Proceedings of the ACS Division of Polymeric Materials Science and Engineering
Affiliations: Hewlett-Packard Co, Santa Rosa, United States
Authors with affiliations: Blackham, David, Hewlett-Packard Co, Santa Rosa, United States
Abstract: This paper describes the parameters that relate the interaction of electromagnetic energy with materials. A knowledge of the material properties can be useful in predicting how efficiently microwave energy will heat a material. If the material is used in electronic applications, a knowledge of material properties is necessary for proper design. Variation in electromagnetic properties has also been used to monitor other properties such as moisture content, density, etc. In addition, two techniques for measuring those properties are presented. In conclusion, the vector network analyzer provides an accurate and fast measurement tool that can be used to determine complex permittivity and permeability of a substance over the microwave frequency range. Measurements across frequency provide insight into the various storage and loss mechanisms of a material.
Index Keywords: Electromagnetic field effects; Instruments; Magnetic permeability; Testing; Complex permittivity; Microwave frequency; Open ended coaxial probe method; Transmission line method; Vector network analyzer; Materials

Authors: Yang K.H., Hwang R.L., Tu Shyh Ta
Title: Duty cycle air-conditioning operation and its energy impact evaluation on buildings
Source title: Proceedings of the Intersociety Energy Conversion Engineering Conference
Affiliations: Natl Sun Yat-Sen Univ, China
Authors with affiliations: Yang, K.H., Natl Sun Yat-Sen Univ, China; Hwang, R.L., Natl Sun Yat-Sen Univ, China; Tu, Shyh Ta, Natl Sun Yat-Sen Univ, China
Abstract: Thermal storage air-conditioning system is very efficient in shifting peak cooling demand to off-peak hours. In this paper, a passive strategy is analyzed, which accomplishes load shifting and peak-cut through precooling and air-conditioning rescheduling operation. The simulation result indicated successful load shifting can be achieved with around 20% of peak-cut, at no significant indoor thermal comfort sacrifice. The operation strategy proposed in this paper and the simulation procedure could become a powerful analytical tool for building - energy conservation.
Index Keywords: Air conditioning; Computer simulation; Energy conservation; Duty cycle air conditioning operation; Energy impact evaluation; Load shifting; Precooling; Thermal energy storage; Buildings

Title: Proceedings of the IFAC Symposium on Control of Power Plants and Power Systems
Abstract: This conference proceedings contains 77 papers concerning the modeling and control of single power plant units and concerning the dynamics of power systems in detail. Topics discussed include the modeling and simulation of fossil-fired power plants; the control of combined cycle power plants and district heating systems; advanced control schemes including predictive control and feedback control; strategies for activation of stored energy; methods of state estimation, fault analysis and diagnosis; the use of artificial intelligence to support power plant operations; tools for control system design, documentation and monitoring; flow calculations and load forecasting; distribution networks and dc transmission; voltage and reactive power scheduling and control; generation scheduling and control; power system control center functions; stability enhancemen and control; dynamic security analysis; expert systems and observers applied to power system problems; and a few survey papers and round table discussions.

Authors: Warnock J.Gavin, Clark Robert H.
Title: State of the art in tidal power recovery
Source title: Ocean Energy Recovery - The State of the Art
Affiliations: LE Energy Ltd, Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Warnock, J.Gavin, LE Energy Ltd, Edinburgh, United Kingdom; Clark, Robert H., LE Energy Ltd, Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Abstract: The State of the Art in tidal power recovery is, in 1990, well advanced and no significant technical or engineering constraints apply. A number of notable tidal power developments have been accomplished and energy has been extracted from simple tidal mills throughout the ages. Any constraints that might arise from economic, financial and environmental considerations today are those associated with development of almost all electrical energy sources. Basic concepts, tidal power technology and the practical achievements in this field will be described. The state of the art employed in the engineering design of major proposed tidal power developments is taken as the basis of this chapter. Intensive design consideration has been given to the application of advanced achievements in marine offshore construction and in the manufacture of large hydroelectric generating units and power plants. Experience in these fields allows for convenient transfer of technology to tidal power recovery. Construction method and means of shortening schedules are critical to minimizing cost. The best endeavours on both counts do not yet achieve an economic outcome which meets the criteria for normal financing of power generating facilities. Secondary benefits from ancillary uses are an important factor in planning for tidal power but rarely contribute significantly to reducing energy cost. Future development of tidal power will be dependent on a return to low discount rates combined with a growing recognition of the human value of security from diversity of energy sources benign in their global effects. Environmental and ecological effects are all important factors in considering the acceptability of energy developments. A tidal development, by its nature, affects the relatively delicate inter-tidal zones of the inlets which create the near resonant conditions and the basin storage necessary for its operation. The scale of changes arising from any sizable tidal power development will almost certainly be substantial and will need to be assessed on a site specific basis.
Index Keywords: Construction; Costs; Economic and social effects; Environmental impact; Renewable energy resources; Tidal power plants; Engineering constraints; Engineering design; Tidal power recovery; Tidal power

Authors: Snijders A.L.
Title: Aquifer seasonal cold storage for space conditioning:some cost-effective applications
Affiliations: IF Technology, Arnhem, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Snijders, A.L., IF Technology, Arnhem, Netherlands
Abstract: The main part of this paper describes two different generic system configurations with seasonal cold storage for space cooling. In both systems, cooling is provided directly (without a chiller) by the seasonal cold storage. The systems differ from each other by the manner in which the cold is produced. In one system, a heat pump is applied to provide heating. In the winter, the heat pump extracts heat from the cold store, thus loading the store. In the other system, the store is loaded in the winter by cooling groundwater with cold air from outside. For both generic system configurations, technical and economic results of detailed design studies and projects in operation are given. These results show that aquifer cold storage can be regarded as a cost-effective technology for energy-efficient space cooling.
Index Keywords: Aquifers; Cooling; Costs; Energy conservation; Heat pump systems; Energy efficiency; Seasonal cold storage; Space conditioning; Winter; Cooling

Authors: Baker R.F.
Title: Campus internal environmental considerations for health care and biomedical research facilities
Affiliations: U.S. Dep of Health and Human, Services, Bethesda, United States
Authors with affiliations: Baker, R.F., U.S. Dep of Health and Human, Services, Bethesda, United States
Abstract: Many large multi-building campuses include central power plants with incinerators, boilers, water treatment, chilled-water refrigeration, and underground storage of fuels and chemicals. These plants, as well as the site distribution systems, potentially offer a myriad of environmental consequences relating to asbestos abatement, pathological waste handling and incineration, fuels and chemical storage, waste water effluent treatment, and polychorinated biphenyl (PCB) remediation. The relationships and priorities in meeting governmental regulations while maintaining critical research and patient care responsibilities and cost-effective facilities management are discussed.
Index Keywords: Biomedical engineering; Cooling; Health care; Heating; Particulate emissions; Campus internal environmental considerations; District energy systems; Government regulations; Multibuilding campuses; Environmental impact

Abstract: Capital and operating costs have been estimated for mid-scale (2 to 200 Mwh) superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) designed to use high temperature superconductors (HTS). Capital costs are dominated by the cost of superconducting materials. Operating costs, primarily for refrigeration, are significantly reduced for HTS-SMES in comparison to low temperature, conventional systems. This cost component is small compared to other O&M and capital components, when levelized annual costs are projected. The developments required for HTS-SMES feasibility are discussed.

Abstract: This volume contains 5 papers from the conference proceedings. The topics discussed by the papers are the following: detailed quench analysis of the Swiss SMES model coil; boiling heat transfer from a horizontal cylinder in liquid nitrogen; steady and unsteady heat transfer from a horizontal wire in a pool of subcooled HE II at pressures from near lambda-pressure to atmospheric; flow impedance and different heat transport regimes in superfluid helium cooling systems for superconducting magnets; and design issues for a superfluid subcooler.

Authors: Abdul Ali A.F.M., Nazer M.O., Rahman A.A.
Title: Heat transfer and hydrodynamic analysis of an energy collection system in a solar rankine engine
Affiliations: King Fahd Univ of Petroleum and, Minerals, Dhahran, Saudi Arabia
Authors with affiliations: Abdul Ali, A.F.M., King Fahd Univ of Petroleum and, Minerals, Dhahran, Saudi Arabia; Nazer, M.O., King Fahd Univ of Petroleum and, Minerals, Dhahran, Saudi Arabia; Rahman, A.A., King Fahd Univ of Petroleum and, Minerals, Dhahran, Saudi Arabia
Abstract: A 10.5-hp turbine, operating on a Rankine thermodynamic cycle, uses R-113 as the working fluid to drive the compressor of a 7. 5-ton-capacity refrigeration system used for cooling a laboratory building. The energy to the refrigerant in the Rankine cycle is supplied by hot water at 10 bar (150 psia) and 172°C (340°F), which, in turn, collects solar energy from a field of line concentrating solar collectors. In order to maintain the operating condition, the water in the solar collector is further circulated through a ″temperature control loop″ (TCL) consisting of an auxiliary boiler, an insulated hot water storage tank, a liquid-to-liquid heat exchanger, a vaporizer, and a combination of computer-actuated solenoid valves. This paper discusses the analytical model developed related to heat transfer and pressure drop for each of the components other than the storage tank. Finally, a simulation program based on the present model is presented, which successfully predicts the thermal performance of the entire system.
Index Keywords: Compressors; Heat transfer; Hydrodynamics; Solar energy; Temperature control; Computer actuated solenoid valves; Energy collection system; Pressure drop; Solar rankine engine; Refrigeration

Authors: Neumann R., Grieser M., Habs D., Schramm U., Schuessler T., Schwalm D., Wolf A.

Abstract: Laser-stimulated radiative recombination in a storage ring was performed with merged beams of protons and electrons, continuing previous work with improved statistics, and was applied also to C6+, thus extending the technique for the first time to a heavy ion. Both gain curves reveal a shoulder on the slope towards lower laser photon energy. For C6+, a finite level above the spontaneous recombination background far into the region below the field-free ionization threshold is not excluded.

Authors: Di Pirro G., Milardi C., Serio M., Stecchi A., Trasatti L.
Title: Centralized control system for the DAΦNE Φ factory

Abstract: We describe the control system for the new DAΦNE Φ - factory under construction at the Frascati National Laboratories. The system is based on a centralized architecture for simplicity and reliability. A central processor unit coordinates all communications between the consoles and the lower level distributed processing power, and continuously updates a central memory which contains the whole machine status. This memory constitutes the machine database prototype. A simple message passing scheme built on a system of mailboxes takes advantage of high speed busses and of Fiber Optic interfaces. Macintosh II personal computers are used as consoles. The lower levels are all built using the VME standard.

Authors: Bejan Adrian
Title: Lubrication by close-contact melting
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Heat Transfer Division, (Publication) HTD
Affiliations: Duke Univ, Durham, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bejan, Adrian, Duke Univ, Durham, United States
Abstract: This invited paper reviews the current research on close-contact melting heat transfer, and the relevance of this work to understanding and predicting melt lubrication. Contact melting and lubrication is a relatively complicated phenomenon, because it combines thin-film fluid mechanics with phase-change heat transfer and solid body mechanics. This research area emerged only recently, as a subfield at the interface between heat transfer and tribology. The paper covers the contact melting of crystalline substances with smooth or rough surfaces. The types of relative motion studied are sliding contact, the movement of a hot body through a melting medium, and the movement and melting of a solid inside a heated capsule. Applications range from the reduction of friction to the energy storage by change of phase, and the disposal of nuclear waste.
Index Keywords: Applications; Fluid mechanics; Heat transfer; Melting; Thin films; Tribology; Contact melting; Melt lubrication; Lubrication

Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Heat Transfer Division, (Publication) HTD
Authors with affiliations: Solomon, A.D.; Alexiades, V.; Jacobs, G.; Naney, M.; Olszewski, M.
Abstract: A necessary component of a solar-based lunar oxygen production system is a thermal energy storage module. We discuss some of the heat transfer and phase change problems associated with the design and operation of such a module based on the latent heat of melting of lunar rock.
Index Keywords: Energy storage; Heat transfer; Mathematical models; Oxygen; Phase transitions; Production; Rocks; Space applications; Latent heat thermal energy storage (LHTES); Lunar oxygen production; Heat storage

Authors: Anzalone A., Barbagallo G., Cali C., Ferrera F.
Title: J11-VAX-Station data acquisition system for low energy nuclear physics
Affiliations: Istituto Nazionale di Fisica, Nucleare (INFN), Catania, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Anzalone, A., Istituto Nazionale di Fisica, Nucleare (INFN), Catania, Italy; Barbagallo, G., Istituto Nazionale di Fisica, Nucleare (INFN), Catania, Italy; Cali, C., Istituto Nazionale di Fisica, Nucleare (INFN), Catania, Italy; Ferrera, F., Istituto Nazionale di Fisica, Nucleare (INFN), Catania, Italy
Abstract: A data acquisition system based on STARBURST J11 processor and a VAX-Station 3100 was developed at INFN-LNS. The read-out process, the spectra builder, and the data recording process runs on J11 with an interrupt technique. The user interface and the spectra visualization was developed to run in a DEC-Window environment on a VAX-Station 3100. The use of an integrated CAMAC trigger module (TINA) makes the system compact and easy to use.

Authors: Marinucci C.
Title: Detailed quench analysis of the Swiss SMES model coil
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Heat Transfer Division, (Publication) HTD
Affiliations: Paul Scherrer Inst, Villigen, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Marinucci, C., Paul Scherrer Inst, Villigen, Switzerland
Abstract: The Paul Scherrer Institute (PSI) is developing, in collaboration with Asea-Brown-Boveri, a 50 kWh superconductive magnetic energy storage (SMES) model coil. The goal of this test device is to demonstrate the feasibility of a 1 MWh SMES concept, designed to level the short term (i.e. few minutes) variations in electrical power required, for example, by Railways applications. During the preliminary design phase, recently completed, a number of conductor and coil configurations have been investigated. The preferred solution is (a) a solenoid system, (b) NbTi in a cable-in-conduit (CIC) conductor type, and (c) forced-flow cooling with supercritical helium. This analysis investigates in detail the quench characteristics of one conductor configuration, and its implications on the design of the helium confinement steel jacket, through (a) a 1-D thermo-hydraulic analysis, and (b) a 2-D finite-element stress analysis of the jacket. The results have shown that all quench characteristics are within possible limits. In particular, the helium pressure is below acceptable mechanical limits of the jacket, subject to a proper selection of its thickness.
Index Keywords: Cooling; Energy storage; Finite element method; Flow of fluids; Helium; Mathematical models; Stress analysis; Superconducting magnets; Cable in conduit conductors; Helium confinement steel jackets; Niobium titanium alloys; Solenoid systems; Superconductive magnetic energy storage; Supercritical helium; Thermal hydraulics; Quenching

Authors: [No author name available]
Title: Two-Phase Flow in Energy Exchange Systems
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Heat Transfer Division, (Publication) HTD
Abstract: This conference proceedings contains 12 papers discussing two-phase flows occuring in industrial applications, such as boilers, condensers, evaporators, steam generators, latent heat energy storage, liquid atomization, and many other emerging applications. The papers included cover both experimental investigation and numerical modeling of practical and innovative energy exchange systems. Heat transfer measurements were made for a heat recovery system, on the outside of the enhanced tubes, and for condensation inside tubes. Based on experimental data, void transport model, abd critical heat flux criteria for flow pattern transition were determined. In one paper, convective heat transfer coefficient was determined for energy storage by phase change material particles. Numerical modeling was done for two-phase flow using Eulerian-Lagrangian approach, transient flow around a droplet, two-phase flow in a vertical bend, and transient blowdown from a cryogenic dewar.

Authors: Auyeung Cheung, Kosmach James J., Orchard Michael T., Kalafatis Tino
Title: Overlapped block motion compensation
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Motorola Inc., Palatine, IL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Auyeung, Cheung, Motorola Inc., Palatine, IL, USA; Kosmach, James J., Motorola Inc., Palatine, IL, USA; Orchard, Michael T., Motorola Inc., Palatine, IL, USA; Kalafatis, Tino, Motorola Inc., Palatine, IL, USA
Abstract: Block motion compensation is a critical component of most efficient video compression algorithms. Applications range from real-time low bit rate teleconferencing codecs to moderate and high bit-rate coding standards currently being considered for CD-ROM video storage and packet video. Recent research has suggested that blocking artifacts can be reduced by applying block motion compensation on overlapped blocks in image frames. In this paper, we formulate overlapped block motion compensation as an optimal linear estimator of pixel intensities given the neighboring block motion estimate in the frame. Applying this framework, we propose a procedure for designing optimal windows for overlapped block motion compensation. When applying block motion compensation with overlapped blocks, the optimal motion vector to apply at each block in an image depends on values of motion vectors in a non-causal neighborhood of that block. Thus, unlike for standard block-based compensation, optimal motion estimates cannot be computed with exhaustive search block- matching algorithms, even with the overlap window incorporated. Instead, we defined a simple iterative procedure for computing optimal motion estimates for overlapped block motion compensation. The performance gains achieved by both optimal motion estimation and optimal overlapped windows are demonstrated in simulations. Together, reductions of up to 30% in displaced frame difference energy are demonstrated compared with standard block motion compensation.
Index Keywords: Algorithms; Estimation; Image analysis; Image compression; Motion pictures; ROM; Vectors; Video recording; Video signal processing; Block motion compensation; Codecs; Motion compensation; Motion vectors; Overlapped blocks; Overlapped motion compensation; Video storage; Teleconferencing

Authors: Braun J.E.
Title: Comparison of chiller-priority storage-priority, and optimal control of an ice-storage system
Affiliations: Johnson Controls, Inc, Milwaukee, United States
Authors with affiliations: Braun, J.E., Johnson Controls, Inc, Milwaukee, United States
Abstract: This paper describes a comparison of control strategies for a partial ice-storage system installed in a office building located in Milwaukee, Wisconsin. Optimal control results for this system in terms of both minimum energy and demand charges were compared with simple chiller-priority and storage-priority control strategies. Chiller priority is common control method whereby storage is only used to match the difference between the building load and the maximum cooling capacity of the chillers. Although this control tends to minimize the use of storage for off-design days, it is easy to implement and there is a significant reduction in the annual peak electrical demand over conventional systems. Storage-priority strategies involve maximizing the use of storage during the on-peak electrical period. The storage-priority strategy that was investigates in this study is termed ″load-limiting″ and involves operating the chillers at a constant cooling rate during the on-peak period such that the storage is fully depleted (i.e., no ice) at the end of the on-peak period. Load-limiting control tends to minimize the cooling plant peak electrical power use, but it was also found to be nearly optimal in terms of energy costs with the presence of time-of-day electric rates. The chiller-priority strategy gave significantly greater demand and energy costs in the presence of time-of day rates for design days.
Index Keywords: Cooling towers; Heat exchangers; Pumps; Storage (materials); Valves (mechanical); Chiller priority strategy; Ice storage systems; Load limiting control; Storage priority strategy; Ice

Authors: Mord Allan J., Snyder Howard A.
Title: Flow impedance and different heat transport regimes in superfluid helium cooling systems for superconducting magnets
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Heat Transfer Division, (Publication) HTD
Affiliations: Ball Electro-Optics and Cryogenics, Div, Boulder, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mord, Allan J., Ball Electro-Optics and Cryogenics, Div, Boulder, United States; Snyder, Howard A., Ball Electro-Optics and Cryogenics, Div, Boulder, United States
Abstract: He II cooling systems can operate in three different regimes, depending on whether internal convection, forced convection, or both carry significant amounts of heat. Small line diameter and/or surface irregularities can limit the effectiveness of internal convection, and can therefore strongly affect the temperature rise between the magnet and the coolant supply. This is true for zero-flow systems that depend only on internal convection within the He II, as well for forced convection systems. Optimized systems that make use of both heat transfer mechanisms can be used to reduce refrigeration costs or to increase margin against magnet quench. Modeling results for a highly simplified system are presented to illustrate these principles for superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) magnets.
Index Keywords: Coolants; Cooling systems; Energy storage; Flow of fluids; Helium; Mathematical models; Superconducting magnets; Flow impedance; Forced convection; Internal convection; Superconducting magnetic energy storage; Superfluid helium; Heat convection

Authors: Antonopoulos K.A., Rogdakis E.D.
Title: Trifluoroethanol/N-Methylpyrrolidinone absorption heat pump for floor heating
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Advanced Energy Systems Division (Publication) AES
Affiliations: Natl Technical Univ of Athens, Athens, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Antonopoulos, K.A., Natl Technical Univ of Athens, Athens, Greece; Rogdakis, E.D., Natl Technical Univ of Athens, Athens, Greece
Abstract: A thermodynamic and thermal analysis is conducted for an energy system composed of a solar driven absorption heat pump using Trifluoroethanol (TFE) and N-Methylpyrrolidinone (NMP) as refrigerant and absorbent, respectively, and a floor heating unit composed of regularly spaced pipes imbedded in the floor of a building. Such systems may offer considerable energy savings because: (a) thermal comfort is obtained with lower temperatures owing to direct contact of people's feet with the heat source, (b) lower heating fluid temperatures are adequate owing to the available large heat exchange surfaces, and (c) heat storage within structural elements may decrease peak load. The analysis presented is based on developed analytic expressions for the thermodynamic properties of the TFE-NMP mixture in conjunction with a procedure which simulates the operation of the corresponding absorption heat pump and provides its exact thermodynamic cycle. The analysis is supplemented by a model which simulates the thermal behaviour of the floor containing the heating pipes. Predictions are presented for operation during the typical winter in the Athens area. Nomographs are also presented for selecting the floor pipe spacing which ensures best thermal matching between the floor and the heat pump. It is found that the theoretical heat gain factor varies from 150-170% and the maximum thermal power produced for 40°C mean floor temperature during November, January and March is 360, 250 and 500 W/m2-floor, respectively.
Index Keywords: Energy conservation; Floors; Heat transfer; Mathematical models; Nomograms; Pipe; Refrigerants; Thermoanalysis; Thermodynamics; Absorption heat pump; Floor heating; N-Methylpyrrolidinone (NMP); Trifluoroethanol (TFE); Heat pump systems

Authors: Takahashi Patrick, Kinoshita Charles, Oney Stephen, Vadus Joseph
Title: Facilitating technology for fuel production and energy-enhanced products
Source title: Ocean Energy Recovery - The State of the Art
Affiliations: Univ of Hawaii at Manoa, Honolulu, United States
Authors with affiliations: Takahashi, Patrick, Univ of Hawaii at Manoa, Honolulu, United States; Kinoshita, Charles, Univ of Hawaii at Manoa, Honolulu, United States; Oney, Stephen, Univ of Hawaii at Manoa, Honolulu, United States; Vadus, Joseph, Univ of Hawaii at Manoa, Honolulu, United States
Abstract: For offshore power production technologies such as ocean thermal energy conversion (OTEC) to prove competitive in the world energy market, energy storage media must be utilized to transfer this resource to areas of high energy consumption. This need has sparked interest in the development of transportable energy carriers and other products which take advantage of power produced by ocean energy conversion systems. Very few studies on facilitating technologies associated with ocean-based fuel production and energy-enhanced products have been performed in the past because the emphasis was on production. Ocean energy conversion systems have not yet reached the commercial stage, this option is on the verge of being utilized. This potential could be enhanced if ancillary products are synergistically developed. It is this integration that will make the development of ocean resource technologies economically viable in the future.
Index Keywords: Energy storage; Energy utilization; Gas fuels; Offshore power plants; Production; Energy enhanced products; Ocean based fuel production; Transportable energy carriers; Ocean thermal energy conversion

Authors: Baumann Philip D.
Title: Potential energy efficiency and conservation, economic, and environmental benefits from the implementation of superconducting magnetic energy storage
Source title: Proceedings of the American Power Conference
Affiliations: InterFact, Inc., Dallas, United States
Authors with affiliations: Baumann, Philip D., InterFact, Inc., Dallas, United States
Abstract: Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage (SMES) is a recent technology that has the capability to significantly improve electrical system operations within electric utility systems. The technology has already been demonstrated by Bonneville Power Administration in a 30-MJ SMES test demonstration unit (1). Savings in utility operations from improved system efficiency, increased reliability, and reduced maintenance requirements contribute to the economic justification of SMES. Beyond these benefits, there are additional benefits which in the long run may equal or outweigh the electrical operational benefits. These benefits are the energy conservation and environmental benefits. The technology has the capability of reducing fuel consumption which can in turn reduce emissions. In a regional setting it can shift emissions both in volumes and in physical. With its capability to strategically shift generation and significantly affect emissions and air quality it can ``stretch'' clean energy generation options, thus SMES can be seen as an energy and environmental management technology and tool.
Index Keywords: Applications; Costs; Electric energy storage; Energy storage; Renewable energy resources; Superconducting cables; Superconducting magnetic energy storage; Electric utilities

Authors: Rustad S., Sundsvold E.
Title: Trends in pump-turbine technology
Source title: International Water Power and Dam Construction
Affiliations: Kvaerner Energy, Oslo, Norway
Authors with affiliations: Rustad, S., Kvaerner Energy, Oslo, Norway; Sundsvold, E., Kvaerner Energy, Oslo, Norway
Abstract: Energy storage cycles of pumped-storage schemes vary from hours, such as at Dinorwic in Wales, to months, as at Ulla-Forre, Norway. Yet within this enormous range, the reversible machine still offers the most cost-effective installation, even though it operates less efficiently than a comparable separate pump and turbine. The author considers the implications of this inherent limitation, and discusses the engineering and testing that is involved in the manufacture of these machines. The article is based on a paper given by the author at the Pump Storage Symposium, which took place in Denver, USA, in July 1991.
