Authors: Moore G.A., Perlman M.
Title: Water-heating energy savings in commercial laundries
Affiliations: Ontario Hydro Research Division, Toronto, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Moore, G.A., Ontario Hydro Research Division, Toronto, Canada; Perlman, M., Ontario Hydro Research Division, Toronto, Canada
Abstract: A heat recovery system to reclaim energy from the exhaust products of commercial-sized laundry dryers and preheat the water used by the washing machines has been designed, built, and installed at a test site. Using two separate methods to reclaim heat, the system consists of a passive and active loop, each connected to a separate storage. The passive loop circulates water from the upstream storage directly through two sets of finless coils placed within the heat stream. Concurrently, the active loop circulates water from the downstream storage through the condenser section of a 5-kW heat pump that collects energy using an evaporator with large fin spacing. A computerized monitoring package has given preliminary results that indicate the passive and active loops supply approximately 35 % and 25 5, respectively, of the daily water-heating energy, while the electric resistance heaters, used as backup, provide the remainder. Overall hot water storage and distribution losses have been minimized to less than 3 %.
Index Keywords: Dryers (equipment); Energy utilization; Heat exchangers; Laundries; Waste heat utilization; Dryer exhaust heat recovery; Energy savings; Energy use patterns; Heat recovery systems; Hot water heating

Authors: Vasiliev L.L., Domorod L.S., Rabetsky M.I., Schirokov E.I.
Title: Residential heater with heat pipe and electric heat storage blocks
Affiliations: Acad of Sciences, Minsk, Belarus
Authors with affiliations: Vasiliev, L.L., Acad of Sciences, Minsk, Belarus; Domorod, L.S., Acad of Sciences, Minsk, Belarus; Rabetsky, M.I., Acad of Sciences, Minsk, Belarus; Schirokov, E.I., Acad of Sciences, Minsk, Belarus
Abstract: Residential heating using Electric Heat Storage Blocks is an actual problem nowadays with the point of view of heat recovery and nature protection. In Luikov Heat and Mass Transfer Institute a new residential electrical heating device (BETA) to heat chambers with controlling air temperature and heat output using heat pipes and electric heat storage block was developed. BETA is compact, has high thermal response, accurate air temperature control, and could be used for heating the residential and office buildings. This heating device is connected with the electric source of energy and during 7 hours of night time accumulate energy sufficient to heat 10 m2 during 17 h. Heating device BETA has ceramic (or cast iron) thermal storage blocks, electric heaters and heat pipe with evaporator inside of ceramic block and constant temperature finned condenser outside of it. The condenser temperature or heat flow could be easily controlled. Some results of experimental evaluation of temperature fields in different parts of BETA with predicted rate of heat generation into the heat store kernel and heat dissipation by heat pipe convector to the ambient media are discussed.
Index Keywords: Buildings; Heat losses; Heat pipes; Heat storage; Heat transfer; Space heating; Temperature control; Air temperature control; Electric heat storage blocks; Heat generation rate; Heat pipe convectors; Residential electrical heating devices (BETA); Thermal response; Electric heating elements

Authors: Fuetterer B., Lausterer G.K., Leibbrandt S.R.
Title: Improved unit dynamic response using condensate stoppage
Affiliations: Siemens AG, Karlsruhe, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Fuetterer, B., Siemens AG, Karlsruhe, Germany; Lausterer, G.K., Siemens AG, Karlsruhe, Germany; Leibbrandt, S.R., Siemens AG, Karlsruhe, Germany
Abstract: Large frequency deviations can cause users to be automatically disconnected (load shedding) from the primary electrical grid. Such disconnections can have serious consequences for the users of the electrical power grid. All power plant units involved in the grid frequency control must provide as fast as possible power to the grid in case of disturbances to the grid frequency. The activation of the necessary power is normally provided by fast opening of the turbine control valves. However the valves must be throttled in normal operation in order to be able to supply power in case of frequency disturbances. This causes a loss in efficiency. The use of the condensate stoppage technique in keeping the turbine control valve throttling to a minimum has proved to be successful. In this paper an expanded control concept is proposed, whereby not only in cases of frequency support but also in cases of large load changes the condensate stoppage technique is used. As a result the fuel over firing can be reduced, this in turn producing a smoother and more optimal firing. The testing of the new control concept was carried out on a nonlinear power plant model. The concept has been included in the control design of a coal fired power plant, which is scheduled for commissioning in 1992.
Index Keywords: Boiler firing; Computer simulation; Dynamic response; Electric energy storage; Electric frequency control; Electric load management; Electric load shedding; Mathematical models; Power control; Steam condensate; Steam turbines; Valves (mechanical); Condensate stoppage; Frequency deviations; Load ramping; Load shedding; Primary electrical grid; Valve throttling; Electric power systems

Authors: Conradie F.H., Kuerten H.
Title: Actual dynamic performance of thermal power plants with various designs and control systems
Affiliations: ESKOM, South Africa
Authors with affiliations: Conradie, F.H., ESKOM, South Africa; Kuerten, H., ESKOM, South Africa
Abstract: Fuel type, boiler and turbine designs, and also the overall unit control arrangements, have a significant effect on the response of thermal units to scheduled and unexpected demands imposed by the grid systems. Very often the load dispatcher is not aware of the real and momentary response capability of the units he has to commit to providing for short-term reserves. To quantify the governing factors and to provide the necessary data for the load dispatcher several measured response versus time curves were recorded and compiled by a CIGRE working group for various types and sizes of thermal units operating with various control strategies. The resulting data base can be utilized to support the development and evaluation of simplified mathematical models for use in on-line dispatching or operations planning studies. This paper presents characteristics in four categories, three of which are: utilization of stored energy provided in boiler or steam cycle, increased fuel flow and a combination of both. The fourth category of results focusses on the response capability in the first 15 seconds to illustrate the possible rate of reaction when immediate emergency power is required, particularly for small and/or island systems. The measured dynamic performance was compiled and analyzed for 32 fossil-fuelled power plants from seven countries. These include drum and once-through boilers in the 120-800 MW capacity range firing coal, oil or gas. The results of 41 stored energy tests, 51 fuel increase tests, 113 combination tests and 59 short-time (seconds-range) response tests illustrate the variety which was obtained with various plants and control configurations.
Index Keywords: Control systems; Data acquisition; Database systems; Dynamic response; Electric energy storage; Electric load management; Electric power generation; Mathematical models; Operations research; Strategic planning; CIGRE working groups; Fuel increase tests; Grid systems; Load dispatcher; On line dispatching; Short time response tests; Stored energy tests; Thermal power plants; Fossil fuel power plants

Abstract: In this paper a new control method for the economic providing of spinning reserve power is presented. The behaviour and efficiency of the control concept at realistic disturbances in an electrical power system are described as well as the reactions to the power system behaviour, in the case that all primary controlled steam power plants will apply the developed control design.

Authors: Canning T.O.M., McNamara F., Egan A., Naughton P.
Title: Novel stored energy techniques for spinning reserve
Affiliations: Electricity Supply Board, Dublin, Ireland
Authors with affiliations: Canning, T.O.M., Electricity Supply Board, Dublin, Ireland; McNamara, F., Electricity Supply Board, Dublin, Ireland; Egan, A., Electricity Supply Board, Dublin, Ireland; Naughton, P., Electricity Supply Board, Dublin, Ireland
Abstract: Ensuring security and quality of supply on small `island' power systems is costly and difficult. Consequently, there is an ever-present motivation to maintain and improve plant response to losses of generation infeed. This paper reports work which enhances conventional thermal plant's reserve capability to improve system performance and cost. Novel strategies of extracting reserve are proposed based on reducing the boiler drum level, steam temperatures and impedance to steam flow. Operational experimentation on these strategies is presented and it is seen that worthwhile gains are achievable in practice.

Abstract: Nonlinear problems in accelerator physics are reviewed. Theoretical tools and methods are introduced and discussed, and it is shown how these concepts can be applied to the study of various nonlinearities in storage rings. The first part treats Hamiltonian systems (proton accelerators) whereas the second part is concerned with explicitly stochastic systems (e.g. electron storage rings).

Authors: Handschin E., Stephanblome Th.
Title: New SMES control strategies as a link between network and power plant control
Affiliations: Univ of Dortmund, Dortmund, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Handschin, E., Univ of Dortmund, Dortmund, Germany; Stephanblome, Th., Univ of Dortmund, Dortmund, Germany
Abstract: Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storages (SMES) with a capacity of about a few 100 kWh becoming great interest with regard to an improved power system stability and a relieve of network control. This work survives the possibility to integrate a SMES into a power system according to operational requirements. Therefore two concepts for SMES control are taken in consideration. First a control scheme basing on frequency and bus-voltage as input signals for SMES control is investigated. Then a state space control basing on a coordinated control of SMES and synchronous generator is introduced and discussed by means of a first case study.

Authors: Suryanarayana P., Acharya H.N., Nicolau Y.F.
Title: Study of charge carrier trapping in solution-grown alpha -HgI2 crystals by thermally stimulated currents
Affiliations: SDA CEERI, Pilani, India
Authors with affiliations: Suryanarayana, P., SDA CEERI, Pilani, India; Acharya, H.N.; Nicolau, Y.F.
Abstract: alpha -HgI2 crystals grown in solution, crystals irradiated by X- or gamma -rays, crystals aged in air, crystals aged after being polarized in a high DC field, and crystals stored in an iodine atmosphere were studied by thermally stimulated currents (TSC). The general TSC spectrum of the crystals shows two peaks: at 170 and 230 K. X-ray irradiation generates deep-donor-type traps and decreases the lifetime of the charge carriers. gamma -ray irradiation introduces a large number of deep traps closely spaced in energy. By aging the crystals in air deep donor traps are introduced into a narrow layer close to the surface of the crystals. Crystals aged in air and polarized in a high DC field show a depletion of the concentration of the deep donor traps in the active zone close to the surface induced by the field. The storage of the crystals in an iodine atmosphere prevents their degradation by aging. Apparently iodine diffusion into the crystals suppresses the slight Hg-rich deviation from the stoichiometry in crystals.
Index Keywords: Mercury Iodide; Thermally Stimulated Currents; Gamma Rays; Mercury Compounds; Semiconductor Materials--Charge Carriers; X-Rays; Crystals

Authors: Schissel D.P., Kellman A.G., Snider R.T., Stambaugh R.D., Burrell K.H., Deboo J.C., Osborne T.H., Callen J.D., Chang Z.
Title: Examination of energy confinement in DIII-D at small values of the plasma safety factor
Affiliations: Gen. Atomics, San Diego, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schissel, D.P., Gen. Atomics, San Diego, CA, United States; Kellman, A.G., Gen. Atomics, San Diego, CA, United States; Snider, R.T., Gen. Atomics, San Diego, CA, United States; Stambaugh, R.D., Gen. Atomics, San Diego, CA, United States; Burrell, K.H., Gen. Atomics, San Diego, CA, United States; Deboo, J.C., Gen. Atomics, San Diego, CA, United States; Osborne, T.H., Gen. Atomics, San Diego, CA, United States; Callen, J.D.; Chang, Z.
Abstract: The effect on H-mode energy confinement of operating at low values of the plasma safety factor q has been investigated experimentally on the DIII-D tokamak (see Plasma Physics and Controlled Nuclear Fusion Research 1986 (Poroc. 11th Int. Conf. Kyoto, 1986), Vol.1, IAEA, Vienna (1987) 159). Operationally, the linear increase of H-mode energy confinement with plasma current ceases when the ratio of the plasma current to the toroidal magnetic field is high than approximately=1 MA/T. Experimentally, it has been determined that this saturation of confinement is not the result of a ceiling imposed by saturated Ohmic confinement, by the plasma reaching a toroidal beta limit, by enhanced plasma radiation or by edge localized modes. The observed saturation of confinement is found to be quantitatively consistent with a model of global energy confinement degradation resulting primarily from the macroscopic phenomena of sawteeth. The experimental data are also qualitatively consistent with an alternative explanation for the confinement saturation which involves enhanced transport brought about by ion temperature gradient driven turbulence.
Index Keywords: Control, Electric Variables - Current; Plasmas - Energy Storage; Tokamak Devices; DIII-D Tokamak; Energy Confinement; H Mode Plasma; Ohmic Confinement; Plasma Safety Factor; Toroidal Magnetic Field; Plasmas
