Authors: Rendell A.P., Lee T.J., Lindh R.
Title: Quantum chemistry on parallel computer architectures: coupled-cluster theory applied to the bending potential of fulminic acid
Affiliations: SERC Daresbury Laboratory, Warrington, WA4 4AD, United Kingdom; NASA Ames Research Center, Moffet Field, CA 94035, United States; Department of Theoretical Chemistry, University of Lund, P.O. Box 124, S-220 00 Lund, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Rendell, A.P., SERC Daresbury Laboratory, Warrington, WA4 4AD, United Kingdom; Lee, T.J., NASA Ames Research Center, Moffet Field, CA 94035, United States; Lindh, R., Department of Theoretical Chemistry, University of Lund, P.O. Box 124, S-220 00 Lund, Sweden
Abstract: We present a formulation of the singles and doubles coupled-cluster (CCSD) method suitable for distributed memory parallel computer architectures. Results from test calculations using up to 128 nodes of the Intel i860 hypercube are presented. Although the new algorithm is highly parallel, the asymptotic speed is quickly reached due to the input/output (IO) demands on the concurrent file system. To alleviate these IO problems, as well as disk storage requirements, we propose a "semi-direct" CCSD method whereby the atomic orbital integrals are evaluated in each iteration of the procedure in order to determine the contribution from certain terms. Using CCSD(T)/TZ2P optimized geometries, the calculations show that the Born-Oppenheimer groundstate potential energy surface yields a linear structure for fulminic acid, HCNO, in agreement with the semirigid bender analysis by Bunker, Landsberg and Winnewisser. © 1992.

Authors: van Langevelde F., Janssens K.H., Adams F.C., Vis R.D.
Title: Prediction of the optical characteristics and analytical qualities of an X-ray fluorescence microprobe at the European Synchrotron Radiation Facility (Grenoble)
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Centre for Micro- and Trace Analysis, Department of chemistry, University of Antwerp, Belgium; Department of Physics and Astronomy, Free University of Amsterdam, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: van Langevelde, F., Centre for Micro- and Trace Analysis, Department of chemistry, University of Antwerp, Belgium; Janssens, K.H., Centre for Micro- and Trace Analysis, Department of chemistry, University of Antwerp, Belgium; Adams, F.C., Centre for Micro- and Trace Analysis, Department of chemistry, University of Antwerp, Belgium; Vis, R.D., Department of Physics and Astronomy, Free University of Amsterdam, Netherlands
Abstract: The optical and analytical performance of an X-ray fluorescence microprobe at the European Synchrotron Radiation Facility (ESRF), Grenoble, France, in terms of attainable lateral resolution and minimum achievable detection limits is estimated. The design of the microprobe, which is based on the use of ellipsoidally bent crystals for focusing the X-ray beam, is outlined and the influence of design parameters such as the distance between storage ring and focusing device, excitation energy, excitation bandwidth and the use of pre-monochromators is discussed. Predictions of minimum achievable spot sizes and photon flux densities are obtained by means of a ray-tracing code. A planar plus ellipsoidal crystal combination is proposed as the optical system for the synchroton X-ray microprobe setup. At ESRF bending magnet, wiggler and undulator sources, typical spot size diameters in the range of, respectively, 2-7, 1-5 and 0.8-3 μm are predicted. At the dipole source, detection limits in the 1 ppm to 10 ppb range are calculated for optimal excitation conditions. © 1992.

Authors: Bulian N., Plaga R.
Title: A CAMAC timing module for the use with high energy resolution detectors
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Max Planck Institut für Kernphysik, P.O. Box 10 39 80, W-6900 Heidelberg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Bulian, N., Max Planck Institut für Kernphysik, P.O. Box 10 39 80, W-6900 Heidelberg, Germany; Plaga, R., Max Planck Institut für Kernphysik, P.O. Box 10 39 80, W-6900 Heidelberg, Germany
Abstract: A CAMAC module which measures event times with a resolution of 10 ns continuously over a period of 32.6 days has been built. The event times are stored in a deep buffer memory in form of 48-bit data words. The pulse amplitude of each event can be measured concurrently in a high resolution ADC and stored in another FIFO buffer memory. These amplitudes are tagged with a flag to correlate time with amplitude value unambiguously. In spite of the high operating frequency of 100 MHz necessitating the use of ECL counters, the module is compact (single-width) thanks to the use of TTL registers for the intermediate storage of the 48-bit time-word. The setup and testing of the modules with a NaI-pair spectrometer used in the GALLEX solar neutrino experiment is described. Other possible applications of the module in the field of non-accelerator particle physics are also mentioned. © 1992.

Authors: Wang X.-L., Suda S.
Title: Reaction kinetics of the mmni4.5al0.5-h system
Affiliations: Department of Chemical Engineering, Kogakuin University, 2665-1, Nakano-machi, Hachioji-shi, 192 Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Wang, X.-L., Department of Chemical Engineering, Kogakuin University, 2665-1, Nakano-machi, Hachioji-shi, 192 Tokyo, Japan; Suda, S., Department of Chemical Engineering, Kogakuin University, 2665-1, Nakano-machi, Hachioji-shi, 192 Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: The hydriding and dehydriding reaction kinetics of the aluminum-substituted mischmetal-nickel hydride were studied. The experiments were carried out by a step-wise method in the α and α+β phase regions in the temperature range from 303.2 to 333.2 K. The effects of the phase change on reaction characteristics were examined. The reaction was found to proceed differently between different phase regions for both the hydriding and dehydriding processes. The reaction order, rate constant, and apparent activation energy change with phase regions under isothermal conditions. However, those parameters are kept constant within a given phase region. © 1992.
Index Keywords: Chemical Reactions - Reaction Kinetics; Electric Batteries; Energy Conversion; Energy Storage; Hydrides; Activation Energy; Aluminum Substituted Mischmetal Nickel Hydrides; Dehydriding Processes; Hydriding Processes; Rate Constant; Reaction Order; Aluminum Compounds

Authors: Mandal P., Dutta K., Ramakrishna K., Sapru K., Srivastava O.N.
Title: Synthesis, characterization and hydrogenation behaviour of Mg-ξwt.%FeTi(Mn) and La2Mg17-ξwt.%LaNi5-new hydrogen storage composite alloys
Affiliations: Department of Physics, Banaras Hindu University, Varanasi, 221 005, India; Technology Innovation Products, Troy, MI 48098, United States; Department of Physics, Banaras Hindu University, Varanasi, 221 005, India
Authors with affiliations: Mandal, P., Department of Physics, Banaras Hindu University, Varanasi, 221 005, India; Dutta, K., Department of Physics, Banaras Hindu University, Varanasi, 221 005, India; Ramakrishna, K., Department of Physics, Banaras Hindu University, Varanasi, 221 005, India; Sapru, K., Technology Innovation Products, Troy, MI 48098, United States; Srivastava, O.N., Department of Physics, Banaras Hindu University, Varanasi, 221 005, India
Abstract: New hydrogen storage materials with higher capacity and better suited for applications have been successfully synthesized. The hydriding behaviour of the new composite materials, Mg-ξwt.%FeTi(Mn) and La2Mg17-ξwt.%LaNi5, were studied for various values of ξ (ξ = 10, 20, 30, 40 and 50). The Mg-ξ-%FeTi(Mn) materials were activated under a hydrogen atmosphere (about 33 kgf cm-2) and an optimum storage capacity of about 3.5 wt.% corresponding to room temperature hydrogenation was established for ξ=40. This high storage capacity-almost double the storage capacity of the well-known FeTi(Mn)-has been observed under ambient conditions. The La2Mg17-ξ-%LaNi6 materials were activated at higher temperatures (about 360 °C) in a hydrogen atmosphere. An optimum storage capacity of 4 wt.% in terms of pressure and composition was observed for La2Mg17-20%LaNi5 at 350 °C. In comparison with the native ingredient La2Mg17, much faster (nearly three times) kinetics were found. In order to understand the hydrogenation behaviour and the high storage capacity, structural-microstructural and chemical analyses of these composite materials were carried out. From the structural investigations it has been found that all the synthesized materials are multiphase. The composite material Mg-FeTi(Mn) was found to contain FeTi1-ξ1 magnesium, titanium and Ti-Mg phases. The higher storage capacity (about 3.5 wt.%) in the case of Mg-40%FeTi(Mn) is probably due to FeTi-Mg complexes. The hydrogen molecule is split at the FeTi surface and diffuses into the magnesium matrix via FeTi. In the case of La2Mg17-ξ%LaNi5, the composite material consists of La2Mg17, MgNi2, nickel and LaNi3 phases. Because of the presence of nickel and nickel-containing phases (e.g. Mg-Ni), it is assumed that the dissociation of hydrogen is easier and hence the system La2Mg17-ξ%LaNi5 has better kinetics than its counterpart La2Mg17 alone. © 1992.
Index Keywords: COMPOSITE MATERIALS; Energy Storage; Hydrogen - Storage; Lanthanum Magnesium Alloys - Characterization; Lanthanum Nickel Alloys - Hydrogenation; Magnesium Iron Titanium Alloys - Microstructure; Hydrogen Storage Materials; Storage Kinetics; Magnesium Iron Titanium Alloys

Authors: Burkel E.
Title: Inelastic X-ray scattering with high energy resolution - a new method for investigations of condensed matter
Source title: Physica B: Physics of Condensed Matter
Affiliations: Sektion Physik, University of Munich, W-8000 Munich, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Burkel, E., Sektion Physik, University of Munich, W-8000 Munich, Germany
Abstract: Inelastic X-ray scattering with high energy resolution has been developed as a new tool to investigate collective excitations in condensed matter. Energy transfers from 10 meV to 5 eV and wave vectors over the whole reciprocal space are accessible. The high energy resolution of 9 meV is achieved by extreme back reflection from perfect crystals at the instrument INELAX, which was recently installed at the storage ring at HASYLAB, Hamburg. © 1992.

Authors: Gnirb M., Wahl F.
Title: A Microscopic Theory of a Single Hydrogen Centre in a Magnesium Crystal*
Source title: Zeitschrift fur Naturforschung - Section A Journal of Physical Sciences
Affiliations: Institut für Theoretische Physik, Universität Tübingen, W-7030 Böblingen, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Gnirb, M., Institut für Theoretische Physik, Universität Tübingen, W-7030 Böblingen, Germany; Wahl, F., Institut für Theoretische Physik, Universität Tübingen, W-7030 Böblingen, Germany
Abstract: A microscopic theory of a single hydrogen center embedded in a magnesium crystal is presented. Starting with a many-particle Schrodinger equation, an adiabatic decoupling yields in an electronic system a protonic system and a host lattice system. The storage energy is defined to consist of an electronic part and lattice contributions. The electronic problem is treated with the help of a special energy difference procedure developed by Wahl et al. This procedure is applied in a higher approximation to calculate the electronic energy difference eigenvalue between a metal crystal with and without a hydrogen impurity. The lattice problem is treated in the classical harmonic approximation. © 1992, Walter de Gruyter. All rights reserved.

Authors: Artemenko S.N.
Title: Analysis of transient processes in SLED system
Authors with affiliations: Artemenko, S.N.
Abstract: The input and output of microwave energy in a SLED system are analyzed in detail by a scattering-matrix method. Analytic expressions are derived for the envelopes formed by the system of rf pulses that enter the load and supply the microwave generator. The dependences of the rf-power amplification of the system on the mismatch of the working frequencies and Q-factors of the storage resonators, their coupling factors with the rf supply circuits, the switching time of the supply-wave phase, and the phase difference of the waves in the waveguide channels of the resonators are determined. © 1993 Plenum Publishing Corporation.

Authors: Schütz G., Fischer P.
Title: Circularly polarized X-rays probing nuclear magnetic moments and magnetism of solids
Source title: Zeitschrift für Physik A Hadrons and Nuclei
Affiliations: Physik Department der TU München, Garching, W-8046, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Schütz, G., Physik Department der TU München, Garching, W-8046, Germany; Fischer, P., Physik Department der TU München, Garching, W-8046, Germany
Abstract: It is demonstrated how circularly polarized x-rays can be used in nuclear and solid state physics. Detection of the radiation pattern of circularly polarized x-rays emitted in highly converted decays of oriented radio isotopes allows the determination of nuclear magnetic moments. Studying the absorption profiles of energy-tunable intense circularly polarized x-rays emitted from high-energy electron storage rings provides a powerful method to determine spin structure of electronic states, local magnetic moments and magnetic short range order in ferromagnetic materials. © 1992 Springer-Verlag.

Authors: Barber Kenneth F.
Title: Overview of the DOE electric and hybrid vehicles program
Affiliations: U.S. Dept of Energy
Authors with affiliations: Barber, Kenneth F., U.S. Dept of Energy
Abstract: In the past year, the department of Energy's (DOE) Electrical Vehicle Program has undergone some significant adjustments in an effort to accomodate the rapid changes that are occuring in industry. The program has become much more focused and directed toward assissting industry in their efforts to move the technology from the laboratories into the market place. This paper overwiews the Electric and hybrid vehicles program.
Index Keywords: Electric batteries; Storage battery vehicles; Advanced battery consortium; Hybrid vehicles; Electric automobiles

Authors: Hsu Chung-Shih, Lee Wei-Jen
Title: Superconducting magnetic energy storage for power systems application
Source title: IEEE Conference Record of Industrial and Commercial Power Systems Technical Conference
Authors with affiliations: Hsu, Chung-Shih; Lee, Wei-Jen
Abstract: A survey of the technology for superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) is discussed. This technology is attractive in terms of its high efficiency and fast response, but the economic benefits are dubious. Research in the USA and Japan resulted in several conceptual designs for utility-scale SMES systems. Experiments on power system models proved that SMES systems offer other benefits in addition to energy storage. Economic evaluations showed that the SMES is competitive with pumped hydro, especially when the energy price increases. A power flow program was used to verify the application of a SMES plant to the Taiwan power system.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Mathematical Models; Superconductivity; Economic Evaluation; Power Flow Program; Power Systems Models; SMES Systems; Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage; Taiwan Power System; Electric Power Systems

Authors: Barraclough Scott
Title: Exploitation of coal bed methane
Affiliations: Nabarro Nathanson
Authors with affiliations: Barraclough, Scott, Nabarro Nathanson
Abstract: In the past coal bed methane has been largely overlooked, being perceived as unwanted, and potentially highly dangerous. But the recent recognition that it is one of the most potent of the greenhouse gases has forced the international mining industry to look again at the subject of methane. Scott Barraclough recounts the history of coal bed methane and reflects on its future potential.
Index Keywords: Coal mines; Energy storage; Environmental protection; Firedamp; Gas emissions; Gas hazards; Methane; Natural gas; Coal bed methane; Gas draining; Methane seepage; Energy resources

Authors: McLarnon Frank R., Kinoshita Kim, Cairns Elton J.
Title: Exploratory Technology Research Program overview
Affiliations: Lawrence Berkeley Lab, United States
Authors with affiliations: McLarnon, Frank R., Lawrence Berkeley Lab, United States; Kinoshita, Kim, Lawrence Berkeley Lab, United States; Cairns, Elton J., Lawrence Berkeley Lab, United States
Abstract: The general research topics addressed by the Exploratory Technology Research (ETR) Program include identification of new electrochemical couples for advanced batteries, determination of technical feasibility of the new couples, improvements in battery components and materials, establishment of engineering principles application to electrochemical energy storage and conversion, and the development of air-systems (fuel cells, metal/air) technology for transportation applications. This paper provides a brief description of the organization of the ETR Program, its goals, and highlights of the research projects. The major goal of the Exploratory Technology Research Program is to develop advanced rechargeable batteries and fuel cells for applications such as electric vehicles. The role of this program is to perform supporting research on advanced battery systems under development by the U.S. Advanced Battery Consortium, to improve the performance and durability of components used in fuel cell systems, and to evaluate new electrochemical systems with potentially superior performance, durability and/or cost characteristics. The Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory (LBL) plays a lead role in the management and coordination of activities in this program, which is divided into three elements: Exploratory Research, Applied Science Research and Air Systems Research. The program structure is shown in Fig. 1.
Index Keywords: Durability; Electric batteries; Electrolytic cells; Fuel cells; Lithium batteries; Electrochemical systems; Exploratory technology research program; High temperature cells; Electric vehicles

Authors: Hayashii H., Noguchi S., Fujiwara N., Iida N., Muramatsu K., Nagira T., Yoake Y., Nakajima M., Nishioka H., Ohkura M., Ikeda H., Tauchi T., Kawabata S.
Title: Performance of the TOPAZ forward calorimeter at the TRISTAN experiment
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Department of Physics, Nara Women's University, Nara, 630, Japan; KEK, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Tsukuba, Ibaraki, 305, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Hayashii, H., Department of Physics, Nara Women's University, Nara, 630, Japan; Noguchi, S., Department of Physics, Nara Women's University, Nara, 630, Japan; Fujiwara, N., Department of Physics, Nara Women's University, Nara, 630, Japan; Iida, N., Department of Physics, Nara Women's University, Nara, 630, Japan; Muramatsu, K., Department of Physics, Nara Women's University, Nara, 630, Japan; Nagira, T., Department of Physics, Nara Women's University, Nara, 630, Japan; Yoake, Y., Department of Physics, Nara Women's University, Nara, 630, Japan; Nakajima, M., Department of Physics, Nara Women's University, Nara, 630, Japan; Nishioka, H., Department of Physics, Nara Women's University, Nara, 630, Japan; Ohkura, M., Department of Physics, Nara Women's University, Nara, 630, Japan; Ikeda, H., KEK, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Tsukuba, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Tauchi, T., KEK, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Tsukuba, Ibaraki, 305, Japan; Kawabata, S., KEK, National Laboratory for High Energy Physics, Tsukuba, Ibaraki, 305, Japan
Abstract: We constructed a new forward calorimeter which covers a small polar angular region in the TOPAZ detector at the TRISTAN e+e- storage ring of KEK. It comprises large BGO crystals with a silicon photodiode readout system for energy measurements, and silicon strip detectors for position measurements. It has been operating since November 1989. We present detailed design considerations and the performance from test beam measurements and e+e- colliding beam experiments. We also show the results of luminosity measurements and discuss the systematic errors. © 1992.
Index Keywords: Accelerators - Storage Rings; Electronic Circuits; Instruments - Readout Systems; Radiation Detectors; TOPAZ Detector; TRISTAN Storage Ring; Calorimeters

Authors: Smith L.T., Powers J.M.
Title: Relative fit of new denture resins polymerized by heat, light and microwave energy.
Affiliations: Dental Branch, University of Texas Health Science Center at Houston.
Authors with affiliations: Smith, L.T., Dental Branch, University of Texas Health Science Center at Houston.; Powers, J.M., Dental Branch, University of Texas Health Science Center at Houston.
Abstract: This study compared in vitro the relative fit of seven denture resins polymerized by different methods to their gypsum casts. Relative fit in the molar-to-molar region of the resin bases on their stone casts was evaluated independently by five evaluators at three times (after processing, after polishing and after storage in water) and ranked using non-parametric statistics. The denture resins polymerized by microwave energy, (Acron MC), low heat, (Perform, 45 degrees C), and visible light, (Triad) fit better after polishing and after storage in water than those resins polymerized at higher temperatures (Lucitone 199, 74 degrees C and Accelar 20, Compak and Permacryl 20, 100 degrees C). The traditional heat-polymerized resin (Lucitone) had an average fit after storage in water.
Index Keywords: acrylic acid resin; article; chemistry; comparative study; dental care; denture; heat; light; microwave radiation; Acrylic Resins; Comparative Study; Dental Models; Denture Bases; Heat; Light; Microwaves

Authors: Hasselbach W., Migala A.
Title: Modulation by Ryanodine of Active Calcium Loading and Caffeine Induced Calcium Release of Heavy Sarcoplasmic Reticulum Vesicles
Source title: Zeitschrift fur Naturforschung - Section C Journal of Biosciences
Affiliations: Max-Planck-Institut für Medizinische Forschung, Abteilung Physiologie, Jahnstraße 29, D-W-6900 Heidelberg, Bundesrepublik Deutschland, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Hasselbach, W., Max-Planck-Institut für Medizinische Forschung, Abteilung Physiologie, Jahnstraße 29, D-W-6900 Heidelberg, Bundesrepublik Deutschland, Germany; Migala, A., Max-Planck-Institut für Medizinische Forschung, Abteilung Physiologie, Jahnstraße 29, D-W-6900 Heidelberg, Bundesrepublik Deutschland, Germany
Abstract: The effect of ATP on the calcium release channel in heavy sarcoplasmic reticulum vesicles modulated by ryanodine has been analyzed by monitoring active calcium uptake and caffeine induced calcium release under near physiological conditions. Native as well as ryanodine reacted vesicles display a complex time course of calcium uptake resulting in nearly complete exhaustion of medium calcium when ATP in combination with an ATP-regenerating system, in contrast to ATP alone, or dinitrophenyl phosphate, were used to support calcium uptake. Applying of dinitrophenyl phosphate as energy yielding substrate, not affecting channel activity, allowed to estimate the fraction of light vesicles devoided of calcium channels contaminating the heavy preparation as the fraction that stores calcium after the preparation has been treated with channel opening, low concentrations of ryanodine (1 μM). Calcium uptake by contaminant light vesicles (25%) cannot account for calcium storage, as well as, abolition of caffeine induced calcium release of ryanodine treated heavy vesicles. Calcium uptake of native and ryanodine treated vesicles is accompanied by the uptake of equivalent amounts of inorganic phosphate arising from ATP hydrolysis indicating that calcium is mainly stored as calcium phosphate. The momentary capability of the preparation to accumulate calcium was measured by activating calcium uptake during the calcium storage period with 0.2 mM 45CaCl2 and 4 mM phosphate at short time intervals. A significant increase of the momentary uptake activity with time was observed being more pronounced for ryanodine treated than for native vesicles indicating that under regenerating conditions, ATP can induce closing of the native and even more effectively of the ryanodine modified calcium release channels. © 1992, Walter de Gruyter. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Caffeine Induced Calcium Release; Ryanodine; Sarcoplasmic Reticulum

Authors: Weber J.-M.
Title: Pathways for oxidative fuel provision to working muscles: Ecological consequences of maximal supply limitations
Affiliations: Biology Department, University of Ottawa, 30 Marie Curie, Ottawa, K1N 6N5, Ontario, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Weber, J.-M., Biology Department, University of Ottawa, 30 Marie Curie, Ottawa, K1N 6N5, Ontario, Canada
Abstract: The study of metabolic fuel provision and its regulation has reached an exciting stage where specific molecular events can be correlated with parameters of the organism's ecology. This paper examines substrate supply pathways from storage sites to locomotory muscle mitochondria and discusses ecological implications of the limits for maximal flux through these pathways. The relative importance of the different oxidative fuels is shown to depend on aerobic capacity. Very aerobic, endurance-adapted animals such as long distance migrants favor the use of lipids and intramuscular fuels over carbohydrates and circulatory fuels. The hypothesis of functional co-adaptation between oxygen and metabolic fuel supply systems allows us to predict that the capacity of several biochemical processes should be scaled with maximal oxygen consumption. Key enzymes, transmembrane transporter proteins, glucose precursor supply and soluble fatty acid transport proteins must all be geared to support higher maximal glucose and fatty acid fluxes in aerobic than in sedentary species. © 1992 Birkhäuser Verlag.
Author Keywords: aerobic capacity; fatty acid; glucose; lactate; Metabolic substrates; migration; regulation

Authors: Swain S.D.
Title: Flight muscle catabolism during overnight fasting in a passerine bird, Eremophila alpestris
Affiliations: Department of Zoology and Physiology, University of Wyoming, Laramie, 82071, WY, United States
Authors with affiliations: Swain, S.D., Department of Zoology and Physiology, University of Wyoming, Laramie, 82071, WY, United States
Abstract: Brood-rearing passerine birds often have sparse lipid reserves coupled with potentially high energy demands. This may necessitate increased fasting protein catabolism; however, the largest source of protein, flight muscle, must be maintained. This problem was examined in the horned lark (Eremophila alpestris), a 28-g passerine. Overnight fasting caused significant depletion of protein in flight muscle and liver, but not in other muscle groups. Proteolytic enzyme activity of the flight muscle doubled during fasting. Biochemical and ultrastructural studies revealed that protein was depleted disproportionately from the sarcoplasm of flight muscle cells. Fasting caused a reduction in the protein-specific glycolytic capacity of flight muscle tissue. Oxidative capacity of the flight muscle, as measured by both in vivo and in vitro assays, was not significantly affected. The disproportionate catabolism of flight muscle sarcoplasmic protein may be due to a greater susceptibility to proteolysis, and not necessarily because it represents a source of redundant storage protein. © 1992 Springer-Verlag.
Author Keywords: Catabolism; Fasting; Muscle; Passerine birds, Eremophila alpestris; Protein

Authors: Abraizov M.G., Chaikovskii I.A.
Title: Effect of film history on the change in its properties under irradiation
Affiliations: Institute of Applied Physics, Kishinev, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Abraizov, M.G., Institute of Applied Physics, Kishinev, Russian Federation; Chaikovskii, I.A., Institute of Applied Physics, Kishinev, Russian Federation
Abstract: The pattern of change in material properties under irradiation depends both on the conditions of irradiation and on the films' initial state. In the present paper the effect of low energy (E = 4 keV) ion bombardment on the electrical properties of CrSiNi films, having different histories, is considered. The films were fabricated with the use of flash thermal evaporation under residual pressures of 2 × 10-3 and 9 × 10-3 Pa and evaporation times of 40-50 and 140-160 s. Some of the films before irradiation were annealed at a temperature of 623 K for 2 h. After annealing, the temperature coefficient of resistance (TCR) of the films shifts to the region of positive values, and the resistance weakly decreased or increased. After irradiation, the resistance of both type of initial film decreased, but the character of the resistance change of films annealed and irradiated after annealing depended on the conditions of deposition. The TCR of annealed films after irradiation shifted to the region of negative values. After storage, the resistivity of the films increased and the absolute value of the TCR decreased. A qualitative explanation of results is proposed. © 1992.

Authors: Clegg J.S., Jackson S.A.
Title: Aerobic heat shock activates trehalose synthesis in embryos of Artemia franciscana
Affiliations: University of California, Davis Bodega Marine Laboratory, Bodega Bay, CA 94923, United States
Authors with affiliations: Clegg, J.S., University of California, Davis Bodega Marine Laboratory, Bodega Bay, CA 94923, United States; Jackson, S.A., University of California, Davis Bodega Marine Laboratory, Bodega Bay, CA 94923, United States
Abstract: Encysted embryos (cysts) of the brine shrimp, Artemia franciscana, contain large amount of trehalose which they use as a major substrate for energy metabolism and biosynthesis for Development under aerobic conditions at 25°C. When cysts are placed at 42°C (heat shock) these pathways stop, and the cysts re-synthesize the trehalose that was utilized during the previous incubation at 25°C, Glycogen and glycerol, produced from trehalose at 25°C, appear to be substrates for trehalose synthesis during heat shock. Anoxia prevents trehalose synthesis in cysts undergoing heat shock. These results are consistent with the view that trehalose may play a protective role in cells exposed to heat shock, and other environmental insults, in addition to being a storage form of energy and organic carbon for development. © 1992.
Author Keywords: Glycerol, Artemia franciscana; Glycogen; Heat shock; Trehalose

Authors: Resch U., Esser N., Raptis Y.S., Richter W., Wasserfall J., Förster A., Westwood D.I.
Title: Arsenic passivation of MBE grown GaAs(100): structural and electronic properties of the decapped surfaces
Affiliations: Institut für Festkörperphysik der TU Berlin, Berlin, Germany; Physics Department, National Technical University Athens, Athens, Greece; Institut für Schicht- und Ionentechnik, KFA Jülich, Jülich, Germany; Physics Department, University of Wales College of Cardiff, Cardiff, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Resch, U., Institut für Festkörperphysik der TU Berlin, Berlin, Germany; Esser, N., Institut für Festkörperphysik der TU Berlin, Berlin, Germany; Raptis, Y.S., Physics Department, National Technical University Athens, Athens, Greece; Richter, W., Institut für Festkörperphysik der TU Berlin, Berlin, Germany; Wasserfall, J., Institut für Festkörperphysik der TU Berlin, Berlin, Germany; Förster, A., Institut für Schicht- und Ionentechnik, KFA Jülich, Jülich, Germany; Westwood, D.I., Physics Department, University of Wales College of Cardiff, Cardiff, United Kingdom
Abstract: The passivation properties and thermal stability of As on GaAs(100) were studied under ultra-high vacuum (UHV) conditions for As caps of different thicknesses and storage times in air. The As desorption was monitored by mass spectrometry (QMS) and the substrate surface quality by means of Auger electron spectroscopy (AES), electron diffraction (LEED) and Raman spectroscopy (RS). Additional desorption experiments were performed in an oven in N2 atmosphere. These samples were then investigated by spatially resolved Raman spectroscopy under atmospheric conditions. The Raman spectra of the air exposed samples show that the cap consists of an amorphous As layer with small As2O3 crystallites on top. AES investigations reveal in addition strong carbon contaminations. Arsenic desorption in UHV takes place in two steps, a first one at around 160°C which can be attributed to the desorption of the As2O3 crystallites and a second one at around 350°C due to the desorption of the amorphous As layer. From 360°C on with further increasing temperature (1 × 1) (2 × 4) and (4 × 1) reconstructions are observed by LEED. The band bendings at the surfaces as determined by Raman scattering were found to be not systematically related to the differently reconstructed surfaces. Residual carbon contaminations were found after Arsenic desorption in many cases, whereas the surfaces are always free of oxygen contaminations. © 1992.
Index Keywords: Arsenic; Crystal structure; Desorption; Electron spectroscopy; Electronic properties; Molecular beam epitaxy; Passivation; Surface properties; Decapped surfaces; Electron energy loss spectroscopy; Thermal desorption; Semiconducting gallium arsenide

Authors: Duś R., Nowicka E., Wolfram Z.
Title: Surface phenomena in titanium hydride formation
Affiliations: The Institute of Physical Chemistry, Polish Academy of Sciences, Kasprzaka 44/52, 01-224 Warsaw, Poland
Authors with affiliations: Duś, R., The Institute of Physical Chemistry, Polish Academy of Sciences, Kasprzaka 44/52, 01-224 Warsaw, Poland; Nowicka, E., The Institute of Physical Chemistry, Polish Academy of Sciences, Kasprzaka 44/52, 01-224 Warsaw, Poland; Wolfram, Z., The Institute of Physical Chemistry, Polish Academy of Sciences, Kasprzaka 44/52, 01-224 Warsaw, Poland
Abstract: Surface phenomena which occur during hydrogen interaction with thin titanium films within the pressure interval 10-10-10-2 Torr, at the temperature range 78-298 K, have been studied through measurement of surface potential changes by means of high sensitivity, short response time static capacitor system, with simultaneous recording of pressure by means of an ultra-sensitive Pirani-type gauge. At the beginning of adsorption negatively polarized adspecies stable on the surface, {A figure is presented} formed. With the increase of the population they are followed by the creation of positively polarized adspecies named β-. The β- adspecies are incorporated quickly below the surface forming percipitates of titanium hydride in a thin titanium film matrix. The activation energy for β+ adspecies incorporation has been estimated to be 6kJ/mol H2. On a titanium hydride surface, positively polarized, weakly adsorbed (Ed < 20 kJ/mol) hydrogen adspecies exist. © 1992.

Authors: Ribberfors R., Matscheko G.
Title: Measurements of high energy photon spectra of synchrotron radiation from a storage ring
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: Department of Physics and Measurement Technology, Theoretical Physics Division, Linköping University, S-58183 Linköping, Sweden; Department of Radiation Physics, Faculty of Health Sciences, Linköping University, S-58185 Linköping, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Ribberfors, R., Department of Physics and Measurement Technology, Theoretical Physics Division, Linköping University, S-58183 Linköping, Sweden; Matscheko, G., Department of Radiation Physics, Faculty of Health Sciences, Linköping University, S-58185 Linköping, Sweden
Abstract: A new method for measuring the photon fluences and polarization degree, in different points, from high energy synchrotron radiation has been developed. Radiation from a beam of photons was scattered under right angles in two independent directions and the scattered radiation was measured and deconvoluted in order to obtain information about the original spectra. The results agree very well with theoretical calculations using experimental parameters for the National Synchrotron Light Source (NSLS) at Brookhaven National Laboratory (BNL), USA. © 1992.

Authors: Wu H.-F., Brodbelt J.S.
Title: Effects of collisional cooling on ion detection in a quadrupole ion trap mass spectrometer
Source title: International Journal of Mass Spectrometry and Ion Processes
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, University of Texas, Austin, TX 78712-1167, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wu, H.-F., Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, University of Texas, Austin, TX 78712-1167, United States; Brodbelt, J.S., Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, University of Texas, Austin, TX 78712-1167, United States
Abstract: The effects of collisional cooling on the storage and detection of ions in a quadrupole ion trap mass spectrometer are examined. Four parameters that affect the storage of ions are evaluated: the pressure of the buffer gas: the qz value which establishes the ion trapping environment; the cooling time during which ions may collapse to the center of the trap; and the supplementary a.c. voltage used to kinetically excite selected ions. The ion trap may be operated effectively at a low helium pressure (0.1 mTorr) if a sufficient delay period is added to allow the diffuse ion cloud to collapse to the center of the trap prior to detection. For a typical experiment, this modified operation at low pressures involves allowing the ions to undergo approximately 30-100 collisions (i.e. in a ≈30 ms interval at 0.1 mTorr). At low helium pressures (≈0.1 mTorr), more ions may be trapped at higher qz values. Collision-activated dissociation (CAD) at low helium pressures indicates that the average internal energy deposition is higher, and sensitivity is not lost, if a collisional cooling delay is added. This latter result potentially has great analytical relevance for CAD of biomolecules which require greater internal energy deposition to induce fragmentation. © 1992.
Author Keywords: collision-activated dissociation; collisional cooling; ion detection.

Authors: Hiramoto K., Nishi M.
Title: An operating method to reduce damping time of betatron oscillations at beam injection in an electron storage ring
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, B
Affiliations: Energy Research Laboratory, Hitachi, Ltd., 1168 Moriyama-cho, Hitachi-shi, Ibaraki-ken, 316, Japan

Abstract: An operating method at beam injection in a compact electron storage ring system is presented for reduction of the damping time of horizontal betatron oscillations. Quadrupole magnets with large K values are introduced so as to increase the horizontal damping partition number and they are operated only during the beam injection. Application to low energy beam injection into an electron storage ring shows that the damping time of the betatron oscillations at beam injection can be reduced to about 1/8 of its value with the conventional operating scheme. © 1992.

Authors: Bellecci C., Conti M.
Title: Thermal energy storage in a porous medium: an entropy generation approach in a power production perspective
Affiliations: Dipartimento di Fisica, Università della Calabria, Rende, 87030, Italy; Dipartimento di Matematica e Fisica dell' Università, Camerino, 62032, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Bellecci, C., Dipartimento di Fisica, Università della Calabria, Rende, 87030, Italy; Conti, M., Dipartimento di Matematica e Fisica dell' Università, Camerino, 62032, Italy
Abstract: A numerical model is proposed to describe the transient behaviour of a porous bed thermal accumulator. Attention has been focused on power production applications where minimum entropy generation in the charge process has to be considered a leading design criterium. The model is solved and the influence of various design parameters on the performances of the storage system are analysed. © 1992 Società Italiana di Fisica.
Author Keywords: Heat capacities of solids; Solar radiation

Authors: Cantoni P., Frabetti P.L., Stagni L., Lanni F., Lo Bianco G., Maggi B., Palombo F., Sala A., Aulchenko V.M., Klimenko S.G., Kolachev G.M., Leontiev L.A., Onuchin A.P., Panin V.S., Pril Yu.V., Rodyakin V.A., Shamov A.G., Skovpen Yu.I., Tayursky V.A., Tikhonov Yu.A., Yurchenko V.I., Manfredi P.F., Re V., Speziali V.

Abstract: Results of the experimental measurement of space and energy resolutions of a liquid krypton (LKr) e.m. calorimeter are presented. A prototype has been exposed to a positron test-beam in the energy range 130-1300 MeV at the VEPP-3 storage ring. © 1992.

Authors: Usry J.L., Turner L.W., Bridges T.C., Nienaber J.A.
Title: Modeling the physiological growth of swine part III: heat production and interaction with environment
Source title: Transactions of the American Society of Agricultural Engineers
Affiliations: Univ of Kentucky, Lexington, United States
Authors with affiliations: Usry, J.L., Univ of Kentucky, Lexington, United States; Turner, L.W., Univ of Kentucky, Lexington, United States; Bridges, T.C., Univ of Kentucky, Lexington, United States; Nienaber, J.A., Univ of Kentucky, Lexington, United States
Abstract: Part 3 of this series presents the development and validation of the relationships used in the NCPIG computer model to simulate heat production and interaction with the thermal environment of growing swine. The model was developed to simulate transient, diurnal energy flows for growing pigs considering metabolic heat production, sensible and radiant heat gains and losses, latent heat losses and heat storage within the animal body. The relationships used in the model are described and the results of comparisons between predicted heat production and observed data for individually housed pigs are presented. The predicted and observed data were for crossbred gilts ranging in weight from 30-100 kg and for three levels of environmental temperature: lower critical temperature (LCT), LCT+5° C, and LCT-5° C. The simulated heat production values for the LCT experiment were within the observed mean minus one standard deviation while those for the LCT+5 and LCT-5 treatments were approximately one standard deviation above and below their respective means.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Heat transfer; Metabolism; Physiological models; Temperature distribution; Thermodynamics; Critical temperatures; Energy flows; Metabolic Heat production; NCPIG computer model; Physiological growth; Swine; Agricultural engineering

Authors: Yoneda Hajime
Title: Double-layer capacitors challenge secondary batteries
Affiliations: Matsushita Electronic Components Co, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Yoneda, Hajime, Matsushita Electronic Components Co, Japan
Abstract: Double-layer capacitors (which Matsushita sells as Gold Capacitors) frequently serve as backup power supplies for semiconductor memories. Recent advances in materials technology make it possible to manufacture double-layer capacitors with extremely low internal resistance and very large capacitance, so the range of uses for these products will widen significantly. Against this backdrop, Matsushita Electronic Components Co., Ltd. markets the Gold Capacitors AL-series of low-resistance, large-capacitance double-layer capacitors. The characteristics of these capacitors enables them to serve in previously untapped applications.
Index Keywords: Activated carbon; Electric batteries; Electrochemical electrodes; Electrolytic capacitors; Energy storage; Secondary batteries; Semiconductor devices; Gold Capacitors; Capacitors

Authors: Amendolia S.R., Galeotti S., Morsani F., Passuello D., Ristori L., Turini N.

Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, A
Affiliations: INFN, Pisa, Italy; University and INFN of Catania, Italy; University of Sassari, Italy; University and INFN of Bologna, Italy

Abstract: An associative memory to be used for super-fast track finding in future high energy physics experiments, has been implemented on silicon as a full-custom CMOS VLSI chip (the AMchip). The first prototype has been designed and successfully tested at INFN in Pisa. It is implemented in 1.6 μm, double metal, silicon gate CMOS technology and contains about 140 000 MOS transistors on a 1 × 1 cm2 silicon chip. © 1992.
Index Keywords: Data Storage Units - Applications; Integrated Circuits, CMOS - Design; Integrated Circuits, VLSI - Design; Associative Memory; CMOS VLSI Chips; Silicon Chip; Track Finding; Particle Detectors

Authors: Ewing Ronald I., Bierman Sidney R.
Title: Measurement techniques for verifying burnup
Source title: JNMM, Journal of the Institute of Nuclear Materials Management
Affiliations: Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ewing, Ronald I., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States; Bierman, Sidney R., Sandia Natl Lab, Albuquerque, United States
Abstract: Measurements of the nuclear radiation from spent reactor fuel are being considered to qualify assemblies for loading into casks that will be used to transport spent fuel from utility sites to a federal storage facility. To ensure nuclear criticality safety, the casks are being designed to accept assemblies that meet restrictions as to burnup, initial enrichment and cooling time. Measurements could be used to ensure that only fuel assemblies that meet the restrictions are selected for loading. The 'Fork' measurement system, designed at Los Alamos National Laboratory and used by the International Atomic Energy Agency to verify burnup and age in international safeguards applications, is being investigated for this application.
Index Keywords: Containers; Legislation; Radioactive Wastes--Storage; Transportation; Fuel Burnup; Nuclear Criticality Safety; Nuclear Reactors

Authors: Holness Gordon V.R.
Title: Combined chilled water thermal energy storage and fire protection storage systems
Affiliations: Albert Kahn Associates, Detroit, United States
Authors with affiliations: Holness, Gordon V.R., Albert Kahn Associates, Detroit, United States
Abstract: The re-emergence of thermal storage as a significant energy cost saving technology can be expected to continue as utility companies struggle to meet consumer energy needs without constructing new power plants. At the same time, the need for reliable water supplies for fire protection service can be expected to grow, with the requirement for sprinkler systems now imposed on most new construction. In many instances, particularly in rural areas, on-site fire protection water storage is required where local water supplies are inadequate for fire service. These trends create an obvious opportunity for combined technology: the use of chilled water thermal storage for fire protection service. This article addresses the issues involved in integrating these systems and uses a recently completed truck assembly plant in South Carolina to illustrate the concept.
Index Keywords: Cooling; Energy Conservation; Fire Protection; Sprinkler Systems (Fire Fighting); Water Supply; Chilled Water Storage; Energy Cost Savings; Integrated Systems Design; Thermal Energy Storage; Truck Assembly Plant; Water Tanks

Authors: Tuzhikov A.A.
Title: Rational use of propellor mixers
Source title: Glass and Ceramics (English translation of Steklo i Keramika)
Authors with affiliations: Tuzhikov, A.A.
Abstract: Propellor mixers are used in electrical porcelain factories for preparing slips by blunging the plastic materials (clays and kaolins) and the returned scrap (porcelain trimmings), and also for mixing the prepared suspensions in order to maintain their uniformity during storage and use. To cut labor and energy costs it is necessary to employ mixers with satisfactory technical performance and to use them rationally. An outline of a modern propellor mixer is shown.
Index Keywords: Ceramic Materials--Mixing; Electric Insulating Materials--Ceramic; Mixers--Design; Homogenization; Porcelain Insulators; Slips; Electric Insulators

Authors: Bridges T.C., Turner L.W., Stahly T.S., Usry J.L., Loewer O.J.
Title: Modeling the physiological growth of swine part I: model logic and growth concepts
Source title: Transactions of the American Society of Agricultural Engineers
Affiliations: Univ of Kentucky, Lexington, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bridges, T.C., Univ of Kentucky, Lexington, United States; Turner, L.W., Univ of Kentucky, Lexington, United States; Stahly, T.S., Univ of Kentucky, Lexington, United States; Usry, J.L., Univ of Kentucky, Lexington, United States; Loewer, O.J., Univ of Kentucky, Lexington, United States
Abstract: This article is Part 1 in a series of three articles describing the computer model (NCPIG) that was developed to simulate the physiological growth of swine. The methods and techniques used to simulate the interaction of feed intake and the various metabolic processes for the growing swine are presented. These processes include nutrient digestion, nutrient storage in the blood, body maintenance, lean mass growth, excess fat growth, and waste and urine production. Animal heat production and thermal energy balance is described in Part 3 of this series. The model was shown to provide reasonable predictions of the empty body weights used to develop the supporting body component growth curves.
Index Keywords: Computer simulation; Mathematical models; Metabolism; Physiological models; Body weights; Feed intake; Growth curves; Metabolic processes; Model logic; Physiological growth; Swine; Agricultural engineering

Authors: Kohyama K., Nishinari K., Yoshida M.
Title: Rheological Study on Gelation of Soybean 11S Protein by Glucono-δ-Lactone
Source title: Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry
Affiliations: National Food Research Institute, Kannondai, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Kanagawa Prefectural Institute of Agriculture, Teradanawa, Hiratsuka, Kanagawa 259-12, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kohyama, K., National Food Research Institute, Kannondai, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Nishinari, K., National Food Research Institute, Kannondai, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan; Yoshida, M., Kanagawa Prefectural Institute of Agriculture, Teradanawa, Hiratsuka, Kanagawa 259-12, Japan
Abstract: Dynamic viscoelasticity studies on gelation of soybean 11S protein by glucono-δ-lactone have been done to analyze the gelation process of tofu. Observed gelation curves at constant temperatures were well approximated by first-order reaction kinetics. The saturated storage modulus depended mainly on the concentration of 11S protein. The saturated modulus was proportional to 3.4th power of 11S concentrations. The rate constant of the gelation increased with increasing gelling temperature and was mainly governed by the concentration of glucono-6-lactone. The activation energy of the gelation was calculated to be 1.5 × 101 kJ/mol from an Arrhenius plot of the rate constants. The latent time at which the shear modulus began to deviate from the baseline became shorter with increasing concentration of glucono-δ-lactone. However, the latent time was not shortened by an increase in protein concentration, in contrast to previous findings for many other protein gels. © 1992, American Chemical Society. All rights reserved.

Authors: Perov P.I., Ermakov M.G., Ermakova O.N., Polyakov V.I., Elinson V.M., Sleptsov V.V., Gerasimovich S.S.
Title: Nonlinear parametric element using a diamond-like carbon film as the accumulation medium
Affiliations: Institute of Radio Engineering and Electronics, Russian Academy of Sciences, 18 Marx Avenue, 103907 Moscow, Russian Federation; NPO Vakuummashpribor, Nagornyi pr. 7, 113105 Moscow, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Perov, P.I., Institute of Radio Engineering and Electronics, Russian Academy of Sciences, 18 Marx Avenue, 103907 Moscow, Russian Federation; Ermakov, M.G., Institute of Radio Engineering and Electronics, Russian Academy of Sciences, 18 Marx Avenue, 103907 Moscow, Russian Federation; Ermakova, O.N., Institute of Radio Engineering and Electronics, Russian Academy of Sciences, 18 Marx Avenue, 103907 Moscow, Russian Federation; Polyakov, V.I., Institute of Radio Engineering and Electronics, Russian Academy of Sciences, 18 Marx Avenue, 103907 Moscow, Russian Federation; Elinson, V.M., NPO Vakuummashpribor, Nagornyi pr. 7, 113105 Moscow, Russian Federation; Sleptsov, V.V., NPO Vakuummashpribor, Nagornyi pr. 7, 113105 Moscow, Russian Federation; Gerasimovich, S.S., NPO Vakuummashpribor, Nagornyi pr. 7, 113105 Moscow, Russian Federation
Abstract: Measurements were made of current-voltage, capacity-voltage and charge-transient characteristics including Q-DLTS spectra for structures having thin (10 to 103 Å) films of diamond-like carbon on Si and GaAs substrates. A memory storage effect resulting from the capture of injected charge carriers on localized defect states in thin diamond-like carbon films has been observed. Dependence of information charge storage time on temperature, intensity and energy of the illumination as well as the captured charge magnitude on the amplitude and duration of the injecting voltage pulse were determined. The possibility of using the manufactured structures as reversible dynamic memory devices, nonlinear parametric elements, and sensitive photosensors have been demonstrated. © 1992.

Authors: Griesmann U., Baig M.A., Ahmad S., Kaenders W.G., Esser B., Hormes J.
Title: Photoionization cross sections of doubly excited resonances in ytterbium
Source title: Journal of Physics B: Atomic, Molecular and Optical Physics
Affiliations: Physikalisches Institut der Universität Bonn, Nußallee 12, Bonn 1, W-5300, Germany; Atomic and Molecular Physics Laboratory, Department of Physics, Quaid-i-Azam University, Islamabad, Pakistan
Authors with affiliations: Griesmann, U., Physikalisches Institut der Universität Bonn, Nußallee 12, Bonn 1, W-5300, Germany; Baig, M.A., Atomic and Molecular Physics Laboratory, Department of Physics, Quaid-i-Azam University, Islamabad, Pakistan; Ahmad, S., Atomic and Molecular Physics Laboratory, Department of Physics, Quaid-i-Azam University, Islamabad, Pakistan; Kaenders, W.G., Physikalisches Institut der Universität Bonn, Nußallee 12, Bonn 1, W-5300, Germany; Esser, B., Physikalisches Institut der Universität Bonn, Nußallee 12, Bonn 1, W-5300, Germany; Hormes, J., Physikalisches Institut der Universität Bonn, Nußallee 12, Bonn 1, W-5300, Germany
Abstract: The authors report measurements of doubly excited resonances in the ground-state photoionization spectrum of ytterbium using the monochromatized synchrotron radiation from the DORIS II storage ring at HASYLAB and a thermionic diode detector. Their measurements cover the J=1’ spectrum between 48000 and 80000 cm-1. It was possible to observe the doubly excited resonances at a much improved signal-to-noise ratio and the error in the cross section is estimated to be about 10%. The photoionization cross section is dominated by strongly autoionizing resonances which are interpreted as members of the doubly excited Rydberg series built on the 4f14 5d (2D32/, 5/2) and 4f14 6p(2P1/2, 3/2) parent ion configurations. Lifetimes, shape parameters and resonance energies of the broad overlapping resonances which belong to the (Xe)4f14 5d6p configuration were extracted from the photoionization cross sections using a relation derived by Mies (1968). © 1992 IOP Publishing Ltd.

Authors: Suter P.M., Schutz Y., Jequier E.
Title: The effect of ethanol on fat storage in healthy subjects
Affiliations: Institute of Physiology, Faculty of Medicine, University of Lausanne, Lausanne, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Suter, P.M., Institute of Physiology, Faculty of Medicine, University of Lausanne, Lausanne, Switzerland; Schutz, Y., Institute of Physiology, Faculty of Medicine, University of Lausanne, Lausanne, Switzerland; Jequier, E., Institute of Physiology, Faculty of Medicine, University of Lausanne, Lausanne, Switzerland
Abstract: Ethanol can account for up to 10 percent of the energy intake of persons who consume moderate amounts of ethanol. Its effect on energy metabolism, however, is not known. We studied the effect of ethanol on 24-hour substrate-oxidation rates in eight normal men during two 48-hour sessions in an idirect-calorimetry chamber. In each session, the first 24 hours served as the control period. On the second day of one session, an additional 25 percent of the total energy requirement was added as ethanol (mean [±SD], 96±4 g per day); during the other session, 25 percent of the total energy requirement was replaced by ethanol, which was isocalorically substituted for lipids and carbohydrates. Both the addition of ethanol and the isocaloric substitution of ethanol for other foods reduced 24-hour lipid oxidation. The respective mean (±SE) decreases were 49.4±6.7 and 44.1 ±9.3 g per day (i.e., reductions of 36±3 percent and 31 ±7 percent from the oxidation rate during the control day; P<0.001 and P<0.0025). This effect occurred only during the daytime period (8:30 a.m. to 11:30 p.m.), when ethanol was consumed and metabolized. Neither the addition of ethanol to the diet nor the isocaloric substitution of ethanol for other foods significantly altered the oxidation of carbohydrate or protein. Both regimens including ethanol produced an increase in 24-hour energy expenditure (7±1 percent with the addition of ethanol, P<0.001; 4±1 percent with the substitution of ethanol for other energy sources, P<0.025). Ethanol, either added to the diet or substituted for other foods, increases 24-hour energy expenditure and decreases lipid oxidation. Habitual consumption of ethanol in excess of energy needs probably favors lipid storage and weight gain. (N Engl J Med 1992;326: 983–7.). © 1992, Massachusetts Medical Society. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: alcohol; carbohydrate; fat; protein; adult; aerobic metabolism; alcohol metabolism; alcohol oxidation; article; caloric intake; calorimetry; controlled study; energy expenditure; human; human experiment; lipid oxidation; lipid storage; male; normal human; priority journal; weight gain; Adult; Calorimetry, Indirect; Dietary Carbohydrates; Dietary Proteins; Energy Intake; Energy Metabolism; Ethanol; Exertion; Human; Lipids; Male; Oxidation-Reduction; Weight Gain

Authors: Meyer H.O., Horowitz C., Nann H., Pancella P.V., Pate S.F., Pollock R.E., Von Przewoski B., Rinckel T., Ross M.A., Sperisen F.
Title: Total cross section for p+p→p+p+π0 close to threshold
Affiliations: Department of Physics, Indiana University, Indiana University Cyclotron Facility, Bloomington, IN 47405, United States
Authors with affiliations: Meyer, H.O., Department of Physics, Indiana University, Indiana University Cyclotron Facility, Bloomington, IN 47405, United States; Horowitz, C., Department of Physics, Indiana University, Indiana University Cyclotron Facility, Bloomington, IN 47405, United States; Nann, H., Department of Physics, Indiana University, Indiana University Cyclotron Facility, Bloomington, IN 47405, United States; Pancella, P.V., Department of Physics, Indiana University, Indiana University Cyclotron Facility, Bloomington, IN 47405, United States; Pate, S.F., Department of Physics, Indiana University, Indiana University Cyclotron Facility, Bloomington, IN 47405, United States; Pollock, R.E., Department of Physics, Indiana University, Indiana University Cyclotron Facility, Bloomington, IN 47405, United States; Von Przewoski, B., Department of Physics, Indiana University, Indiana University Cyclotron Facility, Bloomington, IN 47405, United States; Rinckel, T., Department of Physics, Indiana University, Indiana University Cyclotron Facility, Bloomington, IN 47405, United States; Ross, M.A., Department of Physics, Indiana University, Indiana University Cyclotron Facility, Bloomington, IN 47405, United States; Sperisen, F., Department of Physics, Indiana University, Indiana University Cyclotron Facility, Bloomington, IN 47405, United States
Abstract: Making use of an electron-cooled beam in the IUCF storage ring, we have measured the total cross section σtot for pp→ppπ0 at 31 bombarding energies between 285 and 325 MeV. At a level of about 5%, the data show no fluctuations that could be associated with the onset of other pion production channels. A calculation of the single-partial-wave cross section σss, including direct production only (no rescattering), falls short of the experiment by a factor of 5.2±0.3, but reproduces the observed energy dependence when scaled. This energy dependence is explained by contributions from the phase-space factor and the final-state interaction between the outgoing nucleons. The relative importance of higher partial waves is deduced from the energy dependence of σtot as well as from the angular distributions of reaction protons. © 1992.
Author Keywords: Nuclear reaction

Authors: Ulman A., Evans S.D., Shnidman Y., Sharma R., Eilers J.E.
Title: Mixed alkanethiol monolayers on gold surfaces: Wetting and stability studies
Source title: Advances in Colloid and Interface Science
Affiliations: Corporate Research Laboratories, Information and Computer Technologies Division, Manufacturing Research and Engineering Organization, Rochester, NY 14650-2109, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ulman, A., Corporate Research Laboratories, Information and Computer Technologies Division, Manufacturing Research and Engineering Organization, Rochester, NY 14650-2109, United States; Evans, S.D., Corporate Research Laboratories, Information and Computer Technologies Division, Manufacturing Research and Engineering Organization, Rochester, NY 14650-2109, United States; Shnidman, Y., Corporate Research Laboratories, Information and Computer Technologies Division, Manufacturing Research and Engineering Organization, Rochester, NY 14650-2109, United States; Sharma, R., Corporate Research Laboratories, Information and Computer Technologies Division, Manufacturing Research and Engineering Organization, Rochester, NY 14650-2109, United States; Eilers, J.E., Corporate Research Laboratories, Information and Computer Technologies Division, Manufacturing Research and Engineering Organization, Rochester, NY 14650-2109, United States
Abstract: Studies of wetting and stability of mixed monolayers containing hydrophobie and hydrophilic components are discussed. We are reporting the observation of an apparent concentration-driven transition in the cosine of the contact angles of liquids on mixed monolayers. It is suggested that this phenomenon is due to a possible (true or rounded) surface phase transition, resulting in the formation of a prewetting water layer. This formation is triggered by variations in the quenched distribution of random surface fields. The variation of the surface free-energy, both polar and dispersive parts, has been determined as a function of surface OH-concentration. The surface free-energy of the 100% OH surface is close to that found for water, as might be expected for a surface coated with several monolayers of water. Zisman plots obtained for several of the surfaces using polar and nonpolar liquids give γc values which follow the observed dispersive contribution to the total surface free energy, and thus do not present a good approximation to the surface free energy (i.e., γc < γsv). Contact angle variation was studied on self-assembled alkanethiol monolayers containing mixtures of OH and CH3 groups at their air-monolayer interface. It was found that these high free energy organic surfaces yielded contact angles which were not stable over long periods of time. The extent of the variation was found to be related to the surface free energy (%OH). The effect of different storage environments and temperature on the changing contact angles are discussed. We propose that monolayer surfaces containing high concentrations of OH groups on mobile organic chains are not stable. Such monolayer surfaces may stabilize over time, depending on the chain length, by surface reorganization and the adsorption of contaminants. © 1992.
Index Keywords: Alcohols - Adsorption; Gold and Alloys - Surfaces; Mathematical Statistics - Monte Carlo Methods; Solids - Surfaces; Energy Minimization; Monte Carlo Simulation; Surface Free Energy; Surface Potentials; Water Contact Angle; Surfaces

Title: SO(A 3Π ← X 3Σ-) saturation by narrow and broadband KrF excitation
Affiliations: U.C. Davis and Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, P.O. Box 808, L-395, Livermore, CA 94550, USA, United States; Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, P.O. Box 808, L-490, Livermore, CA 94550, USA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Stuart, B.C., U.C. Davis and Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, P.O. Box 808, L-395, Livermore, CA 94550, USA, United States; Cameron, S.M., U.C. Davis and Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, P.O. Box 808, L-395, Livermore, CA 94550, USA, United States; Powell, H.T., Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, P.O. Box 808, L-490, Livermore, CA 94550, USA, United States
Abstract: We have investigated the saturation of SO(A-X) excitation and the photodissociation of SOCl2 with both narrow and broadband KrF laser emission. The measured SO(A-X) absorption saturation fluences determine the efficiency of SO(A) excitation, with possible applications to an ultraviolet energy storage laser. We see no evidence of excited state absorption at the KrF laser pump wavelength. © 1992.

Authors: Seydack A.H.W., Bigalke R.C.
Title: Nutritional ecology and life history tactics in the bushpig (Potamochoerus porcus): Development of an interactive model
Affiliations: Department of Environment Affairs (Forestry), Private Bag X12, Knysna, 6570, South Africa; Faculty of Forestry, University of Stellenbosch, 7600, South Africa
Authors with affiliations: Seydack, A.H.W., Department of Environment Affairs (Forestry), Private Bag X12, Knysna, 6570, South Africa, Faculty of Forestry, University of Stellenbosch, 7600, South Africa; Bigalke, R.C., Department of Environment Affairs (Forestry), Private Bag X12, Knysna, 6570, South Africa, Faculty of Forestry, University of Stellenbosch, 7600, South Africa
Abstract: A study of the ecology of the bushpig (Potamochoerus porcus) showed that there were regional differences in relative investments made in reproduction and maintenance. Southern Cape populations had relatively low reproductive rates, but levels of energy storage and survival rates were high. The reverse applied to eastern Cape populations. The diets of the two populations differed, with a higher ratio of available production nutrients (NPK) to maintenance nutrients (C) in the eastern Cape. A life history model is developed which accommodates these regional differences by linking nutritional characteristics of the diet with metabolic turnover rates. According to this model, the rate of reproductive investment (number of viable young per unit of time) relative to somatic investment (energy storage, survival) is determined by the rate at which production nutrients (NPK) are procurable. For herbivorous animals this depends on the rate at which the nutrients are available to their food plants, which in turn is linked to soil fertility and thus to the geological parent material. © 1992 Springer-Verlag.
Author Keywords: Life history tactics; Metabolic turnover; Nutrient availability; Potamochoerus porcus
Index Keywords: bushpig; life history; nutrient; South Africa, Cape Province; Potamochoerus porcus

Authors: N'soukpoé-Kossi C.N., Trottier C., Achi C.A., Charlebois D., Leblanc R.M.
Title: Effects of Acid Watering of the Soil on the Photosynthetic Activity, Growth, and Foliar Pigments of Sugar Maple Saplings
Source title: Journal of Environmental Science and Health. Part A: Environmental Science and Engineering and Toxicology
Affiliations: Centre de Recherche en Photobiophysique, Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières, 3351, Boul. des Forges, C.P. 500, Trois-Rivières, Québec, G9A 5H7, Canada
Authors with affiliations: N'soukpoé-Kossi, C.N., Centre de Recherche en Photobiophysique, Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières, 3351, Boul. des Forges, C.P. 500, Trois-Rivières, Québec, G9A 5H7, Canada; Trottier, C., Centre de Recherche en Photobiophysique, Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières, 3351, Boul. des Forges, C.P. 500, Trois-Rivières, Québec, G9A 5H7, Canada; Achi, C.A., Centre de Recherche en Photobiophysique, Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières, 3351, Boul. des Forges, C.P. 500, Trois-Rivières, Québec, G9A 5H7, Canada; Charlebois, D., Centre de Recherche en Photobiophysique, Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières, 3351, Boul. des Forges, C.P. 500, Trois-Rivières, Québec, G9A 5H7, Canada; Leblanc, R.M., Centre de Recherche en Photobiophysique, Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières, 3351, Boul. des Forges, C.P. 500, Trois-Rivières, Québec, G9A 5H7, Canada
Abstract: Photoacoustic spectroscopy has been used to monitor the photosynthetic activity of the leaves of sugar maple saplings treated by watering the soil with simulated acid rain at different pH levels (2.5,3.0,3.5,4.0,4.5,5.0 and 5.6). We also measured the relative growth rate of the plants and the pigment content of leaves. The results indicated an ambivalent effect of acidity: there was a linear decline (r = 0.92) in the photosynthetic O2 evolution as the pH of the simulated rain was lowered from 5.6 to 3.0 and a jump when it reached 2.5, with a stimulation effect on the relative growth rate at lower pH levels. The photochemical energy storage and the relative growth rate increased from pH 5.6 to pH 4.04.5, then decreased at pH 3.0 and increased again at pH 2.5. The pattern of variation of the photochemical energy storage was fairly well correlated with the pigment content of the leaves (r = 0.83). It was concluded that acid rain preferentially affects photosystem II (FSII), inhibiting O2 evolution, and less PSI. The difference between O2 evolution and photochemical energy storage was explained in connection with cyclic electron transport around photosystem I (PSI). © 1992, Taylor & Francis Group, LLC. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Acids--Environmental Impact; Air Pollution--Acid Rain; Biomass--Photosynthesis; Rain and Rainfall--Simulation; Biomass Growth; Foliar Pigments; Sugar Maple Saplings; Biomass; rain; article; energy metabolism; ph; photosynthesis; plant growth; soil

Authors: Kevan L.
Title: Applications of electron spin echo spectroscopy to location control of alkylphenothiazine derivatives in photoinduced charge separation across vesicles, micelles and reverse micelle interfaces
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, University of Houston, Houston, TX 77204-5641, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kevan, L., Department of Chemistry, University of Houston, Houston, TX 77204-5641, United States
Abstract: The efficiency of photoinduced charge separation across surfactant interfaces of micelles and vesicles depends in part on the location of electron donors and acceptors relative to the interface. Achievement and assessment of control of such location by the addition of pendant alkyl chains to donors and acceptors is shown to be achievable. The net photoionization efficiency can be measured by electron spin resonance of radical ions in frozen surfactant solutions. Assessment of relative locations of radical ions with respect to a surfactant interface has been achieved by analysis of electron spin-echo modulation from deuterium in deuterated water at the interface. Results for a series of positive, neutral and negatively charged alkylphenothiazine derivatives in vesicle, micelle and reverse micelle surfactant assemblies of different interface charge are discussed. Controlling factors involve the alkyl chain length of the electron donors, the relative charge of the surfactant assembly interface versus that of the electron donor derivative, and the degree of molecular order in the interface. Secondary factors include alkyl chain bending, photoinduced radical conversion and back electron transfer.The efficiency of photoinduced charge separation across surfactant interfaces of micelles and vesicles depends in part on the location of electron donors and acceptors relative to the interface. Achievement and assessment of control of such location by the addition of pendant alkyl chains to donors and acceptors is shown to be achievable. The net photoionization efficiency can be measured by electron spin resonance of radical ions in frozen surfactant solutions. Assessment of relative locations of radical ions with respect to a surfactant interface has been achieved by analysis of electron spin-echo modulation from deuterium in deuterated water at the interface. Results for a series of positive, neutral and negatively charged alkylphenothiazine derivatives in vesicle, micelle and reverse micelle surfactant assemblies of different interface charge are discussed. Controlling factors involve the alkyl chain length of the electron donors, the relative charge of the surfactant assembly interface versus that of the electron donor derivative, and the degree of molecular order in the interface. Secondary factors include alkyl chain bending, photoinduced radical conversion and back electron transfer.

Authors: Baillieul J.
Title: Kinematic redundancy and the control of robots with flexible components
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE International Conference on Robotics and Automation
Affiliations: Aerosp/Mech Eng Dept, Boston Univ,, MA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Baillieul, J., Aerosp/Mech Eng Dept, Boston Univ,, MA, USA
Abstract: The author studies robot manipulators which simultaneously exhibit features of joint elasticity and kinematic redundancy. More specifically, he discusses manipulators in which there are more controlled (joint space) degrees of freedom than task space degrees of freedom and in which at least one of these controlled joints is connected to an adjacent link through an elastic coupling. It is shown that there is a wide class of examples for which it is impossible to find joint space motions which track a given end effector trajectory and do not at the same time excite elastic dynamics. For this class geometries, the most one can in general hope to achieve no net storage of elastic energy in the joints. For certain congenial manipulator geometries, it is shown that under certain assumptions it is possible to plan motions which store no elastic energy. It is shown how trajectories interpolating prescribed endpoints in the work space may be planned using fifth-order splines. The problem of exactly tracking end effector trajectories with minimum average elastic energy storage is discussed.
Index Keywords: Kinematics; Manipulators; Redundancy; Elastic coupling; End effectors; Kinematic redundancy; Robot manipulators; Robots

Authors: Flakoll P.J., Wentzel L.S., Rice D.E., Hill J.O., Abumrad N.N.
Title: Short-term regulation of insulin-mediated glucose utilization in four-day fasted human volunteers: role of amino acid availability
Affiliations: Department of Surgery, Vanderbilt University Medical Center Nashville, Tennessee, United States; Department of Pediatrics, Vanderbilt University Medical Center Nashville, Tennessee, United States; Department of Medicine, Vanderbilt University Medical Center Nashville, Tennessee, United States; Department of Molecular Physiology and Biophysics, Vanderbilt University Medical Center Nashville, Tennessee, United States
Authors with affiliations: Flakoll, P.J., Department of Surgery, Vanderbilt University Medical Center Nashville, Tennessee, United States; Wentzel, L.S., Department of Surgery, Vanderbilt University Medical Center Nashville, Tennessee, United States; Rice, D.E., Department of Surgery, Vanderbilt University Medical Center Nashville, Tennessee, United States; Hill, J.O., Department of Pediatrics, Vanderbilt University Medical Center Nashville, Tennessee, United States; Abumrad, N.N., Department of Surgery, Vanderbilt University Medical Center Nashville, Tennessee, United States, Department of Medicine, Vanderbilt University Medical Center Nashville, Tennessee, United States, Department of Molecular Physiology and Biophysics, Vanderbilt University Medical Center Nashville, Tennessee, United States
Abstract: Glucose homeostasis in men fasted for 84 h was assessed using isotopes, indirect calorimetry and forearm balance techniques during a basal period and three sequential hyperinsulinaemic euglycaemic clamps each lasting for 150 min. Two protocols (n=12 in each) were used: subjects were either allowed to develop hypoaminoacidaemia or received a commercial solution of L-amino acids while maintaining near-basal plasma leucine levels. Insulin infusions resulted in 3-, 35- and 650-fold increases in plasma insulin levels in both protocols. The infusion of amino acids produced a rightward shift in the dose-response curve of insulin's effect on suppressing hepatic glucose production, indicating decreased sensitivity in addition to blunting of the maximal responsiveness. Total body glucose rate of disappearance was progressively increased with escalating insulin doses, but was 22% lower at the intermediate and highest insulin doses in the group that was infused with amino acids (3.44±0.53 vs 4.82±0.71 and 7.72±1.01 vs 10.36±1.08 mg·kg-1·min-1, respectively; p<0.05). Forearm balance data confirmed the isotopic data, since amino acid infusions blunted the insulin-mediated increase in net forearm glucose utilization (by 50-83%). Furthermore, the infusion of amino acids resulted in marked reductions in the rate of carbohydrate oxidation and storage as assessed by indirect calorimetry. The data indicate that the amino acid-mediated suppression of glucose utilization and carbohydrate oxidation is exerted on the responsive component of insulin action. © 1992 Springer-Verlag.
Author Keywords: euglycaemic clamp; glucose production; glucose utilization; hyperinsulinaemic; Insulin responsiveness; insulin sensitivity
