Authors: Lafleur P.M.
Title: Energy balance and evapotranspiration from a subarctic forest
Affiliations: Department of Geography, Trent University, Peterborough, Ont. K9J 7B8, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Lafleur, P.M., Department of Geography, Trent University, Peterborough, Ont. K9J 7B8, Canada
Abstract: Measurements of energy balance components were made over subarctic forest near Churchill, Manitoba, Canada, during summer 1989. For the study, soil heat storage comprised 9% of net radiation, and the sensible and latent heat fluxes were of similar magnitude. However, on a daily basis the Bowen ratio varied considerably around an overall mean of 0.94. Canopy transpiration was computed from measurements of leaf conductance and vapour pressure deficit. These results indicated that, on average, only 20% of the total evaporation flux originated from the tree canopy. © 1992.
Index Keywords: Bowen ratio; canopy transpiration; energy balance; evapotranspiration; latent heat flux; sensible heat flux; soil heat storage; subarctic forest; Canada, Manitoba, Churchill

Authors: Ohtsu T., Kimura M.T., Hori S.H.
Title: Energy storage during reproductive diapause in the Drosophila melanogaster species group
Affiliations: Department of Zoology, Faculty of Science, Hokkaido University, Sapporo, Hokkaido, 060, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ohtsu, T., Department of Zoology, Faculty of Science, Hokkaido University, Sapporo, Hokkaido, 060, Japan; Kimura, M.T., Department of Zoology, Faculty of Science, Hokkaido University, Sapporo, Hokkaido, 060, Japan; Hori, S.H., Department of Zoology, Faculty of Science, Hokkaido University, Sapporo, Hokkaido, 060, Japan
Abstract: Temperate species of the Drosophila melanogaster group enter reproductive diapause for overwintering in response to short daylength. During the prediapause period they accumulate triacylglycerols, but not glycogen, as energy resources. The capacity for storing triacylglycerols differs between species, and appears to be closely correlated with diapause and cold-hardiness; cool-temperate species, such as those of the auraria species complex, which enter a deep diapause and are highly cold-hardy, accumulate larger quantities of triacylglycerols than warm-temperate species, such as D. rufa and D. lutescens, which enter a weak diapause and are less cold-hardy. Among the cool-temperate spcies, D. subauraria occurs at a higher latitude and has the greatest capacity for accumulating triacylglycerols. A subtropical species, D. takahashii, which has no diapause in nature and is not cold-hardy, is unable to store the same quantities of triacylglycerols as temperate species. © 1992 Springer-Verlag.
Author Keywords: Drosophila; Glycogen; Overwintering; Reproductive diapause; Triacylglycerols

Authors: Geissel H.
Title: Unique channeling experiments with cooled relativistic heavy ions
Source title: Nuclear Inst. and Methods in Physics Research, B
Affiliations: Gesellschaft für Schwerionenforschung, GSI, Planckstrasse 1, D-61 Darmstadt, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Geissel, H., Gesellschaft für Schwerionenforschung, GSI, Planckstrasse 1, D-61 Darmstadt, Germany
Abstract: The new accelerator facilities at GSI extend heavy-ion reseach to relativistic energies. The synchrotron SIS can accelerate all ions up to a maximum magnetic rigidity of 18 T m corresponding to 1-2 GeV/u. The storage and cooler ring ESR opens the possibility for experiments requiring a high phase-space density, such as channeling in single crystals at high energies. The projectile fragment separator FRS can produce and separate radioactive beams allowing collision studies with unstable exotic projectiles. Unique channeling experiments with cooled heavy ions can be performed with the new facilities SIS, FRS, and ESR. © 1992.

Authors: Franceschini M.A., Pini R., Salimbeni R., Vannini M.
Title: Auto-prepulse operation of a long-pulse XeCl laser
Source title: Applied Physics B Photophysics and Laser Chemistry
Affiliations: Istituto di Elettronica Quantistica del C.N.R., Via Panciatichi 56/30, Florence, I-50127, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Franceschini, M.A., Istituto di Elettronica Quantistica del C.N.R., Via Panciatichi 56/30, Florence, I-50127, Italy; Pini, R., Istituto di Elettronica Quantistica del C.N.R., Via Panciatichi 56/30, Florence, I-50127, Italy; Salimbeni, R., Istituto di Elettronica Quantistica del C.N.R., Via Panciatichi 56/30, Florence, I-50127, Italy; Vannini, M., Istituto di Elettronica Quantistica del C.N.R., Via Panciatichi 56/30, Florence, I-50127, Italy
Abstract: A standard corona preionized XeCl laser prototype has been excited by a very simple L-C circuit consisting of a large storage capacitance charged at relatively low voltage (12 kV) and discharged via a switch on the electrodes, tightly coupled with the peaking capacitors. The resulting overvoltage following the switch closure behaves as an effective and automatic prepulse, providing a homogeneous discharge lasting up to 400 ns. Energy output levels of the order of 150 mJ at 1.4% overall efficiency have been achieved. © 1992 Springer-Verlag.

Authors: Sakai T., Yoshinaga H., Miyamura H., Kuriyama N., Ishikawa H.
Title: Rechargeable hydrogen batteries using rare-earth-based hydrogen storage alloys
Affiliations: Government Industrial Research Institute, Osaka, Ikeda 1-8-31, Osaka, 563, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Sakai, T., Government Industrial Research Institute, Osaka, Ikeda 1-8-31, Osaka, 563, Japan; Yoshinaga, H., Government Industrial Research Institute, Osaka, Ikeda 1-8-31, Osaka, 563, Japan; Miyamura, H., Government Industrial Research Institute, Osaka, Ikeda 1-8-31, Osaka, 563, Japan; Kuriyama, N., Government Industrial Research Institute, Osaka, Ikeda 1-8-31, Osaka, 563, Japan; Ishikawa, H., Government Industrial Research Institute, Osaka, Ikeda 1-8-31, Osaka, 563, Japan
Abstract: Electrochemical properties of low cost MmNi5-based-hydrogen storage alloys (Mm ≡ mischmetal) were extensively examined. The alloy MmNi3.5Co0.7Al0.8 showed a very long cycle life with reasonable discharge capacity (250 mA h g-1) and rate capability. An ingot with a very high endurance and low lattice strain was obtained under controlled conditions, including high rate cooling in the casting process for obtaining a columnar structure, no heat treatment and prevention of stoichiometric deviation. A columnar structure was formed so that the c-axis of the hexagonal structure was oriented parallel to the cooling plane. This alloy was significantly distinguished in crystal growth from a manganese-containing alloy (MmNl3.5Co0.5Al0.3Mn0.4) which had an equiaxial structure with considerable lattice strain, which needed conventional heat treatment. Deviation from stoichiometric composition to the nickel-rich side caused a significant decrease in capacity and cycle life owing to the precipitation of AlNi3 at grain boundaries. The decay in capacity of the MH electrode using MmNi3.6Co0.7Al0.8 was only 10% after 2000 cycles. The cylindrical sealed cell also showed a very long cycle life (a capacity decay of 6% after 2000 cycles). The high capacity sealed cell had a 1.5-2 times higher energy density (210 W h dm-3; 65 W h kg-1) with a longer cycle life and better rate capability than the high capacity Ni-Cd battery. © 1992.
Index Keywords: Electric Batteries, Secondary - Service Life; Hydrogen; Nickel And Alloys; Rare Earth Compounds; High Capacity Sealed Cells; Hydrogen Batteries; Mischmetal; Rare Earth Based Hydrogen Storage Alloys; Electric Batteries, Secondary

Authors: Iljinov A.S., Ivanov D.I., Mebel M.V., Nedorezov V.G., Sudov A.S., Kezerashvili G.Ya.
Title: Fissilities of 238U and 237Np nuclei measured with tagged photons in the energy range 60-240 MeV
Affiliations: Institute for Nuclear Research, Moscow, Russian Federation; Institute of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Iljinov, A.S., Institute for Nuclear Research, Moscow, Russian Federation; Ivanov, D.I., Institute for Nuclear Research, Moscow, Russian Federation; Mebel, M.V., Institute for Nuclear Research, Moscow, Russian Federation; Nedorezov, V.G., Institute for Nuclear Research, Moscow, Russian Federation; Sudov, A.S., Institute for Nuclear Research, Moscow, Russian Federation; Kezerashvili, G.Ya., Institute of Nuclear Physics, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation
Abstract: The photofission cross sections of 238U and 237Np nuclei have been measured using bremsstrahlung tagged photons at the ROKK-2 facility of the storage ring VEPP-3 INR (Novosibirsk). Fission fragments were detected by the low-pressure multiwire proportional chambers. The behavior of the photofission cross sections and relative fissilities has been compared with theoretical evaluations based in the cascade evaporation and double-humped fission barrier model. © 1992.
Author Keywords: Photonuclear reactions

Authors: Heathcote P., Wyman M., Carr N.G., Beddard G.S.
Title: Partial uncoupling of energy transfer from phycoerythrin in the marine cyanobacterium Synechococcus sp. WH7803
Affiliations: School of Biological Sciences, Queen Mary and Westfield College, University of London, London, United Kingdom; Department of Biological Sciences, University of Warwick, Conventry, United Kingdom; Department of Chemistry, University of Manchester, Manchester, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Heathcote, P., School of Biological Sciences, Queen Mary and Westfield College, University of London, London, United Kingdom; Wyman, M., Department of Biological Sciences, University of Warwick, Conventry, United Kingdom; Carr, N.G., Department of Biological Sciences, University of Warwick, Conventry, United Kingdom; Beddard, G.S., Department of Chemistry, University of Manchester, Manchester, United Kingdom
Abstract: Time-resolved fluorescence spectroscopy of the marine cyanobacterium Synechococcus sp WH7803 showed that a significant fraction of the biliprotein phycoerythrin did not transfer its excitation energy to the photosynthetic reaction centres when the organism had been cultured in non-limiting light conditions and with excess nitrogen supplied as nitrate. We consider that this partial decoupling of energy transfer shows the capacity that this organism has to use a portion of the phycocrythrin as a nitrogen reserve, without the corresponding photo-oxidative damage that could occur from having a larger functional antenna than is required by photosynthesis. © 1992.

Authors: Ziemann V.
Title: Free-electron laser supermodes for bunches with longitudinal energy-position correlation
Affiliations: Stanford Linear Accelerator Center, Stanford University, Stanford, 94309, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Ziemann, V., Stanford Linear Accelerator Center, Stanford University, Stanford, 94309, CA, United States
Abstract: In this note the theory of Free-Electron Laser (FEL) supermodes is extended to cover particle distributions with a correlation between energy and longitudinal position in a Gaussian bunch. This extension is important for FEL's in storage rings, because wake forces stemming from discontinuities in the vacuum chamber as well as the FEL process itself give rise to such correlations. © 1992 Società Italiana di Fisica.

Abstract: A selection of opportunities for neutrino physics from a source generated from pions that decay in flight and at rest is described. The present source at LAMPF has a duty factor of about 6%; improvements in opportunities that emerge from a source using a pulse 0.25 μsec long from a proton storage ring are also described. © 1992 Springer-Verlag.

Abstract: The Crystal Ball detector at the e+e- storage ring DORIS-II has been used to search for radiative B meson decays, especially of the type b→sγ. No monoenergetic γ-lines have been found in the inclusive photon spectrum from U{cyrillic}(4 S) decays, and upper limits are obtained for radiative decays of B mesons to various strange mesons and to the D*. Integrating the photon spectrum over the corresponding energy range, we find {Mathematical expression}at 90% confidence level for the mass range 892 MeV ≦MX≦2045 MeV. © 1992 Springer-Verlag.

Authors: Granéli W., Weisner S.E.B., Sytsma M.D.
Title: Rhizome dynamics and resource storage in Phragmites australis
Affiliations: Limnology, Department of Ecology, University of Lund, Box 65, Lund, S-221 00, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Granéli, W., Limnology, Department of Ecology, University of Lund, Box 65, Lund, S-221 00, Sweden; Weisner, S.E.B., Limnology, Department of Ecology, University of Lund, Box 65, Lund, S-221 00, Sweden; Sytsma, M.D., Limnology, Department of Ecology, University of Lund, Box 65, Lund, S-221 00, Sweden
Abstract: Seasonal changes in rhizome concentrations of total nonstructural carbohydrates (TNC), water soluble carbohydrates (WSC), and mineral nutrients (N, P and K) were monitored in two Phragmites australis stands in southern Sweden. Rhizome biomass, rhizome length per unit ground area, and specific weight (weight/ length ratio) of the rhizomes were monitored in one of the stands. Rhizome biomass decreased during spring, increased during summer and decreased during winter. However, changes in spring and summer were small (< 500 g DW m-2) compared to the mean rhizome biomass (approximately 3000 g DW m-2). Winter losses were larger, approximately 1000 g DW m-2, and to a substantial extent involved structural biomass, indicating rhizome mortality. Seasonal changes in rhizome length per unit ground area revealed a rhizome mortality of about 30% during the winter period, and also indicated that an intensive period of formation of new rhizomes occurred in June. Rhizome concentrations of TNC and WSC decreased during the spring, when carbohydrates were translocated to support shoot growth. However, rhizome standing stock of TNC remained large (> 1000 g m-2). Concentrations and standing stocks of mineral nutrients decreased during spring/ early summer and increased during summer/ fall. Only N, however, showed a pattern consistent with a spring depletion caused by translocation to shoots. This pattern indicates sufficient root uptake of P and K to support spring growth, and supports other evidence that N is generally the limiting mineral nutrient for Phragmites. The biomass data, as well as increased rhizome specific weight and TNC concentrations, clearly suggests that "reloading" of rhizomes with energy reserves starts in June, not towards the end of the growing season as has been suggested previously. This resource allocation strategy of Phragmites has consequences for vegetation management. Our data indicate that carbohydrate reserves are much larger than needed to support spring growth. We propose that large stores are needed to ensure establishment of spring shoots when deep water or stochastic environmental events, such as high rhizome mortality in winter or loss of spring shoots due to late season frost, increase the demand for reserves. © 1992 SPB Academic Publishing.
Author Keywords: biomass; carbohydrates; nitrogen; phosphorus; Phragmites australis; potassium; reed; rhizome; translocation; wetland
Index Keywords: carbohydrate; reed; rhizome; Sweden; Phragmites australis

Authors: Karia Kris
Title: Protovoltaic power system for a lunar base
Affiliations: Spar Aerospace Ltd
Authors with affiliations: Karia, Kris, Spar Aerospace Ltd
Abstract: The Lunar/Mars Mission, under the U.S. Space Exploration Initiative (SEI) program, will require 10's to 100's of kilowatts of electrical power to support operational activities on the lunar surface. Most NASA studies have assumed a nuclear power source for a permanent lunar base industrial facility. This study looks at photovoltaic power system as an alternative low-risk, low-cost, modular and safely transportable power system for the initial phase of the lunar base mission.
Index Keywords: Energy storage; Photovoltaic cells; Solar cell arrays; Space research; Technology; Energy storage technology; Lunar base photovoltaic power system; Lunar/Mars mission; Power system concept; Solar array sun tracking; Solar arrays substrate technology; Moon bases

Authors: Forrest Robert
Title: Knocking the bugs out of starch
Authors with affiliations: Forrest, Robert
Abstract: Like other corrugated converting mills, MacMillan Bathurst Inc. (MBI) in Whitby, Ont. had difficulty maintaining an acceptable viscosity in its starch mixing storage tanks, particularly over weekends when the five-day mill was not running. The standard measurement used for evaluating the starch mixture is viscosity. While water contamination or over-circulation can lead to starch viscosity breakdown, by far the most common cause is microbiological activity. In late 1988, the problem of viscosity breakdown in the starch mixture became serious enough to try something new. Enter the ion stick. This wand-like device is inserted in a water supply to prevent and remove hard water scale, and control and eliminate algae in recirculating water systems. MBI conducted an evaluation of the stick's performance in the double backer tank, between January and April, 1989, compared to the use of biocide in the single facer system. In January, the only problem occurred when the power supply was accidentally shut off over a weekend as part of an energy conservation program. A dedicated line solved that problem. In mid-March, the ion stick was shut down to observe the results. Viscosity remained stable until mid-April when it declined suddenly. The ion stick was reactivated and, within 48 hours, the viscosity level had stabilized again.
Index Keywords: Bacteria--Control; Water Treatment, Industrial--Ionization; Hazard Free Biocide; Ion Stick; Starch

Authors: Kim Deog-Yung, Qi Guojun, Itagaki Kimio
Title: Thermodynamic consideration of metallothermic reduction process for direct production of nickel-rare earth alloys
Source title: Metallurgical Review of MMIJ (Mining and Metallurgical Institute of Japan)
Affiliations: Tohoku Univ, Sendai, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Kim, Deog-Yung, Tohoku Univ, Sendai, Japan; Qi, Guojun, Tohoku Univ, Sendai, Japan; Itagaki, Kimio, Tohoku Univ, Sendai, Japan
Abstract: Aiming at the development of less energy-consumptive and cheap process to directly produce nickel-rare earth compounds for use of hydrogen storage materials, metallothermic reduction of oxides, chlorides and fluorides of rare earth elements (R = La, Ce, Pr and Nd) was thermodynamically discussed for metal reductants of Ca, Mg, Li and Na. Conditions for the phase stability of Ni-R alloys in the direct production process were clarified at 1173 and 1373K, based on potential (log PO(2), log PCl(2) and log PF(2)) - alloy composition diagrams and relations between activity of reductant and alloy composition. Thermal balance was also calculated, assuming a calciothermic reduction of lanthanum oxide to directly produce Ni5La.
Index Keywords: Hydrogen; Mathematical models; Rare earth alloys; Reduction; Storage (materials); Thermodynamics; Calciothermic reduction; Lanthanum oxide; Metallothermic reduction; Nickel rare earth alloys; Nickel alloys

Authors: Bonwick W.J., Conlon M.F., Giesner D.B.
Title: Superconducting magnetic energy storage applications to power systems
Source title: Journal of Electrical and Electronics Engineering, Australia
Affiliations: Monash Univ
Authors with affiliations: Bonwick, W.J., Monash Univ; Conlon, M.F., Monash Univ; Giesner, D.B., Monash Univ
Abstract: A superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) system has been built to examine the contribution that stored energy can make a to power system. The helium cooled SC coil is connected to a single machine, model power system through a GTO bridge. The real and reactive power from the bridge into the power system can be separately controlled. A control strategy has been developed to improve the power system behaviour following a fault. The behaviour following a fault is illustrated theoretically. Considerable experience has been gained working with the cryogenic equipment and this is discussed. A comprehensive measurement system has been developed to support the experimental work. A set of experimental results using some of this system shows the results of a typical experiment involving the SC coil.
Index Keywords: High Temperature Superconductors; Superconducting Magnets - Energy Storage; High Temperature Superconducting (HTSC); Low Temperature Superconducting (LTSC); Superconducting Magnetic Energy Storage (SMES); Energy Storage

Authors: Kesavan S., Prud'homme R.K.
Title: Rheology of Guar and HPG Cross-Linked by Borate
Affiliations: Department of Chemical Engineering, Princeton University, Princeton, New Jersey 08544-5263, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kesavan, S., Department of Chemical Engineering, Princeton University, Princeton, New Jersey 08544-5263, United States; Prud'homme, R.K., Department of Chemical Engineering, Princeton University, Princeton, New Jersey 08544-5263, United States
Abstract: Measurements have been conducted on the linear viscoelastic properties of guar and (hydroxypropyl)guar (HPG) polymer solutions cross-linked with borate ions to form gels. Chemical equilibria involving boric acid, borate ions, and borate ions associated with cis-diol sites on the polysaccharide chains determine the number of cross-links. These equilibria are functions of temperature and pH, and thus the rheology of the borate gels depends on temperature and pH. Measurements on 0.48 wt % polymer solutions were performed over the temperature range from 15 to 65 °C and the pH range from 6.35 to 9.5. The storage and loss moduli obey time–temperature superposition so that master curves can be constructed over 6 decades in frequency. The shift factors along the time axis follow a single-exponential Arrhenius form at pH values above 8 with activation energies that vary from 90 to 115 kJ/mol. The activation energies for guar and HPG are identical, which is consistent with the cis-diols on each polymer being the active site for cross-linking. Also, the data at different pH values can be superimposed by “time–pH” shifting to produce master curves from which the temperature and pH sensitivity of the gel rheology can be determined. Leibler et al. have recently proposed a theory for the rheology of associating polymer systems. Following this theory, we have subtracted the solution moduli from the gel moduli, and the resulting reduced moduli data follow a single time constant Maxwell model, where the time constant reflects the relaxation time ofborate/cis-diol interactions in the network. © 1992, American Chemical Society. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Boron Compounds - Applications; Polymers - Physical Properties; Polysaccharides - Crosslinking; Borate Crosslinking Agent; Guar Polymer Rheology; Hydroxypropyl Guar Polymer; Master Curves; Storage Modulus; Polysaccharides

Authors: Slocombe J.W., Feyerherm A.M., Stetson L.E.
Title: Electrical energy usage on Kansas grain farms
Affiliations: Kansas State Univ, Manhattan, United States
Authors with affiliations: Slocombe, J.W., Kansas State Univ, Manhattan, United States; Feyerherm, A.M., Kansas State Univ, Manhattan, United States; Stetson, L.E., Kansas State Univ, Manhattan, United States
Abstract: Four thousand Kansas agricultural producers were surveyed to determine electrical equipment and energy management practices used for grain, livestock, and dairy production in 1989. Completed questionnaires were obtained from 1177 producers, of which 554 were grain producers. Data from these producers were analyzed to determine types of equipment used for grain production, handling, and processing by geographic location and variables that could be used to predict electrical energy consumption for grain producers. Over 70% of the grain producers reported an average electrical energy consumption of 1395 kWh per month. Less than 20% of these producers used both single- and three-phase electricity on their operation. The most frequently used grain drying system was natural air. Producers who had bins reported an average of three or fewer of any given size. Sixteen percent of the producers used electrically operated irrigation pumps, whereas 24%, 47%, and 14% used diesel, natural gas, and LPG fuel sources, respectively. On the average, electric powered irrigation pumps operated for 4500 h. Potential variables to predict electrical energy consumption of grain production enterprises in Kansas included total kWh consumption, m3 (bu) grain dried, total grain storage capacity, number of aeration fans, total fan kW (hp), and hours of operation for electrically operated irrigation pumps.
Index Keywords: Agriculture--Kansas; Electric Power Utilization; Energy Utilization; Electric Energy Usage; Kansas Grain Farms; Farms

Authors: Hawley J.G., Reader G.T.
Title: Advanced power systems for autonomous unmanned underwater vehicles
Affiliations: Royal Naval Engineering Coll, Plymouth, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Hawley, J.G., Royal Naval Engineering Coll, Plymouth, United Kingdom; Reader, G.T., Royal Naval Engineering Coll, Plymouth, United Kingdom
Abstract: The underwater scientific, commercial and defence communities have long been aware of the potential uses of unmanned Autonomous Underwater Vehicles (AUVs) and the development of miniature high capacity computers and artificial intelligence systems has allowed more ambitious missions to be considered for such vessels. However, to carry out these envisaged tasks, new power systems will be required which are superior to those currently used in non-nuclear underwater vehicles. Existing systems, almost exclusively, use lead-acid battery driven electric motors and the energy storage capacity of these systems is only sufficient for short reach missions. Consequently, alternative power systems are being developed which make use of advanced batteries, fuel cells, semi-cells, radioisotopes and non-air breathing heat engines. This paper details the power requirements for AUVs, examines the advanced power systems that are being developed for use in such vessels and describes the driving forces behind their possible realisation.
Index Keywords: Electric Power Systems - Applications; Ocean Engineering; Advanced Power Systems; Autonomous Unmanned Underwater Vehicles; Submersibles

Authors: Pauly S.
Title: The radiation resistance of thermoset plastics - III. Oxygen permeation experiments
Authors with affiliations: Pauly, S.
Abstract: For the interpretation of the results of long term irradiation experiments in the presence of air it is necessary to know about the penetration of oxygen into the plastic material in the course of time. Therefore the oxygen permeability of two thermoset plastics (made from two unsaturated polyester resin thermosetting moulding compounds) was measured in the temperature range 20-60°C. For the Typ 802, the following data were generated at 23°C: permeability coefficient P = 3.08 x 10-15 cm3 · cm/cm2 · s · Pa, diffusion coefficient D = 1.03 x 10-8 cm2/s, solubility coefficient S = 3.00 x 10-7 cm3/cm3 Pa. The permeability of two thermoset phenol-formaldehyde plastics and one melamine-formaldehyde plastic was found to be immeasurably small, i.e. P < 3 x 10-17 cm3 · cm/cm2 · s · Pa at 60°C. For discs of 4 mm thickness made from the polyester plastics, oxygen concentration profiles were calculated which are built up in the course of time during storage in air at 23°C. For both other materials the profiles were estimated by assuming P = 3 x 10-17 at 60°C and the activation energy and the solubility being the same as in the case of polyester plastics.For the interpretation of the results of long term irradiation experiments in the presence of air it is necessary to know about the penetration of oxygen into the plastic material in the course of time. Therefore the oxygen permeability of two thermoset plastics (made from two unsaturated polyester resin thermosetting moulding compounds) was measured in the temperature range 20-60°C. For the Typ 802, the following data were generated at 23°C: permeability coefficient P = 3.08 × 10-15 cm3 · cm/cm2 · s · Pa, diffusion coefficient D = 1.03 × 10-8 cm2/s, solubility coefficient S = 3.00 × 10-7 cm3/cm3 · Pa. The permeability of two thermoset phenol-formaldehyde plastics and one melamine-formaldehyde plastic was found to be immeasurably small, i.e. P < 3 × 10-17 cm3 · cm/cm2 · s · Pa at 60°C. For discs of 4 mm thickness made from the polyester plastics, oxygen concentration profiles were calculated which are built up in the course of time during storage in air at 23°C. For both other materials the profiles were estimated by assuming P = 3 × 10-17 at 60°C and the activation energy and the solubility being the same as in the case of polyester plastics.

Abstract: The production of D*(2010)+ and J/ψ mesons and prompt leptons has been investigated in e+e- interactions at the Ψ(1 S) resonance energy. The data were collected at the storage ring DORIS II at DESY with the ARGUS detector. We obtain upper limits of BRdir (Υ{hooked} (1 S)→D*(2010)±+X)<0.019 (for xp>0.2) and BRdir (Υ{hooked}(1 S)→J/ψ+X)<0.68×10-3, both at the 90% confidence level. From the prompt lepton analysis, a model dependent limit of BRdir (Υ{hooked}(1 S)→Yc+X)<0.034 (Yc denoting a charm-containing particle) is derived. © 1992 Springer-Verlag.

Authors: Spaargaren D.H.
Title: Transport function of branching structures and the "Surface law" for basic metabolic rate
Affiliations: Netherlands Institute for Sea Research P.O. Box 59, 1790 AB Den Burg, Texel, The Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Spaargaren, D.H., Netherlands Institute for Sea Research P.O. Box 59, 1790 AB Den Burg, Texel, The Netherlands
Abstract: In larger animals a considerable part (e.g. body water, dissolved substances, mineral and organic deposits) of the total body mass does not consume significant amounts of oxygen. These materials can be considered to form a metabolically inert infrastructure which mainly serves three functions: (1) structural support to the organism, (2) storage of nutrients (building material and energy stores) and (3) transport and distribution of these materials. Considering the transport and support function of the metabolically inert structures and their interconnnections it is likely that the infrastructure will basically show some tree-like, branching building plan. In this paper a method is described to determine both the surface area (Abs) and the volume (Vbs) of simple (dichotomal) branching structures in relation to a few parameters (e.g. the radius and the length of a primary branch. Just as in the calculation of the surface area and volume of other geometrical objects the obtained values are determined by the definition of the branching system). Experimental data concerning basic metabolic rate (P) in relation to body weight (W) fit the equation W=k1P+k2P1·5 (k1 and k2 being constants), which can be derived by considering the body to comprise a metabolically active part combined with a metabolically inert infrastructure. With increasing size of an organism the volume of its metabolically inert infrastructure increases disproportionally. Just as with the "power law" for basic metabolic rate, the theoretical equation requires the assessments of two parameters. Reasonable estimates are given in this paper. © 1992 Academic Press Limited.
Index Keywords: article; basal metabolic rate; body weight; mathematical model; oxygen consumption; priority journal; thermogenesis; transport kinetics

Authors: Andersen L.H., Andersen T., Haugen H.K., Hertel N., Hvelplund P., Møller S.P., Smith W.W.

Authors with affiliations: Andersen, L.H., Institute of Physics and Astronomy, University of Aarhus, DK-8000 Aarhus C, Denmark; Andersen, T., Institute of Physics and Astronomy, University of Aarhus, DK-8000 Aarhus C, Denmark; Haugen, H.K., Institute of Physics and Astronomy, University of Aarhus, DK-8000 Aarhus C, Denmark; Hertel, N., Institute of Physics and Astronomy, University of Aarhus, DK-8000 Aarhus C, Denmark; Hvelplund, P., Institute of Physics and Astronomy, University of Aarhus, DK-8000 Aarhus C, Denmark; Møller, S.P., Institute of Physics and Astronomy, University of Aarhus, DK-8000 Aarhus C, Denmark; Smith, W.W., Institute of Physics and Astronomy, University of Aarhus, DK-8000 Aarhus C, Denmark
Abstract: The storage times of selected atomic and molecular negative ions have been investigated at an energy of 100 keV. Collisional- detachment processes with residual gas atoms restrict beam lifetimes to ∼ 1-5 s. The perspectives for negative-ion research are briefly discussed. © 1992.

Authors: Dumas M., Nouaoura M., Bertru N., Lassabatère L., Chen W., Kahn A.
Title: Sb-capping and decapping of MBE-grown GaSb(100)
Affiliations: Laboratoire d'Etude des Surfaces, Interfaces et Composants, Université de Montpellier II, Place Eugène Bataillon, 34095 Montpellier Cedex 2, France; Department of Electrical Engineering, Princeton University, Princeton, NJ 08544, United States

Abstract: We present a study of GaSb(100) surfaces grown by molecular beam epitaxy, protected by an Sb cap during ambient storage, and annealed in ultra-high vacuum. The surface structure, composition and electronic transitions are investigated with low energy electron diffraction, Auger electron spectroscopy, and electron energy loss spectroscopy. Successful Sb-decapping is achieved by annealing at 300° C for 30 min. It leads to a (2 × 3)-c(2 × 6) reconstructed surface with less residual damage and higher Sb concentration than surfaces prepared by sputtering and annealing. © 1992.
Index Keywords: Heat Treatment--Annealing; Molecular Beam Epitaxy--Applications; Protective Coatings--Removal; Semiconducting Films--Protective Coatings; Surfaces--Spectroscopic Analysis; Antimony Capping Layer; Antimony Decapping; Auger Electron Spectroscopy; Electron Energy Loss Spectroscopy; Semiconducting Gallium Antimonide; Semiconductor Surface Protection; Semiconducting Gallium Compounds

Authors: Matsuno A., Motokawa T.
Title: Evidence for calcium translocation in catch connective tissue of the sea cucumber Stichopus chloronotus
Affiliations: Department of Biology, Shimane University, Nishikawazu, Matsue, 690, Japan; Biological Laboratory, Faculty of Science, Tokyo Institute of Technology, O-okayama, Meguro, Tokyo, 152, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Matsuno, A., Department of Biology, Shimane University, Nishikawazu, Matsue, 690, Japan; Motokawa, T., Biological Laboratory, Faculty of Science, Tokyo Institute of Technology, O-okayama, Meguro, Tokyo, 152, Japan
Abstract: Catch connective tissue is collagenous connective tissue that changes its mechanical properties rapidly. Calcium has been assumed to play a key role in the catch mechanism because calcium concentration profoundly affects the mechanical properties. We have found a calcium-storage cell, the vacuole cell, in the dermis of the sea cucumber Stichopus chloronotus a wellstudied catch connective tissue. The processes of this cell are packed with vacuoles measuring 0.1-1.5 μm in diameter. The ultrastructure was compared in a relaxed state and in a catch (stiff) state induced by high-potassium artificial sea water. When fixed with pyroantimonate, the vacuoles contained precipitates in the relaxed state but not in the catch state. Analysis with an energy-dispersive X-ray microanalyzer suggested that the precipitate contains calcium. The release of calcium ions from the vacuole cell is proposed to induce connective tissue catch. © 1992 Springer-Verlag.
Author Keywords: Calcium, localization; Catch connective tissue; Dermis; Sea cucumber; Stichopus chloronotus (Echinodermata); Vacuole cell
Index Keywords: article; calcium transport; cell ultrastructure; cell vacuole; connective tissue; dermis; echinoderm; nonhuman; priority journal; X ray microanalysis

Authors: Labrador M., Cuevas-Diarte M.A., Mondieig D., Haget Y.
Title: The application of DSC to the study of phase segregation during the thermal cycling of para-dihalosubstituted derivatives of benzene and their alloys
Affiliations: Dep. Cristallografia, Mineralogia i Dipòsits Minerals, Fac. Geologia Universitat de Barcelona, c / Martí i Franqués, s/n, E-08028 BarcelonaSpain; Lab. Cristallographie et Physique Cristalline, URA 144 CNRS Université Bordeaux I, 351, Cours de la Libération, F-33405 TalenceFrance

Cristallographie et Physique Cristalline, URA 144 CNRS Université Bordeaux I, 351, Cours de la Libération, F-33405 TalenceFrance
Abstract: Calorimetric techniques are most commonly used in our research into organic compounds and their alloys, both for the initial characterization of the products and for the determination of phase diagrams that may be established. They are equally useful for the cycling of materials used for energy storage by latent heat, and for the study of their behaviour. This paper also demonstrates the use of the DSC technique to study the homogeneity of these materials when they are subjected to continuous thermic cycling. © 1992.

Authors: Charland M., Veeranjaneyulu K., Charlebois D., Leblanc R.M.
Title: Photoacoustic signal generation in leaves: are O2-consuming processes involved?
Affiliations: Centre de recherche en photobiophysique, Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières, Trois-Rivières, Que., Canada
Authors with affiliations: Charland, M., Centre de recherche en photobiophysique, Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières, Trois-Rivières, Que., Canada; Veeranjaneyulu, K., Centre de recherche en photobiophysique, Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières, Trois-Rivières, Que., Canada; Charlebois, D., Centre de recherche en photobiophysique, Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières, Trois-Rivières, Que., Canada; Leblanc, R.M., Centre de recherche en photobiophysique, Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières, Trois-Rivières, Que., Canada
Abstract: The photoacoustic signal from a green leaf is the vectorial sum of photothermal (heat emitted by non-radiative deexcitation of molecules) and photobaric (photosynthetic O2 exchanges) contributions. With sugar maple leaf, we have observed a decline of the O2 signal in the course of time, once the leaf attained a steady-state photosynthesis. This decline of the O2 signal was not due to a decrease in photochemical activity as was evident by a stable fluorescence signal and constant energy storage. The rate and the extent of decline were larger at low modulation frequency and low modulated light intensity. The decline continued even in the presence of background far-red light (λ>715 nm). The above observations lead us to conclude that the photoacoustic O2 signal from leaves is influenced by O2-consuming processes. Data are discussed in relation to a possible occurrence of an equilibrium between oxygen-evolving and oxygen-consuming processes to account for the O2 signal in the plant cell. Moreover, the oxygen-uptake component may have to be included in the vectorial model of photoacoustic signal generation in leaves. © 1992 Elsevier Science Publishers B.V. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: (Sugar maple); Oxygen evolution; Oxygen uptake process; Photoacoustic spectroscopy; Photosynthesis
Index Keywords: article; nonhuman; oxygen consumption; photosynthesis; plant leaf; priority journal; signal transduction

Authors: March R.E., Londry F.A., Alfred R.L., Franklin A.M., Todd J.F.J.
Title: Mass-selective isolation of ions stored in a quadrupole ion trap. A simulation study
Source title: International Journal of Mass Spectrometry and Ion Processes
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, Trent University, Peterborough, Ont. K9J 7B8, Canada; Department of Physics, Trent University, Peterborough, Ont. K9J 7B8, Canada; University Chemical Laboratory, University of Kent, Canterbury, Kent CT2 7NH, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: March, R.E., Department of Chemistry, Trent University, Peterborough, Ont. K9J 7B8, Canada; Londry, F.A., Department of Physics, Trent University, Peterborough, Ont. K9J 7B8, Canada; Alfred, R.L., Department of Physics, Trent University, Peterborough, Ont. K9J 7B8, Canada; Franklin, A.M., University Chemical Laboratory, University of Kent, Canterbury, Kent CT2 7NH, United Kingdom; Todd, J.F.J., University Chemical Laboratory, University of Kent, Canterbury, Kent CT2 7NH, United Kingdom
Abstract: Trajectories of single ions stored in the quadrupole ion trap have been calculated using a simulation program described as the specific program for quadrupolar resonance (SPQR). Previously, the program has been used for the investigation of quadrupolar resonance excitation of ions with a static working point (or co-ordinates) in the stability diagram. The program has been modified to accommodate continuous d.c. and/or r.f. voltage ramps so as to permit calculation of ion trajectories while the working point is being changed. The modified program has been applied to the calculation of ion trajectories during ion isolation, or mass-selective storage, in the ion trap. The quadrupolar resonance excitation aspect of SPQR was not used in this study. Trajectories are displayed as temporal variations of ion kinetic energy, and axial and radial excursions from the centre of the ion trap. The working points of three ion species (m/z 144, 146 and 148), located initially on the qz, axis with qz ≈ 0.12, were moved to the vicinity of the upper apex by a combination of r.f. and d.c. voltages applied in succession. Stable trajectories were maintained only for the ion species of m/z 146 for which the working point lay within this apex; the other ion species were ejected either radially or axially. The d.c. voltage was then reduced to zero so as to restore the working point of the isolated ion species to the qz axis. The amplitude of the r.f voltage was reduced to its initial value so as to retrieve the initial working point for m/z 146. The process extended over a real time of 2.9 ms, and was collision-free. The trajectory of the isolated ion was stable during this process; the ion species with m/z value lower than that of the target ion, that is, m/z 144, was ejected axially at the βz = 1 boundary, while that with higher m/z value, that is, m/z 148, was ejected radially at the βr = 0 boundary, as expected. The moderating effects of buffer gas were not taken into consideration and ion kinetic energies during the sorting period were found to be sufficiently great that dissociative losses may be appreciable in a collisional system. A possible strategy for reducing kinetic energy during this process has been proposed. © 1992.
Author Keywords: ion isolation; mass spectrometry; Quadrupole ion trap; tandem mass spectrometry.; trajectory simulation

Authors: Nagarajan R.
Title: Cavitation erosion of substrates in disk drive component cleaning: An exploratory study
Affiliations: International Business Machines Corporation, Storage Systems Products Division, 5600 Cattle Road, San Jose, CA 95193, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nagarajan, R., International Business Machines Corporation, Storage Systems Products Division, 5600 Cattle Road, San Jose, CA 95193, United States
Abstract: The intent in this paper is threefold: to describe the phenomenon of cavitation erosion, and its occurrence and relevance in substrate cleaning using ultrasound in the magnetic data storage device industry; to introduce a novel method, liquid-borne particle counting, that provides a quantitative measure of erosion without the need for direct surface inspection; to establish a fundamental relationship between substrate surface properties, such as surface energy, and its credibility. The paper concludes with recommendations for surface finishes and coatings to minimize surface attrition due to cavitation erosion. © 1992.
Index Keywords: Data Storage, Magnetic--Storage Devices; Metal Cleaning--Ultrasonic; Particle Size Analysis; Substrates--Erosion; Ultrasonic Effects--Cavitation; Liquid-Borne Particle Counters; Magnetic Disk Drive Substrate Cleaning; Substrate Cavitation Erosion; Ultrasonic Substrate Cleaning; Data Storage Units

Authors: Neumann F.G.
Title: Regulation and usage of insecticides in Australian forestry from the mid-1960s to 1990: Australian forestry council, research working group 8
Affiliations: Department of Conservation and Natural Resources, 378 Cotham Road, Kew, VIC, 3101, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Neumann, F.G., Department of Conservation and Natural Resources, 378 Cotham Road, Kew, VIC, 3101, Australia
Abstract: Since the mid-1960s, 28 insecticide sprays or dusts, five fumigants (aluminium phosphide, dazomet, methyl bromide, naphthalene and p-dichlorobenzene) and one microbial insecticide (Bacillus thuringiensis) have been used, mostly in small quantities, by Australian forest services for control of indigenous and accidentally introduced insect pests in native forests, eucalypt or pine plantations, forest nurseries, and wooden structures. All of the applied insecticides have been officially registered for agricultural purposes (which include forestry applications) in each State/Territory under the provisions of a specific Act of Parliament. Until July 1989, the registration of insecticides by State/Territory authorities was subject to stringent evaluation and clearance by the Technical Committee on Agricultural Chemicals, a central authority responsible to the Co-ordinating Committee on Agricultural Chemicals, and through it to the Australian Agricultural Council. Since then, evaluation and clearance for registration has been the function of the Australian Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Council with direct responsibility to the Federal Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. This Council, established under the Commonwealth Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Act (1988), aims to ensure uniformity of assessment and registration of insecticides throughout Australia. In each State, special permits may be issued to allow insecticides to be used for purposes not covered by the registered product label or unregistered insecticides to be used in research trials. Additional legislation in the form of Acts of State Parliament, and Associated Regulations, governs the distribution, application and safe handling of registered insecticides. Most forest authorities now record insecticide purchases and consumption, and all have issued detailed instructions to their staff on spray preparation, storage, disposal, safe transport, spillage, accidental poisoning, loss or theft. The most extensive use of insecticides has been against the indigenous Spur-legged Stick Insect, Didymuria violescens (Phasmatidae), in Victorian ash-type eucalypt forests by aerial spraying with malathion, and for eradication of the accidentally introduced West Indian Drywood Termite, Cryptotermes brevis (Kalotermitidae), in south-eastern Queensland and New South Wales, by fumigating entire buildings and furniture with methyl bromide. In Tasmania, extensive aerial applications of synthetic pyrethroids have been carried out by APPM Forest Products to safeguard young plantations of principally Eucalyptus nitens (Shining Gum) from defoliation by the Tasmanian Eucalyptus Leaf Beetle, Chrysophtharta bimaculata. Outbreaks of all these pests cause serious economic damage when left unchecked. A sustained media campaign critical of pesticide usage in Australia has induced a much greater public awareness of the likely health risks posed by insecticides. Forest services are now committed to limit the use of insecticides and to promote biological and silvicultural techniques as alternative controls. Using insect resistant genotypes in eucalypt plantation programs is also expected to relieve insect pest problems in the future. However, insecticide applications are likely to remain front-line options for eradicating exotic insect pests of high destructive potential and for controlling large outbreaks of indigenous pests in commercial eucalypt plantations or in forest nurseries. © 1992 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Authors: Dowling J.J.
Title: The effect of muscle mechanics on human movement outcomes as revealed by computer simulation
Affiliations: McMaster University, Hamilton, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Dowling, J.J., McMaster University, Hamilton, Canada
Abstract: Computer simulations were performed using a model of the human elbow joint as controlled by a single equivalent flexor muscle. The mechanical output of the muscle was determined from a user-specified neural drive according to the force-time, force-length, and force-velocity relations. The model allowed no storage of mechanical energy and no potentiation via the stretch reflex. The effects of different activation patterns as well as initial kinematic conditions on the maximum final velocity were examined. The results revealed a very nonlinear dependence of final velocity on both initial joint angle and angular velocity. Contrary to the principles of particle physics, it could be shown that an activation pattern that reached a maximum early in the movement achieved shorter movement times and, quite often, higher final velocities than an activation pattern that reached a maximum later in the movement. It was also found that by taking advantage of the nonlinear force-time, force-length and force-velocity relations, higher final velocities could be achieved if the muscle contracted from a previously stretch state with the absence of stored elastic energy. It was also found that with the same neural drive, the final velocities that could be achieved when the muscle was first required to absorb large amounts of energy in an eccentric contraction were similar to the final velocities that could be achieved when no negative work needed to be performed. © 1992.

Authors: Priest E.R.
Title: Basic magnetic configuration and energy supply processes for an interacting flux model of eruptive solar flares
Affiliations: Mathematical and Computational Sciences Department The University, St Andrews, KY16 9SS, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Priest, E.R., Mathematical and Computational Sciences Department The University, St Andrews, KY16 9SS, United Kingdom
Abstract: A review is given of our current understanding of: The basic magnetic configuration of a flare, including loop and arcade structures, prominence models and interactions of separate flux systems; the process of preflare energy storage in excess of potential due to photospheric motions; the conditions for flare occurrence, including shear in the corona and complexity and the roles of spot motions, flux cancellation and prominences; theories for eruption by magnetic nonequilibrium. In the course of this, the elements of a new Interacting Flux Model for flares are outlined. © 1992, Springer Science and Business Media Deutschland GmbH. All rights reserved.

Authors: Ditl P., Rieger F., Rousar I.
Title: The design of agitated dissolution tanks
Authors with affiliations: Ditl, P.; Rieger, F.; Rousar, I.
Abstract: We propose a theoretical and experimental approach for optimizing agitated dissolution tanks to minimize energy requirements. Semiempirical equations for estimation of the mass transfer coefficient and the minimum impeller speed for suspension are reported. Conclusions of practical importance have been gained showing the effect of impeller speed and final solution concentration on the specific energy consumption required for preparation of storage solutions of chemicals. In addition, the efficiency of the classical dissolution tank stirred with a single axial impeller has been compared with high aspect ratio tanks agitated with multiple axial impellers. (Authors)
Index Keywords: Impellers; Mixing; Optimization; Solubility; Stirred Tanks

Authors: Dunn P.D., Gomez S.
Title: Asynchronous machines for use with variable speed wind turbines for isolated electrical grids
Authors with affiliations: Dunn, P.D.; Gomez, S.
Abstract: This paper considers the use of a variable speed wind turbine in association with an asynchronous generator. Frequency control is achieved by resonating the leakage inductance of the generator with an external capacitor bank. Medium term voltage control is achieved by load control, however, short term energy storage is also incorporated. The system is shown schematically. (from Authors)
Index Keywords: Asynchronous; Generators; Isolated Grids; Wind Turbines-Variable Speed

Authors: Van Beesten C.
Title: Hydraulic structures in flood control systems
Authors with affiliations: Van Beesten, C.
Abstract: Discusses operations experience of a variety of flood protection methods on the River Lee system in Hertfordshire. Outlines the reasons for unstable flow conditions at a set of three siphons at Ware Lock (air pocket problems) and proposes a flood storage outlet control role for siphons. Describes how to design fluming for bridge structures (minimum energy principles) and how to convert conventional weirs to a modified sawtooth (folded) weir line, noting examples of labyrinth and folded weirs. Mentions problems with gates and possible solutions. (C.J.U.)
Index Keywords: Bridges; Flood Protection; Flumes; River Lee; Siphons

Authors: Midkiff K.C., Brett C.E., Balaji K., Song Y.K.
Title: Long-term performance of an air-conditioning system based on seasonal aquifer chill energy storage
Affiliations: University of Alabama, United States
Authors with affiliations: Midkiff, K.C., University of Alabama, United States; Brett, C.E., University of Alabama, United States; Balaji, K., University of Alabama, United States; Song, Y.K., University of Alabama, United States
Abstract: A nominal 520 kW (thermal) air-conditioning system based on the seasonal storage of cold water in an aquifer has cooled a University of Alabama building since 1983. During cold weather, ambient, 18°C water is pumped from warm supply wells, chilled to about 6° C in a cooling tower, and reinjected into separate cold storage wells. In warm weather, water is withdrawn from the cold wells and pumped through building heat exchangers for air conditioning. Presented here are results of 6 years of study [sponsored by the U.S. Department of Energy through Pacific Northwest Laboratory] of the first successful U.S. application of this technology. This system yields high energy efficiency, with measured annual average COP of about 5 (SEER = 17 Btu/Wh), and energy recovery efficiency ranging from 40 to 85%, shifts utility loads from summer to winter, and no chlorofluorocarbon (CFC) release.
Index Keywords: Aquifers; Cold storage; Energy efficiency; Annual average; Energy recovery efficiency; High energy efficiency; Long term performance; Pacific Northwest; Seasonal storage; U.S. Department of Energy; University of Alabama; Air conditioning

Authors: Hajjar R.A., Wu T.H., Fu H., Mansuripur M.
Title: Measurement of the magnetic anisotropy energy constants for magneto-optical recording media
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Optical Sciences Center, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ  85721, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hajjar, R.A., Optical Sciences Center, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ  85721, United States; Wu, T.H., Optical Sciences Center, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ  85721, United States; Fu, H., Optical Sciences Center, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ  85721, United States; Mansuripur, M., Optical Sciences Center, University of Arizona, Tucson, AZ  85721, United States
Abstract: Measurement of the magneto-optical polar Kerr effect is performed on rare earth-transition metal (RE-TM) amorphous films using in-plane fields. From this measurement and the measurement of the saturation magnetization using a vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM), the magnetic anisotropy constants are determined. In this paper, we present the temperature dependence of the magnetic anisotropy in the range of -175°C to 175°C. The results show a dip in the anisotropy near magnetic compensation. This anomaly is explained based on the finite exchange coupling between the rare earth and transition metal subnetworks. © 1992 SPIE. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Amorphous films; Digital storage; Magnetic anisotropy; Magnetic recording; Optical anisotropy; Optical Kerr effect; Rare earths; Saturation magnetization; Temperature distribution; Transition metals; Magnetic anisotropy constant; Magnetic anisotropy energy; Magnetic compensation; Magnetooptical recording; Polar Kerr effect; Rare earth transition metal; Temperature dependence; Vibrating sample magnetometer; Optical data storage

Authors: Spaepen F.
Title: Fundamentals of nucleation and growth
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Division of Applied Sciences, Harvard University, Cambridge, MA  02138, United States
Authors with affiliations: Spaepen, F., Division of Applied Sciences, Harvard University, Cambridge, MA  02138, United States
Abstract: The free energy associated with the formation of the crystal-melt interface ("interfacial tension") is an important parameter in the theory of homogeneous nucleation. In the proximity of a crystal plane the liquid is more ordered than in the bulk. Static structural modeling1, as well as molecular dynamics simulations2, show that the liquid atoms are localized to a varying degree in planes parallel to the interface. The loss in entropy associated with the ordering of the liquid is the main factor contributing to the interfacial tension1. Density functional calculations on hard sphere systems have confirmed this3. © 1992 SPIE. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Crystal atomic structure; Digital storage; Free energy; Liquids; Molecular dynamics; Nucleation; Crystal planes; Crystal-melt interface; Hard sphere systems; Homogeneous nucleation; Molecular dynamics simulations; Nucleation and growth; Structural modeling; Optical data storage

Authors: Bijkerk P., Shmaenok L., Louis E., Nikolaus B., Voß F., Désor R.
Title: Characterization op a novel two-stage KrF laser with high pulse energy and low beam divergence
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: FOM-Institute for Plasma Physics Rijnhuizen, Edlsonbaan 14, Nieuwegein, 3439 MN, Netherlands; Lambda Physik GmbH, Hans Böcklerstaße 12, Göttingen, D-3400, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Bijkerk, P., FOM-Institute for Plasma Physics Rijnhuizen, Edlsonbaan 14, Nieuwegein, 3439 MN, Netherlands; Shmaenok, L., FOM-Institute for Plasma Physics Rijnhuizen, Edlsonbaan 14, Nieuwegein, 3439 MN, Netherlands; Louis, E., FOM-Institute for Plasma Physics Rijnhuizen, Edlsonbaan 14, Nieuwegein, 3439 MN, Netherlands; Nikolaus, B., Lambda Physik GmbH, Hans Böcklerstaße 12, Göttingen, D-3400, Germany; Voß, F., Lambda Physik GmbH, Hans Böcklerstaße 12, Göttingen, D-3400, Germany; Désor, R., Lambda Physik GmbH, Hans Böcklerstaße 12, Göttingen, D-3400, Germany
Abstract: We present experimental results on the performance of a novel two-stage KrF excimer laser designed and constructed to drive a laser plasma XUV source, an application which requires high pulse energy and high beam quality In order to produce XUV radiation with high efficiency. The system consists of two high power laser modules that can be configurated as power oscillator-power amplifier (popa), or as an injection seeded system. In the first case the pulse energy and beam divergence amount to respectively 1.5 J and 0.15 × 0.12 mrad (FWHM), in the second case 0.95 J and 0.07 × 0.13 mrad. At 50 Hz the power amounts to resp. 67 and 42 W. Progress in excimer laser engineering has led to many improvements that give more reliability at higher pulse energies and higher average power, while maintaining beam properties essential for the application under study. The aim of this work is to develop the laser plasma for x-ray lithography, i.e. to construct a prototype source with a high XUV flux as an alternative to electron storage rings. © 1992 Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Chemical lasers; Excimer lasers; Flow of gases; High power lasers; Laser produced plasmas; Plasma interactions; Power amplifiers; Storage rings; X ray lithography; Beam divergence; Beam properties; Electron storage ring; High beam quality; High pulse energy; KrF excimer laser; Low-beam divergence; Power oscillator; Laser radiation

Authors: Vail L.W., Jenne E.A., Eary L.E.
Title: H20TREAT: An aid for evaluating water treatment requirements for aquifer thermal energy storage
Affiliations: Pacific Northwest Lab., United States
Authors with affiliations: Vail, L.W., Pacific Northwest Lab., United States; Jenne, E.A., Pacific Northwest Lab., United States; Eary, L.E., Pacific Northwest Lab., United States
Abstract: A public-domain software package is available to aid engineers in the design of water treatment systems for Aquifer Thermal Energy Storage (ATES). Geochemical phenomena that cause problems in ATES systems include formation of scale in heat exchangers, clogging of wells, corrosion in piping and heat exchangers, and degradation of aquifer materials. Preventing such problems frequently requires employing water treatment systems. Individual water treatment methods vary in cost, effectiveness, environmental impact, corrosion potential, and acceptability to regulatory bodies. Evaluating these water treatment options is generally required to determine the feasibility of ATES systems. The H2OTREAT software was developed by Pacific Northwest Laboratory for use by engineers with limited or no experience in geochemistry. At the feasibility analysis and design stages, the software utilizes a recently revised geochemical model, MINTEQ, to calculate the saturation indices of selected carbonate, oxide, and hydroxide minerals based on water chemistry and temperature data provided by the user. The saturation index of a specific mineral defines whether that mineral is oversaturated, hence may precipitate at the specified temperature. The saturation indices of key calcium, iron, silica, and manganese carbonates, oxides, and hydroxides (calcite, rhodochrosite, siderite, Fe(OH)3[a], bimessite, chalcedony, and SiO2) are calculated. User input is separated into "required" and "optional" data (Table 1). Currently, H2OTREAT does not perform cost calculations; however, treatment capacity requirements are provided. Treatments considered include 1) Na and H ion exchangers and pellet reactors to avoid calcite precipitation, and 2) in situ nitrate addition and cascade precipitators to prevent Fe and Mn oxide precipitation. The H2OTREAT software also provides the user with guidance on other geochemical problems that must be considered, such as SiO2 precipitation, corrosion, and environmental considerations. The sodium adsorption ratio and sodium hazard are calculated to evaluate the likelihood of clay swelling and dispersion caused by high Na concentrations (e.g., as a result of Na ion exchange water treatment used to prevent calcite precipitation). H2OTREAT is available for DOS and UNIX computers.
Index Keywords: Aquifers; Calcite; Chemical analysis; Corrosion; Digital storage; Environmental impact; Heat exchangers; Heat storage; Hydrochemistry; Ion exchange; Ion exchangers; Iron oxides; Open source software; Precipitation (chemical); Silica; Sodium; Thermal energy; Aquifer thermal energy storage; Calcite precipitation; Corrosion potentials; Environmental considerations; Feasibility analysis; Sodium adsorption ratio; Water treatment methods; Water treatment systems; Water treatment

Authors: Kimnach G.L., Baez A.N.
Title: Power system monitoring and source control of the Space Station Freedom DC-power system testbed
Affiliations: NASA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kimnach, G.L., NASA, United States; Baez, A.N., NASA, United States
Abstract: Unlike a terrestrial electric utility which can purchase power from a neighboring utility, the Space Station Freedom (SSF) has strictly limited energy resources; as a result, source control, system monitoring, system protection and load management are essential to the safe and efficient operation of the SSF Electric Power System (EPS). These functions are being evaluated in the DC Power Management and Distribution (PMAD) Testbed which NASA LeRC has developed at the Power System Facility (PSF) located in Cleveland, Ohio. The testbed is an ideal platform to develop, integrate, and verify power system monitoring and control algorithms. State Estimation (SE) is a monitoring tool used extensively in terrestrial electric utilities to ensure safe power system operation. It uses redundant system information to calculate the actual state of the EPS, to isolate faulty sensors, to determine source operating points, to verify faults detected by subsidiary controllers, and to identify high impedance faults. Source control and monitoring safeguard the power generation and storage subsystems and ensure that the power system operates within safe limits while satisfying user demands with minimal interruptions. System monitoring functions, in coordination with hardware implemented schemes, provide for a complete fault protection system. The objective of this paper is to overview the development and integration of the state estimator and the source control algorithms.
Index Keywords: Electric fault currents; Electric power system measurement; Electric power system protection; Electric power systems; Electric utilities; Energy resources; Monitoring; NASA; Space stations; State estimation; Testbeds; Electric power systems (EPS); Fault protection systems; High impedance fault; Limited energy resource; Power system operations; Storage subsystems; System monitoring; System protection; Electric power system control

Authors: Hall S.H., Raymond J.R.
Title: Geohydrologic characterization for aquifer thermal energy storage
Affiliations: Pacific Northwest Lab., United States
Authors with affiliations: Hall, S.H., Pacific Northwest Lab., United States; Raymond, J.R., Pacific Northwest Lab., United States
Abstract: Successful operation of an aquifer thermal energy storage system depends on three elements: 1) the presence of a suitable aquifer for ground-water supply and energy storage; 2) the availability of a source of free or low-cost thermal energy, such as industrial waste heat or environmental chill; and 3) a temporal mismatch between thermal energy availability and thermal energy use. Using conventional hydrogeologic methods for aquifer characterization, the presence of a suitable aquifer is the most difficult of these three elements to assess quantitatively. By combining conventional methods with drift-and-pumpback and point-dilution single-well tracer tests, however, the rate of ground-water flow, the effective porosity, and the vertical distribution of hydraulic conductivity of the aquifer can be estimated quickly and economically.
Index Keywords: Aquifers; Energy utilization; Flow of water; Heat storage; Hydrogeology; Thermal energy; Waste heat; Water supply; Aquifer characterization; Aquifer thermal energy storage; Conventional methods; Effective porosity; Energy availability; Thermal energy use; Tracer tests; Vertical distributions; Groundwater resources

Authors: Adinolfi M., Ruck W.
Title: Microbiological and environmental effects of aquifer thermal energy storage
Affiliations: Universität of Stuttgart, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Adinolfi, M., Universität of Stuttgart, Germany; Ruck, W., Universität of Stuttgart, Germany
Abstract: The storage of thermal energy, either heat or chill, in aquifers or impoundments creates local perturbations of the indigenous microflora and the environmental properties. Within an international working group of the International Energy Agency (IEA Annex VI*) possible environmental impacts of ATES**-systems were recognized and investigated. Investigations of storage systems on natural sites, man-made aquifers and large-scale models of impounded aquifers showed changes in microbial populations, but until now no adverse microbiological processes associated with ATES-systems could be documented (Winters, 1992). However, examinations with a model system indicate an increased risk of environmental impact. Therefore, the operation of ATES-systems should be accompanied by chemical and biological investigations.
Index Keywords: Aquifers; Heat storage; Hydrogeology; Thermal energy; Aquifer thermal energy storage; Chemical and biologicals; Environmental property; International energy agency; Large-scale models; Local perturbation; Microbial populations; Microbiological process; Environmental impact

Authors: Ashley C.R., Hayden J.H., Ibrahim T.H.
Title: An electrical power system for a mobile communications spacecraft
Affiliations: Hughes Aircraft Co., United States
Authors with affiliations: Ashley, C.R., Hughes Aircraft Co., United States; Hayden, J.H., Hughes Aircraft Co., United States; Ibrahim, T.H., Hughes Aircraft Co., United States
Abstract: A regulated high voltage solar array/battery system using large area silicon solar cells and a group of Ni-H energy storage cells meets the requirements of a multikilowatt geosynchronous orbit application. The electrical power bus operates at approximately 50 Vdc, minimizing unbalanced magnetic torques and distribution harness weight. The program design goal of 12 years of operation on station, including up to 2 years of orbital storage, represents a significant extension of total mission life.
