Authors: Bowles E.E., Heyse M.W., Cornette J.B.
Title: 30 kA, 5000 v solid state opening switch for inductive energy stores
Source title: 20th Conference Record on Power Modulator Symposium, MODSYM 1992
Affiliations: General Atomics, San Diego, CA  92186, United States; Wright Laboratory, Eglin Air Force Base, FL  32542, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bowles, E.E., General Atomics, San Diego, CA  92186, United States; Heyse, M.W., Wright Laboratory, Eglin Air Force Base, FL  32542, United States; Cornette, J.B., Wright Laboratory, Eglin Air Force Base, FL  32542, United States
Abstract: Inductive energy stores have demonstrated higher energy storage densities than capacitive energy stores. A limitation in the use of inductive energy stores has been the availability of adequately rated opening switches. A self commutated solid state switch has been developed for use as an opening device for an inductive energy store. A single switch module is rated at 30 kA and 5000 V. The charging pulse lengths for the intended application vary from 0.1 to 5 seconds. Efficiency and volumetric power density were optimized. The switch topology is a two stage hybrid consisting of an SCR-FET / SCR-IGBT combination. The switch is designed to charge an inductive energy store and repetitively commutate the current to a railgun load. The first of ten switch modules for a 250 kA switch has been built and successfully tested on a battery test stand at General Atomics. The theory of operation, circuit topology and test results are given in this paper. © 1992 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Capacitive energy stores; Energy storage density; General atomics; Opening switch; Solid state switch; Switch modules; Switch topology; Volumetric power density; Topology

Authors: Kim A., Zeto R., Youmans R., Weiner M.
Title: Monolithic, photoconductive GaAS switch with fast current turn-off properties
Source title: 20th Conference Record on Power Modulator Symposium, MODSYM 1992
Affiliations: ET and D Laboratory, Labcom, Fort Monmouth, NJ  07703-5000, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kim, A., ET and D Laboratory, Labcom, Fort Monmouth, NJ  07703-5000, United States; Zeto, R., ET and D Laboratory, Labcom, Fort Monmouth, NJ  07703-5000, United States; Youmans, R., ET and D Laboratory, Labcom, Fort Monmouth, NJ  07703-5000, United States; Weiner, M., ET and D Laboratory, Labcom, Fort Monmouth, NJ  07703-5000, United States
Abstract: A GaAs photoconductive wafer switch, forming a radial transmission line, has successfully generated narrow 5 kV pulses, about 500 ps wide, into a 50 Ω load. A mode locked NdYAG laser pulse was used to illuminate the wafer. Wider output pulses (-2 ns) were obtained when using laser diode illumination. With these devices the GaAs wafer serves as both the energy storage element and the switch. Normally the pulse behavior follows a capacitive decay. With these devices, however, a new mode of operation was observed, in which current turn-off was achieved in a time interval much smaller than the normal capacitive decay time. The conditions are described under which current turn-off is observed. A model is advanced, which includes avalanche effects, that accounts for the current turn-off. © 1992 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Gallium arsenide; III-V semiconductors; Photoconductivity; Semiconducting gallium; Avalanche effects; Current turns; Mode of operations; Mode-locked; Nd-YAG lasers; Output pulse; Storage elements; Time interval; Photoconductive switches

Authors: Vijayakumar M., Das S.
Title: Reliable crowbar protection for high power TWT
Source title: 20th Conference Record on Power Modulator Symposium, MODSYM 1992
Affiliations: Electronics and Radar Development Establishment, Bangalore, India
Authors with affiliations: Vijayakumar, M., Electronics and Radar Development Establishment, Bangalore, India; Das, S., Electronics and Radar Development Establishment, Bangalore, India
Abstract: Microwave Tubes are associated with high voltages which if proper protection is not taken are not only dangerous to persons working on it but also to the Tubes. This paper describes a simple but reliable method to protect a high power TWT amplifier. This circuit has been fabricated, successfully tested and working reliably in Radar Systems. In ground based radar transmitter systems, a high voltage energy storage capacitor is provided to meet the peak pulse current requirements and to minimize the 'droop' on the EHT pulse generated by the system. Energy stored in the capacitor is much higher (order of 100 times) than the safe energy the tube can dissipate in the event of an internal electrical arc. It becomes essential to save the costly tube from damage from this uncontrolled discharge. To achieve this a triggered spark gap is fired whenever excess current is sensed in any of the TWT electrodes. Spark gap triggering circuit is designed in such a way that a burst of pulses is generated immediately on sensing excess current. A current boosting circuit increases the power level of these pulses which guarantees the firing of the trigged spark gap.This effectively acts as a crowbar to safely dissipate the stored energy through a path away from the tube. © 1992 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Electric discharges; Microwave amplifiers; Radar; Superconducting materials; Tubes (components); Crowbar protection; Electrical arc; Energy storage capacitor; Excess current; Ground based radar; High-power TWT; Reliable methods; Triggering circuits; Traveling wave tubes

Authors: Thomas B.L., Strickland B.E., Cathell F.J.
Title: A 6 kA, 100 Hz SCR switched modulator for driving an inductive load
Source title: 20th Conference Record on Power Modulator Symposium, MODSYM 1992
Affiliations: Balboa Division, Maxwell Laboratories Inc., 8888 Balboa Ave., San Diego, CA  92123, United States
Authors with affiliations: Thomas, B.L., Balboa Division, Maxwell Laboratories Inc., 8888 Balboa Ave., San Diego, CA  92123, United States; Strickland, B.E., Balboa Division, Maxwell Laboratories Inc., 8888 Balboa Ave., San Diego, CA  92123, United States; Cathell, F.J., Balboa Division, Maxwell Laboratories Inc., 8888 Balboa Ave., San Diego, CA  92123, United States
Abstract: The SCR switch modulator provided current waveforms of the correct shape and amplitude required by the load. All components were sized to handle the 366 A RMS current provided by the 100 Hz, 6 kA peak current pulses. To protect the SCR switch from di/dt damage, a saturable reactor was used to limit the initial di/dt. The Maxwell CCDS power provided an efficient and reliable method of charging the energy storage capacitors. Special attention to thermal management issues assured that the ambient temperatures reached in the modulator during continuous operation were below those required by any component in the modulator. © 1992 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Continuous operation; Energy storage capacitor; Inductive loads; Peak currents; Reliable methods; Wave forms

Authors: Kirkman G., Hur J., Jiang B., Reinhardt N., Schoenbach K.
Title: GaAs switch controlled by low-energy electron beam
Source title: 20th Conference Record on Power Modulator Symposium, MODSYM 1992
Affiliations: Integrated Applied Physics, Inc., 50 Thayer Rd., Waltham, MA  02154, United States; Old Dominion University, Norfolk, VA  23529-0246, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kirkman, G., Integrated Applied Physics, Inc., 50 Thayer Rd., Waltham, MA  02154, United States; Hur, J., Integrated Applied Physics, Inc., 50 Thayer Rd., Waltham, MA  02154, United States; Jiang, B., Integrated Applied Physics, Inc., 50 Thayer Rd., Waltham, MA  02154, United States; Reinhardt, N., Integrated Applied Physics, Inc., 50 Thayer Rd., Waltham, MA  02154, United States; Schoenbach, K., Old Dominion University, Norfolk, VA  23529-0246, United States
Abstract: An electron-beam-controlled GaAs closing and opening switch with megahertz repetition rate capability has been demonstrated. A 2-mm thick semi-insulating GaAs bulk switch was switched at 250 V, 9 A/cm2 with less than 20 % dissipation and an opening time of 250 nsec. The switch was fabricated in a hermetically sealed vacuum package, incorporating an electron-beam driver and a bulk switch in a single modular unit. The switch uses a low voltage (< 50 keV) electron beam incident on the surface of the semiconductor sample to generate photons through cathodoluminescence; the photons then ionize the bulk sample as in photoconductive switch. The device exhibited a switching threshold at an electron-beam energy of about 35 keV and a low dissipation switching at 45 keV. The electron-beam- controlled GaAs switch results in a much higher overall system efficiency and less complexity due to the elimination of the high power laser required by direct photoconductive switching. This study has demonstrated the feasibility of producing electron-beam controlled semiconductor switches for practical applications. This switch can have application in many pulsed power systems including ballistic missile defense radar systems, radio-frequency induction accelerators, and systems that require an opening switch for inductive energy storage or for pulse length modulation. © 1992 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Ballistic missiles; Electric power systems; Electron beam lithography; Electron beams; Electrons; Gallium arsenide; High power lasers; III-V semiconductors; Photoconductivity; Photons; Semiconducting gallium; Semiconductor switches; Ballistic missile defense; Electron beam energy; Induction accelerators; Inductive energy storage; Low energy electron beams; Photoconductive switching; Pulsed power systems; Switching thresholds; Photoconductive switches

Authors: Bredenkamp G.L., Nel J.J.
Title: MOSFET laser pulsers: Opening or closing switches?
Source title: 20th Conference Record on Power Modulator Symposium, MODSYM 1992
Affiliations: Rand Afrikaans University, Auckland Park, P.O. Box 524, Johannesburg, 2000, South Africa
Authors with affiliations: Bredenkamp, G.L., Rand Afrikaans University, Auckland Park, P.O. Box 524, Johannesburg, 2000, South Africa; Nel, J.J., Rand Afrikaans University, Auckland Park, P.O. Box 524, Johannesburg, 2000, South Africa
Abstract: An inductive discharge system, with intermdiate capacitor, was optimised by means of a PSPICE simulation, for maximum energy transfer during the first 100 ns of the discharge. This system proved to be more efficient than a comparable 1 joule capacitor discharge system. It is finally concluded, however, that the capacitor storage system, with closing switch, is more cost effective than the inductive storage system with opening switch. © 1992 IEEE.

Authors: Zhang W., Bunicci J., Soukas A.V., Zhang S.Y.
Title: The booster to AGS beam transfer fast kicker systems
Source title: 20th Conference Record on Power Modulator Symposium, MODSYM 1992
Affiliations: AGS Department, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY  11973, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zhang, W., AGS Department, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY  11973, United States; Bunicci, J., AGS Department, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY  11973, United States; Soukas, A.V., AGS Department, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY  11973, United States; Zhang, S.Y., AGS Department, Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, NY  11973, United States
Abstract: The Brookhaven AGS Booster had a very successful commissioning period in June 1991. The third phase of that commissioning was a beam extraction test. The Booster extraction fast kicker (F3) deflected a 1.2 Gev proton beam from the Booster circulating orbit into the extraction septum aperture, partially down the.extraction line to a temporary beam stop. Now, the Booster is committed to the AGS operations program for both heavy ion and proton beams. Thus, the Booster extraction and the corresponding AGS injection systems must operate routinely up to a pulse repetition frequency of 7.5 Hertz, and up to a beam energy of 1.5 Gev. The injection fast kicker is located in the A5 section of the AGS ring and is used to deflect the proton or heavy ion beam into its final AGS closed orbit. The Booster extraction and the AGS injection fast kickers are both multi-module systems. Also, they both serve the dual-function of deflecting the proton or heavy ion beams, which require a change in pulse rise time, amplitude, flat top duration, and the fall time. For each system, the multiple modules are arranged electrically in parallel. Each module drives one lumped inductance picture frame magnet section, and the magnets are arranged mechanically in series. The pulsed current delivered from the modulator creates a pulsed magnetic field in the magnet aperture which imparts an angular deflection to the passing particle beam from/into the machine orbit. A distinctive feature of the AGS injection fast kicker modulators is the tail-bitting function required for proton beam injection. This enables the system to produce a fast current fall time (<140 ns) to go along with the high current pulse amplitude 1100 Ampere/module) modulator consists of two thyratrons. The main PFN thyratrons switch on the current, and the tail bitting thyratrons are used to force the magnet current to decrease rapidly. Two digital pulse delay generators are used to align the main thyratrons and the tail bitting thyratrons respectively. The system has been tested and installed. The final commissioning of the Booster to AGS beam transfer line and injection is currently being undertaken. In this article, the system design, realization techniques and performance data will be presented. © 1992 IEEE.

Authors: Podlesak T., Pastore R., Fonda K., Singh H., Behr S., Jusinski M., Creedon J.
Title: A mobile 2N megajoule pulser
Source title: 20th Conference Record on Power Modulator Symposium, MODSYM 1992
Affiliations: U.S. Army et and DL, Labcom, Fort Monmouth, NJ  07703-5000, United States; Vitronics, Eatontown, NJ, United States; Little Silver, NJ, United States
Authors with affiliations: Podlesak, T., U.S. Army et and DL, Labcom, Fort Monmouth, NJ  07703-5000, United States; Pastore, R., U.S. Army et and DL, Labcom, Fort Monmouth, NJ  07703-5000, United States; Fonda, K., U.S. Army et and DL, Labcom, Fort Monmouth, NJ  07703-5000, United States; Singh, H., U.S. Army et and DL, Labcom, Fort Monmouth, NJ  07703-5000, United States; Behr, S., Vitronics, Eatontown, NJ, United States; Jusinski, M., Vitronics, Eatontown, NJ, United States; Creedon, J., Little Silver, NJ, United States
Abstract: A completely mobile pulser system, capable of being built in two megajoules multiples, is described. The system consists of a power supply section, with a 1 megawatt diesel generator, which is housed in a 40 foot semitrailer, and a series of pulser modules, each capable of 2 megajoule energy storage, which may be housed in a variety of transportable containers. Each pulser module is a five section C type pulse forming network, controlled by triggered spark gaps. The five sections may be fired in any desired sequence, thus yielding any desired pulse waveform.Each pulser module measures 2 meters high by 6 meters long and less than 1 meter deep. As such, two such units may be mounted in a standard 20 foot shipping container or trailer, for a 4 MJ subsystem, or four in a forty foot container or trailer for an 8 MJ subsystem. Several of these subsystems may be arrayed together to provide an even larger pulser, transportable in sections in such containers. With the addition of the power supply section, such a system may be operated in a field setting, totally independent of power lines, since the power supply section holds not only the main charging generator but also a smaller auxiliary diesel generator for auxiliary power. Prior to installing the module in the mobile van it was assembled in the laboratory and its operation was evaluated. Satisfactory operation at 2 megajoules was demonstrated. Fault mode operation was also studied. The experimental observations are presented. © 1992 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Diesel engines; Auxiliary power; Diesel generators; Fault modes; Power lines; Power supply; Pulse forming networks; Shipping containers; Spark gaps; Containers

Authors: Wait G.D., Barnes M.J., Figley C.B.
Title: Results for the 150 kW prototype 1 MHz chopper at 100 % duty cycle
Source title: 20th Conference Record on Power Modulator Symposium, MODSYM 1992
Affiliations: TRIUMF, 4004 Wesbrook Mall, Vancouver, BC  V6T 2A3, Canada; SAL, Saskatoon, SK, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Wait, G.D., TRIUMF, 4004 Wesbrook Mall, Vancouver, BC  V6T 2A3, Canada; Barnes, M.J., TRIUMF, 4004 Wesbrook Mall, Vancouver, BC  V6T 2A3, Canada; Figley, C.B., SAL, Saskatoon, SK, Canada
Abstract: The KAON Factory at TRIUMF requires a 1 MHz chopper to create appropriate holes in the extracted 1 GeV/c H- cyclotron beam to allow sufficient time to operate kicker magnets. Deflection of beam bursts to be eliminated by the 1 MHz chopper will be predominantly provided by an electric field between a set of deflector plates. A novel design concept for the 1 MHz chopper has been developed involving an energy storage system where the electric pulses are stored in low loss coaxial cable. The beam chopper "kick" must have a rise and fall time of less than 39 ns and a flat top of at least 49 ns for "narrow" pulses and 92 ns for "wide" pulses. Results of the latest measurements on the single tetrode ("reference") design, at 100 % duty factor on a 2.2 MHz prototype using a 150 kW tetrode, are presented and compared with theoretical predictions. The measured rise and fall times for narrow pulse pattern meet the design goal, but rise and fall time for the wide pattern are not quite so satisfactory. However the rise and fall times are all expected to be within specification for a fully engineered version. © 1992 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Choppers (circuits); Electric fields; Beam chopper; Electric pulse; Energy storage systems; Kaon factories; Kicker magnets; Narrow pulse; Novel design; Rise and fall time; Electric losses

Authors: Jarvis L.
Title: Low cost, improved magnesium battery
Source title: Proceedings of the 35th International Power Sources Symposium
Affiliations: Electronic Technology Devices Laboratory, Power Sources Division, Fort Monmouth, NJ  07703-5000, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jarvis, L., Electronic Technology Devices Laboratory, Power Sources Division, Fort Monmouth, NJ  07703-5000, United States
Abstract: A prototype magnesium/manganese dioxide battery, the BA-4590/U, was developed as a cost-effective training battery replacement for the lithium/sulfur dioxide BA-5590/U battery. Requirements mandate the magnesium battery to be identical in size form, and function to its lithium counterpart. Testing demonstrated the delivered capacity of the magnesium BA-4590/U to be highly dependent upon discharge conditions. Continuous 500 mA discharge at 4.4, 21.1, and 43.3 degrees C delivered capacities of 2.0, 3.3, and 4.3 Ah, respectively. Under simulated intermittent use conditions the magnesium battery, due to anodic corrosion, lost approximately 1/3 of its available capacity during storage following partial usage. In addition, the effects of communication and electronics equipment drains were investigated. Overall, on the basis of projected cost per unit of delivered energy, the magnesium BA-4590/U battery has the potential for significant cost savings, particularly under low-power, tepid operating temperature conditions. © 1992 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Corrosion; Cost effectiveness; Costs; Lithium compounds; Magnesium compounds; Available capacity; Battery replacements; Cost effective; Cost per unit; Cost saving; Discharge conditions; Magnesium batteries; Operating temperature; Lithium batteries

Authors: Zagrodnik J., Jones K.
Title: Nickel-hydrogen battery-common pressure vessel
Source title: Proceedings of the 35th International Power Sources Symposium
Affiliations: Johnson Controls Battery Group, Inc., 12500 W. Silver Spring Drive, Butler, WI  53007, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zagrodnik, J., Johnson Controls Battery Group, Inc., 12500 W. Silver Spring Drive, Butler, WI  53007, United States; Jones, K., Johnson Controls Battery Group, Inc., 12500 W. Silver Spring Drive, Butler, WI  53007, United States
Abstract: Common pressure vessel (CPV) Ni-H2 battery designs have been developed for geosynchronous (GEO) and low Earth orbit (LEO) aerospace applications, terrestrial remote energy storage, and aircraft starting. The first aerospace CPV prototype, a 10 in diameter, 24 Ah, 26 cell battery, was fabricated in 1988. A second generation 5 in diameter aerospace CPV was then developed which incorporated a loose heat fin designed to overcome the manufacturing problems that caused the premature failure of the first prototype. In addition to the revised heat fin, the second generation battery incorporated several additional design improvements which enhanced the reliability and manufacturability of the CPV. Based on the early success of the loose fin design approach in the 5 in design, the same approach was adapted for use in the original 10 in version. Prototypes of this design have been produced in a 125 Ah GEO version as well as a high power prototype aircraft starting battery. The design for terrestrial applications is discussed. The testing of the three load profiles demonstrated the excellent performance and flexibility of the CPV Ni-H2 battery. Simple battery control schemes based on charge pressure and discharge voltage proved adequate. The ability of the battery to withstand catastrophic system failures and total discharge proved to be a valuable asset. © 1992 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Aerospace applications; Aircraft; Fins (heat exchange); Hydrogen; Nickel compounds; Orbits; Pressure vessels; Systems engineering; Common pressure vessels; Design improvements; Discharge voltages; High power prototype; Low earth orbit(LEO); Nickel hydrogen batteries; Premature failures; Terrestrial application; Secondary batteries

Authors: Jaenke P.E.
Title: Weight, volume, and power consumption reductions in Side Look Sonar Systems for autonomous underwater vehicles
Source title: Proceedings of the 1992 Symposium on Autonomous Underwater Vehicle Technology, AUV 1992
Affiliations: Westinghouse Electric Corporation, Oceanic Division, P.O. Box 1488, M.S. 9105, Annapolis, MD  21404, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jaenke, P.E., Westinghouse Electric Corporation, Oceanic Division, P.O. Box 1488, M.S. 9105, Annapolis, MD  21404, United States
Abstract: This paper describes research to increase the capability of autonomous underwater vehicles (AUVs) for search applications. Reducing the "hotel load" contribution of the Side Looking Sonar System increases the endurance of the AUV. Technologies and designs that reduce the weight, volume, and power consumption of the transducers and electronics are explored and developed. Recent trends in the underwater search arena are moving systems away from towed vehicles toward tethered and ultimately to AUVs. In towed search vehicles, weight is required to counter the upward force of the tow cable; whereas, for free swimming AUVs, minimizing the vehicle weight is necessary to achieve neutral buoyancy. Furthermore, for towed vehicles, mission duration is not limited by search vehicle endurance; however, the weight, volume, and power consumption all contribute to the hotel load of the AUVs, thus reducing endurance. Reduced weight means less vehicle displacement or floatation is needed to achieve neutral buoyancy. Less displacement, or lower volume, can allow either lower drag area or greater volume for energy storage. Finally, reducing the power consumption allows the redirection of the finite energy available from hotel load to the propulsion system. A detailed analysis of a state-of-the-art SLS system is performed to obtain a baseline for the study. The relative contributions of transducer, electronics, and interconnections toward the weight, volume, and power consumption are determined. This provides valuable direction in selecting areas where improvements are most promising. Research and analysis is performed to determine and trade off technologies, materials, processes, and designs which produce the greatest improvements. Detail applications of these technologies are developed into design concepts. Finally, an improved SLS system design is formulated iv anticipation of fabricating a working prototype. © 2019 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Autonomous vehicles; Buoyancy; Economic and social effects; Electric power utilization; Hotels; Propulsion; Sonar; Transducers; Underwater acoustics; Of autonomous underwater vehicles; Power consumption reduction; Propulsion system; Relative contribution; Research and analysis; Search application; Side-looking sonars; Underwater searches; Autonomous underwater vehicles

Authors: Surina I.I.
Title: On a continuous-type associative memory
Source title: Proceedings 1992 RNNS/IEEE Symposium on Neuroinformatics and Neurocomputers, RNNS 1992

Authors with affiliations: Surina, I.I., Russian National Research Center, Kurchatov Institute, Kurchatov Square, 1, Moscow, 123182, Russian Federation
Abstract: Some considerations on a notion of a associative memory are first presented. A novel model of an associative memory with complex-valued neurons is then presented. The proposed model, called an associative complex-valued neural network (ACNN), and its variations can lead to many useful applications. It has a clear algebraic structure which helps in the analysis of its properties. It is suggested that it might be possible to find an energy function resembling Hopfield's and that learning without spurious memories might be constructed in this model. Hopfield's model is embedded into the ACNN and can be examined in this context. © 1992 IEEE.

Authors: Yin W., Tanaka J., Damon D.H.
Title: Thermally stimulated discharge in filled LDPE films
Source title: Annual Report - Conference on Electrical Insulation and Dielectric Phenomena, CEIDP
Affiliations: Electrical Insulation Research Center, Institute of Materials Science University of Connecticut, Storrs, CT  06269-3136, United States
Authors with affiliations: Yin, W., Electrical Insulation Research Center, Institute of Materials Science University of Connecticut, Storrs, CT  06269-3136, United States; Tanaka, J., Electrical Insulation Research Center, Institute of Materials Science University of Connecticut, Storrs, CT  06269-3136, United States; Damon, D.H., Electrical Insulation Research Center, Institute of Materials Science University of Connecticut, Storrs, CT  06269-3136, United States
Abstract: The accumulation of space charges in the polymeric insulation distorts the uniform electric field distribution and causes breakdown [1-3]. The knowledge of how the space charges form and are stored in the dielectrics thus becomes important. Various advanced methods, including thermal pulses, pressure wave propagation and electro-acoustic pulses, have been developed to study the space charge distribution in solid dielectrics W. However, the effect on space charge formation by fillers, which are often used with polymeric insulation, is not well understood and studied. It was found that the breakdown behavior of filled EPR item was very much dependent on the chemical structure of the fillers . To understand how the chemical structure of fillers affects space charge formation and storage in the filled polymeric insulation, we have investigated the carrier traps in LDPE films filled with different type of zeolites by the measurement of thermally stimulated current. The characteristics of trapped carriers is assigned, and relaxation time as well as the activation energy is calculated by computer simulation based on a single relaxation time model. Other thermal analysis methods, including differential scanning calorimetry (DSC), dynamic mechanical thermal analysis (DMTA), time-domain dielectric loss spectroscopy (TDS), are also employed to elucidate molecular relaxation behavior. © 1992 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Acoustic wave propagation; Activation energy; Dielectric losses; Dielectric materials; Differential scanning calorimetry; Electric fields; Electric insulation; Electric space charge; Fillers; Relaxation time; Structure (composition); Thermal insulation; Thermoanalysis; Zeolites; D. dynamic mechanical thermal analyses (DMTA); Polymeric insulation; Pressure wave propagation; Single relaxation time models; Space charge formations; Thermally stimulated current; Thermally stimulated discharges; Uniform electric fields; Time domain analysis

Authors: Stuchly S.S., Sibbald C.L.
Title: A new model for open-ended dielectric sensors
Affiliations: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Victoria, P.O. Box 3055, Victoria, BC  V8W3P6, Canada; Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Ottawa, Ottawa, ON  KIN6N5, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Stuchly, S.S., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Victoria, P.O. Box 3055, Victoria, BC  V8W3P6, Canada; Sibbald, C.L., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Ottawa, Ottawa, ON  KIN6N5, Canada
Abstract: A new approach to modeling of open-ended dielectric sensors used for measurements of homogeneous, lossy dielectrics is presented. The model is based on the physical and mathematical properties of the driving point admittance of passive, stable one-port networks. The model parameters, which depend upon the geometry of the waveguide and aperture, are accurately determined from a relatively small number of admittances computed using Moment method. This computed data is obtained by a full-wave solution and, hence, includes the effects of radiation and energy storage in the near field and the evanescent modes. The accuracy of the numerical method is demonstrated by comparison with measured values. As an example, the mode] parameters are determined for the coaxial-line geometry of the sensor. The accuracy of the model, for both the direct and inverse problem, is verified. The new model has important practical applications in the field dielectric spectroscopy. © 1992 IEEE.

Vetoio, Coppito L'Aquila, 67010, Italy
Abstract: The switches and energy storage elements losses, that only marginally affect the cyclic steady state of Switch-Mode Power Supplies, may drastically change their dynamic behavior. In coupledinductors topologies both "iron" and "copper" losses must be separately modeled in the equivalent circuit of the reactive components. The paper analyzes in detail the effects of each loss component in a coupled-inductor Cuk cell, under direct and indirect control, by means of an original state-space Z-transform-based method. Experimental data measured on a small-power prototype are reported. © 1992 IEEE.

Authors: Franck F., Schröder D.
Title: The influence of finite rated filter and energy-storage elements on the behaviour of multi-resonant single-cell converters
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Technische Universität München, Lehrstuhl für Elektrische Antriebstechnik, Arcisstraße 21, München 2, 8000, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Franck, F., Technische Universität München, Lehrstuhl für Elektrische Antriebstechnik, Arcisstraße 21, München 2, 8000, Germany; Schröder, D., Technische Universität München, Lehrstuhl für Elektrische Antriebstechnik, Arcisstraße 21, München 2, 8000, Germany
Abstract: In most cases filters are treated as sources with constant characteristics. But in reality finite rated filter and energy-storage elements have a large impact on the behaviour of DC-DC converters working in resonant mode. They change the operating area and define the low-frequency characteristics. These effects are shown together with the mathematical backgrounds. To optimize a resonattt converter - e.g. to reduce the stresses and to improve the efficiency - the proper design of filter and energystorage components is also necessary, beside the design of the resonant elements. As example a ZVS multi-resonant Cuk converter is investigated. In detail it will be shown that by shrinking the rating of the Cuk typical capacitor and by altering the winding ratios of transformer and coupled inductor the operating area will be improved. © 1992 IEEE.

Abstract: This paper is concentcd with the measurement and analysis of insulation property of PP (polypropylene) film after it is radiated by X-ray λ = 1.54 A). The DRJC {Delayed Radiation Induced conductivety is found in experiments. The result shows that resistivity p of the sample decreases with the increasing dose rate and recovers gradunlly to original value in period of storage, The p of sample exposed with different doze rates have the similar recov- cring speed in starting period of stoiage. (The slopes of p curves are the same when is smaller). If the samper is radiated for a enuough long time with a larger dose rate, the p couldn't recover completely. TSC-{Thermally Stimulated Current) test shows it is possible that some delerts arc formed in this situntion. In order to explain the experiment, we use the excitation and reconbination ihcoiy of electron-hole pairs, suppose an energy-level model of PP material Theoretical deduction agrees with experiment basically Conbining deduced formula with test data, we can know that the same slopes of starting part of p-1 curves means that the reconbination facter of electrons and holes in PP film can be treated as a constant. © 1992 IEEE.

Authors: Matsuo H., Hayashi H., Kurokawa F., Asano M.
Title: Output characteristics in the discontinuous reactor current mode of the zero-voltage switching DC-DC converter
Affiliations: Dept. of Electron., Nagasaki Univ., Nagasaki, 852, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Matsuo, H., Dept. of Electron., Nagasaki Univ., Nagasaki, 852, Japan; Hayashi, H., Dept. of Electron., Nagasaki Univ., Nagasaki, 852, Japan; Kurokawa, F., Dept. of Electron., Nagasaki Univ., Nagasaki, 852, Japan; Asano, M., Dept. of Electron., Nagasaki Univ., Nagasaki, 852, Japan
Abstract: It is often observed that the switching frequency in the zero-voltage switching DC-DC converter becomes extremely low when the load current increases and/or when the input voltage decreases. This lowering deteriorates the advantage of the high frequency in designing the energy-storage elements of the DC-DC converter. The output characteristics of the zero-voltage switching DC-DC converter operating in the discontinuous reactor current mode are analyzed. It is shown that there exists a useful discontinuous mode in which the variation of the switching frequency can be restricted within +or-5% when the output voltage can be regulated for the load change from no load to full load or for +or-15% change of the input voltage. The voltage stress of the switch can be sufficiently suppressed compared with that in the continuous reactor current mode. © 1992 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Current voltage characteristics; DC-DC converters; Electric inverters; Continuous reactors; Discontinuous mode; High frequency HF; Input voltages; Output characteristics; Output voltages; Storage elements; Voltage stress; Zero voltage switching

Title: Multistage switching power supply circuits

Abstract: A method for designing the output stage of switching power supplies by employing multiple stage circuit structures is presented. Using this method, the switching noise at the output of the power supply can be reduced dramatically, while keeping the cost of the circuit almost the same as that for a single stage supply. The method treats the output stage circuit from the view point of a filter network, instead of that of energy storage. The analyses and results for the circuits are given. © 1992 IEEE.

Authors: Kwan K.S., Tsai M.H.
Title: Superconducting magnetic energy storage for voltage stabilizer in electric power systems
Source title: IEEE International Symposium on Industrial Electronics
Affiliations: Materials Research Laboratories, Industrial Technology Research Institute, Chutung, Hsinchu, 31015, Taiwan
Authors with affiliations: Kwan, K.S., Materials Research Laboratories, Industrial Technology Research Institute, Chutung, Hsinchu, 31015, Taiwan; Tsai, M.H., Materials Research Laboratories, Industrial Technology Research Institute, Chutung, Hsinchu, 31015, Taiwan
Abstract: Superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) which consists of a 6.7 H superconducting coil and a 50 ampere 36 volt three-phase power converter has been developed. The bidirectional converter uses a single bridge IGBT. The independent control of active and reactive power is achieved by controlling the phase and modulation index using the PWM method. The SMES system was connected to a simple power system model consisting of: A three-phase isolator power transformer connected to the power utility; three 28 mH inductors as a transmission line model; and a 1/2 hp induction motor as a disturbance source. The PWM pattern, synchronized with the power system, was generated by a hardware circuit to have a fast response. A hardware circuit to calculate RMS voltage, and the active and reactive power of the system has also been developed. They were interfaced to a personal computer, in which two proportional integral (PI) control loops were calculated to keep the superconducting current and the voltage of power system model at their target values. By running the induction motor, a voltage drop was created; using SMES system, the undervoltage was quickly compensated. In this paper, the experimental performances of the SMES system are presented. © 1992 IEEE.

Authors: Nakamura Y., Kudou T., Ishibashi F., Hibino S.
Title: High-efficiency drive due to power factor control of a permanent magnet synchronous motor
Source title: Conference Proceedings - IEEE Applied Power Electronics Conference and Exposition - APEC

Abstract: A drive system of a permanent magnet motor without magnetic position detector is described. Generally, the position data of a magnet is obtained from terminal voltage of the motor. In the newly developed method, the inverter dc-link current waveform provides the control signal for driving without a detector. Since the power factor of the motor is controlled at around 1.0, the motor runs at a higher efficiency than that of the conventional method. Therefore, this control method saves energy. Current pulsation induced by sudden load fluctuations has been studied and its stabilization has been achieved. This paper provides the principle and operation of the new control method, simulated characteristics and experimental results. © 1992 IEEE.

Abstract: This paper presents a method of fundamental reactive power compensation of three-phase systems which does not need any energy storage elements is presented. A set of bidirectional switches is imposed between the supply lines and the load. Alternate switching of one supply line and two load lines is the basis of the operation. The basis of the system is phase angle modulation. © 1992 IEEE.

Title: DRAM variable retention time

Box 218, Yorktown Heights, NY  10598, United States, IBM Technology Products, Essex Junction, VT  05452, United States
Abstract: A DRAM bit has variable retention time (VRT) when the memory cell leakage, which determines how long a cell can retain information, varies with time. This paper reports on a study of VRT in cells from 4Mbit and 16 Mbit DRAM chips produced by a variety of manufacturers and in a number of technologies including trench capacitor and stacked capacitor cells. VRT cells were found on all chips. This paper describes the detection and characterization of two classes of VRT cells: 2-state and multi-state VRT cells, and presents a model containing 4 activation energies and 3 pre-factors that describes the temperature dependence of retention times and transition rates for the 2-state VRT cells. A description of new test techniques and the analysis needed to detect and study VRT are provided as well as examples from typical 4 Mbit chips. © 1992 IEEE.
