Abstract: The gains of gated MCPIIs at high repetition rates (up to 10 kHz) were measured. Comparisons were made between the gain behavior of a standard ITT type F4111 MCPII and similar device incorporating a high strip current microchannel plate. The most notable effect observed for the standard MCPII is a decline in luminous gain with increasing gate repetition rate and with higher input irradiances. The intensifier with the higher strip current microchannel plate (MCP), on the other hand, exhibited little or no reduction in gain for gating frequencies up to 10 kHz under similar test conditions (60 pJ/cm2 input energy density). The charge storage capacity and recharge time of the standard MCPII are most likely the limiting factors in its ability to maintain a constant gain at high repetition rates. The limiting effect of the recharge time on the MCP gain is calculated and compared to the actual measurements. © 1992 SPIE. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Image storage tubes; Microchannels; Video recording; Actual measurements; Charge storage capacity; Constant gain; High repetition rate; Limiting effects; Micro channel plate; Repetition rate; Test condition; High speed photography

Authors: Nelson S.O.
Title: Potential agricultural applications for microwave energy
Affiliations: U.S. Dept. of Agriculture, Agricultural Research Service, Russell Research Center, P.O. Box 5677, Athens, GA  30613, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nelson, S.O., U.S. Dept. of Agriculture, Agricultural Research Service, Russell Research Center, P.O. Box 5677, Athens, GA  30613, United States
Abstract: Research findings are reviewed concerning certain microwave energy applications that have been studied for potential use in agriculture. Included are product drying seed treatment for stimulation of germination stored-product insect control product processing to improve nutritional value or improve quality retention in storage, and sensing of product moisture content. © 1992 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Seed; Thermal processing (foods); Microwave energies; Nutritional value; Product moisture content; Product processing; Quality retention; Seed treatment; Stored-product insect; Microwaves

Authors: Matsuo H., Kurokawa F., Iida K., Koga T., Kishimoto T.
Title: An improved gate drive circuit using an air core reactor developed for high power GTO thyristors
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference
Affiliations: Department of Electronics, Nagasaki University, Nagasaki, 852, Japan; Toyo Electric Mfg. Co., Ltd., Sagami Works, Kanagawa, 243-04, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Matsuo, H., Department of Electronics, Nagasaki University, Nagasaki, 852, Japan; Kurokawa, F., Department of Electronics, Nagasaki University, Nagasaki, 852, Japan; Iida, K., Toyo Electric Mfg. Co., Ltd., Sagami Works, Kanagawa, 243-04, Japan; Koga, T., Toyo Electric Mfg. Co., Ltd., Sagami Works, Kanagawa, 243-04, Japan; Kishimoto, T., Toyo Electric Mfg. Co., Ltd., Sagami Works, Kanagawa, 243-04, Japan
Abstract: This paper presents an improved gate drive circuit for high power GTO thyristors. The energy-storage/transfer characteristics of an air-core reactor and the fast switching characteristics of FET are employed to make the high gate current of sharp pulse form. The power loss in the gate drive circuit can be reduced by using the low resistance and the hysteresis comparator to detect and control the steady on-gate current. The proposed gate drive circuit is analysed and its usefulness is confirmed by experiments. © 1992 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Timing circuits; Air-core reactor; Fast switching; Gate current; Gate drive circuits; High power; Hysteresis comparator; Low resistance; Power-losses; Thyristors

Authors: Mehta R.K., Schultz C.W.
Title: A Novel Energy Efficient Process for Ultra-Fine Coal Grinding
Affiliations: Mineral Resources Institute, The University of Alabama, Box 870204, Tuscaloosa, Alabama, 35487-0204, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mehta, R.K., Mineral Resources Institute, The University of Alabama, Box 870204, Tuscaloosa, Alabama, 35487-0204, United States; Schultz, C.W., Mineral Resources Institute, The University of Alabama, Box 870204, Tuscaloosa, Alabama, 35487-0204, United States
Abstract: This paper presents the results of an experimental study undertaken to demonstrate the feasibility of using silica sand as a grinding media in stirred ball mills for ultra-fine coal grinding. Laboratory batch as well as bench scale continuous tests indicate that when fracturing silica sand is substituted for steel media, then superior energy savings on the order of 50% and more can be realized. Moreover, this approach has been found to eliminate the disadvantages observed with grinding using steel media such as high replacement cost, contamination of coal through media wear, greater degree of coal oxidation due to higher slurry temperature and greater level of noise dissipation. Additionally, coal-sand attrition system reduces the manpower time because steel media after grinding needs precautionary measures to be taken such as thorough cleaning and their storage in inert atmosphere to avoid rust and corrosion problems. © 1992, Taylor & Francis Group, LLC. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: media wear; specific energy; stirred ball mills; ultra-fine grinding

Authors: Himdan T.A., Noethig-Laslo V., Bilinski H.
Title: Paramagnetic molecular centers in the gamma-irradiated precipitates obtained in the system AlCl3-beta-alanine-NaOH
Source title: International Journal of Radiation Applications and Instrumentation. Part
Affiliations: Ruder Bošković Institute, 41000 Zagreb, Croatia
Authors with affiliations: Himdan, T.A., Ruder Bošković Institute, 41000 Zagreb, Croatia; Noethig-Laslo, V., Ruder Bošković Institute, 41000 Zagreb, Croatia; Bilinski, H., Ruder Bošković Institute, 41000 Zagreb, Croatia
Abstract: The presented results are the continuation of our work on paramagnetic molecular centers in the model clay compounds. Here it was attempted to incorporate β-alanine in the aluminium hydroxide matrix. A series of precipitates were prepared with the highest ratio of β-alanine/Al = 0.22 obtained at pH = 7. X-ray diffraction analysis revealed in addition to amorphous precipitates, microcrystalline samples of four different X-ray patterns in nine precipitates, indicating variations in the structure of aluminium hydroxide matrix with incorporated β-alanine. Selected samples were exposed to γ-irradiation at 77 K, and at room temperature (293 K) in the presence and in the absence of air. In all the samples of amorphous structure no stable paramagnetic centers were determined by ESR after γ-irradiation in air. In all samples of microcrystalline structure similar stable paramagnetic centers were determined by ESR after γ-irradiation in air and in the evacuated tubes. These paramagnetic centers that we were unable to identify due to the poor resolution of the lines in the ESR spectrum can be most probably ascribed to structural defects introduced into the aluminium hydroxide matrix by β-alanine. In all amorphous samples γ-irradiated in the absence of air, the radical C̊H2CH2COOH formed by abstraction of amino group from the β-alanine was determined by ESR. The radical was unstable in air. Thus in the absence of air β-alanine may be considered as a storage site for the γ-irradiation energy in the amorphous aluminium hydroxides. © 1992.

Authors: Pauly S.
Title: The radiation resistance of thermoset plastics-III. Oxygen permeation experiments
Source title: International Journal of Radiation Applications and Instrumentation. Part
Affiliations: Hoechst AG Werk Kalle-Albert, D-W, 6200 Wiesbaden, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Pauly, S., Hoechst AG Werk Kalle-Albert, D-W, 6200 Wiesbaden, Germany
Abstract: For the interpretation of the results of long term irradiation experiments in the presence of air it is necessary to know about the penetration of oxygen into the plastic material in the course of time. Therefore the oxygen permeability of two thermoset plastics (made from two unsaturated polyester resin thermosetting moulding compounds) was measured in the temperature range 20-60°C. For the Typ 802, the following data were generated at 23°C: permeability coefficient P=3.08 × 10-15cm3·cm{plus 45 degree rule}cm2·s·Pa, diffusion coefficient D=1.03×10-8cm2{plus 45 degree rule}s, solubility coefficient S=3.00×10-7cm3{plus 45 degree rule}cm3·Pa. The permeability of two thermoset phenol-formaldehyde plastics and one melamine-formaldehyde plastic was found to be immeasurably small, i.e. P<3×10-17cm3·cm{plus 45 degree rule}cm2·s·,Pa at 60°C. For discs of 4mm thickness made from the polyester plastics, oxygen concentration profiles were calculated which are built up in the course of time during storage in air at 23°C. For both other materials the profiles were estimated by assuming P=3×10-17 at 60°C and the activation energy and the solubility being the same as in the case of polyester plastics. © 1992.

Authors: Tiller W.A.
Title: Fundamental aspects of film nucleation and growth in chemical vapor deposition
Affiliations: Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Stanford University, Stanford, California, 94305-2205, United States
Authors with affiliations: Tiller, W.A., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Stanford University, Stanford, California, 94305-2205, United States
Abstract: The importance of surface reconstruction plus the generation of stress and electric fields at expanding islands during film formation are extremely important considerations for both surface cluster formation and ledge movement kinetics in the overall film deposition process. Using computer simulations and semi-empirical potential energy functions for Si and GaAs, both long-range field effects and cluster excess energy effects are demonstrated. Using a continuum approach with a ledge energy that depends on cluster radius, great differences relative to the classical nucleation picture are found. For vicinal surface orientations, an equation for film growth velocity is developed which incorporates gas phase transport, surface transport, ledge collection efficiency, ledge attachment kinetics and excess energy storage due to deposition stress and adsorbate trapping. The paper first treats the case of Si film formation from SiH4 in H2 with only SiH2 forming in the adlayer. It then extends the treatment to deal with other Si intermediates formed in the adlayer which then desorb into the gas phase. Finally, the treatment is extended to consider SiNx film formation from SiH4 + NH3 in H2. © 1992, Elsevier Sequoia. All rights reserved. All rights reserved.

Authors: Schreiner K.E., Roth M.E.
Title: Resonant mode controllers for launch vehicle applications
Source title: Conference Proceedings - IEEE Applied Power Electronics Conference and Exposition - APEC
Affiliations: General Dynamics, Space Systems Division, P.O. Box 85990 MZ22-8740, San Diego, CA  92129, United States; NASA Lewis Research Center, 21000 Brookpark Rd. MS301-2, Cleveland, OH  44135, United States
Authors with affiliations: Schreiner, K.E., General Dynamics, Space Systems Division, P.O. Box 85990 MZ22-8740, San Diego, CA  92129, United States; Roth, M.E., NASA Lewis Research Center, 21000 Brookpark Rd. MS301-2, Cleveland, OH  44135, United States
Abstract: Electro-mechanical actuator (EMA) systems are currently being investigated for the National Launch System (NLS) as a replacement for hydraulic actuators due to the large amount of manpower and support hardware required to maintain the hydraulic systems. EMA systems in weight sensitive applications, such as launch vehicles, have been limited to around 5 HP due to system size, controller efficiency, thermal management, and battery size. This paper presents design and test data for an EMA system that competes favorably in weight and is superior in maintainability to the hydraulic system. An EMA systarr. uses dc power provided by a high energy density bipolar lithium thionyl chloride battery, with power conversion performed by low loss resonant topologies, and a high efficiency induction motor controlled with a high performance field oriented controller to drive a linear actuator. © 1992 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Controllers; Digital storage; Electromechanical devices; Hydraulic actuators; Hydraulic equipment; Induction motors; Launch vehicles; Linear actuators; Lithium batteries; Lithium Chloride; Mechanical actuators; Power electronics; Secondary batteries; Design and tests; Electro mechanical actuator (EMA); High energy densities; Hydraulic system; Power conversion; Thionyl chlorides; Vehicle applications; Weight-sensitive applications; Electromechanical actuators

Authors: Wesche R.
Title: Optimization studies of solenoidal windings for superconducting magnetic energy storage
Affiliations: Paul Scherrer Institute (PSI), CH-5232 Villigen, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Wesche, R., Paul Scherrer Institute (PSI), CH-5232 Villigen, Switzerland
Abstract: A simple model of hoop stress and quench behaviour has been developed for NbTi cable-in-conduit conductors. Using this model the winding volume necessary for a superconducting solenoid with a stored energy of 50 kW h has been investigated as a function of solenoid shape and maximum magnetic field at the conductor. However, this model is not restricted to the case considered and may be used for a superconducting solenoid with an arbitrary amount of stored energy. While a minimum superconducting volume is economically desirable, too thin a winding leads to prohibitively high current densities. The current density is nearly independent of the ratio of solenoid length to diameter. The optimum operating field is about 5 T, below which the necessary winding volume decreases only slowly with decreasing field. © 1992.
Author Keywords: energy storage; NbTi; superconducting magnets

Authors: Kienle P.
Title: Directions of heavy ion research at low and intermediate energies
Affiliations: Gesellschaft für Schwerionenforschung (GSI), Postfach 11 05 52, D-6100 Darmstadt 11, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Kienle, P., Gesellschaft für Schwerionenforschung (GSI), Postfach 11 05 52, D-6100 Darmstadt 11, Germany
Abstract: Recent developments and advances in heavy ion research at low and intermediate energies are reviewed. Emphasis is layed on the progress of accelerator technology, especially in producing high phase space density heavy ion beams in cooler-storage rings. A report is presented on some selected topics of current interest in nuclear structure research such as the production of super-heavy elements, the excitation of multi-phonon vibrational states and giant-dipole resonances. Nuclear dynamics studies from the Coulomb barrier to relativistics energies will be addressed including the production of dense heated and excited nuclear matter and the study of the properties of hadrons in such a medium. Finally, some atomic physics experiments with heavy ions will be presented with emphasis on quasi-atomic e+e- pair production. © 1992.

Authors: Green M.A.
Title: Helium cooling systems for large superconducting physics detector magnets
Affiliations: Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory Berkeley, CA 94720, United States
Authors with affiliations: Green, M.A., Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory Berkeley, CA 94720, United States
Abstract: The large superconducting detector magnets used for high energy physics experiments are virtually all indirectly cooled. In general, these detector magnets are not cryogenically stabilized. Therefore, there are a number of choices for cooling large indirectly cooled detector magnets. These choices include; 1) forced two-phase helium cooling driven by the helium refrigerator J-T circuit, 2) forced two-phase helium cooling driven by a helium pump, and 3) a peculation gravity feed cooling system which uses liquid helium from a large storage dewar. The choices for the cooling of a large detector magnet are illustrated by applying these concepts to a 4.2 meter diameter 0.5 tesla thin superconducting solenoid for an experiment at the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider (RHIC). © 1992.

Authors: Nowak G.
Title: Rare B, D meson decays from crystal ball
Affiliations: Institute of Nuclear Physics, High Energy Physics Laboratory, Kawiory 26A, 30-055 Cracow, Poland
Authors with affiliations: Nowak, G., Institute of Nuclear Physics, High Energy Physics Laboratory, Kawiory 26A, 30-055 Cracow, Poland
Abstract: The Crystal Ball detector at e+e- storage ring DORIS II has been used to search for rare B and D meson decays. We have looked for the radiative B meson decays of the type b → sγ. No mono-energetic γ-lines have been found in the inclusive photon spectrum from γ(4S) decays and upper limits are obtained for radiative decays of B mesons to various strange mesons. Integrating the photon spectrum over the corresponding energy range, we get BR(B → γX) < 2.8 × 10-3 at 90% confidence level for the mass range 892 MeV < Mx < 2045 MeV. We have also searched for the decay modes D → π°π° and B → π°π°. No evidence for these Cabibbo suppressed decays was found and 90% confidence level upper limits of BR(D → π°π°) < 3.8 × 10-3 and BR(B → π°π°) < 4.6 × 10-4 are given. © 1992.

Authors: Chang-Yong C., Hsieh C.K.
Title: Solution of Stefan problems imposed with cyclic temperature and flux boundary conditions
Source title: International Journal of Heat and Mass Transfer
Affiliations: Mechanical Engineering Department, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL 32611, United States
Authors with affiliations: Chang-Yong, C., Mechanical Engineering Department, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL 32611, United States; Hsieh, C.K., Mechanical Engineering Department, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL 32611, United States
Abstract: Stefan problems imposed with cyclic temperature and flux boundary conditions are solved by using source and sink methods. A source front is associated with a moving freeze front while a sink front is associated with a moving melt front. The solution is expressed in a set of coupled integrodifferential equations, which are solved numerically for interface positions, temperature profiles, and cumulative and instantaneous heat storage and release. The solution methods have been shown to be unique, convergent, stable, and accurate. While they are used to test one cycle each of the temperature and flux conditions, the developed methods are general and applicable to multiple cycles. The numerical results reveal interesting phenomena not previously reported in the literature. Their relevance to energy storage and material processing and treatment is also covered. © 1992.

Authors: Seifritz W.
Title: Partial and total reduction of CO2-emissions of automobiles using CO2-traps
Affiliations: Institute for Energy Economics, the Rational Use, Energy University of Stuttgart, Heßbrühlstr. 49a, D-7000 Stuttgart 80, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Seifritz, W., Institute for Energy Economics, the Rational Use, Energy University of Stuttgart, Heßbrühlstr. 49a, D-7000 Stuttgart 80, Germany
Abstract: A new hybrid hydrogen/hydrocarbon-driven motor-car is proposed which is equipped with a CO2-trap and which exhibits an energy absorption ability in its storage systems (with respect to their masses) much larger than that of a hydrogen- or battery-powered car. The principal idea is to use light metal hydrides (like MgH2) as energy storage facilities whose metallic atoms not only carry fuel atoms but, if is discharged, also the carbon dioxide from the burned hydrocarbons. In the opinion of the author, a system is presented for the first time which would be able to bind and collect the CO2 of a large number of diffuse CO2-sources for the purpose of its central disposal. © 1992.

Authors: Okken P.A., Lako P., Gerbers D., Kram T., Ybema J.R.
Title: CO2 removal in competition with other options for reducing CO2 emissions
Affiliations: ESC/Energy Studies, Netherlands Energy Research Foundation ECN, PO Box 1, 1755 ZG Petten, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Okken, P.A., ESC/Energy Studies, Netherlands Energy Research Foundation ECN, PO Box 1, 1755 ZG Petten, Netherlands; Lako, P., ESC/Energy Studies, Netherlands Energy Research Foundation ECN, PO Box 1, 1755 ZG Petten, Netherlands; Gerbers, D., ESC/Energy Studies, Netherlands Energy Research Foundation ECN, PO Box 1, 1755 ZG Petten, Netherlands; Kram, T., ESC/Energy Studies, Netherlands Energy Research Foundation ECN, PO Box 1, 1755 ZG Petten, Netherlands; Ybema, J.R., ESC/Energy Studies, Netherlands Energy Research Foundation ECN, PO Box 1, 1755 ZG Petten, Netherlands
Abstract: CO2-reduction scenarios are calculated with the MARKAL-model in a bottom-up analysis of the evolution of the Netherlands energy system for the period 2000-2040. In these calculations moderate fuel price increases, stringent environmental constraints, steady improvements in energy efficiency and major energy alternatives are taking into account. Preliminary results indicate a strong potential for CO2 removal from fossil fuels in combination with electricity and hydrogen production, at severe CO2 emission constraints. © 1992.
Author Keywords: carbon dioxide; Coal gasification; cost; forecasting; hydrogen; M codes; recovery; removal; storage

Authors: Holt T., Lindeberg E.
Title: Thermal power - without greenhouse gases and with improved oil recovery
Affiliations: IKU - Continental Shelf and Petroleum Technology Research Institute, N-7034 Trondheim, Norway
Authors with affiliations: Holt, T., IKU - Continental Shelf and Petroleum Technology Research Institute, N-7034 Trondheim, Norway; Lindeberg, E., IKU - Continental Shelf and Petroleum Technology Research Institute, N-7034 Trondheim, Norway
Abstract: The accumulation of CO2 in the atmosphere rather than the scarcity of fossile fuels may be the future constrain on fossile energy use. A solution for the petroleum industry is to take the large volume offered by oil and gas reservoirs into use as these can store two thirds of the CO2 produced by combustion of the world's oil and gas reserves. Concepts for combining power production with CO2 injection into petroleum reservoirs are presented. Only as injection fluid for improved oil recovery large quantities of CO2 can be utilized commercially. A brief economic analysis show that an emission free gas power plant for given conditions has a positive present value. © 1992.
Author Keywords: CO2 emissions; CO2 injection; Improved oil recovery; Petroleum reservoirs; Storage capacity; Thermal power production

Authors: Tassou S.A., Leung Y.K.
Title: Energy conservation in commercial air conditioning through ice storage and cold air distribution design
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, Brunel University, Uxbridge, Middlesex UB8 3PH, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Tassou, S.A., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Brunel University, Uxbridge, Middlesex UB8 3PH, United Kingdom; Leung, Y.K., Department of Mechanical Engineering, Brunel University, Uxbridge, Middlesex UB8 3PH, United Kingdom
Abstract: This paper investigates the feasibility of the application of ice storage/cold air distribution based air conditioning systems in commercial buildings in the South-Eastern Mediterranean area. An office building currently under construction in Nicosia, Cyprus, has been used as an example in the feasibility study. The objective of the study is to compare the performance of the ice storage/cold air distribution system with conventional all air systems in terms of their capital and running costs using current Cyprus Electricity Authority supply regulations and tariff structures. The results show that the application of ice storage combined with cold air distribution will lead to slightly lower capital cost than the conventional system and would result in significant energy cost savings over the life cycle of the system. Changing current Electricity Authority regulations to allow the same equipment to be operated both on-peak and off-peak tariffs will increase further the first cost advantage of the ice storage/cold air distribution air conditioning system over the conventional system. © 1992.

Authors: Manassen J.
Title: The new role of rechargeable batteries
Authors with affiliations: Manassen, J.
Abstract: With the era of high energy fossil fuels coming to an end and the increasing importance of electrical energy, a better way of storage has to be found. The old classical batteries do not meet the demands of the society to come and enormous research and development efforts are being invested to find new ways of chemical storage of electrical energy. © 1992.

Authors: Tanahashi S.
Title: Experiences on maintenance and operation of the 125 MVA flywheel motor generator facility at the National Institute for Fusion Science
Affiliations: National Institute for Fusion Science, Chikusa-ku, Nagoya, 464-01, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Tanahashi, S., National Institute for Fusion Science, Chikusa-ku, Nagoya, 464-01, Japan
Abstract: Some problems have appeared during maintenance and operation of the 125 MVA flywheel motor generator facility in the 254 thousand accumulated shots during the past 15 years. Prior to commissioning, we had an initial accident in which the bearing metal of the flywheel motor generator melted. After this accident, the control system was improved and redundancy was added to the lubricating oil supply system with a new safety philosophy of direct participation by the human operators controlling these enormous energy-storage devices. After commissioning, problems which have appeared are lubricating oil pump noise, drive motor end ring cracking, abrasion of the anti-corona coatings on the generator stator windings, excessive main shaft vibration, etc. We report on some of the countermeasures used to solve these problems. We also report on the annual number of fault occurrences and shots. Finally, we remark on the importance of human operators in the maintenance and operation of the facility. © 1992.

Authors: Pajek M., Schuch R.
Title: Photon polarization in radiative recombination of bare ions with low-energy free electrons
Affiliations: Manne Siegbahn Institute of Physics, S-104 05 Stockholm, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Pajek, M., Manne Siegbahn Institute of Physics, S-104 05 Stockholm, Sweden; Schuch, R., Manne Siegbahn Institute of Physics, S-104 05 Stockholm, Sweden
Abstract: The polarization of photons emitted from radiative recombination of bare ions with free electrons is discussed in the nonrelativistic dipole approximation in the low-relative-energy limit. Within this approach an analytical expression is derived for the degree of polarization of photons from radiative recombination of ions with fixed-energy electrons for an arbitrary (n,l) state. For a relative-velocity distribution of the electron beam, characterized by the longitudinal kT and transverse kT electron-beam temperatures, we found also analytical forms for the polarization rates. For a flattened distribution (kTkT) the polarization rates for different (n,l) states peak at a direction, perpendicular to the ion-beam axis (in the moving frame), where the photons are completely linearly polarized for the s states. The results are discussed in the context of experiments aimed to observe the photons from radiative recombination in the electron coolers of storage rings. © 1992 The American Physical Society.

Authors: Lai J.-S., Levy S., Rose M.F.
Title: High Energy Density Double-Layer Capacitors for Energy Storage Applications
Source title: IEEE Aerospace and Electronic Systems Magazine
Affiliations: Power Electronics Applications Center, Tennessee Center for R & D, 10521 Research Dr., Suite 400, Knoxville, TN 37932, United States; Space Power Institute, Auburn University, 231 Leach Center, Auburn, AL 36849-3501, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lai, J.-S., Power Electronics Applications Center, Tennessee Center for R & D, 10521 Research Dr., Suite 400, Knoxville, TN 37932, United States; Levy, S., Power Electronics Applications Center, Tennessee Center for R & D, 10521 Research Dr., Suite 400, Knoxville, TN 37932, United States; Rose, M.F., Space Power Institute, Auburn University, 231 Leach Center, Auburn, AL 36849-3501, United States
Abstract: The double-layer capacitor improves energy storage density by two orders of magnitude over the traditional electrolytic capacitors. Compared to batteries, the energy density of the double-layer capacitor is lower, but its charge/discharge rate is significantly higher. The application of double-layer capacitors can be tailored to auxiliary energy and burst mode storages which require fast charge/discharging and high energy density. This paper describes: 1) the double-layer capacitor technologies including its materials, structure, and characteristics; 2) potential application areas of double-layer capacitors; and 3) analytical and experimental results of double-layer capacitor applications. © 1992 IEEE

Authors: Spies W., Maller A., Linkemann J., Frank A., Wagner M., Kozhuharov C., Franzke B., Beckert K., Bosch F., Eickhoff H., Jung M., Klepper O., König W., Mokler P.H., Moshammer R., Nolden F., Schaaf U., Spädtke P., Steck M., Zimmerer P., Gran N., Scheid W., Pindzola M.S., Badnell N.R.
Title: Dielectronic and radiative recombination of lithiumlike gold
Affiliations: Institut for Kernphysik, Universität Giessen, D-6300 Giessen, Germany; Gesellschaft for Schwerionenforschung (GSI), D-6100 Darmstadt, Germany; Institut for Theoretische Physik, Universität Giessen, D-6300 Giessen, Germany; Department of Physics, Auburn University, Auburn, AL 36849, United States
Authors with affiliations: Spies, W., Institut for Kernphysik, Universität Giessen, D-6300 Giessen, Germany; Maller, A., Institut for Kernphysik, Universität Giessen, D-6300 Giessen, Germany; Linkemann, J., Institut for Kernphysik, Universität Giessen, D-6300 Giessen, Germany; Frank, A., Institut for Kernphysik, Universität Giessen, D-6300 Giessen, Germany; Wagner, M., Institut for Kernphysik, Universität Giessen, D-6300 Giessen, Germany; Kozhuharov, C., Gesellschaft for Schwerionenforschung (GSI), D-6100 Darmstadt, Germany; Franzke, B., Gesellschaft for Schwerionenforschung (GSI), D-6100 Darmstadt, Germany; Beckert, K., Gesellschaft for Schwerionenforschung (GSI), D-6100 Darmstadt, Germany; Bosch, F., Gesellschaft for Schwerionenforschung (GSI), D-6100 Darmstadt, Germany; Eickhoff, H., Gesellschaft for Schwerionenforschung (GSI), D-6100 Darmstadt, Germany; Jung, M., Gesellschaft for Schwerionenforschung (GSI), D-6100 Darmstadt, Germany; Klepper, O., Gesellschaft for Schwerionenforschung (GSI), D-6100 Darmstadt, Germany; König, W., Gesellschaft for Schwerionenforschung (GSI), D-6100 Darmstadt, Germany; Mokler, P.H., Gesellschaft for Schwerionenforschung (GSI), D-6100 Darmstadt, Germany; Moshammer, R., Gesellschaft for Schwerionenforschung (GSI), D-6100 Darmstadt, Germany; Nolden, F., Gesellschaft for Schwerionenforschung (GSI), D-6100 Darmstadt, Germany; Schaaf, U., Gesellschaft for Schwerionenforschung (GSI), D-6100 Darmstadt, Germany; Spädtke, P., Gesellschaft for Schwerionenforschung (GSI), D-6100 Darmstadt, Germany; Steck, M., Gesellschaft for Schwerionenforschung (GSI), D-6100 Darmstadt, Germany; Zimmerer, P., Institut for Theoretische Physik, Universität Giessen, D-6300 Giessen, Germany; Gran, N., Institut for Theoretische Physik, Universität Giessen, D-6300 Giessen, Germany; Scheid, W., Institut for Theoretische Physik, Universität Giessen, D-6300 Giessen, Germany; Pindzola, M.S., Department of Physics, Auburn University, Auburn, AL 36849, United States; Badnell, N.R., Department of Physics, Auburn University, Auburn, AL 36849, United States
Abstract: We report the first measurements on radiative and dielectronic recombination (RR and DR) of very highly charged ions at energies Ecm as low as 0 to 50 eV. Novel techniques were employed at the heavy-ion storage ring ESR to obtain absolute recombination rates of Au76+(1s22s). The increase of the RR rate for Ecm0 could be recorded and single DR resonances in Au75+(1s22p3/26lj) resolved. The experimental data allow sensitive judgement of calculations based on the Bethe-Salpeter approach to RR combined with results for DR from perturbative-relativistic, semirelativistic, and fully relativistic theories. Significant discrepancies are found only in the energy region of the 2p3/26l3/2 resonances. © 1992 The American Physical Society.

Authors: Horlitz G.
Title: Refrigeration of large scale superconducting systems for high energy accelerators
Affiliations: DESY, Notkestrasse 85, D 2000 Hamburg 52, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Horlitz, G., DESY, Notkestrasse 85, D 2000 Hamburg 52, Germany
Abstract: For large superconducting accelerators in the energy range of one or several TeV the requirements both for refrigeration capacity and linear extension in space are increasing enormously. Problems related to these dimensions are: size of refrigerators, transportation of coolants over long distances, two phase flow in non equigravitational lines, safety and gas storage. The most important topics are discussed and compared with existing or planned installations. © 1992.

Authors: Bakirtzis A.G., Gavanidou E.S.
Title: Optimum operation of a small autonomous system with unconventional energy sources
Affiliations: Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, Salonika, Greece
Authors with affiliations: Bakirtzis, A.G., Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, Salonika, Greece; Gavanidou, E.S., Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, Salonika, Greece
Abstract: This paper presents a method for the determination of the optimum operation of a small autonomous system with both conventional and unconventional energy sources and storage battery. The system generation consists of diesel generators, wind turbine generators and photovoltaic panels. This is the generation mix of the Greek island of Cythnos; it may be applied to other small islands. A stochastic dynamic programming based algorithm is employed to determine the optimal short-term generation scheduling and battery storage policy which minimize the fuel consumption for the next 24-hour period. An application of the method to the power system of Cythnos is also presented. © 1992.

Authors: West M.M., Lott J.N.A., Murray D.R.
Title: Studies of storage reserves in seeds of the marine angiosperm Zostera capricorni
Affiliations: Department of Biology, McMaster University, Hamilton, Ont. L8S 4K1, Canada
Authors with affiliations: West, M.M., Department of Biology, McMaster University, Hamilton, Ont. L8S 4K1, Canada; Lott, J.N.A., Department of Biology, McMaster University, Hamilton, Ont. L8S 4K1, Canada; Murray, D.R., Department of Biology, McMaster University, Hamilton, Ont. L8S 4K1, Canada
Abstract: The structure of Zostera capricorni Aschers, seeds was determined to be similar to that of Zostera marina L. Staining with Lugol's iodine revealed large quantities of starch in all tissues of the embryo. Other stains revealed smaller amounts of lipids and proteins. Electron-dense globoid crystals were present in all tissues of the embryo. Energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) analysis revealed the presence of varying amounts of P, Mg, K and Ca in the globoid crystals. Small amounts of Ca were detected in globoid crystals of all tissues of the embryo. Neutron activation analysis (NAA) results showed elevated contents of Na and Cl in whole seed samples. Varying amounts of these two elements were found in globoid crystals of the embryo. © 1992.

Authors: Arbuzov V.L., Davletshin A.E.
Title: Continuous-flow helium cryostat for electron irradiation
Affiliations: Institute of Metal Physics, Ural Division, Russian Academy of Sciences, GSP-170, 620219 Ekaterinburg, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Arbuzov, V.L., Institute of Metal Physics, Ural Division, Russian Academy of Sciences, GSP-170, 620219 Ekaterinburg, Russian Federation; Davletshin, A.E., Institute of Metal Physics, Ural Division, Russian Academy of Sciences, GSP-170, 620219 Ekaterinburg, Russian Federation
Abstract: Continuous flow-helium cryostat for irradiation of materials with high energy electrons up to 50 μA/cm2 beam density and subsequent annealing in the range 4.2-500 K is described. During the operation liquid helium is fed from a large storage vessel through a flexible vacuum-insulated transpire line. The cryostate design allows to replace the storage vessel without warming the samples, that eliminates the limitations to the time of continuous operating. In the range 150-500 K it is possible to use helium gas with either external cooling or internal heating. Helium consumption is to 5 1/h (liquid) or 10 m3/h (gas) depending on the irradiation temperature and a heat evolved in the irradiation zone. © 1992.

Authors: De Baar H.J.W.
Title: Options for enhancing the storage of carbon dioxide in the oceans: A review
Affiliations: Netherlands Institute for Sea Research, P.O.Box 59, 1790 AB Den Burg, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: De Baar, H.J.W., Netherlands Institute for Sea Research, P.O.Box 59, 1790 AB Den Burg, Netherlands
Abstract: The various proposed options for enhancing CO2 storage are often ingenious but rarely feasible. Fertilizing the central gyres would require enormous amounts of N and P fertilizer. Addition of iron to the Southern Ocean has been rejected as inefficient. The deep sea disposal of 50-100% of fossil fuel CO2 would suppress the predicted transient peak of atmospheric CO2 but eventually the atmospheric CO2 level will be the same as without, unless rapid buffering by dissolution of calcite is significant. Ocean disposal applies only to point sources representing ∼30% of fossil fuel emissions; relocation of these plants to maritime regions may not be economical either. Also ocean disposal costs ∼30-45% of the energy produced. Current research is focusing on production and oceanic mixing behaviour of the effluent stream (this volume). In this paper the fate of the disposed CO2 is assessed. The various proposed forms appear chemically unstable relative to ambient seawater. However the higher CO2 contents of seawater might lead to part of the CO2 being buffered forever through enhanced dissolution of existing calcite deposits. The predicted impact depends on the selected rate constant of latter dissolution. Ocean dumping is a fallback option, in case the sensible options of energy conservation and shifting to other energy sources would not be implemented adequately. Latter options would require societal and economic adaptations but appear the most efficient, if not inevitable, policy for imminent reduction of CO2 emissions. © 1992.

Authors: Parrini F., Vitale S., Alabiso M., Castellano L.
Title: Rational analysis of mass, momentum, and heat transfer phenomena in liquid storage tanks under realistic operating conditions: 1. Basic formulation
Affiliations: ENEL (Italian National Electricity Board)-CRTN, via Monfalcone 15, 20132 Milan, Italy; MATEC S.r.l., via Rondoni 11, 20146 Milan, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Parrini, F., ENEL (Italian National Electricity Board)-CRTN, via Monfalcone 15, 20132 Milan, Italy; Vitale, S., ENEL (Italian National Electricity Board)-CRTN, via Monfalcone 15, 20132 Milan, Italy; Alabiso, M., ENEL (Italian National Electricity Board)-CRTN, via Monfalcone 15, 20132 Milan, Italy; Castellano, L., MATEC S.r.l., via Rondoni 11, 20146 Milan, Italy
Abstract: This paper presents a computer code that analyses the performance of storage tanks using water as the working fluid. The new aspects of our work include the following items: (a) the transient Navier-Stokes equations are expressed in two-dimensional Cartesian and cylindrical coordinates, under the assumption of the Boussinesq approximation, (b) the effective viscosity and thermal diffusivity are evaluated by using a simplified form of the Deardorff turbulence model, (c) the energy equation is solved over a domain which includes the tank and a large portion of the surrounding soil, (d) some properly defined source terms have been introduced in the governing equations to describe inlet/outlet devices inside the tank, and localized friction losses, and (e) the boundary conditions are time-dependent to correctly describe the daily heat exchanges between tank, solar collectors and heat pumps for space conditioning. The DF technique and an improved formulation of the MAC method are used to solve the conservation equations. Comparisons with literature studies indicate discrepancies between 0.02 and 0.5%. The results of several tests simulating realistic operating conditions will be shown in the second part of the paper [29]. © 1992.

Authors: Radhakrishnan K.B., Balakrishnan A.R.
Title: Heat transfer analysis of thermal energy storage using phase change materials
Affiliations: Department of Chemical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Madras, Madras, 600 036, India
Authors with affiliations: Radhakrishnan, K.B., Department of Chemical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Madras, Madras, 600 036, India; Balakrishnan, A.R., Department of Chemical Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Madras, Madras, 600 036, India
Abstract: An analytical study is described of a freezing/melting phenomenon of a phase change material encapsulated in a pipe with the heat transfer fluid flowing in the annulus of a concentric pipe. The moving front problem is solved numerically using the boundary immobilization technique. Parameters such as the Stefan number, the Fourier number and the diameter ratio of the two concentric pipes to obtain sufficiently large heat transfer rates to make the system suitable for thermal energy storage are examined. © 1992.

Authors: Wendland R.D., Blatt M.H.
Title: Reliable and efficient: Cool storage meets the challenges of the '90s
Authors with affiliations: Wendland, R.D.; Blatt, M.H.
Abstract: Long reviled by some conservation advocates as a mere load-shifting technology, cool storage is much more. It has the potential to achieve significant energy savings and more efficient system use by utilities, as well as cost savings for customers. © 1992.

Authors: Lee D., Schultz M.H., Siegmann W.L., St. Mary D.F.
Title: A numerical marching scheme to compute scattering in the ocean
Affiliations: Naval Underwater Systems Center, New London, CT, United States; Department of Computer Science, Yale University, New Haven, CT, United States; Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, Troy, NY, United States; Department of Mathematics, University of Massachusetts, Amherst, MA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lee, D., Naval Underwater Systems Center, New London, CT, United States; Schultz, M.H., Department of Computer Science, Yale University, New Haven, CT, United States; Siegmann, W.L., Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, Troy, NY, United States; St. Mary, D.F., Department of Mathematics, University of Massachusetts, Amherst, MA, United States
Abstract: In the study of underwater propagation of sound in an ocean environment, much effort has been expended in considering energy propagating in a designated direction. In a range-dependent ocean environment, scattering in all directions will occur, but in some ocean environments the all-direction scattering is weak and often can be ignored. For long-range propagation, keeping the cumulative weak scattering can be important. Numerical treatment of this type of scattering in a very long range presents two computational problems: (1) the required memory storage, and (2) the required computation time. In this paper, a marching technique is developed to handle the cumulative scattering, thus alleviating the memory storage problem, and an efficient numerical solution is introduced which reduces the computation time. When using a marching technique to solve this problem, one usually encounters the problem of well-posedness. In the context of the development of the numerical scheme, an approximation is made which suppresses the instability associated with the well-posedness question. Additionally, in the scheme, at large distances from the source a continuation process is employed (essentially a PE) to continue the solution, thereby modeling an actual physical environment without scattering. The theoretical formulation of a representative scattering equation and the development of the scheme for solving this equation will be discussed. Moreover, a realistic problem with weak scattering is presented to demonstrate the validity of this treatment. © 1992.

Authors: Foltin M., Grill V., Rauth T., Märk T.D.
Title: Metastable fragmentation of (C4H10)nC 4H7+ cluster ions induced by delayed isomerization reactions of C4H7+
Affiliations: Institut für Ionenphysik, Leopold Franzens Universität, Technikerstrasse 25, A 6020 Innsbruck, Austria
Authors with affiliations: Foltin, M., Institut für Ionenphysik, Leopold Franzens Universität, Technikerstrasse 25, A 6020 Innsbruck, Austria; Grill, V., Institut für Ionenphysik, Leopold Franzens Universität, Technikerstrasse 25, A 6020 Innsbruck, Austria; Rauth, T., Institut für Ionenphysik, Leopold Franzens Universität, Technikerstrasse 25, A 6020 Innsbruck, Austria; Märk, T.D., Institut für Ionenphysik, Leopold Franzens Universität, Technikerstrasse 25, A 6020 Innsbruck, Austria
Abstract: The metastable fragmentation of the cluster ions (C4H 10)nC4Hq+ (q = 7 to 10) produced by the electron impact ionization of a neutral n-butane cluster beam has been studied with a double focusing sector field mass spectrometer. For q > 7, the usual statistical single-monomer evaporation is the only observable metastable fragmentation channel. Surprisingly, the (C4H 10)n C4 H7+ cluster ions were found to exhibit a more complex metastable decay pattern, involving not only the single-monomer evaporation, but also two additional fragmentation channels leading to evaporation of 2 to 4 and 4 to 7 (C4H 10) monomers, respectively. After studying the dependence of the parent and the fragment ion currents on the electron energy, we concluded that the C4H7+ ionic chromophore of the (C 4H10)nC4H7+ cluster ion is produced after internal H- transfer between n-C 4H10 and some primary fragment ion (e.g., C2 H5+, C2 H3+, C 3 H3+, CH3+, C 3 H4+) of n-butane within the cluster. A mechanism based on the energy storage in metastable isomers of the C 4H7+ chromophore ion is suggested to explain the unusual metastable fragmentation pattern of (C4H 10)nC4H7+ cluster ions. © 1992 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Frantz D.D., Freeman D.L., Doll J.D.
Title: Extending J walking to quantum systems: Applications to atomic clusters
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, University of Lethbridge, Lethbridge, T1K 3M4, Canada; Department of Chemistry, University of Rhode Island, Kingston, RI 02881, United States; Department of Chemistry, Brown University, Providence, RI 02912, United States
Authors with affiliations: Frantz, D.D., Department of Chemistry, University of Lethbridge, Lethbridge, T1K 3M4, Canada; Freeman, D.L., Department of Chemistry, University of Rhode Island, Kingston, RI 02881, United States; Doll, J.D., Department of Chemistry, Brown University, Providence, RI 02912, United States
Abstract: The J-walking (or jump-walking) method is extended to quantum systems by incorporating it into the Fourier path integral Monte Carlo methodology. J walking can greatly reduce systematic errors due to quasiergodicity, or the incomplete sampling of configuration space in Monte Carlo simulations. As in the classical case, quantum J walking uses a jumping scheme to overcome configurational barriers. It couples the usual Metropolis sampling to a distribution generated at a higher temperature where the sampling is sufficiently ergodic. The J-walker distributions used in quantum J walking can be either quantum or classical, with classical distributions having the advantage of lower storage requirements, but the disadvantage of being slightly more computationally intensive and having a more limited useful temperature range. The basic techniques are illustrated first on a simple one-dimensional double well potential based on a quartic polynomial. The suitability of J walking for typical multidimensional quantum Monte Carlo systems is then shown by applying the method to a multiparticle cluster system consisting of rare gas atoms bound by pairwise Lennard-Jones potentials. Different degrees of quantum behavior are considered by examining both argon and neon clusters. Remarkable improvements in the convergence rate for the cluster energy and heat capacity, analogous to those found in classical systems, are found for temperatures near the cluster transition regions. © 1992 American Institute of Physics.

Authors: Schiller E.J., Latham B.G.
Title: A generalized method for designing rainwater collectors
Affiliations: Department of Civil Engineering, University of Ottawa, Ottawa, ON, Canada; Dept. of Indian and Northern Affairs, Yellowknife, NWT, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Schiller, E.J., Department of Civil Engineering, University of Ottawa, Ottawa, ON, Canada; Latham, B.G., Dept. of Indian and Northern Affairs, Yellowknife, NWT, Canada
Abstract: The collection of rainwater can provide clean water by using renewable solar energy. The parameters involved in the design of a rainwater collection system are explained and related by means of a Design Curve. A method of developing this curve is presented and it is shown that its storage estimates have a reliability between 99 and 100 per cent. Practical use of the Design Curve is briefly described. © 1992 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Authors: Csonka P.L.
Title: Proof of a generalized Robinson's theorem on beam damping
Affiliations: Institute of Theoretical Science, University of Oregon, Eugene, OR 97403, United States
Authors with affiliations: Csonka, P.L., Institute of Theoretical Science, University of Oregon, Eugene, OR 97403, United States
Abstract: A Robinson-type theorem concerning beam damping is proved, based directly on Liouville's theorem. The theorem so obtained is somewhat general: The radiating particles need not be relativistic, and they need not form a beam, the emitted radiation may be arbitrary (not necessarily electromagnetic), provided only that the emission process is short enough and not too violent. The proof makes no reference to transfer matrices, nor to properties of the guiding forces (which need not be electromagnetic), except that they are derivable from a Hamiltonian. Then in general the sum of the instantaneous damping coefficients is =i=13ai=1/2i=13k ̄i/pi =1/2̄pk̄, where k is the time rate of momentum given up by a particle of momentum p̄ and i=1,2,3 denotes the three components. When k̄ is parallel to p̄, and k=tsumn=MNk(n), where k(n)∼pn, then =tsumn(2+n)k(n)/2p. If, further, the emitting and emitted particles are both ultrarelativistic, and the sum of powers reduces to a single second-order term (as during photon emission by ultrarelativistic electrons in storage rings), then =4/2E, where is the power radiated out by particles of energy E. Taking the usual time average for quasi-harmonically oscillating beams gives T=4/2E: Robinson's original result. Special cases are discussed, including certain ones where the sum of the damping partition numbers 4. © 1992 The American Physical Society.

Authors: Pollard B.C., Nelms R.M.
Title: Using the series-parallel resonant converter in capacitor charging applications
Source title: Conference Proceedings - IEEE Applied Power Electronics Conference and Exposition - APEC
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Auburn UniversityAL  36849, United States
Authors with affiliations: Pollard, B.C., Department of Electrical Engineering, Auburn UniversityAL  36849, United States; Nelms, R.M., Department of Electrical Engineering, Auburn UniversityAL  36849, United States
Abstract: For applications in pulse power systems, energy storage capacitors must be charged repetitively to significant DC voltage levels (greater than 1 KV). Resonant converter topologies may be used for this purpose and they consist of 3 main types: series-loaded, parallel-loaded, and series-parallel loaded. A circuit has been built that incorporates the third type, the concept of splitting the resonant circuit capacitance into a series component and a parallel component. The operation, control, and design of the series-parallel or hybrid resonant converter in capacitor charging applications are presented in this paper. © 1992 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Capacitance; Power electronics; Resonant circuits; Capacitor charging; Circuit capacitance; DC voltage level; Energy storage capacitor; Parallel component; Pulse power systems; Resonant converters; Series-parallel resonant converters; Power converters

Authors: Watanabe Y.
Title: Nucleation Characteristics of NaCH3C00.3H2O Melt with Sodium Oxysalts
Affiliations: NOK CORPORATION, Fujisawa 251, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Watanabe, Y., NOK CORPORATION, Fujisawa 251, Japan
Abstract: Nucleation characteristics of NaCH3COO.3H2O melt (m.p. 331 K) with fifteen kinds of sodium oxysalt, added respectively, were investigated by a method of continuous cooling at a constant rate of 1 K/min. The superheating temperatures for melting prior to the cooling were varied in a range from 12 to 34 K. The added oxysalts showed remarkable effects of acceleration on the nucleation of the melt. But they became inactive by superheating beyond a certain temperature (upper limiting temperature). The upper limiting temperature of the melt with Na2SeO3 was a constant value of 28 K for additions of more than 0.8 mol%. No relationships between the nucleation characteristic of the melt with oxysalt added in a given amount of 3 mol% and the chemical structure of the oxysalt's anion or the atomic weight of the central element of the anion were recognized. It was suggested that the upper limiting temperature was related to the interfacial energy of the NaCHsCOO-SEbO cluster generated in the supercooled melt by inactivation, the critical radius for nucleation of the melt on the activated condition and the solubility of the oxysalt in water. © 1992, The Society of Chemical Engineers, Japan. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Crystallization; Heat Storage Material; Nucleation; Salt Hydrate; Sodium Oxysalt
Index Keywords: Chemical elements; Crystallization; Heat storage; Nobelium; Atomic weights; Constant values; Continuous cooling; Critical radius; Limiting temperature; Salt hydrates; Supercooled melt; Superheating temperature; Nucleation

Authors: Ristić G.S., Marinković M.D., Čomor J.J., Vasić V.M., Ristić M.S., Nikolić R.M.
Title: Possibility of photochemical energy storage in the norbornadiene - Quadricyclane System. Part II
Affiliations: Boris Kidrič Institute of Nuclear Sciences, P.O. Box 522, 11001 Belgrade; Institute for Medicinal Plant Research Dr Josif Pančić, 11000 Belgrade
Authors with affiliations: Ristić, G.S., Boris Kidrič Institute of Nuclear Sciences, P.O. Box 522, 11001 Belgrade; Marinković, M.D., Boris Kidrič Institute of Nuclear Sciences, P.O. Box 522, 11001 Belgrade; Čomor, J.J., Boris Kidrič Institute of Nuclear Sciences, P.O. Box 522, 11001 Belgrade; Vasić, V.M., Boris Kidrič Institute of Nuclear Sciences, P.O. Box 522, 11001 Belgrade; Ristić, M.S., Institute for Medicinal Plant Research Dr Josif Pančić, 11000 Belgrade; Nikolić, R.M., Boris Kidrič Institute of Nuclear Sciences, P.O. Box 522, 11001 Belgrade
Abstract: Sensitization effect of an organic sensitizer propiophenone in the photoisomeric system norbornadiene - quadricyclane was investigated. Experimental data on the N - Q conversion for various concentrations of the sensitizer and irradiation times were given. Results confirmed a proposed kinetic model. © 1992.

Authors: Kundrt V., Lokajíček M., Krupa D.
Title: High-energy elastic hadron scattering in Coulomb and hadronic regions
Affiliations: Institute of Physics, Czechoslovak Academy of Sciences, 18040 Prague 8; Institute of Physics, Slovak Academy of Sciences, 89930 Bratislava 1
Authors with affiliations: Kundrt, V., Institute of Physics, Czechoslovak Academy of Sciences, 18040 Prague 8; Lokajíček, M., Institute of Physics, Czechoslovak Academy of Sciences, 18040 Prague 8; Krupa, D., Institute of Physics, Slovak Academy of Sciences, 89930 Bratislava 1
Abstract: The analysis of pp elastic scattering data at an energy of 53 GeV, reached at the CERN Intersecting Storage Rings, is performed with the help of a formula which is based on the impact parameter approach and is more general than the currently used formula of West and Yennie. More precise values of tot, B, and are established (some of them differing from those derived earlier). The peripheral picture of elastic pp hadron scattering is shown to be fully consistent with experimental data; it seems even to be preferred. © 1992 The American Physical Society.

Authors: Zaheer-Uddin M., Wang J.C.Y.
Title: Start-stop control strategies for heat recovery in multi-zone water-loop heat pump systems
Affiliations: Centre for Building Studies, Concordia University, 1455 de Maisonneuve Blvd, West Montreal, Que. H3G 1M8, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Zaheer-Uddin, M., Centre for Building Studies, Concordia University, 1455 de Maisonneuve Blvd, West Montreal, Que. H3G 1M8, Canada; Wang, J.C.Y., Centre for Building Studies, Concordia University, 1455 de Maisonneuve Blvd, West Montreal, Que. H3G 1M8, Canada
Abstract: A study is made to determine the energy saving potential of a start-stop controlled water-loop heat pump (WLHP) system. The physical model consists of individual heat pumps for each zone, a two-pipe water-loop system (with and without a storage tank), a boiler and an evaporative cooler. The overall system consists of four input energy controllers and an equal number of mass flow rate controllers. A simple start-stop control strategy for the system is developed. Results showing the typical daily operation of the system under changing heating and cooling loads are presented. A method for selecting the appropriate limits for loop water temperature which results in energy savings is given. © 1992.

Authors: Phillips J., Hodapp T., Holtrop K., Jackson G.L., Moyer R., Watkins J., Winter J.
Title: Initial boronization of the DIII-D tokamak
Source title: Journal of Vacuum Science and Technology A: Vacuum, Surfaces and Films
Affiliations: General Atomics, P.O. Box 85608, San Diego, California, 92186-9784, United States; University of California, Los Angeles California, 90024-1597, United States; Sandia National Laboratories, P.O. Box 5800, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87185, United States; Institute of Plasmaphysics, Research Centre Jülich GmbH, Association Euratom/Kernforschungsanlage, P.O. Box 1913, Jülich, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Phillips, J., General Atomics, P.O. Box 85608, San Diego, California, 92186-9784, United States; Hodapp, T., General Atomics, P.O. Box 85608, San Diego, California, 92186-9784, United States; Holtrop, K., General Atomics, P.O. Box 85608, San Diego, California, 92186-9784, United States; Jackson, G.L., General Atomics, P.O. Box 85608, San Diego, California, 92186-9784, United States; Moyer, R., University of California, Los Angeles California, 90024-1597, United States; Watkins, J., Sandia National Laboratories, P.O. Box 5800, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87185, United States; Winter, J., Institute of Plasmaphysics, Research Centre Jülich GmbH, Association Euratom/Kernforschungsanlage, P.O. Box 1913, Jülich, Germany
Abstract: A system has been installed to deposit a thin film of elemental boron on the walls of the DIII-D tokamak, in order to reduce the influx of impurities during plasma discharges. Subsequently new regimes of substantially improved tokamak energy confinement were obtained. The deposition of the boron layer is achieved during a glow-discharge session using a helium-diborane gas mixture and a film of =100 nm is deposited. The boronization system includes special storage and handling precautions for the diborane, a delivery and metering system for the glow discharge, modifications to the tokamak's residual gas analyzer system, and a dedicated system for handling and neutralizing the exhaust gas from the tokamak. Tokamak discharges with similar parameters before and after boronization are used to characterize the effects of the boron film. Nickel has been reduced by a factor of 30, while impurities such as oxygen and carbon are reduced fivefold. A system of pulsing the glow discharge has been developed in order to improve the uniformity of the film applied. © 1992, American Vacuum Society. All rights reserved.

Authors: Foerster C.L., Halama H.J., Korn G.
Title: Photodesorption from copper, beryllium, and thin films
Source title: Journal of Vacuum Science and Technology A: Vacuum, Surfaces and Films
Affiliations: Brookhaven National Laboratory, National Synchrotron Light Source-Bldg, 725C, Upton New York, 11973, United States
Authors with affiliations: Foerster, C.L., Brookhaven National Laboratory, National Synchrotron Light Source-Bldg, 725C, Upton New York, 11973, United States; Halama, H.J., Brookhaven National Laboratory, National Synchrotron Light Source-Bldg, 725C, Upton New York, 11973, United States; Korn, G., Brookhaven National Laboratory, National Synchrotron Light Source-Bldg, 725C, Upton New York, 11973, United States
Abstract: Ever increasing circulating currents in electron-positron colliders and light sources demand lower and lower photodesportion (PSD) from the surfaces of their vacuum chambers and their photon absorbers. This is particularly important in compact electron storage rings and B meson factories where photon power of several kW cm 1 is deposited on the surfaces. Given the above factors we have measured PSD from 1 m long bars of (a) solid copper and solid beryllium, and (b), TiN, Au, and C thin films deposited on solid copper bars. Each sample was exposed to about 1023 photons/m with a critical energy of 500 eV at the vacuum ultraviolet ring of the National Synchrotron Light Source. PSD was recorded for two conditions: After a 200 °C bakeout and after an Ar glow discharge cleaning. In addition, we also measured reflected photons, photoelectrons, and desorption as functions of normal, 75, 100, and 125 mrad incident photons. © 1992, American Vacuum Society. All rights reserved.

Authors: Gekat F., Klingenberg H.H.
Title: Design of microwave pulse compression circuits for the excitation of pulsed high power gas lasers
Source title: 20th Conference Record on Power Modulator Symposium, MODSYM 1992
Affiliations: DLR-Institute for Technical Physics, Pfaffenwaldring 38-40, Stuttgart 80, D-7000, Germany; Siemens AG, Magnet and Accelerator Technology, Friedrich-Ebert-Str., Bergisch Gladbach, D-5060, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Gekat, F., DLR-Institute for Technical Physics, Pfaffenwaldring 38-40, Stuttgart 80, D-7000, Germany; Klingenberg, H.H., Siemens AG, Magnet and Accelerator Technology, Friedrich-Ebert-Str., Bergisch Gladbach, D-5060, Germany
Abstract: During the last decade, the microwave discharge was investigated as an alternative technique avoiding some of the disadvantages associated with the transversely excited atmosphere (TEA-) discharge such as preionization, instabilities and pulse length limitations due to the metallic electrodes. However, up to now one drawback of the pulsed high power microwave discharge was the lack of commercially available high power microwave tubes with pulsed output powers in the region of 100 MW to1 GW. There are two methods for achieving output powers comparable to relativistic sources. One way is the combining of several conventional tubes, which is rather complicated especially for magnetrons. The other method is the compression of the microwave pulse of a conventional tube by means of a microwave cavity or a network of delay lines and hybrids. This paper describes the application of microwave pulse compression using Q-switching for discharging the storage cavity. Under optimum conditions, up to 80 % of the microwave pulse energy can be stored in a cavity and delivered to a matched load via triggering a suited switching element. The design discussed in this paper uses the laser discharge as switch. The plasma tube is integrated in the storage cavity and the discharge is triggered when the electric field strength exceeds the holdoff field strength of the gas mixture. The microwave source was operated at power levels of 4.5 - 5 MW and at repetition rates of 10 - 20 Hz. With a stored energy of 1.4 J a XeCl laser featuring a pulse energy of 4 mJ and a pulse length of 16 ns could be realized without any preionization. The discharge structure was in no way optimized. Principal limitations in laser pulse energy and repetition frequency are arising from the fact that the discharge acts both as a switch and as laser amplifier. Considerable improvements in the performance of the complete system can be expected, if the cavity is discharged by an optimized switch while the laser discharge acts only as a load. Some theoretical aspects of the pulse compression circuit will be presented together with experimental results. The results show the potential of realizing microwave discharge pumped excimer lasers with output powers ranging from 10 to 100 d.A laser head powered by a S-band (3 GHz) magnetron would be rather compact, because it comprises only a storage cavity and a discharge structure without any high voltage component. The feeding could be done via a flexible waveguide. In this way using microwave pulse compression techniques, the microwave discharge is an interesting alternative to TEA-discharges. © 1992 IEEE.
Index Keywords: Chlorine compounds; Excimer lasers; Gas lasers; Magnetrons; Microwave circuits; Microwaves; Pulsed lasers; Pumping (laser); Timing circuits; Discharge structures; Electric field strength; High power microwaves; High voltage components; High-power gas lasers; Microwave discharge; Microwave pulse compression; Repetition frequency; Electric discharges

Authors: Bridger K., Sutherland A., Fiore E., Bailey A., Christodoulou J., Winzer S.
Title: Lead magnesium niobate dielectrics for high-field applications
Source title: Proceedings of the 35th International Power Sources Symposium
Affiliations: Martin Marietta Lab., 1450 South Rolling Road, Baltimore, MD, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bridger, K., Martin Marietta Lab., 1450 South Rolling Road, Baltimore, MD, United States; Sutherland, A., Martin Marietta Lab., 1450 South Rolling Road, Baltimore, MD, United States; Fiore, E., Martin Marietta Lab., 1450 South Rolling Road, Baltimore, MD, United States; Bailey, A., Martin Marietta Lab., 1450 South Rolling Road, Baltimore, MD, United States; Christodoulou, J., Martin Marietta Lab., 1450 South Rolling Road, Baltimore, MD, United States; Winzer, S., Martin Marietta Lab., 1450 South Rolling Road, Baltimore, MD, United States
Abstract: The authors present some preliminary results aimed at exploring the potential of lead magnesium niobate (PMN) as an energy storage dielectric. In particular, relative permittivity and resistivity were studied as a function of electric field. The PMN dielectrics were evaluated as capacitor materials for pulse discharge applications. A series of compositions were prepared and compared to pure and commercial strontium titanate dielectrics. The comparison results are discussed. © 1992 IEEE.

Authors: Campet G., Portier J., Morel B., Ferry D., Chabagno J.M., Benotmane L., Bourrel M.
Title: Highly Reversible Electrochemical Insertion of Lithium, Accompanied with a Marked Color Change, Occuring in Microcrystalline Lithium Nickel Oxide Films
Affiliations: Laboratoire de Chimie du Solide du CNRS, 351 cours de la Libération - 33405, Talence cédex, France; Groupe de Recherches de Lacq du Groupe Elf-Aquitaine, B.P. 34 - 64170 Artix, France
Authors with affiliations: Campet, G., Laboratoire de Chimie du Solide du CNRS, 351 cours de la Libération - 33405, Talence cédex, France; Portier, J., Laboratoire de Chimie du Solide du CNRS, 351 cours de la Libération - 33405, Talence cédex, France; Morel, B., Groupe de Recherches de Lacq du Groupe Elf-Aquitaine, B.P. 34 - 64170 Artix, France; Ferry, D., Groupe de Recherches de Lacq du Groupe Elf-Aquitaine, B.P. 34 - 64170 Artix, France; Chabagno, J.M., Groupe de Recherches de Lacq du Groupe Elf-Aquitaine, B.P. 34 - 64170 Artix, France; Benotmane, L., Groupe de Recherches de Lacq du Groupe Elf-Aquitaine, B.P. 34 - 64170 Artix, France; Bourrel, M., Groupe de Recherches de Lacq du Groupe Elf-Aquitaine, B.P. 34 - 64170 Artix, France
Abstract: Thin films of lithium-nickel oxide, whose texture consists of microcrystallites with an average grain size of 50 Å, permit highly reversible electrochemical insertion of lithium ions in Li+ conducting electrolytes. Therefore, the corresponding materials would be of great interest for energy storage applications. In addition, the lithium insertion/extraction reactions in the nickel-based layers are accompanied with a marked color change, making these films of interest for the development of electrochromic displays for the control of light transmission in windows (“smart windows”). © 1992, Gordon and Breach Science Publishers S.A.
