Authors: Masuda M., Sukehiro S., Mollhoff T., Hua Rong Lu, Van Belle H., Flameng W.
Title: Degradation of myocardial high-energy phosphates during twenty-four hours of cold storage: Effects of cardioplegic versus noncardioplegic arrest
Source title: Journal of Thoracic and Cardiovascular Surgery
Affiliations: Department of Cardiac Surgery, University Clinic Gasthuisberg, Herestraat 49, B-3000 Leuven, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Masuda, M., Department of Cardiac Surgery, University Clinic Gasthuisberg, Herestraat 49, B-3000 Leuven, Belgium; Sukehiro, S., Department of Cardiac Surgery, University Clinic Gasthuisberg, Herestraat 49, B-3000 Leuven, Belgium; Mollhoff, T., Department of Cardiac Surgery, University Clinic Gasthuisberg, Herestraat 49, B-3000 Leuven, Belgium; Hua Rong Lu, Department of Cardiac Surgery, University Clinic Gasthuisberg, Herestraat 49, B-3000 Leuven, Belgium; Van Belle, H., Department of Cardiac Surgery, University Clinic Gasthuisberg, Herestraat 49, B-3000 Leuven, Belgium; Flameng, W., Department of Cardiac Surgery, University Clinic Gasthuisberg, Herestraat 49, B-3000 Leuven, Belgium
Abstract: Purine nucleotide catabolism was examined during 24 hours of cold (0.5° C) storage of human transplant recipient hearts, baboon hearts, and dog hearts. The hearts were excised either after cold hyperkalemic cardioplegic arrest or after simple hypothermic arrest (25° C). In human myocardium, hypothermia alone preserved the adenosine triphosphate pool markedly. Even after 24 hours of cold storage adenosine triphosphate was still 9.5 ± 2.5 μmol/gm dry weight (58% of the preischemic value). The major fraction of catabolites remained nucleotides: adenosine triphosphate plus adenosine diphosphate plus adenosine monophosphate decreased only from 99% ± 1% (preischemic value) to 80% ± 13% of the total purine content. The remaining catabolites were mainly nucleosides (adenosine 0.2% ± 0.1% and inosine 19% ± 13% of the total purine content). Cardioplegic arrest before cold storage did not change the pattern of purine nucleotide catabolism in any respect (p > 0.05). In baboon myocardium, hypothermia alone preserved the adenosine triphosphate content somewhat less than in human myocardium. Adenosine triphosphate content after 24 hours was 5.2 ± 1.6 μmol/gm dry weight (40% of the preischemic value). The catabolism of adenosine triphosphate, however, did not proceed far beyond the level of adenosine monophosphate, so that the sum of nucleotides remained the same as in human hearts. Adenosine was 0.2% ± 0.3% and inosine 17% ± 4% of the total sum of purines. Also in the baboon heart, cardioplegia did not influence the pattern of catabolism significantly (p > 0.05). In the dog myocardium, hypothermia alone did not protect against severe catabolism of adenosine triphosphate. The adenosine triphosphate content at 24 hours of storage was 3.5 ± 2.5 μmol/gm dry weight (25% of the preischemic value). Catabolism of adenosine triphosphate proceeded far beyond the level of the nucleotides (63% ± 17% of the total sum of purines), resulting in an accumulation of adenosine and inosine (5% ± 4% and 30% ± 13% of the total sum of purines) and even of hypoxanthine (1% ± 1% of the total sum of purines). In the dog heart cardioplegic arrest inhibited adenosine triphosphate catabolism considerably. Adenosine triphosphate content at 24 hours was 8.1 ± 1.8 μmol/gm dry weight (56% of the preischemic value); 83% ± 5% of the total purine content remained present as nucleotides, and the nucleoside content was reduced to 2% ± 3% for adenosine and 11% ± 6% for inosine. Hypoxanthine was barely detectable. In conclusion, these data suggest that there is little effect of cardioplegic arrest on the catabolism of high-energy phosphates when human and baboon hearts are stored cold for 24 hours.
Index Keywords: adenosine; adenosine phosphate; adenosine triphosphate; cardioplegic agent; hypoxanthine; inosine; nucleoside; purine nucleotide; animal model; animal tissue; article; baboon; cardioplegia; catabolism; clinical article; controlled study; cryopreservation; dog; energy consumption; heart preservation; heart transplantation; high energy phosphate; human; human tissue; nonhuman; priority journal

Authors: Hoogendoorn C.J., Bart G.C.J.
Title: Performance and modelling of latent heat stores
Affiliations: Applied Physics Department, Delft University of Technology, P.O. Box 5046, 2600 GA Delft, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Hoogendoorn, C.J., Applied Physics Department, Delft University of Technology, P.O. Box 5046, 2600 GA Delft, Netherlands; Bart, G.C.J., Applied Physics Department, Delft University of Technology, P.O. Box 5046, 2600 GA Delft, Netherlands
Abstract: A study has been made on organic phase change materials (PCM) for thermal energy storage in solar systems. The latent heat effects of these materials are obtained from calorimetric Differential Thermal Analyser (DTA) measurements. Over the whole range of 25-150°C, suitable organic materials are available with heat effects of 150-230 kJ kg-1 including sensible heat. The low value of the thermal conductivity of these materials can be greatly improved by embedding a metal matrix structure in them. A numerical simulation model for the transient heat transfer in a PCM heat storage vessel has been set up and included in TRNSYS. Experiments with a 400 L vessel confirmed the data obtained with this simulation model. © 1991.
Index Keywords: Calorimetry; Heat Storage--Equipment; Mineralogy--Organic Materials; Thermal Conductivity; Differential thermal analyzers; Latent heat stores; Heating

Authors: Daniels H., Forkel C.
Title: Application of finite elements to time- and density-dependent problems related to large scale thermal energy storage basins
Source title: Finite Elements in Water Resources, Proceedings of the International Conference
Affiliations: RWTH, Aachen, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Daniels, H., RWTH, Aachen, Germany; Forkel, C., RWTH, Aachen, Germany
Abstract: Natural convection flow patterns with advection-diffusion energy transport phenomena are examined in large scale artificial basins for thermal energy storage. Experimental data from a field test site is compared to finite element simulation results. Later the simulation tools are applied to study two- and three-dimensional basin geometries. Fully three-dimensional density- and time-dependent flow and transport are simulated in different gravel pits of 20000 m3 volume. The computer code uses latest numerical engineering developments. A semi-implicit advection-diffusion scheme [7] is used for the transport equations. Time step and mesh size are monitored by an estimate of the local error [9] as well as the global dissipation [4]. Partial mass lumping allows to couple large solid regions with no flow to the porous region with little extra costs.
Index Keywords: Aquifers - Density; Aquifers - Transport Properties; Heat Storage; Heat Transfer - Convection; Mathematical Techniques - Finite Element Method; Advection Diffusion Energy Transport; Gravel Pits; Large Scale Thermal Energy Storage Basins; Partial Mass Lumping; Transport Equations; Flow of Water

Authors: Tokoi H., Takahashi K., Shimoyashiki S.
Title: Application of a Sodium Sulfur Cell with Dynamic Sulfur Electrode to a Battery System
Affiliations: Hitachi, Limited, Energy Research Laboratory, 1168 Moriyama-cho, Hitachi, Ibaraki 316, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Tokoi, H., Hitachi, Limited, Energy Research Laboratory, 1168 Moriyama-cho, Hitachi, Ibaraki 316, Japan; Takahashi, K., Hitachi, Limited, Energy Research Laboratory, 1168 Moriyama-cho, Hitachi, Ibaraki 316, Japan; Shimoyashiki, S., Hitachi, Limited, Energy Research Laboratory, 1168 Moriyama-cho, Hitachi, Ibaraki 316, Japan
Abstract: The construction and performance of a sodium sulfur battery system with dynamic sulfur electrodes are described. Three cells were first connected in parallel, then two such groups were connected in series. Each cell included a liquid sodium filled β”–alumina tube and a system to feed liquid sulfur into the annular cathode. Low–resistance graphite felt was tightly packed around the β”–alumina tube. Sodium pentasulfide was removed from the sulfur electrode. The battery was operated automatically and stably charged and discharged in the two-phase region. The discharged energy was 4372 Wh (capacity 1170 Ah) during a continuous operation of 19.5 h. The discharge/charge energy efficiency of the battery was 82% at an averaged current density of 100 mA/cm2 and operating temperature of 350°C. The deviation of the cell current in a parallel chain was less than 7%, and this was induced by the difference in internal resistance. In the daily charge/discharge cycle, cell capacity with the dynamic sulfur electrode was 1.5 times higher than that with the static sulfur electrode using the same active surface of β”–alumina, because the internal resistance of the former cell was constant regardless of cell capacity. This battery system with a dynamic sulfur electrode can be applied to energy storage systems, such as large scale load leveling systems, electric vehicle batteries, and solar energy systems. © 1991, The Electrochemical Society, Inc. All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Electrodes - Sulfur; Electrodes, Electrochemical - Performance; Sulfur - Electrochemistry; Dynamic Sulfur Electrodes; Sodium Sulfur Cells; Electric Batteries, Secondary

Authors: BOCTOR A.M., MEHTA S.C.
Title: Enhancement of the stability of thrombin by polyols: microcalorimetric studies
Affiliations: Pharmaceutics Department, Parke-Davis Pharmaceutical Research Division, Warner-Lambert Company, 170 Tabor Road, Morris Plains, New Jersey, 07950, United States
Authors with affiliations: BOCTOR, A.M., Pharmaceutics Department, Parke-Davis Pharmaceutical Research Division, Warner-Lambert Company, 170 Tabor Road, Morris Plains, New Jersey, 07950, United States; MEHTA, S.C., Pharmaceutics Department, Parke-Davis Pharmaceutical Research Division, Warner-Lambert Company, 170 Tabor Road, Morris Plains, New Jersey, 07950, United States
Abstract: Abstract— Glycerol increased the transition temperature (Tm) of thrombin in a concentration‐dependent fashion up to a concentration of 50% glycerol in aqueous buffer solution. Glycerol showed a comparable effect on Tm of trypsin. This effect on Tm of thrombin was not seen in the presence of excess sodium chloride (1·2 m) in aqueous buffer solution. The stabilizing effect of glycerol may be due to increased energy demand to unfold the protein molecule, as reflected by an increase in Tm. This stabilizing effect, as measured by Tm, was seen for other polyols, including sucrose, and was also dependent on the concentration of the stabilizing agent. Micro‐calorimetry may be used as an effective tool to screen for the protective action of compounds in enzyme stabilization studies before conducting the time‐consuming and expensive stability studies of proteins in the presence of additives under different storage conditions. 1992 Royal Pharmaceutical Society of Great Britain
Index Keywords: glycerol; polyol; thrombin; article; microcalorimetry; protein stability; temperature; Calorimetry; Dose-Response Relationship, Drug; Drug Stability; Glycerol; Heat; Thrombin

Authors: Anon
Title: Phosphate fuel cells promise clean energy source (Part II)
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: In Japan, under the government's Moonlight Project and private projects of the power, gas and petroleum companies, 37 systems (26 constructed by Fuji Electric Co., Ltd.) ranging from 3kW to 1mW experimental plants have been constructed and put into operation. The Fuji pressure-model 50kW machine run by Tohoku Electric Power Co., Ltd has been in continuous operation for 9,500 hours. Among the imported systems, the record is 15,000 hours, held by a 40kW machine produced by IFC, operated at a restaurant by Osaka Gas Co., Ltd. The applications of these systems are varied and include power generation and on-site uses, as well as use on remote islands and in automobiles.

Authors: Lobos J.H., Leib T.K., Su T.-M.
Title: Biodegradation of bisphenol A and other bisphenols by a gram-negative aerobic bacterium
Affiliations: General Electric Corporate Research, Schenectady, NY 12301-0008, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lobos, J.H., General Electric Corporate Research, Schenectady, NY 12301-0008, United States; Leib, T.K., General Electric Corporate Research, Schenectady, NY 12301-0008, United States; Su, T.-M., General Electric Corporate Research, Schenectady, NY 12301-0008, United States
Abstract: A novel bacterium designated strain MV1 was isolated from a sludge enrichment taken from the wastewater treatment plant at a plastics manufacturing facility and shown to degrade 2,2-bis(4-hydroxyphenyl)propane (4,4'-isopropylidenediphenol or bisphenol A). Strain MV1 is a gram-negative, aerobic bacillus that grows on bisphenol A as a sole source of carbon and energy. Total carbon analysis for bisphenol A degradation demonstrated that 60% of the carbon was mineralized to CO2, 20% was associated with the bacterial cells, and 20% was converted to soluble organic compounds. Metabolic intermediates detected in the culture medium during growth on bisphenol A were identified as 4-hyrdoxybenzoic acid, 4-hydroxyacetophenone, 2,2-bis(4-hydroxyphenyl)-1-propanol, and 2,3-bis(4-hydroxyphenyl)-1,2- propanediol. Most of the bisphenol A degraded by strain MV1 is cleaved in some way to form 4-hydroxybenzoic acid and 4-hydroxyacetophenone, which are subsequently mineralized or assimilated into cell carbon. In addition, about 20% of the bisphenol A is hydroxylated to form 2,2-bis(4-hydroxyphenyl)-1- propanol, which is slowly biotransformed to 2,3-bis(4-hydroxyphenyl)-1,2- propanediol. Cells that were grown on bisphenol A degraded a variety of bisphenol alkanes, hydroxylated benzoic acids, and hydroxylated acetophenones during resting-cell assays. Transmission electron microscopy of cells grown on bisphenol A revealed lipid storage granules and intracytoplasmic membranes.
Index Keywords: 4 hydroxyacetophenone; 4 hydroxybenzoic acid; 4,4' isopropylidenediphenol; alkane; carbon; aerobic bacterium; article; bacterium culture; bacterium isolation; biodegradation; culture medium; Gram negative bacterium; nonhuman; plastic industry; priority journal; sludge; transmission electron microscopy; aerobic bacillus; Bacteria (microorganisms); Negibacteria

Authors: Hellenbrand K.E., Reade A.E.
Title: Microorganisms associated with fuel wood chips and their impact on indoor air quality: a review
Affiliations: Nova Scotia Research Foundation Corporation, PO Box 790, Dartmouth, NS B2Y 3Z7, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Hellenbrand, K.E., Nova Scotia Research Foundation Corporation, PO Box 790, Dartmouth, NS B2Y 3Z7, Canada; Reade, A.E., Nova Scotia Research Foundation Corporation, PO Box 790, Dartmouth, NS B2Y 3Z7, Canada
Abstract: The emerging use of wood chips as an alternative energy source has led to an increase in the number of wood chip piles in domestic and institutional environments. The presence of these piles may have an adverse effect on the quality of the air around them because of microorganisms surviving or growing on the wood. Depending on the type of wood used and the harvesting, handling and storage conditions, fuel wood chips have been found to support growth of a wide range of microorganisms, particularly fungi. In indoor storage areas of wood chips, spores, cells and cell particles can become airborne and be inhaled by persons working in these areas. A number of methods exist to sample and monitor airborne microbial particles. These methods, particularly if two or more are combined, are suitable to detect and quantify viable and non-viable airborne microbial particles, to determine particle sizes and, in most cases, to identify to the species level the microorganisms collected. Many of the fungi, actinomycetes and other bacteria which have been reported to occur on wood chips are potentially pathogenic or toxigenic. Inhalation of microbial spores, cells or fragments, especially at high concentrations and small particle sizes, can lead to serious allergic reactions or pulmonary diseases. There is evidence that even low concentrations of microbial aerosals may have sub-acute long-term health effects. Some microorganisms appear to produce toxins in sufficient concentration that toxicoses can be caused by them via the inhalation route. Microbially produced volatiles have also been suspected to cause adverse health effects. © 1992.
Index Keywords: Aerosols--Concentration; Air Pollution--Indoor; Wood--Fuels; Fuel Wood Chips; Wood

Authors: Lee H.O., Luan H., Daut D.G.
Title: Use of an ultrasonic technique to evaluate the rheological properties of cheese and dough
Affiliations: Department of Chemical and Biochemical Engineering, Rutgers - The State University of New Jersey, Piscataway, NJ 08855-0909, United States; Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Rutgers - The State University of New Jersey, Piscataway, NJ 08855-0909, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lee, H.O., Department of Chemical and Biochemical Engineering, Rutgers - The State University of New Jersey, Piscataway, NJ 08855-0909, United States; Luan, H.; Daut, D.G., Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, Rutgers - The State University of New Jersey, Piscataway, NJ 08855-0909, United States
Abstract: The utility of an ultrasonic technique to evaluate the rheological properties of viscoelastic food samples has been demonstrated. Rheology can be described by the rates of mechanical energy dissipation and storage during the wave propagation. As ultrasonic wave propagates through a material, it creates mechanical vibration of material particles. Detailed development of the experimental technique, analysis of data, and results are described and illustrated in this paper. Some key experiments were carried out using a transmission method to obtain time-domain spectra. The time-domain responses were digitized; frequency spectra were obtained by Fourier transformation. Food materials studied included cheese and dough of various moisture contents. Good qualitative agreement was found between the ultrasonic technique and traditional rheometry. Thus, there is potential of developing an on-line ultrasonic rheological sensor for non-invasive and non-destructive evaluation of foods. © 1992.
Index Keywords: Food Products - Nondestructive Examination; Food Products - Ultrasonic Applications; Mathematical Techniques - Time Domain Analysis; Mathematical Transformations - Fourier Transforms; Ultrasonic Waves - Effects; Cheese and Dough Rheology; Rheological Properties; Food Products

Authors: Sona Alberto
Title: Lasers for bio-optics
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: CISE SpA, Segrate, Milano, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Sona, Alberto, CISE SpA, Segrate, Milano, Italy
Abstract: Lasers are being increasingly used in bioptics and in life sciences in general, especially for medical applications for therapy and diagnostics. Lasers are also broadly used in environment sciences to monitor atmospheric parameters and concentrations of molecular species of natural origin or coming from human activities such as the various kind of pollutants. The peculiar features of lasers exploited in these areas are mainly the capability of developing an action or performing a measurement without physical contact with the target and, if required, from a remote position with the assistance of suitable beam delivery systems such as telescopes, microscopes, or optical fibers. These features are directly related to the space and time coherence of the laser light and to the energy storage capability of the laser material which allow an extremely effective concentration of the beam energy in space, direction frequency, or time. A short description of the principle of operation and relevant properties of lasers are given and the most significant properties of the laser emission are briefly reviewed. Lasers for medical applications (mainly for therapy) will be mentioned, pointing out the specific property exploited for the various applications. Finally, examples of laser applications to the environmental sciences will be reported. A summary of the properties exploited in the various bio-optical applications is shown.
Index Keywords: Air Pollution--Monitoring; Biomedical Engineering--Ophthalmology; Biomedical Engineering--Surgery Applications; Remote Sensing; Water Pollution--Oil Spills; Angioplasty; Dermatology; DIAL; Endoscopic Surgery; LIDAR; Photoradiation Therapy; Lasers

Authors: Roizin Yacov O.
Title: Charge storage and transport in insulators with negative correlation energy traps
Affiliations: Odessa State Univ, Odessa, USSR
Authors with affiliations: Roizin, Yacov O., Odessa State Univ, Odessa, USSR
Abstract: The problem of charge injection into an insulator with negative correlation energy traps is analyzed. It is shown that consideration of the interaction between the traps makes it possible to explain the long-lasting relaxation region on the injection current vs. time plots and the peculiarities of charge accumulation at the contacts.

Authors: Klaassens J.Ben, van Wesenbeeck Marinus P.N., Lauw Hian K.
Title: Series-resonant single-phase AC-DC power supply with control of reactive power
Authors with affiliations: Klaassens, J.Ben; van Wesenbeeck, Marinus P.N.; Lauw, Hian K.
Abstract: It is shown that the resolution of the high-frequency input current of the series-resonant converter leads to the possibility of accurately controlling the waveform of the source current. In combination with the accurate positioning of the high-frequency current pulses, it is possible to influence the exchange of power with the source by introducing active filtering. A power factor equal to one would lead to optimal operation. However, the zero crossing of the AC source voltage introduces the need to store energy. Bulky low-frequency storage elements increase the specific volume and weight of the converter, while the exchange of energy with storage elements decreases the overall efficiency. The energy stored in the resonant circuit is fundamentally too low to solve this problem. The stored energy in the output capacitor necessary to decrease the high-frequency ripple voltage is available for these purposes. To meet the optimal conditions for the power factor at the source, a bipolar flow of energy is required.
Index Keywords: Computer Simulation; Electric Energy Storage; Electric Networks, Switching - Resonant Circuits; Electric Power Factor - Control; Electric Waveforms - Control; AC-DC Power Supply; Active Filtering; Reactive Power Control; Series-Resonant AC-DC Converters; Electric Converters, Static

Authors: Brusewitz G.H., Zhang X., Smith M.W.
Title: Picking time and postharvest cooling effects on peach weight loss, impact parameters, and bruising
Affiliations: Oklahoma State Univ, Stillwater, United States
Authors with affiliations: Brusewitz, G.H., Oklahoma State Univ, Stillwater, United States; Zhang, X., Oklahoma State Univ, Stillwater, United States; Smith, M.W., Oklahoma State Univ, Stillwater, United States
Abstract: Fruit handlers need better methods to extend shelf-life and thus expand their alternatives to provide high quality fresh peaches. This study investigated the effect of picking time (morning vs. afternoon) and various cooling and storage treatments. The treatments included: hydrocooled and stored in 4°C (39°F)/93% RH air, stored in 4°C (39°F)/93% RH air, stored in 6°C (43°F)/68% RH air, and no cooling, i.e., stored at 23°C (73°F)/50-60% RH air. Other independent variables were stage of ripeness and time in storage. During a two-week period after harvest, measurements were made of fruit weight loss, drop impact parameters, and bruise diameter resulting from a single 15 cm (5.9 in.) drop impact. Impact parameters determined were contact time, peak force, time-to-peak force, absorbed energy, and skewness of the force versus time curve. Results confirmed the beneficial effects of cooling and high air humidity on quality.
Index Keywords: Agricultural Engineering--Scheduling; Agricultural Products--Mechanical Properties; Materials Testing--Impact; Bruising; Peaches; Picking Times; Postharvest Cooling; Agricultural Products

Authors: Liang Q., Johnson L.E., Strzepek K.M.
Title: Application of probability aggregation to multiple hydropower reservoir operation
Source title: Finite Elements in Water Resources, Proceedings of the International Conference
Affiliations: Univ of Colorado, Boulder, United States
Authors with affiliations: Liang, Q., Univ of Colorado, Boulder, United States; Johnson, L.E., Univ of Colorado, Boulder, United States; Strzepek, K.M., Univ of Colorado, Boulder, United States
Abstract: A new application of the aggregation-decomposition approach to the optimal operation of a large scale hydropower system with m reservoirs is presented. The m reservoirs are divided into two groups. The reservoirs in group 1 are independently optimized. The reservoirs in group 2 are optimized knowing the total energy of the rest of the reservoirs and the optimal operating policy for each reservoir is found as a function of the initial storage and inflow of that reservoir and the total energy of the remaining reservoirs. This method takes into account the local constraints as well as the stochasticity and correlation of the inflows.
Index Keywords: Mathematical Programming, Dynamic - Applications; Probability; Reservoirs - Optimization; Aggregation Decomposition Method; Multiple Hydropower Reservoir Operation; Stochastic Dynamic Programming; Power Generation

Authors: Polk C., Boom R.W., Eyssa Y.M.
Title: Superconductive Magnetic Energy Storage (SMES) External Fields and Safety Considerations
Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Rhode Island, Kingston, Rhode Island, United States; Applied Superconductivity Center, University of Wisconsin, Madison, Wisconsin, United States
Authors with affiliations: Polk, C., Department of Electrical Engineering, University of Rhode Island, Kingston, Rhode Island, United States; Boom, R.W., Applied Superconductivity Center, University of Wisconsin, Madison, Wisconsin, United States; Eyssa, Y.M., Applied Superconductivity Center, University of Wisconsin, Madison, Wisconsin, United States
Abstract: This paper addresses preferred SMES configurations and the external magnetic fields which they generate. Possible. biological effects of fields are reviewed briefly. It is proposed that SMES units be fenced at the 10 gauss (1 mT) level to keep unrestricted areas safe, even for persons with cardiac pacemakers. For a full size 5000 MWh (1.8 x 1013 J) SMES the magnetic field decreases to 10 gauss at a radial distance of 2 km from the center of the coil. Other considerations related to the environmental impact of large SMES magnetic fields are discussed briefly. Copyright © 1992 by The Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, Inc.
Index Keywords: Biological Materials; Magnetic Fields; Prosthetics--Pacemakers; Cardiac pacemakers; External magnetic fields; Superconducting Magnets

Authors: Xue Y., Xie C., Zhang Z., Wu J.
Title: Study on the numerical simulation of heat transfer in aquifer
Source title: Finite Elements in Water Resources, Proceedings of the International Conference
Affiliations: Nanjing Univ, Nanjing, China
Authors with affiliations: Xue, Y., Nanjing Univ, Nanjing, China; Xie, C., Nanjing Univ, Nanjing, China; Zhang, Z., Nanjing Univ, Nanjing, China; Wu, J., Nanjing Univ, Nanjing, China
Abstract: A three-dimensional model for aquifer thermal energy storage is set up in this paper. It is coupled by a flow model, which describes the movement of groundwater, and a heat transfer model, which describes the heat transfer in aquifer. The flow field is considered to be transient in the flow model. In the energy model, not only the convection and conduction terms but also the mechanical heat dispersion term are considered. The characteristic Douglas-Brian ADI scheme is adopted to solve the thermal energy storage model. Finally, this model is applied to simulate a multi-well thermal energy storage experiment which was conducted in a confined aquifer in Shanghai, China. The simulated temperatures tally well with the observed field data. The total mean value of the absolute errors is 0.65°C and the average relative error is 3.43%. The satisfying results demonstrate that this model is reliable and effective.
Index Keywords: Flow of Water - Mathematical Models; Heat Storage - Mathematical Models; Heat Transfer - Conduction; Heat Transfer - Convection; Heat Transfer - Mathematical Models; Douglas Brian ADI Scheme; Shanghai, China; Aquifers

Authors: Bradley Albert M.
Title: Low power navigation and control for long range Autonomous Underwater Vehicles
Affiliations: Woods Hole Oceanographic Inst, Woods Hole, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bradley, Albert M., Woods Hole Oceanographic Inst, Woods Hole, United States
Abstract: This paper discusses the ultimate limits to the range of conventionally powered deep ocean Autonomous Underwater Vehicles (AUVs). It is intended as an introduction to the unique problems of vehicles designed for speeds between 0.2 and 2 knots. We first present the relationship between range, size, non-propulsion energy requirements and flotation efficiency for vehicles using various common battery technologies. We then demonstrate that, at these speeds, the non-propulsion energy requirements severely limit the ultimate range. We next discuss strategies for implementing navigation and control systems at power levels of 0.1 to 1 Watt. We present systems which are based on existing technologies in use in various areas of oceanographic research but not generally utilized in the AUV community. We conclude that ocean-crossing AUV's of modest size are possible. To support this thesis, we present a design example of a vehicle suitable for economical monitoring of a hypothetical deep ocean dumpsite. This 3.5 m vehicle will have a range in excess of 6000 km at a speed of 0.5 m/sec.
Index Keywords: Electric Batteries; Navigation; OCEANOGRAPHY; Storage Battery Vehicles; Vehicles; Autonomous Underwater Vehicles; Submersibles

Authors: Ekstrand A., Saloranta C., Ahonen J., Grönhagen-Riska C., Groop L.C.
Title: Reversal of steroid-induced insulin resistance by a nicotinic-acid derivative in man
Affiliations: Fourth Department of Medicine, Helsinki University Hospital, Helsinki, Finland; the Fourth Department of Surgery, Helsinki University Hospital, Helsinki, Finland
Authors with affiliations: Ekstrand, A., Fourth Department of Medicine, Helsinki University Hospital, Helsinki, Finland, the Fourth Department of Surgery, Helsinki University Hospital, Helsinki, Finland; Saloranta, C., Fourth Department of Medicine, Helsinki University Hospital, Helsinki, Finland, the Fourth Department of Surgery, Helsinki University Hospital, Helsinki, Finland; Ahonen, J., Fourth Department of Medicine, Helsinki University Hospital, Helsinki, Finland, the Fourth Department of Surgery, Helsinki University Hospital, Helsinki, Finland; Grönhagen-Riska, C., Fourth Department of Medicine, Helsinki University Hospital, Helsinki, Finland, the Fourth Department of Surgery, Helsinki University Hospital, Helsinki, Finland; Groop, L.C., Fourth Department of Medicine, Helsinki University Hospital, Helsinki, Finland, the Fourth Department of Surgery, Helsinki University Hospital, Helsinki, Finland
Abstract: A recent report suggested that the glucose-free fatty acid (FFA) cycle may contribute to steroid-induced insulin resistance in rats, and that glucose tolerance could be restored to normal when FFA levels were lowered with nicotinic acid. To test this hypothesis in man, we measured insulin sensitivity (by euglycemic insulin clamp in combination with indirect calorimetry and infusion of tritiated glucose) before and after short-term administration of a nicotinic-acid derivative (Acipimox) in 10 steroid-treated, kidney transplant patients with insulin resistance. Thirty-five healthy subjects served as controls. Six of them reveived Acipimox. Total body glucose metabolism was reduced in steroid-treated patients compared with control subjects (41.7 ± 3.3 v 50.0 ± 2.2 μmol/kg lean body mass [LBM] · min, P < .05). The reduction in insulin-stimulated glucose uptake was mainly due to an impairment in nonoxidative glucose metabolism (primarily glucose storage as glycogen) (18.3 ± 2.8 v 27.2 ± 2.2 μmol/kg LBM · min, P < .01). Acipimox lowered basal FFA concentrations (from 672 ± 63 to 114 ± 11 μmol/L, P < .05) and the rate of lipid oxidation measured in the basal state (1.5 ± 0.2 to 0.6 ± 0.1 μmol/kg LBM · min, P < .01) and during the clamp (0.7 ± 0.2 to 0.03 ± 0.2 μmol/kg LBM · min, P < .05). In addition, Acipimox administration normalized total glucose disposal (to 54.4 ± 4.4 μmol/kg LBM · min), mainly due to enhanced nonoxidative glucose metabolism (to 28.9 ± 3.9 μmol/kg LBM · min) in steroid-treated patients (both P < .05 v before Acipimox). In keeping with these findings, Acipimox also enhanced nonoxidative glucose metabolism by 28% in six control subjects (P < .05). Therefore, the improvement in nonoxidative glucose metabolism after Acipimox was unrelated to the degree of insulin resistance. We conclude that corticosteroids cause insulin resistance primarily by affecting glucose storage. Although there is no evidence that an operative glucose-FFA cycle would contribute to this defect, short-term lowering of FFAs by a nicotinic-acid derivative, Acipimox, restored glucose storage to normal. This effect may be unrelated to the FFA-lowering effect of the drug. © 1992.

Authors: Mensink R.P., Zock P.L., Katan M.B., Hornstra G.
Title: Effect of dietary cis and trans fatty acids on serum lipoprotein[a] levels in humans
Affiliations: Department of Human Biology, Universiteitssingel 50, P.O. Box 616, 6200 MD Maastricht, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Mensink, R.P., Department of Human Biology, Universiteitssingel 50, P.O. Box 616, 6200 MD Maastricht, Netherlands; Zock, P.L., Department of Human Biology, Universiteitssingel 50, P.O. Box 616, 6200 MD Maastricht, Netherlands; Katan, M.B., Department of Human Biology, Universiteitssingel 50, P.O. Box 616, 6200 MD Maastricht, Netherlands; Hornstra, G., Department of Human Biology, Universiteitssingel 50, P.O. Box 616, 6200 MD Maastricht, Netherlands
Abstract: Serum lipoprotein[a] (Lp[a]) is a strong risk factor for coronary heart disease. We therefore examined the effect of dietary fatty acid composition on serum Lp[a] levels in three strictly controlled experiments with healthy normocholesterolemic men and women. In Expt. I, 58 subjects consumed a control diet high in saturated fatty acids for 17 days. For the next 36 days, 6.5% of total energy intake from saturated fatty acids was replaced by monounsaturates plus polyunsaturates (monounsaturated fatty acid diet; n = 29) or by polyunsaturates alone (polyunsaturated fatty acid diet; n = 29). Both diets caused a slight, nonsignificant, increase in median Lp[a] levels, with no difference between diets. In Expt. II, 10% of energy from the cholesterol-raising saturated fatty acids (lauric, myristic, and palmitic acid) was replaced by oleic acid or by transmonounsaturated fatty acids. Each of the 59 participants received each diet for 3 weeks in random order. The median level of Lp[a] was 26 mg/l on the saturated fatty acid diet; it increased to 32 mg/l (P < 0.020) on the oleic acid diet and to 45 mg/l (P < 0.001) on the trans-fatty acid diet. The difference in Lp[a] between the trans-fatty acid and the oleic acid diets was also highly significant (P < 0.001). Expt. III involved 56 subjects; all received 8% of energy from stearic acid, from linoleic acid, or from trans-monounsaturates, for 3 weeks each. All other nutrients were equal. Median Lp[a] levels were 69 mg/l on both the stearate diet and linoleate diet, and rose to 85 mg/l (P < 0.01) on the trans diet. Changes in Lp[a] were positively related to initial levels. Samples from Expt. I had been stored for 43 months, those from Expt. II for 31 months, and samples from Expt. III for 14 months at -40°C or lower. Comparison of 19 paired samples suggested that storage may have caused an overall decrease of 5-12% in Lp[a] levels, with no effect on the order of ranking of Lp[a] within studies. These short-term experiments suggest that diets high in trans-monounsaturated fatty acids may increase serum levels of Lp[a].
Author Keywords: linoleic acid; oleic acid; saturated fatty acids

Authors: Paulson D.J., Mathews R., Bowman J., Zhao J.
Title: Metabolic effects of treadmill exercise training on the diabetic heart
Affiliations: Dept. of Physiology, Chicago Osteopathic Medicine College, 555 31st St., Downers Grove, IL 50515, United States
Authors with affiliations: Paulson, D.J., Dept. of Physiology, Chicago Osteopathic Medicine College, 555 31st St., Downers Grove, IL 50515, United States; Mathews, R., Dept. of Physiology, Chicago Osteopathic Medicine College, 555 31st St., Downers Grove, IL 50515, United States; Bowman, J., Dept. of Physiology, Chicago Osteopathic Medicine College, 555 31st St., Downers Grove, IL 50515, United States; Zhao, J., Dept. of Physiology, Chicago Osteopathic Medicine College, 555 31st St., Downers Grove, IL 50515, United States
Abstract: This study determined whether exercise training in rats would prevent the accumulation of lipids and depressed glucose utilization found in hearts from diabetic rats. Diabetes was induced by intravenous streptozotocin (60 mg/kg). Trained diabetic rats were run on a treadmill for 60 min, 27 m/min, 10% grade, 6 days/wk for 10 wk. Training of diabetic rats had no effect on glycemic control but decreased plasma lipids. In vivo myocardial long-chain acylcarnitine, acyl-CoA, and high-energy phosphate levels were similar in sedentary control, sedentary diabetic, and trained diabetic groups. The levels of myocardial triacylglycerol were similar in sedentary control and diabetic rats but decreased in trained diabetic rats. Hearts were perfused with buffer containing diabetic concentrations of glucose (22 mM) and palmitate (1.2 mM). D-[U-14C] glucose oxidation rates (14CO2 production) were depressed in hearts from sedentary diabetic rats relative to sedentary control rats. Hearts from trained diabetic rats exhibited increased glucose oxidation relative to those of sedentary diabetic rats, but this improvement was below that of the sedentary control rats. [9,10-3H]palmitate oxidation rates (3H2O production) were identical in all three groups. These findings suggest that exercise training resulted in a partial normalization of myocardial glucose utilization in diabetic rats.
Author Keywords: diabetic cardiomyopathy; glucose and fatty acid oxidation; hyperlipidemia

Authors: Delmas-Beauvieux M.-C., Gallis J.-L., Rousse N., Clerc M., Canioni P.
Title: Phosphorus-31 nuclear magnetic resonance of isolated rat liver during hypothermic ischemia and subsequent normothermic perfusion
Affiliations: Université de Bordeaux II, Institut de Biochimie Cellulaire et Neurochimie, CNRS, Bordeaux, France
Authors with affiliations: Delmas-Beauvieux, M.-C., Université de Bordeaux II, Institut de Biochimie Cellulaire et Neurochimie, CNRS, Bordeaux, France; Gallis, J.-L., Université de Bordeaux II, Institut de Biochimie Cellulaire et Neurochimie, CNRS, Bordeaux, France; Rousse, N., Université de Bordeaux II, Institut de Biochimie Cellulaire et Neurochimie, CNRS, Bordeaux, France; Clerc, M., Université de Bordeaux II, Institut de Biochimie Cellulaire et Neurochimie, CNRS, Bordeaux, France; Canioni, P., Université de Bordeaux II, Institut de Biochimie Cellulaire et Neurochimie, CNRS, Bordeaux, France
Abstract: The effects of prolonged hypothermic ischemia and subsequent normothermic perfusion on the energetic metabolism and intracellular pH (pHin) of isolated rat livers were studied by phosphorus-31 nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy. Nucleoside triphosphate (NTP) depletion and intracellular pH were studied within an 18-h-storage phase, by using the following preservation media: Eurocollins (EC), UW Lactobionate (UW) and Bretschneider's solution (HTK). Values obtained after 8-h ischemia were chosen to estimate the performance of the various media: NTP levels were 37 ± 7%, 10 ± 5% and 0% of control levels, respectively, in livers stored in UW, HTK and EC solutions. pHin reached values of 7.15 ± 0.10 in UW and HTK, and 6.96 ± 0.10 in EC-stored livers. Ischemic damage was assessed by reperfusing the stored organ with Krebs medium: NTP recovery was around 70 ± 20% for the three solutions used. Recovery of pHin was near the control value (7.23 ± 0.08), except for EC solution (7.05 ± 0.20). The main results are that (i) the rates of NTP and pHin decrease are strongly dependent on the nature of the preservation solution, whereas (ii) NTP recovery is not significantly different during post-ischemic reperfusion. With regard to animal survival, UW solution is at present considered largely superior to EC medium for liver preservation. Thus, our data suggest that the rates of NTP depletion and pHin fall during cold preservation could be both considered as better indicators assessing liver injury than the post-ischemic NTP recovery. © 1992.

Authors: Bradshaw Dale T., Brewer James E.
Title: Potential strategic operating and environmental benefits of TVA's compressed air energy storage (CAES) program
Source title: Proceedings of the American Power Conference
Authors with affiliations: Bradshaw, Dale T.; Brewer, James E.
Abstract: The Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA) is currently looking at compressed air energy storage (CAES) as a new capacity option. In CAES technology, air is compressed with a motor/generator using low cost-cost, off-peak electricity and stored underground in caverns or porous media. The air is stored at pressures less than the hydrostatic pressures which increase with increasing depth. This pressurized air is released from the ground when a simple one-way valve is opened. It is then mixed and burned with a small amount of gas in a combustor in order to heat the air. The hot expanding gases drive a turbo expander and run a motor/generator which, in turn, produces electricity during peak demand periods. Exhaust heat is recovered in a recuperator or heat recovery steam generator. Storage technologies offer improved air quality and cost savings.
Index Keywords: Air Pollution - Particulate Emissions; Electric Power Generation - Computer Aided Analysis; Electric Power Plants; Electric Utilities - Economics; Clean Air Act Amendments (CAAA); Compressed Air Energy Storage (CAES) Technology; DYNAMICS Scheduling Package; Emissions Trading Market; Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA); Compressed Air

Authors: Grote Hans
Title: First polarization calculations in MAD
Source title: Conference Record of the 1991 IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
Affiliations: CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Grote, Hans, CERN, Geneva, Switzerland
Abstract: A module has been added to the MAD (Methodical Accelerator Design) program allowing the calculation of polarization levels in electron and positron storage rings. It is based on the program SITF developed at DESY (Deutsches Elektronen-Synchrotron). Its availability inside MAD offers the advantage of allowing it to use machine descriptions in the MAD format, and to change single elements interactively, thus showing immediately the impact on the polarization level. Calculations are performed for thick elements, with alignment and field errors, and the depolarizing effects caused by quantum diffusion in energy and by quantum excitation of vertical motion are treated. The calculations are based on linear spin-orbit coupling, and use a first-order perturbative approach.
Index Keywords: Accelerators, Electron Ring; Particle Beams; Quantum Theory; DESY; Electron storage rings; Positron storage rings; Accelerators, Synchrotron

Authors: Shirakura R., Matsuda H., Nakano S., Nakata S., Kaneko M., Takami H., Miyagawa S., Fukushima N., Kitagawa S., Naka Y., Matsumiya G., Kawashima Y.
Title: Myocardial energy metabolism in asphyxiated canine hearts preserved for 24 hours
Affiliations: First Department of Surgery, Osaka University Medical School, Fukushima-Ku, Osaka, 553, Japan; National Cardiovascular Center, 5-7-1 Fujishirodai, Suita, Osaka, 565, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Shirakura, R., First Department of Surgery, Osaka University Medical School, Fukushima-Ku, Osaka, 553, Japan; Matsuda, H., First Department of Surgery, Osaka University Medical School, Fukushima-Ku, Osaka, 553, Japan; Nakano, S., First Department of Surgery, Osaka University Medical School, Fukushima-Ku, Osaka, 553, Japan; Nakata, S., First Department of Surgery, Osaka University Medical School, Fukushima-Ku, Osaka, 553, Japan; Kaneko, M., First Department of Surgery, Osaka University Medical School, Fukushima-Ku, Osaka, 553, Japan; Takami, H., First Department of Surgery, Osaka University Medical School, Fukushima-Ku, Osaka, 553, Japan; Miyagawa, S., First Department of Surgery, Osaka University Medical School, Fukushima-Ku, Osaka, 553, Japan; Fukushima, N., First Department of Surgery, Osaka University Medical School, Fukushima-Ku, Osaka, 553, Japan; Kitagawa, S., First Department of Surgery, Osaka University Medical School, Fukushima-Ku, Osaka, 553, Japan; Naka, Y., First Department of Surgery, Osaka University Medical School, Fukushima-Ku, Osaka, 553, Japan; Matsumiya, G., First Department of Surgery, Osaka University Medical School, Fukushima-Ku, Osaka, 553, Japan; Kawashima, Y., First Department of Surgery, Osaka University Medical School, Fukushima-Ku, Osaka, 553, Japan, National Cardiovascular Center, 5-7-1 Fujishirodai, Suita, Osaka, 565, Japan
Abstract: Myocardial energy metabolism in asphyxiated cadaver hearts preserved in UW solution (UWS; group 1, n=6) or modified Collins* solution (MCS; group 2, n=6) was compared with that in cardioplegic arrested hearts immersed in ice-cold MCS with (group 3, n=6) or without myoprotective drugs (group 4, n=5). All hearts were stored for 24 hr. The hearts in groups 1 and 2 were pretreated with prostacyclin, verapamil, and propranolol; asphyxiated for 10 min, reversed by coronary perfusion with warm blood cardioplegia (WBCP); perfused with ice-cold crystalloid cardioplegia for 2 hr; excised and immersed in cold storage solution for 22 hr; and perfused again with WBCP before reperfusion. ATP contents were measured in biopsy specimens by HPLC. Myocardial ATP level decreased significantly from 23.7±1.7 to 15.9±2.5 µmol/g dry wt. (P<0.0001) by asphyxia, but recovered to within normal limits by WBCP in group 1. The ATP level again decreased to 15.8±2.4 µmol/g dry wt. during 24-hr storage, but finally rose to 22.4±3.5 µmol/g dry wt. by terminal WBCP. The ATP metabolism in group 2 was similar to that in group 1. The ATP content in group 4 was significantly lower than that in other groups (P<0.01) after 24-hr preservation. The study shows that damage to cadaver hearts can be reversed and the hearts maintained satisfactorily viable for 24 hr. © 1992 by Williams and Wilkins.

Authors: Bennett C., Reed G.W., Peters J.C., Abumrad N.N., Sun M., Hill J.O.
Title: Short-term effects of dietary-fat ingestion on energy expenditure and nutrient balance
Affiliations: Department of Pediatrics, D-4130 Medical Center North, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37232, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bennett, C., Department of Pediatrics, D-4130 Medical Center North, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37232, United States; Reed, G.W., Department of Pediatrics, D-4130 Medical Center North, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37232, United States; Peters, J.C., Department of Pediatrics, D-4130 Medical Center North, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37232, United States; Abumrad, N.N., Department of Pediatrics, D-4130 Medical Center North, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37232, United States; Sun, M., Department of Pediatrics, D-4130 Medical Center North, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37232, United States; Hill, J.O., Department of Pediatrics, D-4130 Medical Center North, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN 37232, United States
Abstract: Joule for joule, dietary fat may promote obesity more than protein or carbohydrate. In this study we determined whether the addition of 50 g dietary fat to a standard breakfast would increase energy expenditure or fat oxidation during the immediate 6-h postprandial period or over the ensuing 18 h. We also determined whether subjects with a high level of aerobic physical fitness would show a greater increase in fat oxidation after the ingestion of the extra fat than would less fit subjects. Adding fat did not increase fat oxidation or energy expenditure either during the immediate 6-h postprandial period or over the following 18 h. This was true regardless of the subject's fitness level. Acutely, dietary fat ingested in excess of its usual rate of oxidation appears to be stored in the body. Being physically fit does not appear to provide an advantage in avoiding short-term storage of excess dietary fat.

Authors: Del Monaco J.L., Pandya D.A., Salko J.J.
Title: Low-cost retrofit cool storage rooftop project
Source title: Proceedings of the American Power Conference
Affiliations: Public Service Electric and Gas Co, Newark, United States
Authors with affiliations: Del Monaco, J.L., Public Service Electric and Gas Co, Newark, United States; Pandya, D.A., Public Service Electric and Gas Co, Newark, United States; Salko, J.J., Public Service Electric and Gas Co, Newark, United States
Abstract: Cool storage is potentially attractive to summer peaking utilities because it offers an opportunity for load management. At times of low demand for electricity, it can be used to produce cooling energy which is stored in a medium such as water or ice. During the daytime period of normally high electrical demand, the storage medium would be used to provide cooling needs, thus reducing the summer peak demand for electric power. This paper provides a summary of a prior 1986-87 study and an overview of the retrofit rooftop cool storage project in Cherry Hill, New Jersy. An analysis of the three year performance will be provided. The initial conclusion was that this concept could be a viable option for load management and may offer significant cost savings to commercial customers.
Index Keywords: Electric Power Systems - Load Management; Electric Power Utilization - Planning; Cool Storage Rooftop Units; Air Conditioning

Affiliations: Sverdrup Technology, Brook Park OH 44142, United States

Abstract: PROVIDING power over the 354-h lunar night provides a considerable challenge to solar power concepts for a moonbase.1‘2 While some systems can be run at reduced power, others, such as air recycling, may even have increased power consumption during the night. The storage required for night operation is the major mass component of a photovoltaic system. The photovoltaic panels themselves would be quite light, e.g., on the order of 500 kg for an APS A technology array with thin GaAs cells. © 1992 American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc., All rights reserved.

Authors: Wyczalek Floyd A.
Title: Heat transfer model for heating and cooling battery electric vehicles
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Petroleum Division (Publication) PD
Affiliations: FWLilly Inc, Bloomfield, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wyczalek, Floyd A., FWLilly Inc, Bloomfield, United States
Abstract: Battery electric vehicles (EV) present a particular challenge to the development of more efficient and more effective heating and cooling systems for automotive applications. Because the heating and air conditioning (HAC) systems are electrically powered, vehicle range is reduced when the HAC system is operating. While air conditioning power and energy demands in the contemporary gasoline powered vehicle are comparable in magnitude to the power and energy levels needed to propel the vehicle at level road load cruising conditions, HAC energy demand levels of this magnitude are not acceptable for battery electric vehicles. Consequently, it is necessary to devise new approaches which significantly reduce the HAC energy requirements. Specifically, the summertime interior heat load must be reduced by limiting infrared (IR) energy transmission into the passenger compartment. Furthermore, heat pump efficiency needs improvement. The scope of this paper is limited to illustrating the basis for determining HAC boundary design assumptions and showing methods for estimating the HAC load and energy requirements for battery electric vehicles. This includes: the effects of vehicle windows (glazing) which absorb and/or reflect the IR portion of the solar spectrum, coefficient of performance (COP) needed by a practical EV heat pump, and specific application of this HAC design method to the 1992 Nissan-FEV Future Electric Vehicle.
Index Keywords: Heat Pump Systems; Heat Transfer - Mathematical Models; Storage Battery Vehicles - Air Conditioning; Coefficient of Performance; Storage Battery Vehicles

Affiliations: Department of Physics, University of Rajasthan, Jaipur, 302004, India; University Science Instrumentation Centre, University of Rajasthan, Jaipur, 302004, India
Authors with affiliations: Upadhyaya, K.S., Department of Physics, University of Rajasthan, Jaipur, 302004, India; Singh, M., Department of Physics, University of Rajasthan, Jaipur, 302004, India; Banthia, A.S., Department of Physics, University of Rajasthan, Jaipur, 302004, India; Vijay, Y.K., Department of Physics, University of Rajasthan, Jaipur, 302004, India; Jain, I.P., University Science Instrumentation Centre, University of Rajasthan, Jaipur, 302004, India
Abstract: The FeTi films of different thicknesses were deposited onto glass substrate at different deposition angles (θ = 0°, 30°, 45°, 60° and 75°) simultaneously. The resistance and activation energy of FeTi films is found to decrease with thickness of the films and increase with the angle of deposition. It was found that on hydrogenation of these FeTi films the activation energy as well as resistance increase with the thickness. It was also found that the amount of absorbed hydrogen at 1 atm hydrogen pressure increases with the film thickness and becomes almost constant beyond 1300 Å. © 1992.

Authors: Yeh H.-M., Cheng C.-Y.
Title: Cool thermal storage by vacuum freezing of water with constant volume rate of sublimation

Abstract: A new type of cool thermal storage, based on solid-liquid-vapor multiple phase transformation operation, has been introduced. In this process, ice is made for cool thermal storage at reduced pressure during off-peak power consumption hours and melted for producing chilled water during on-peak power consumption hours. The phenomena of ice storage, produced by vacuum freezing of water with sublimation of ice at the free surface, have been investigated. The equations for estimating the temperature-time history in the ice layer have been derived. The penetration distance of solidification from the original surface is also obtained from the mass balance. The estimation of the capacity of cool thermal storage has been illustrated with a constant-volume rate of sublimation as parameter. © 1992.

Abstract: Two insulating materials have been tested for their relative performance for retaining solar heated hot water for the duration of the night. The insulating materials tested in this study are fibreglass wool and sawdust. The performance study has been carried out under similar environmental conditions using two identical storage systems. The water heating efficiency and storage efficiency have been calculated, and it has been observed that low cost and abundantly available sawdust insulating material can be successfully employed in solar water heaters. © 1992.

Authors: Fajardo M.E.
Title: Limitations on stored energy densities in systems of separated ionicspecies
Affiliations: Astronautics Laboratory, Edwards Air Force Base CA 93523, United States
Authors with affiliations: Fajardo, M.E., Astronautics Laboratory, Edwards Air Force Base CA 93523, United States
Abstract: A classical electrostatic model of the energetics of systems of ionic species trapped in insulating solids is adapted from the standard theories of ionic crystals and continuum dielectrics. An analysis of the dependence of the stored energy density (energy/volume) of such systems on the separations between the ionic species is made that includes the effects of the Coulombic interactions amongst the ions, as well as the effects of the induced polarization of the insulating solid. Application of the analysis to systems composed of real chemical species at "reasonable" ionic eoncentrations reveals that the energy stored per ion pair is degraded by these effects to approximately one-half of the energy inherent to an infinitely separated gas phase ion pair. Nevertheless, the calculated stored energies are still sufficiently large that these systems may be potentially useful as rocket propellants, provided that several possible instabilities are not ultimately prohibitive. © 1992 American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics, Inc., All rights reserved.
Index Keywords: Energy Storage; Propellants; Ionic Species; Stored Energy Densities; Ions

Authors: Anashin V.V., Barkov L.M., Blinov G.A., Kolachev G.M., Pivovarov S.G., Smakhtin V.P., Sukhanov S.V.
Title: Superconducting magnetic system of the detector KEDR
Affiliations: Institute of Nuclear Physics Siberian Division of the USSR Academy of Sciences, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Anashin, V.V., Institute of Nuclear Physics Siberian Division of the USSR Academy of Sciences, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Barkov, L.M., Institute of Nuclear Physics Siberian Division of the USSR Academy of Sciences, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Blinov, G.A., Institute of Nuclear Physics Siberian Division of the USSR Academy of Sciences, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Kolachev, G.M., Institute of Nuclear Physics Siberian Division of the USSR Academy of Sciences, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Pivovarov, S.G., Institute of Nuclear Physics Siberian Division of the USSR Academy of Sciences, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Smakhtin, V.P., Institute of Nuclear Physics Siberian Division of the USSR Academy of Sciences, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation; Sukhanov, S.V., Institute of Nuclear Physics Siberian Division of the USSR Academy of Sciences, Novosibirsk, Russian Federation
Abstract: The detector KEDR1 is now under construction at the Institute of Nuclear Physics (Novosibirsk, USSR). This detector will be used in high-energy physics experiments on the storage ring VEPP-4M. The paper describes the KEDR magnetic system that consists of a main superconducting coil, compensating superconducting solenoids an iron yoke closing the magnetic flux. The main superconducting coil is a one-layer solenoid of 3 m diameter 3 m length with the inductance of 1.2 H, the effective field 2 T, the stored energy 42 MJ. The superconducting coil was wound around soldered to the inner surface of a ringlike helium vessel is cooled indirectly through a 10 mm stainless steel wall of the vessel. A superconducting flux pump supplies the coil with 8 kA current. The iron yoke provides the required uniformity of the field. The compensating superconducting solenoids have a length of 450 mm, a diameter of 120 mm, a magnetic field of 6.7 T. The total weight of KEDR is approximately equal to 1000 tons. Authors: Laghari Javaid R., Sarjeant W.James
Title: Energy-storage pulsed-power capacitor technology
Authors with affiliations: Laghari, Javaid R.; Sarjeant, W.James
Abstract: Fundamentals of dielectric capacitor technology and multifactor stress aging of all classes of insulating media that form elements of this technology are addressed. The goal is the delineation of failure processes in highly stressed compact capacitors. Factors affecting the complex aging processes such as thermal, electromechanical, and partial discharges are discussed. Diagnostic measurement techniques available and those being developed to determine material degradation affecting available life and failure probability of capacitors are presented.

Authors: Marriott D.L.
Title: Current trends in high temperature design
Source title: International Journal of Pressure Vessels and Piping
Affiliations: Mechanical Engineering Department, University of Illinois at Urbana, Champaign, IL 61801, United States
Authors with affiliations: Marriott, D.L., Mechanical Engineering Department, University of Illinois at Urbana, Champaign, IL 61801, United States
Abstract: A review of high temperature design guidelines has been carried out in preparation for designing a solar storage module for the Freedom Spacelab. Three major guidelines, N47, R5 and RCC-MR form the basis of the survey. The main issues with current, mature design in the power industry appear to be adequately covered by these guidelines. A significant finding is that long established models of material damage have survived the test of time very well. A new design regime referred to as Very High Temperature Design (VHTD) is identified. The characteristics of this regime are changing material properties which require some changes in philosophy in drafting of future codes, particularly in regard to definitions of yield strengths and other design allowables. Finally, there is some discussion of the more general use of the stress/strain plane, e.g. isochronous curves, for representation of very complex material constitutive behavior. A concept called the 'Relaxation Locus', which summarizes essential local constrained component behavior, is introduced and its application to high temperature design problems is discussed briefly. © 1992.

Authors: Bercovitch F.B.
Title: Estradiol concentrations, fat deposits, and reproductive strategies in male rhesus macaques
Affiliations: Caribbean Primate Research Center, University of Puerto Rico, Medical Sciences Campus, P. O. Box 1053, Sabana Seca, Puerto Rico 00952; Wisconsin Regional Primate Research Center, University of Wisconsin, 1223 Capitol Court, Madison, WI 53715, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bercovitch, F.B., Caribbean Primate Research Center, University of Puerto Rico, Medical Sciences Campus, P. O. Box 1053, Sabana Seca, Puerto Rico 00952, Wisconsin Regional Primate Research Center, University of Wisconsin, 1223 Capitol Court, Madison, WI 53715, United States
Abstract: Squirrel monkeys (Saimiri spp.) are thought to undergo a unique pattern of seasonal weight change among the Primates that reflects a fatted male phenomenon. But many male mammals, including rhesus macaques (Macaco mulatta), undergo circannual weight changes concurrent with mating season activity. Four adult male rhesus macaques living in a heterosexual social group in an outdoor enclosure were studied over a 2-year period in order to ascertain potential mechanisms underlying seasonal weight changes. Alterations in weight were significantly correlated with changes in abdominal fat levels and in body mass index. Neither testosterone nor estradiol fluctuations were correlated with weight changes, but estradiol levels were significantly correlated with body mass index. The annual profile of changes in abdominal fat level reflected the annual profile of variation in circulating estradiol levels. The fatted male phenomenon appears to characterize circannual weight fluctuations in rhesus macaques. Seasonal weight changes resulting from fat deposition are suggested to provide a substrate for adipose tissue aromatization that yields elevated estradiol levels and enables males to forego feeding and concentrate their energy budgets on activities directly related to mate acquisition and retention. © 1992.

Authors: Tu P., Hock S.M., Thresher R.W., McCoy Timothy J.
Title: Potential of hybrid wind energy systems for utility system applications
Source title: American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Solar Energy Division (Publication) SED
Affiliations: Natl Renewable Energy Lab, Golden, United States
Authors with affiliations: Tu, P., Natl Renewable Energy Lab, Golden, United States; Hock, S.M., Natl Renewable Energy Lab, Golden, United States; Thresher, R.W., Natl Renewable Energy Lab, Golden, United States; McCoy, Timothy J., Natl Renewable Energy Lab, Golden, United States
Abstract: Wind energy is currently one of the most economically attractive renewable forms of bulk electrical generation, with over 2 billion kWh of energy produced during 1990 in California alone. However, in order to increase the value of wind energy to utilities, it is necessary to provide firm capacity during peak load periods. This paper investigates the technical and economic merits of several wind hybrid system configurations to meet this goal. A systems simulation model has been developed specifically for this study. The model includes hybrid configurations, using wind and Photovoltaics (PV) as the primary renewable energy sources combined with a natural-gas-fired combustion turbine (CT) and storage such as pumped hydro or batteries. A simple spread-sheet cost model is used to perform cost-of-energy (COE) analyses from the perspective of an independent power producer, who may be bidding on firm capacity. The model uses typical California seasonal and diurnal wind speed, and solar insolation distributions with corresponding utility load curves to estimate the COE for varying proportions of wind/PV capacity, the backup CT, and the storage system. A wind system without storage or CT backup is first analyzed as the baseline configuration. Results from a parametric study of a hybrid wind/CT generating station provide the COE estimates for stations with 0% to 100% CT backup for a range of fuel prices. In addition, pumped hydro and battery storage elements are modeled to determine their potential, improve profitability, and provide firm capacity. The intent is to identify practical hybrid configurations with the potential to profitably shift the intermittently generated energy to peak load periods in order to provide firm capacity. Results from a tradeoff study of the storage capacity provide a hybrid configuration with the best potential for profitability.
Index Keywords: Electric Power Generation - Costs; Electric Utilities; Cost-of-Energy (COE) Analysis; Hybrid Wind Energy Systems; Systems Simulation Model; Wind Power

Authors: Sato T., Hasegawa M., Mizoguchi T., Sahashi M.
Title: Planar inductor for very small DC-DC converters
Authors with affiliations: Sato, T.; Hasegawa, M.; Mizoguchi, T.; Sahashi, M.
Abstract: The authors describe the development of a planar inductor and its application to DC-DC converters. The planar inductor fabricated had a small size (11 × 11 × 0.8 mm), 33 μH inductance, and a maximum quality factor of 14. The very small DC-DC converter, using the planar inductor as an energy storage element, had a 250-kHz switching frequency, a 5-V-2-W typical output, and a power/volume ratio of up to 1.7 W/cm3.

Authors: Tripanagnostopoulos Y., Yianoulis P.

Abstract: Stationary concentrating solar devices, of the integrated collector and storage (ICS) type, that consist of a cylindrical tank placed horizontally in a properly shaped, curved mirror envelope, were designed. Prototype models were constructed, tested, and compared with conventional solar water heaters. In this article we describe the design of the ICS solar units with respect to the minimization of thermal losses from the absorber to the ambient. Experimental results were derived from the constructed models, a conventional concentrating stationary ICS prototype, and flat plate collectors of the thermosiphon type. Finally some conclusions regarding the practical application of the integrated units are presented. © 1991.

Authors: Tripathy S.C., Kalantar M., Balasubramanian R.
Title: Stability simulation and parameter optimization of a hybrid wind‐diesel power generation system
Affiliations: Centre for Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, New Delhi, 110016, India
Authors with affiliations: Tripathy, S.C., Centre for Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, New Delhi, 110016, India; Kalantar, M., Centre for Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, New Delhi, 110016, India; Balasubramanian, R., Centre for Energy Studies, Indian Institute of Technology, New Delhi, 110016, India
Abstract: In this paper a systematic method of choosing the gain parameter of the wind turbine generator pitch control is presented using the Lyapunov technique that guarantees stability. A comprehensive digital computer model of a hybrid wind–diesel power generation system including the diesel and wind power dynamics with a superconducting magnetic energy storage (SMES) unit for stability evaluation is developed. The effect of introducing an SMES unit for improvement of stability and system dynamic response is studied. Analysis of stability has further been explored using an eigenvalue sensitivity technique. The eigenvalues of the system with and without an SMES unit are studied and the effect of variation of the SMES unit parameters on eigenvalue locations are plotted. The dynamic response of the power system to random load changes with optimal gain setting is also presented. Copyright © 1992 John Wiley & Sons, Ltd.

Authors: Roscher H.
Title: Current problems and required measures facing management of water distribution systems in the eastern part of Germany
Authors with affiliations: Roscher, H.
Abstract: The low rate of rehabilitation, the high rate of damaged networks and the inadequate structure of pipe materials result in the need for the following urgent measures for the renewal of networks and the reduction of water losses during the years to come: a systematic analysis of damages and maintenance; pipe cleaning mainly by means of mechanical methods; rehabilitation by mortar lining; replacement of damaged pipes and pipes of small diameter. Approximately 60,000km of water networks have to be rehabilitated or replaced. Some 3 or 4 million water meters must be installed and the installations in buildings erected after 1960 replaced. Because of water shortage or inadequate water quality the long distance and district water systems have to be extended. Other important problems facing water supply in the eastern part of Germany are: Increasing the water storage capacity; improving the technical equipment for water storage; introducing process control in water supply systems (long distance and towns). These measures should result in: Decreasing water losses; reducing the specific water consumption; diminishing the rate of damage; improving the economic efficiency of water supply management; reducing energy consumption; improving the safety of water supply systems.Water supply and sewage treatment in the eastern part of Germany has until recently included 15 enterprises which correspond to the structure of 15 districts. This article reviews the available water resources and their uses, and discusses rehabilitation of the existing distribution system.
