Authors: Shaw Chris C., Herron John M., Gur David
Title: Signal fading, erasure, and rescan in storage phosphor imaging
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Univ. of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, PA,, USA
Authors with affiliations: Shaw, Chris C., Univ. of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, PA,, USA; Herron, John M., Univ. of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, PA,, USA; Gur, David, Univ. of Pittsburgh, Pittsburgh, PA,, USA
Abstract: This paper addresses three problems in storage phosphor imaging: natural fading of latent image signals, proper erasure of the exposed plates, and re-scanning for a second readout. Signal and signal-to-noise ratios were measured as a function of time, erasure power/time, or number of pre-scans to study these problems. The latent image signals were found to decay very rapidly during the first several minutes and stabilize after several hours. The fading effect results in a variable signal gain (signal per unit exposure), which may affect the system calibration and quantitative use of the image data. Complete erasure of the latent image signals is necessary to ensure that no residual image signals are present when the plate is exposed again. It was found that plates used in high exposure applications (GI, therapeutic imaging) may require an excessively long erasure time to prepare them for use in low exposure applications (chest imaging). Although the latent image is partially erased during the readout process, it may sometimes become necessary to re-scan the plate for a second or third readout. It was found that because a large number of energy traps are generated for each X-ray photon, a significant portion of the X-ray information remains intact for reuse after the first or second scans. Measurement of the signals and signal-to-noise ratios are presented to demonstrate and discuss the aforementioned problems or effects.
Index Keywords: Image Storage, Digital--Imaging Techniques; Laser Beams--Effects; Phosphors--Medical Applications; Signal Processing--Digital Techniques; Digital Storage Phosphor Imaging; Digital X-Ray Radiography; Laser Beam Scanning; Latent Image Signal Erasure; Latent Image Signal Fading; X-Ray Plate Laser Readout; Radiography

Authors: Esposito A., Manfredotti C., Pelliccioni M., Ongaro C., Zanini A.
Title: A moderator type dose equivalent monitor for environmental neutron dosimetry
Affiliations: INFN, Laboratori Nazionali di Frascati, Roma, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Esposito, A., INFN, Laboratori Nazionali di Frascati, Roma, Italy; Manfredotti, C., INFN, Laboratori Nazionali di Frascati, Roma, Italy; Pelliccioni, M., INFN, Laboratori Nazionali di Frascati, Roma, Italy; Ongaro, C., INFN, Laboratori Nazionali di Frascati, Roma, Italy; Zanini, A., INFN, Laboratori Nazionali di Frascati, Roma, Italy
Abstract: The neutron monitors used daily in working areas around particle accelerators must be practical, economical, easy to read and to install and sensitive to low neutron dose equivalents. An environmental neutron detector, which responds satisfactorily to these requirements, was developed at LNF (Laboratori Nazionali di Frascati, Roma, Italy), for neutron monitoring in the area of the storage ring ADONE. It consists of a cylindrical moderator (height 15 cm, diameter 15 cm) of polyethylene with five TLD-600, sensitive to n+γ radiation and five TLD-700, sensitive to γ radiation, placed in the centre. A simulation of the instrument was performed using the 3-D Monte Carlo computer code MCNP (Monte Carlo Neutron and Photon transport), in order to obtain the theoretical fluence and dose equivalent response as a function of neutron energy. An accurate calibration of the instrument was carried out at the PTB (Physikalisch-Technische Bundesanstalt, Braunschweig, FRG) exposing it to monoenergetic neutron beams (with energies of 14.2, 5, 0.57, 0.144 MeV and thermal neutrons). A further calibration has been carried out at the CRE ENEA (Frascati, Roma, Italy), with a continuous spectrum from a 252Cf fission neutron source (E = 2.3 MeV). From the results of the calibration, an average instrument response of 1.3-1.5 nC.mSv-1 seems to represent a sufficiently conservative choice in the evaluation of dose equivalent for high energy neutrons (over 5 MeV); however, for neutrons highly degraded in energy, such a factor could give an overestimation of the dose equivalent of more than a factor two.
Index Keywords: calibration; computer simulation; conference paper; dose response; fission neutron; neutron dosimetry; neutron radiation; radiation dose; radiation monitoring

Authors: Kim A.H., Zeto Robert J., Youmans Robert J., Weiner Maurice, Tran G., Jasper L., Lalevic Bogoliub
Title: Monolithic photoconductive GaAs pulser and its radiated waveform
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: U.S. Army Electronics Technology and, Devices Lab., Fort Monmouth, NJ, USA
Authors with affiliations: Kim, A.H., U.S. Army Electronics Technology and, Devices Lab., Fort Monmouth, NJ, USA; Zeto, Robert J., U.S. Army Electronics Technology and, Devices Lab., Fort Monmouth, NJ, USA; Youmans, Robert J., U.S. Army Electronics Technology and, Devices Lab., Fort Monmouth, NJ, USA; Weiner, Maurice, U.S. Army Electronics Technology and, Devices Lab., Fort Monmouth, NJ, USA; Tran, G., U.S. Army Electronics Technology and, Devices Lab., Fort Monmouth, NJ, USA; Jasper, L., U.S. Army Electronics Technology and, Devices Lab., Fort Monmouth, NJ, USA; Lalevic, Bogoliub, U.S. Army Electronics Technology and, Devices Lab., Fort Monmouth, NJ, USA
Abstract: A monolithic, photoconductive impulse generating device, in which the functions of energy storage and switching are combined into a single semi-insulating GaAs wafer substrate, was investigated under various operating conditions. Depending on the load impedance, this new type of device produced nanosecond impulses with various pulse shapes. The operation of this device with a positively mismatched load impedance (50 ohm) resulted in output voltage enhancement (voltage gain factor of 2.0) as well as fast pulse risetime (260 ps). Further, an ultrawideband horn antenna was excited by a output pulse from this device and its radiative waveform was measured using a B-dot sensor.

Authors: Bradford J.M., Truman C.C., Huang C.
Title: Comparison of three measures of resistance of soil surface seals to raindrop splash
Affiliations: National Soil Erosion Research Laboratory Bldg. SOIL, Purdue University West Lafayette, Indiana 47907 U.S.A., United States
Authors with affiliations: Bradford, J.M., National Soil Erosion Research Laboratory Bldg. SOIL, Purdue University West Lafayette, Indiana 47907 U.S.A., United States; Truman, C.C., National Soil Erosion Research Laboratory Bldg. SOIL, Purdue University West Lafayette, Indiana 47907 U.S.A., United States; Huang, C., National Soil Erosion Research Laboratory Bldg. SOIL, Purdue University West Lafayette, Indiana 47907 U.S.A., United States
Abstract: The relationship between rainsplash and three measures of soil strength was investigated for surface soil seals using a laboratory rainfall simulator and erosion pans. A significantly high correlation was found between pocket penetrometer and torvane strengths (R2 = 0.49), and a lower correlation between both pocket penetrometer (R2 = 0.24) and torvane (R2 = 0.24) strengths and the fall-cone strength was found. Rainsplash was highly correlated (R2 = 0.49) with rainfall kinetic energy (KE) divided by the fall-cone shear strength (FC) but was not related to penetrometer and torvane strengths. Addition of a silt content term to the KE/FC linear equation slightly decreased R2. Improvements in the prediction of rainsplash can be achieved by including terms defining the macro- and microtopography, such as slope steepness, surface roughness, and depressional storage. © 1992.
Index Keywords: fall cone; penetrometer; rain simulator; raindrop splash; resistance measure; shear strength; soil surface seal

Authors: Reindl D.T., Beckman W.A., Mitchell J.W.
Title: Transient natural convection in enclosures with application to solar thermal storage tanks
Affiliations: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, United States
Authors with affiliations: Reindl, D.T., Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, United States; Beckman, W.A., Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, United States; Mitchell, J.W., Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, United States
Abstract: Many previously studied natural convection enclosure problems in the literature have the bounding walls of the enclosure responsible for driving the flow. A number of relevant applications contain sources within the enclosure which drive the fluid flow and heat transfer. The motivation for this work is found in solar thermal storage tanks with immersed coil heat exchangers. The heat exchangers provide a means to charge and discharge the thermal energy in the tank. The enclosure is cylindrical and well insulated. Initially the interior fluid is isothermal and quiescent. At time zero, a step change in the source temperature begins to influence the flow. The final condition is a quiescent isothermal fluid field at the source temperature. The governing time dependent Navier-Stokes and energy equations for this configuration are solved by a finite element method. Solutions are obtained for 103 ≤ RaD ≤ 106. Scale analysis is used to obtain time duration estimates of three distinct heat transfer regimes. The transient heat transfer during these regimes are compared with limiting cases. Correlations are presented for the three regimes.
Index Keywords: Heat Transfer--Convection; Tanks--Heat Transfer; Isothermal Fluid Field; Thermal Storage; Solar Energy

Authors: Oosthuizen P.H., Bashagur H.
Title: Evaluation of the use of an energy storage system around the chimney in an indirect solar crop dryer
Affiliations: Queen's Univ, Kingston, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Oosthuizen, P.H., Queen's Univ, Kingston, Canada; Bashagur, H., Queen's Univ, Kingston, Canada
Abstract: Indirect natural convective (i.e. passive) solar crop dryers have often been proposed as a replacement for simple sun-drying which is extensively used in much of the ``developing'' world. Such indirect dryers have the potential to significantly reduce the losses that can occur during sun-drying. It has often been suggested that such indirect dryers should incorporate some form of energy storage system that would allow energy to be stored prior to the crop being placed in the dryer thus increasing the drying rate. Little success has, however, been achieved with such energy storage due to the fact that the storage beds used have either increased the pressure loss in the dryer by an excessive amount or that the rate at which heat could be removed from the bed was too low to significantly effect the drying rate. The present study is concerned with an evaluation of an energy storage system placed around the chimney of a passive dryer. Because such a system does not impose any significant extra pressure losses on the dryer and yet is placed at a position where the air velocity is reasonably high, it may overcome some of the problems that limit the usefulness of existing energy storage systems. The storage could be either in the form of a water jacket around the chimney or in the form of a high conductivity granular material placed around the chimney. This arrangement has been numerically evaluated here. It has been assumed that the energy storage material is charged for an extended period of time before drying begins and so reaches an equilibrium temperature. The drying of the crop has then been studied using a simple numerical model for the dryer. The results of the study indicate that a storage bed surrounding the chimney does have the potential to improve the drying performance of an indirect passive solar dryer but that the extent of the improvement is limited by the low heat transfer rate to the air passing through the chimney. Ways of overcoming this deficiency are discussed.
Index Keywords: Chimneys - Thermal Conductivity; Dryers - Mathematical Models; Dryers - Solar; Energy Storage - Efficiency; Energy Storage Systems; Indirect Solar Crop Dryer; Dryers

Authors: Bocek Michael, Choi Jae-Ho
Title: Criticality and structural flow instability
Source title: Zeitschrift fuer Metallkunde/Materials Research and Advanced Techniques
Affiliations: Inst fuer Material- und, Festkoerperforschung, Karlsruhe, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Bocek, Michael, Inst fuer Material- und, Festkoerperforschung, Karlsruhe, Germany; Choi, Jae-Ho, Inst fuer Material- und, Festkoerperforschung, Karlsruhe, Germany
Abstract: The stability of high temperature plastic flow is examined by means of a dislocation population model. The energy ratio λ ≡ W/Ws (expended to stored energy) which is considered as a measure for the distance from thermodynamic equilibrium appears as the characteristic quantity of the model. According to the latter instability of the deformation structure (structural instability) which gives rise to a macroscopic flow instability, does occur at a critical model value λm*. This depends on stress and structural parameters and is in the range from 20 to 100. In particular, λm* should be independent of the loading procedure. From the view of the model, instability is the consequence of the exhaustion of energy storage capability. Structural instability appears to be a critical phenomenon initiated by the growth of (critical) fluctuations in size ds of the deformation substructure. In accordance with model expectations the observed critical λ* values for different materials are within the margins of λm*, and, in accordance with the model, they are proportional to a critical stress σ*. Moreover, the λ* values are dependent on temperature and independent of loading procedure and loading path. Hence λ* reveals properties of a quantity of state. In situ examinations conducted on Cu at homologous temperatures Th > 0.4 have shown that the strain distribution during flow instability is macroscopically uniform. This indicates a high growth rate of critical structural instabilities at higher temperatures. It depends on the growth rate of critical ds fluctuations, whether strain distribution remains uniform or will become localized (shape instability).
Index Keywords: Copper and Alloys - High Temperature Properties; Crystals - Dislocations; Mathematical Models; Critical Model Value; Dislocation Population Model; Energy Ratio; Flow Instability; Strain Distribution; Structural Instability; Metals and Alloys

Authors: Parneix J.C.
Title: Effects of hydrothermal alteration on radioelement migration from a hypothetical disposal site for high level radioactive waste: examples from the Auriat granite, France
Affiliations: CEA/DRDD BP 6 92265 Fontenay-aux-Roses Cedex, France.
Authors with affiliations: Parneix, J.C., CEA/DRDD BP 6 92265 Fontenay-aux-Roses Cedex, France.
Abstract: The effects of hydrothermal alteration of a granite due to the emplacement of a disposal facility for high-level radioactive waste has been evaluated. The alteration, whose extent was related to the thermal energy emitted by the waste, corresponded to a phase dissolution of primary minerals, followed by a phase of precipitation. Two aspects of alteration were favourable to the isolation of waste; a decrease in porosity of the rock and an increase in sorption potential. It was possible to predict the rock volume involved in alteration around the disposal site, as well as the nature and the volume of alteration minerals. -from Author
Index Keywords: granite; hydrothermal alteration; migration; porosity; radioactive waste storage; radionuclide; sorption

Authors: Sankaran A., Chuang Keh-Shih, Yonekawa H., Huang H.K.
Title: Comparison of imaging characteristics of multiple-beam equalization and storage phosphor direct digitizer radiographic systems
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: UCLA Sch. of Medicine, Los Angeles,, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Sankaran, A., UCLA Sch. of Medicine, Los Angeles,, CA, USA; Chuang, Keh-Shih, UCLA Sch. of Medicine, Los Angeles,, CA, USA; Yonekawa, H., UCLA Sch. of Medicine, Los Angeles,, CA, USA; Huang, H.K., UCLA Sch. of Medicine, Los Angeles,, CA, USA
Abstract: The imaging characteristics of two chest radiographic equipments, Advanced Multiple Beam Equalization Radiography (AMBER) and the Konica Direct Digitizer [using a storage phosphor (SP) plate] systems have been compared. The variables affecting image quality and the computer display/reading systems used are detailed. Utilizing specially designed wedge, geometric, and anthropomorphic phantoms, studies were conducted on: the exposure and energy response of the detectors; nodule detectability; different exposure techniques; various look-up tables, gray-scale displays and laser printers. Methods for scatter estimation and reduction were investigated. It is concluded that AMBER with screen-film and equalization techniques provides better nodule detectability than SP plates. However, SP plates have other advantages such as flexibility in the selection of exposure techniques, image processing features, and excellent sensitivity when combined with optimum reader operating modes. The equalization feature of AMBER provides better nodule detectability under the denser regions of the chest. Results of diagnostic accuracy are demonstrated with nodule detectability plots and analysis of images obtained with phantoms.
Index Keywords: Image Storage, Digital--Medical Applications; Imaging Techniques--Efficiency; X-Ray Apparatus--Imaging Techniques; Digital Radiographic Imaging; Digital X-Ray Radiography; Multiple-Beam Equalization Radiography; Storage Phosphor Direct Digitizers; Radiography

Authors: Perez-Davis Marla E., McKissock Barbara I., DiFilippo Frank
Title: Thermomechanical energy storage for lunar base
Affiliations: NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, United States
Authors with affiliations: Perez-Davis, Marla E., NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, United States; McKissock, Barbara I., NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, United States; DiFilippo, Frank, NASA Lewis Research Cent, Cleveland, United States
Abstract: A thermochemical solar energy storage concept involving the reversible reaction CaO + H2O ⇔ Ca(OH)2 is proposed as a power system element for a lunar base. The operation and components of such a system are described. The CaO/H2O system is capable of generating electric power during both the day and night. Mass of the required amount of CaO is neglected since it is obtained from lunar soil. Potential technical problems, such as reactor design and lunar soil processing, are reviewed.
Index Keywords: Moon; Power Generation--Solar Energy; Lunar Soils; Thermomechanical Energy; Solar Energy

Authors: Bose James, Smith Marvin
Title: Performance of new ground heat exchanger configurations for heat pumps
Affiliations: Oklahoma State Univ, Stillwater, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bose, James, Oklahoma State Univ, Stillwater, United States; Smith, Marvin, Oklahoma State Univ, Stillwater, United States
Abstract: Ground-coupled heat pumps have gained international attention as a proven means in energy conservation and demand reduction. An important factor in reducing the first cost of these systems is to identify new ground installation procedures and plastic pipe ground heat exchanger configurations. A family of low cost heat exchangers has been developed, and initial data on their performance is available. These heat exchangers are constructed from coiled plastic pipe rolls of 152.4 meter (500 feet) of pipe and are tied in a circular pattern so that they can be placed in narrow 0.15 meter (six inch) wide trenches in trench lengths varying from 12.2 to 38.1 meters (40 to 125 feet). These same coils when placed in multiple passes have the potential to be used for cool, warm and hot storage systems that would be placed below grade. Performance data of these various types of coils will be presented and will compare these coils to conventional ground heat exchangers. The coils tested include: 1. two and 4 pipe heat exchangers installed in open trenches 2. loop type systems installed in closed trench horizontally bored holes at various depths 3. circular type heat exchangers of 152.4 meters (500 feet) of pipe buried in narrow 0.15 meters (six inch) wide open trenches of 12.2 to 38.1 meters (40 to 125 feet) in length. The soil type and heat exchanger cycle time were selected based on typical soil and weather data from the Stillwater, Oklahoma area.
Index Keywords: Energy Conservation; Heat Exchangers - Construction; Heat Exchangers - Design; Heat Pump Systems - Components; Heat Pump Systems - Plastics Applications; Ground Coupled Heat Pumps; Heat Exchangers

Authors: Turner Robert H., Kiley Matthew N., Harris Gregory P., Cengel Yunus A.
Title: Thermal storage in the walls of a solar house
Affiliations: Univ of Nevada, Reno, Reno, United States
Authors with affiliations: Turner, Robert H., Univ of Nevada, Reno, Reno, United States; Kiley, Matthew N., Univ of Nevada, Reno, Reno, United States; Harris, Gregory P., Univ of Nevada, Reno, Reno, United States; Cengel, Yunus A., Univ of Nevada, Reno, Reno, United States
Abstract: Residential winter thermal energy storage (TES) features water encapsulated into 3 inch (7.6 cm) diameter plastic pipes, mounted into conventional stud wall cavities of a house. With an air solar collector, solar heated air can be passed through the stud cavities, heating the water. During the discharge mode, this water loses its heat directly to the house, and the radiating walls allow the residents to feel warm even at lower interior air temperatures. Empirical and theoretical component performance data are reported for the waterwall TES unit. The interaction between a large air heating solar collector and the waterwall TES is considered for the winter heating mode. The collector-storage thermal integration analysis is detailed for a charging flowrate of 40 CFM per cavity. A simpler but reasonably accurate integration analysis is illustrated for 10 CFM/cavity flowrate. Performance parameters indicate that the waterwall TES approach is very compatible with a solar air heater.
Index Keywords: Heating--Solar; Solar Energy; Component Performance; Thermal Integration Analysis; Houses

Authors: Nair S.S., Singh R., Waldron K.J., Vohnout V.J.
Title: Power system of a multi-legged walking robot
Affiliations: Dept. of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, University of Missouri-Columbia, Columbia, MO 65211, United States; Dept. of Mechanical Engineering, The Ohio State University, Columbus, OH 43210, United States; Adaptive Machine Technologies, Inc., Columbus, OH 43212, United States
Authors with affiliations: Nair, S.S., Dept. of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, University of Missouri-Columbia, Columbia, MO 65211, United States; Singh, R., Dept. of Mechanical Engineering, The Ohio State University, Columbus, OH 43210, United States; Waldron, K.J., Dept. of Mechanical Engineering, The Ohio State University, Columbus, OH 43210, United States; Vohnout, V.J., Adaptive Machine Technologies, Inc., Columbus, OH 43212, United States
Abstract: The power system of a legged vehicle is considerably more complex than the one used by a conventional land vehicle because of the wide range of power demands and the coordination and stability issues due to the large number of degrees of freedom. This paper is concerned with the conceptual and physical characteristics of the power system of a rough terrain, six-legged, walking vehicle. Modelling techniques and detailed analytical and simulation models are developed for the vehicle power system consisting of the prime mover, energy storage system, mechanical drives, hydraulic actuation systems and the associated control systems. Dynamics of the various subsystem and their interactions have been studied for control and optimization purposes. Validation of the models is provided by several experiments performed on a prototype leg and the vehicle. © 1992.
Author Keywords: Dynamic simulation; Legged robots; Robot power system; System integration
Index Keywords: Control Systems - Controllability; Electric Measurements - Power; Mathematical Models; Mechanisms - Degrees of Freedom; Robots - Stability; Dynamic Simulation; Legged Robots; Robot Power System; System Integration; Robots

Authors: Hanlon James Casey
Title: Investigation of using lunar regolith for thermal energy storage
Affiliations: Sverdrup Technology Inc, Cleveland, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hanlon, James Casey, Sverdrup Technology Inc, Cleveland, United States
Abstract: This paper presents the results of a conceptual study in which the lunar regolith latent heat of fusion is used to store thermal energy for the night time operation of a heat engine. The study examined a system in which thermal energy would be stored directly in the lunar soil. This would be accomplished by heat transfer devices that were driven or screwed into the ground. The results indicated that over the course of a lunar day/night cycle approximately 28 to 34% of the energy deposited in the regolith would be unrecoverable. Due to the strong dependence of performance on the local regolith properties, any power conversion system utilizing this concept would have to be tailored to a specific location. Although this concept may be feasible, the temperature profiles in the regolith indicate that the heat transport device may present a challenging engineering problem. These profiles suggest that a large surface area to volume ratio may be required to transfer the energy to and from the soil.
Index Keywords: Solar Energy--Energy Storage; Lunar Regolith; Lunar Soils; Thermal Energy Storage; Heat Engines

Authors: Brown D.R., LaMarche J.L., Spanner G.E.
Title: Chemical energy storage system for SEGS solar thermal power plant
Affiliations: Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, United States
Authors with affiliations: Brown, D.R., Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, United States; LaMarche, J.L., Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, United States; Spanner, G.E., Pacific Northwest Lab, Richland, United States
Abstract: The Pacific Northwest Laboratory evaluated the potential feasibility of using chemical energy storage at the Solar Electric Generating System (SEGS) power plants developed by Luz International. Like sensible or latent heat energy storage systems, chemical energy storage can be beneficially applied to solar thermal power plants to dampen the impact of cloud transients, extend the daily operating period, and/or allow a higher fraction of power production to occur during high-valued peak demand periods. Higher energy storage densities make chemical energy storage a potentially attractive option. The results of the evaluation indicated that a system based on the reversible reaction, CaO + H2O = Ca(OH)2, could be technically and economically feasible for this application, but many technical and economic issues must be resolved.
Index Keywords: Chemical Reactions--Energy Storage; Economics; Pacific Northwest Laboratory; Peak Demand Periods; Solar Power Plants

Authors: Kerslake Thomas W.
Title: Parametric studies of phase change thermal energy storage canisters for space station freedom
Affiliations: Natl Aeronautics and Space, Administration, Cleveland, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kerslake, Thomas W., Natl Aeronautics and Space, Administration, Cleveland, United States
Abstract: This paper discusses Phase Change Material (PCM) canister parametric studies wherein the thermal-structural effects of changing various canister dimensions and contained PCM mass values are examined. With the aim of improving performance, 11 modified canister designs are analyzed and judged relative to a baseline design using five quantitative performance indicators. Consideration is also given to qualitative factors such as fabrication/inspection, canister mass production, and PCM containment redundancy. Canister thermal analyses are performed using the finite-difference based computer program NUCAM-2DV. Thermal-stresses are calculated using closed-form solutions and simplifying assumptions. Canister wall thickness, outer radius, length, and contained PCM mass are the parameters considered for this study. Results show that singular canister design modifications can offer improvements on one or two performance indicators. Yet, improvement in one indicator is often realized at the expense of another. This confirms that the baseline canister is well designed. However, two alternative canister designs, which incorporate multiple modifications, are presented that offer modest improvements in mass or thermal performance, respectively.
Index Keywords: Mathematical Techniques--Finite Element Method; Solar Radiation--Concentrators; Stresses--Thermal; Canisters; Phase Change Material; Space Stations

Authors: Nishikawa Y., Tezuka T., Kita H., Kang M.‐S.
Title: Economic evaluation of a photovoltaic power generation introduced into an electric power system with electricity storage
Affiliations: Kyoto University, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Nishikawa, Y., Kyoto University, Japan; Tezuka, T., Kyoto University, Japan; Kita, H., Kyoto University, Japan; Kang, M.‐S., Kyoto University, Japan
Abstract: Renewable energy utilization and electricity storage will soon be introduced into the conventional electric power system. This study assumes that a photovoltaic (PV) power generation system, a set of the PV units, is installed into the electric power system with electricity storage; moreover, the effects of uncertain variation characteristics of the PV system output on the operations of the conventional power generation system and the storage units are evaluated by simulations, with cost a major consideration. According to the simulation results, it is clearly demonstrated that the costs of the PV system are influence sharply by the prediction accuracy of their output. Authors: Gilmore D.B.
Title: Fuel economy goals for vehicles with regenerative braking energy storage systems
Affiliations: Univ of Queensland, Brisbane
Authors with affiliations: Gilmore, D.B., Univ of Queensland, Brisbane
Abstract: The recovery of vehicle braking energy through an on-board regenerative system with energy storage has been well demonstrated experimentally. Energy normally dissipated in brakes is directed by a power transmission system to the energy store. That energy is held until required again by the vehicle. This paper examines the effect of regenerative systems on the fuel economy of a vehicle over the urban driving schedule. The effects of vehicle mass regenerative system efficiency, storage size and power rating are investigated using a numerical simulation procedure.

Authors: Calico S.E., O'Loughlin J.P., Copeland R.P., Pelletier P.
Title: Compact 1 MV, 1 microsecond pulser using partial magnetic energy storage and closing switches
Source title: 20th Conference Record on Power Modulator Symposium, MODSYM 1992

Abstract: The incorporation of a pulse transformer into a circuit designed to deliver high voltage to a load is a common and well documented practice1-6. A usual procedure is to use the transformer to charge some pulse forming stage which is subsequently discharged into the load. A method of delivering energy from the transformer directly to the load without the use of a full pulse forming stage will be discussed and a design example will be given. © 1992 IEEE.

Authors: Papadia S., Karlsson K., Nilsson P.O., Jarlborg T.
Title: Electronic structure of metallic superlattices: Mo/V
Affiliations: Institute of Theoretical Physics, Chalmers University of Technology, S-412 96 Göteborg, Sweden; Department of Physics, Chalmers University of Technology, S-412 96 Göteberg, Sweden; DPMC, Université de Genève, 24 Quai Ernest Ansermet, CH 1211 Genève 4, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: Papadia, S., Institute of Theoretical Physics, Chalmers University of Technology, S-412 96 Göteborg, Sweden; Karlsson, K., Department of Physics, Chalmers University of Technology, S-412 96 Göteberg, Sweden; Nilsson, P.O., Department of Physics, Chalmers University of Technology, S-412 96 Göteberg, Sweden; Jarlborg, T., DPMC, Université de Genève, 24 Quai Ernest Ansermet, CH 1211 Genève 4, Switzerland
Abstract: The electronic structure for a metallic superlattice system, Mo/V, has been calculated using the linear muffin-tin orbital method in the atomic-sphere approximation (ASA). Total energies have been calculated in the local-density approximation (LDA). Emphasis has been given to the electronic-density variation in these materials in order to understand hydrogen storage in metallic superlattices. It is found, within effective-medium theory, that the balance between charge transfer at the interfaces and volume changes of the constituents determines preferred hydrogen sites in Mo/V. Total-energy considerations favor a tetragonal distortion of the Mo/V superlattice over a cubic structure. Results for the LDA bands, charge transfer, and density of states are compared to other electronic-structure calculations of metallic superlattices, which gives rise to a consistent picture of electronic effects in these systems. The dependence of the results on the ASA is discussed. © 1992 The American Physical Society.

Authors: Falco C.M., Engel B.N.
Title: MBE growth and magneto-optic properties of magnetic multilayers
Affiliations: Optical Sciences Center, Department of Physics, The University of Arizona, 1118 E. 4th Street, Tuczon, AZ 85721, United States
Authors with affiliations: Falco, C.M., Optical Sciences Center, Department of Physics, The University of Arizona, 1118 E. 4th Street, Tuczon, AZ 85721, United States; Engel, B.N., Optical Sciences Center, Department of Physics, The University of Arizona, 1118 E. 4th Street, Tuczon, AZ 85721, United States
Abstract: Recent interest in the magnetic and magneto-optic properties of transition metal/transition metal multilayers has been stimulated by the discovery of perpendicular magnetism in particular systems such as Co/Pd and Co/Pt. Due to their favorable magneto-optic wavelength dependence and enhanced corrosion resistance, these materials show promise as future data storage media. However, partially due to the large variety of thin-film deposition methods and growth conditions, it has been difficult to obtain a clear understanding of the mechanisms of magnetic anisotropy in these systems. In order to create controlled and well characterized model systems, we have grown a series of epitaxial Co/Pd superlattices oriented along the three high-symmetry crystal directions [001], [110], and [111] on single-crystal GaAs substrates by molecular beam epitaxy [MBE]. Simultaneously, we have deposited polycrystalline Co/Pd multilayers on Si substrates mounted alongside the GaAs for direct comparisons of epitaxial and non-epitaxial films produced under identical conditions. The structural properties of these multilayers were determined by low-and reflection high-energy electron diffraction (LEED and RHEED), low- and high-angle X-ray diffraction, and scanning tunneling microscopy (STM). The dependence of the uniaxial magnetic anisotropy energy on the Co thickness in these superlattices showed significant systematic differences for each of the three crystal orientations. A review of our work on the structural influences responsible for these differences is presented. © 1992.

Authors: Lutfi N., Veziroǧlu T.N.
Title: Solar-hydrogen demonstration project for Pakistan
Affiliations: National Institute of Silicon Technology, 25, H-9, Islamabad, Pakistan, Pakistan; Clean Energy Research Institute, University of Miami, Coral Gables, FL 33124, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lutfi, N., National Institute of Silicon Technology, 25, H-9, Islamabad, Pakistan, Pakistan; Veziroǧlu, T.N., Clean Energy Research Institute, University of Miami, Coral Gables, FL 33124, United States
Abstract: With the R&D activities carried out around the globe, hydrogen produced from solar energy has established itself as the most efficient, cleanest and non-petroleum commercial fuel of the 21st century free from the problem of fuel crisis and environmental pollution. In order to accomplish the scientific and technological prerequisites for the future solar-hydrogen energy system it is proposed to build a 140 kW demonstration project in Pakistan. The demonstration project would be composed of a PV-Electrolyser unit to produce DC electricity and hydrogen and a storage and distribution system. There would be a desalination plant, a fish freezing and packing plant, a residential unit, a fuel cell power plant and a gas filling station to demonstrate the utilization of hydrogen. Also there would be cash crop producing farm under the PV panels. This project would be helpful in accumulating experience with the emerging solar-hydrogen technology and would provide a means for realistic testing and demonstration of the solar-hydrogen concept. © 1992.

Abstract: Two laminar amplitude multilayer gratings with 250-nm pitch were produced using UV holography and reactive ion etching. The diffraction properties of these structures were measured at 150 eV using synchrotron radiation. The experimental results, giving the position and absolute reflectivity of the various orders, are discussed within a kinematical model.

Authors: Bannerot R.B.
Title: On the determination of the average temperature in a horizontal storage tank and its use in monitoring the performance of a solar thermosyphon system
Source title: Journal of Solar Energy Engineering, Transactions of the ASME
Affiliations: Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Houston, Houston, TX, 77204-4792, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bannerot, R.B., Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Houston, Houston, TX, 77204-4792, United States
Abstract: The mass weighted average storage temperature is a useful parameter for evaluating the performance of thermal storage systems. It is commonly used in system simulations since detailed temperature data in the storage medium are not known (or even considered). However, it is rarely used in the evaluation of operating systems because of the difficulty in determining it, especially in potentially multidimensional storage configurations, like a horizontal tank. This paper examines the issue of the evaluation of the average storage temperature, specifically from the point of view of reproducibility and how much data is required for a confident calculation. Unfortunately, this issue was not completely resolved and was shown to be strongly dependent on the locations of the measurements. Two examples are presented that demonstrate the usefulness of knowing the average storage temperature. The examples also give a quantitative demonstration of the effect of withdrawal flow rate on the amount of thermal energy that can be withdrawn from a given system. A reduction in flow rate by a factor of four increased the delivered energy by 70 percent. © 1992 by ASME.

Authors: Alberdi B., Lucía C., Martín R., López A.
Title: Design and construction of an RF Power Supply at 100 KV, 30 a DC output using solid state DC-DC converters
Source title: PESC Record - IEEE Annual Power Electronics Specialists Conference

Complutense 22, Madrid, 28040, Spain; López, A., Fusion Division, EUR/CIEMAT Ass., Av. Complutense 22, Madrid, 28040, Spain
Abstract: In this paper a new design of Power Supply for RF equipment by high frequency commutation technology, totally solid state, without energy storage at the output filter neither protection Crowbar is presented. The Power Supply (3 MW, 100 KV, 30 A) procures a low ripple, excellent dynamic and static stability and very fast turnoff quicker than 5 ps required by RF equipments. It presents more conclusive advantages than today's power supplies based on vacuum tubes. © 1992 IEEE.

Authors: Sun B., Skyllas-Kazacos M.
Title: Chemical modification of graphite electrode materials for vanadium redox flow battery application-part II. Acid treatments
Affiliations: School of Chemical Engineering, and Industrial Chemistry, The University of New South Wales, P.O. Box 1, Kensington, NSW 2033, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Sun, B., School of Chemical Engineering, and Industrial Chemistry, The University of New South Wales, P.O. Box 1, Kensington, NSW 2033, Australia; Skyllas-Kazacos, M., School of Chemical Engineering, and Industrial Chemistry, The University of New South Wales, P.O. Box 1, Kensington, NSW 2033, Australia
Abstract: The surface modification of graphite felt with concentrated sulphuric acid has led to dramatic improvement in the electroactivity of this material in the vanadium redox cell. A cell resistance of 2.50 Ω cm2 and energy efficiency of 91% were obtained in the vanadium cell, after the graphite felt electrode material was treated with boiling concentrated sulphuric acid for 5h. The electrochemical activity of the graphite felt was found to increase with increasing sulphuric acid concentration. Treatment of graphite felt with nitric acid and mixtures of sulphuric and nitric acids, however, led to higher cell resistance values compared with the sulphuric acid treatment. Surface analysis of treated and untreated felts using the XPS method has shown that the functional groups CO and CO increased dramatically compared with untreated samples. A sequence reaction mechanism was proposed for the VO2+ ⇌ VO+2 and V2+ ⇌ V3+ charge-discharge reactions occurring in the positive and negative 1 2-cells, respectively of the vanadium redox battery. © 1992.
Author Keywords: batteries; energy storage; surface activation

Authors: Stanley S.H., Richards A.O'L., Suzuki M., Dalton H.
Title: The biotransformation of propylene to propylene oxide by methylococcus capsulatus (Bath): 2. A study of the biocatalyst stability
Affiliations: Department of Biological Sciences, University of Warwick, Coventry, CV4 7AL, England, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Stanley, S.H., Department of Biological Sciences, University of Warwick, Coventry, CV4 7AL, England, United Kingdom; Richards, A.O'L., Department of Biological Sciences, University of Warwick, Coventry, CV4 7AL, England, United Kingdom; Suzuki, M., Department of Biological Sciences, University of Warwick, Coventry, CV4 7AL, England, United Kingdom; Dalton, H., Department of Biological Sciences, University of Warwick, Coventry, CV4 7AL, England, United Kingdom
Abstract: Methylococcus capsulatus (Bath) possesses methane monooxygenase (MMO) which catalyses the epoxidation of propylene to propylene oxide. MMO activity could be maintained in whole cells by storage in unagitated vessels for several days. However if these cells were agitated and aerated in the absence of a carbon and energy source then 80% of the propylene-oxidizing activity Was lost within 24 h. It was shown that this loss of activity was due to the inability of the cells to provide energy to drive the oxidation process rather than the loss of MMO activity per se. If propylene oxide was added to these aerated cells then the rate of inactivation was increased and 50% of the activity was lost over a 10 min period. The addition of an exogenous energy source caused a doubling in the rate of inactivation. These marked increases in the rates of inactivation in the presence of propylene oxide were found to be caused by the loss of the methane monooxygenase activity per se rather than a further loss of the energy-producing systems. Cells actively producing propylene oxide from propylene, using methanol as an energy source, also lost their propylene oxide-producing capacity rapidly due to loss of the methane monooxygenase activity. The rate of inactivation under these circumstances was related to the rate of propylene oxide production from propylene rather than the level of this product in the culture supernatant. © 1992 Informa UK Ltd All rights reserved: reproduction in whole or part not permitted.
Author Keywords: Methylococcus capsulatus (Bath); Product toxicity; Propylene oxide

Authors: Hsieh C.K., Choi C.-Y.
Title: A general analysis of phase-change energy storage for solar energy applications
Source title: Journal of Solar Energy Engineering, Transactions of the ASME
Affiliations: Mechanical Engineering Department, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL, 32611, United States
Authors with affiliations: Hsieh, C.K., Mechanical Engineering Department, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL, 32611, United States; Choi, C.-Y., Mechanical Engineering Department, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL, 32611, United States
Abstract: A unified approach is developed for the analysis of one, two, or three-phase melting or solidification of a semi-infinite medium with or without subcooling or superheating and imposed with constant, monotonic, or cyclic temperature or flux conditions. A source and sink method is presented in which a sink front is used to characterize a melt front while a source front is used to characterize a freeze front. An integrodifferential equation is then derived for the interface position which is linearized locally for numerical solution. This position is, in turn, used as input for the determination of the temperature distribution and energy storage and release in different phases of the medium. The numerical solution presented in this paper has shown to be unique, convergent, stable, and accurate. The analysis has been applied to the study of phase change in a subcooled paraffin wax imposed with a cyclic temperature condition. Test results yield some interesting phenomena related to the merging of phase-change fronts and hysteresis of energy storage and release, among others, which have not previously been reported in the literature. Their relations to the energy storage and release are particularly stressed in the paper. © 1992 by ASME.

Authors: Davidson J.H., Carlson W.T., Duff W.S.
Title: Impact of component selection and operation on thermal ratings of drain-back solar water heaters
Source title: Journal of Solar Energy Engineering, Transactions of the ASME
Affiliations: Solar Energy Applications Laboratory, Colorado State University, Fort Collins, CO, 80523, United States
Authors with affiliations: Davidson, J.H., Solar Energy Applications Laboratory, Colorado State University, Fort Collins, CO, 80523, United States; Carlson, W.T., Solar Energy Applications Laboratory, Colorado State University, Fort Collins, CO, 80523, United States; Duff, W.S., Solar Energy Applications Laboratory, Colorado State University, Fort Collins, CO, 80523, United States
Abstract: A half-factorial, two-level experimental design is used to determine the effects of changes in collector area, storage tank volume, collector flow rate, recirculation flow rate, and storage tank design on thermal rating of a solar drain-back water heating system. Experimental ratings are determined in accordance with the Solar Rating and Certification Corporation guidelines. Storage tank design is varied by using a stratification manifold in place of the standard drop tube. Variations in other component sizes and operating factors are based on current industry standards. Statistical analyses indicate that a change in collector area accounts for nearly 90 percent of the variation in heat output. Doubling collector area from 2.78 m2 to 5.56 m2 increases delivered solar energy by 31 percent. Use of a stratification manifold increases the delivery of solar energy by six percent. Doubling collector flow rate from 0.057 to 0.114 1/s increases solar output by approximately three percent; however, the increase in pumping energy outweighs the benefits of increasing collector flow rate. The effects of recirculation flow rate and tank volume are obscured by experimental error. © 1992 by ASME.

Authors: El-Osairy M.A., El-Osery I.A., Metwally A.M., Keshk M.M.
Title: On the optimization of convective hydrogen storage bed model using LaNi5H6 or FeTiH1.6
Affiliations: Mathematics and Physics Department, Faculty of Engineering, Alexandria University, Egypt; Nuclear Power Plants Authority, P.O. Box 108, Abbassia, Cairo, Egypt, Egypt; Nuclear Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Alexandria University, Egypt
Authors with affiliations: El-Osairy, M.A., Mathematics and Physics Department, Faculty of Engineering, Alexandria University, Egypt; El-Osery, I.A., Nuclear Power Plants Authority, P.O. Box 108, Abbassia, Cairo, Egypt, Egypt; Metwally, A.M., Nuclear Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Alexandria University, Egypt; Keshk, M.M., Mathematics and Physics Department, Faculty of Engineering, Alexandria University, Egypt
Abstract: This paper is part of an integrated calculation scheme in the context of hydrogen energy systems. The work aims at the development of an optimized hydrogen storage bed based on the convective bed model and using LaNi5H6 or FeTiH1.6 metal hydride as the hydrogen charging-discharging medium. In this paper, the main factors affecting the rate of hydrogen release have been studied and found to be ordered as follows according to their potential impact on the hydrogen discharging rate: inlet hydrogen temperature, bed pressure, inlet gas mass flow rate, bed length and bed void fraction. © 1992.

Authors: Mikkelsen A., Skibsted L.H.
Title: Kinetics of enzymatic reduction of metmyoglobin in relation to oxygen activation in meat products
Affiliations: Chemistry Department and RVAU Center for Food Research, Royal Veterinary and Agricultural University, Thorvaldsensvej 40, Frederiksberg C, DK-1871, Denmark
Authors with affiliations: Mikkelsen, A., Chemistry Department and RVAU Center for Food Research, Royal Veterinary and Agricultural University, Thorvaldsensvej 40, Frederiksberg C, DK-1871, Denmark; Skibsted, L.H., Chemistry Department and RVAU Center for Food Research, Royal Veterinary and Agricultural University, Thorvaldsensvej 40, Frederiksberg C, DK-1871, Denmark
Abstract: Enzymatic reduction of metmyoglobin by partially purified Cytochrome b5 reductase and cytochrome b5 from beef liver and NADH was investigated in model systems by absorbance measurements; and the influence on myoglobin-induced oxidation of linoleic acid was investigated by measuring oxygen consumption of emulsified linoleic acid solutions. The effect of the enzyme system was further investigated for meat products in order to elucidate the coupling between redox processes of meat pigments and lipids during freezer storage of minced beef. The rate of enzymatic reduction of metmyoglobin to myoglobin was strongly dependent on pH, ionic strength and temperature. For excess of NADH, the energy of activation was pH-dependent and approximated 60 kJ-mol-1, and was assigned to the electron transfer between reduced cytochrome b5 and metmyoglobin. The pH-dependence indicated parallel reactions of two protein forms in acid/base equilibrium with each other; a p Ka=6.0 suggests the involvement of an imidazol moiety, for which the protonization facilitates the electron transfer. The reaction centres of the proteins are oppositely charged, as concluded from a decrease in rate with increasing, ionic strength. For conditions of high enzyme activity, metmyoglobin was reduced to myoglobin but not further oxygenated to oxymyoglobin, indicating oxygen consumption as the result of a direct reduction of O2 by cytochrome b5. For intermediate enzyme activity (25° C, pH 6.3 and 5.8), the liver extract and NADH were capable of decreasing the metmyoglobin-induced oxygen consumption rate of linoleic acid emulsions by a factor of 10, showing that the iron(III) form of myoglobin is the active oxidation catalyst. However, for meat products, addition of the liver extract and NADH did not improve the colour stability as monitored by tristimulus colorimetric measurements but significantly increased lipid oxidation, as indicated by an increase in thiobarbituric-acid-reactive substances. © 1992 Springer-Verlag.

Abstract: We have measured the R value in non-resonant e+e- annihilation using the ARGUS detector at the storage ring DORIS II. At a centre-of-mass energy {Mathematical expression} GeV the ratio of the hadronic cross-section to the μ-pair cross section in lowest order QED has been determined to be R=3.46±0.03±0.13. In addition, we have measured the charged-particle multiplicities in non-resonant hadron production at {Mathematical expression} GeV just below the B {Mathematical expression} threshold and in Υ{hooked} (4 S) resonance decays. For the average charged-particle multiplicities in continuum events and Υ{hooked}(4 S)→B {Mathematical expression} decays we obtain <n>cont=8.35±0.02±0.20 and <n>Υ{hooked}(4 s)=10.81±0.05±0.23. © 1992 Springer-Verlag.

Authors: Rollett A.D., Luton M.J., Srolovitz D.J.
Title: Microstructural simulation of dynamic recrystallization
Affiliations: Mail Stop K765, Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM 87545, USA, United States; Corporate Research, Exxon Research and Engineering Company, Annandale, NJ 08801, United States; Department of Materials Science and Engineering, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rollett, A.D., Mail Stop K765, Los Alamos National Laboratory, Los Alamos, NM 87545, USA, United States; Luton, M.J., Corporate Research, Exxon Research and Engineering Company, Annandale, NJ 08801, United States; Srolovitz, D.J., Department of Materials Science and Engineering, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109, United States
Abstract: A Monte Carlo model for dynamic recrystallization has been developed from earlier models used to simulate static recrystallization and grain growth. The model simulates dynamic recrystallization by adding recrystallization nuclei and stored energy continuously with time. The simulations reproduce many of the essential features of dynamic recrystallization. The stored energy of the system, which may be interpreted as a measure of the flow stress, goes through a maximum and then decays, monotonically under some conditions and in an oscillatory manner under others. The principle parameters that were studied were the rate of adding stored energy, ΔH, and the rate of adding nuclei, ΔN. As ΔH increases, for fixed ΔN, the oscillations decay more rapidly and the asymptotic energy rises. As ΔN increases again the oscillations decay more rapidly but the asymptotic stored energy decreases. The mean grain size of' the system also oscillates in a similar manner to the stored energy but out of phase by 90°. The flow stress oscillations occurred for conditions which lead to both coarsening and refinement of the initial grain size. Necklacing of the prior grain structure by new grains were observed for low ΔH and high ΔN; it is, however, not an invariable feature of grain refinement. The initial grain size has a profound influence on the microstructure that evolves during the first cycle of recrystallization but at long times, a mean grain size is established which depends on the values of ΔH and ΔN alone. Comparison of the relationships between the energy storage rate, maximum and asymptotic stored energy and the grain size suggest that in physical systems the energy storage rate and the nucleation rate are coupled. Comparison of the simulation results with experimental trends suggests that the dependence of nucleation rate on storage should be positive but weak. All of these results were obtained without the addition of special parameters to the model. © 1992.

Authors: Hasse R.W.
Title: Relaxation of energy from the transverse to the longitudinal direction of a cold-ion string in a storage ring
Affiliations: ESR Division, Gesellschaft für Schwerionenforschung Darmstadt M.b.H., D-6100 Darmstadt, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Hasse, R.W., ESR Division, Gesellschaft für Schwerionenforschung Darmstadt M.b.H., D-6100 Darmstadt, Germany
Abstract: With the help of molecular dynamics we study the properties of a string of ions that is confined by an external harmonic potential and that initially is cold in the beam direction but warm in the transverse one. Under the influence of the mutual Coulomb repulsion, intrabeam scattering leads to a flow of energy from the transverse to the longitudinal direction. Depending on the density and the initial transverse temperature T0, three regimes can be distinguished: a fast transient increase of the longitudinal temperature T0 in a fraction of a betatron period, a slow linear increase in some ten betatron periods, and a fast exponential increase followed by complete thermal equilibration. If T0 is large, linear order is lost and thermal equilibrium is postponed to large times. Fourier analyses show that the energy flows into the long-wavelength modes of the collective string excitations. A comparison of calculated heating rates with achievable cooling rates reveals that maintaining linear order in a storage ring is marginal. © 1992 The American Physical Society.

Authors: Dutta P.
Title: Towards energy storage
Affiliations: Department of Chemistry, Ohio State University, Columbus, OH 43210-1173, United States

Authors: Winkelmann G.
Title: Structures and functions of fungal siderophores containing hydroxamate and complexone type iron binding ligands
Affiliations: Department of Microbiology and Biotechnology, University of Tübingen, Auf der Morgenstelle 1, Tübingen, 7400, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Winkelmann, G., Department of Microbiology and Biotechnology, University of Tübingen, Auf der Morgenstelle 1, Tübingen, 7400, Germany
Abstract: A variety of fungi are able to synthesize iron chelating compounds (siderophores) which are excreted into the cultivation medium for iron sequestering purposes. Most ascomycetous and basidomycetous fungi synthesize hydroxamate-type siderophores containing N5-hydroxy-N5-acyl-l-ornithine residues which constitute the iron binding ligands. After complexing of ferric ions, octahedral complexes are formed. Uptake of iron via siderophores involves the recognition of siderophores by the cognate transport systems which is dependent on the configuration of the metal centre (Λ/Δ) and its surrounding functionalities. Transport across the membrane requires metabolic energy and can be inhibited by respiratory poisons, uncouplers, low temperatures, anaerobiosis and is functioning in a pH range of pH 2–7. Four classes of hydroxamate siderophores have so far been isolated: ferrichromes, fusarinines, coprogens and rhodotorulic acid. Besides their function in solubilizing and transport of iron, hydroxamate siderophores are also involved in iron storage. Recently, a novel complexone type siderophore (rhizoferrin) has been discovered which seem to be widespread in the Mucorales. Interestingly the Mucorales are the only fungal group where ferritin has been detected so far, suggesting that the substitution of hydroxamate siderophores by complexone siderophores has led to the formation of ferritins as the eucaryotic iron storage proteins. © 1992, British Mycological Society. All rights reserved.

Authors: Geissel H., Beckert K., Bosch F., Eickhoff H., Franczak B., Franzke B., Jung M., Klepper O., Moshammer R., Münzenberg G., Nickel F., Nolden F., Schaaf U., Scheidenberger C., Spädtke P., Steck M., Sümmerer K., Magel A.
Title: First storage and cooling of secondary heavy-ion beams at relativistic energies
Affiliations: Gesellschaft für Schwerionenforschung, D-61 Darmstadt, Germany; II. Physikalisches Institut, Universität Giessen, D-63 Giessen, Germany
